name: Grizzly Flat Trail and Canyon Trail to Monte Bello Open Space
description: Try this 15.8-km out-and-back trail near Los Gatos, California. Generally considered a challenging route, it takes an average of 5 h 5 min to complete. This is a popular trail for hiking and walking, but you can still enjoy some solitude during quieter times of day. The trail is open year-round and is beautiful to visit anytime.

name: Bay Area Ridge Trail: San Francisco Presidio
description:
• Access Information: Part of this route is temporarily closed to dog walking to reduce the potential for coyote/dog conflict, but you can still enjoy other sections of this trail. For information, please visit https://presidio.gov/about/sustainability/coyotes-in-the-presidio

Explore the charm, seclusion, natural wonders, and historic and cultural variety of the 1,491-acre Presidio. Stunning views await you on this trip through forests and along coastal bluffs that ends at the Golden Gate Bridge. Interpretive panels along the route provide information about the Presidio’s unique natural and cultural history.

Accessibility: There are 3 designated accessible spaces in the paved parking lot off of Arguello Boulevard at the south end of the trail. All of them are van-accessible with striped access aisles. The trail surface is paved or packed dirt. It is typically at least 4 feet wide. 

The whole trail is estimated to be in the moderately steep (5-8%) grade category. All-terrain tires or motorized equipment may be needed for the surface type and grade. Trail goers using wheelchairs/mobility equipment or strollers may need assistance along this entire route due to the consistent sections above a 5% grade (especially if using manual equipment).

Part of the first 0.7 miles of this route is on a roadway shared with motor vehicles (no sidewalks) so caution and the use of a helmet, reflective material, and/or lights are suggested on wheelchairs and strollers in this section. The route joins a roadway without sidewalks again at 1.5 miles. 

Depending on recent, current, and potential weather/trail conditions, trail goers using mobility equipment or a stroller may need to avoid the unpaved areas of the trail from about the 1.0 to 1.5-mile mark. There is a bike lane along Washington Boulevard if wishing to avoid this unpaved section.

At 1.8 miles the route leaves the roadway and joins the Coastal Trail. More information about the most accessible parts of the Coastal Trail from Baker Beach to the Bridge can be viewed on this trail page: https://www.alltrails.com/trail/us/california/golden-gate-bridge-from-baker-beach-trail

name: Sunnyvale Baylands Park Guadalupe Slough
description:
• General fee: Sunnyvale Baylands Park charges a fee to enter. For more information, please visit https://parks.sccgov.org/santa-clara-county-parks/sunnyvale-baylands-park

This is a series of trails along the shoreline and levies of San Francisco Bay where wetland wildlife can be seen at close range. The shoreline trails are paved and wheelchair accessible. The trails along the levies are gravel and dirt. These trails are ideal for large groups, families with children, bicycles, pedestrians, and joggers.

Accessibility: There is 1 designated accessible space in the small paved parking lot off of Carl Road at the west end of the trail. It is van-accessible with a striped access aisle. The trail surface is paved concrete, asphalt, decomposed granite, or a natural (dirt) surface. It is typically at least 5 feet wide with some wider passing spaces. There is a double track along some/most of the trail, which may have a raised center section and create an uneven cross slope difficult to navigate.

The entire trail is estimated to be in the gentle grade category (3% or less). All-terrain tires or motorized equipment may be needed for the unpaved surfaces. There are benches and picnic tables along the route for resting. There are wheelchair-accessible bathrooms at the east end of the trail.

name: Pacific Grove Monarch Sanctuary Trail
park: Pacific Grove Monarch Sanctuary Trail. Always observe wildlife from a safe distance.Top trails nearbyMonterey Peninsula Recreational Trail and Asilomar Ave LoopMonterey Peninsula Recreational Trail and Asilomar Ave LoopPerkins Park4.7·Easy·4.1 mi·Est. 1h 19mMonterey Waterfront City WalkMonterey Waterfront City WalkLovers Point Park4.6·Easy·4.4 mi·Est. 1h 19mAsilomar State Beach and Coast TrailAsilomar State Beach and Coast TrailAsilomar State Beach4.7·Easy·3.6 mi·Est. 1h 13mHuckleberry Hill LoopHuckleberry Hill LoopVeterans Memorial Park4.4·Moderate·1.8 mi·Est. 1h 5mSFB Morse Botanical ReserveSFB Morse Botanical ReserveSFB Morse Botanical Reserve4.4·Moderate·3.0 mi·Est. 1h 15mHistoric Cannery Row Walking TourHistoric Cannery Row Walking Tour4.4·Easy·1.5 mi·Est. 28mSpanish Bay TrailSpanish Bay TrailMoss Beach4.4·Easy·2.9 mi·Est. 55mRestless Sea and China RockRestless Sea and China Rock4.6·Easy·2.8 mi·Est. 51mTwo Huckleberry Hill and Outer LoopTwo Huckleberry Hill and Outer LoopSFB Morse Botanical Reserve
description:
According to Access Northern California (http://accessnca.org/access-northern-california/explore/explore-detail-view/?site_id=34): Pacific Grove, CA is nicknamed "Butterfly Town USA" due to the thousands of monarch butterflies that migrate to the area each year. Every fall and early winter, thousands of Monarch butterflies travel amazing distances from the northern United States and southern Canada to spend the winter at a handful of sites along the California coast. One of these is a grove of eucalyptus and Monterey pines in the little coastal town of Pacific Grove, on Monterey Bay. To reach their overwintering sites, Monarch butterflies may travel as far as 2,000 miles, covering perhaps a hundred miles a day, and fly as high as 10,000 feet. 

On a cool day, you might mistake the butterflies clustered in the trees for dead leaves, but as sunlight warms them they begin to move and take flight, filling the air with flickers of orange. They mate here, then in spring fly north in search of milkweed plants on which to deposit their eggs. Docents are on hand November through mid-February, noon-3 PM every day except Friday. The sanctuary is open from 8 AM to 5 PM daily.

Accessibility: There is at least 1 designated accessible parking, van accessible, that is firm and level or with a slope no greater than 2% next to the school on Ridge Road. There are wheelchair-accessible restrooms at the trailhead at the north end of the trail.

The trail surface is a mix of cement, asphalt, and packed dirt and typically at least four feet wide. The estimated grade is typically mostly gentle (5% grade or less) and at a maximum- steep at 12% grade or less. There are benches along the route for resting. Most of the trees are in the upper area, so you can avoid going down the steep section and still get a good view.

name: Chamise, Toyon, and Fern Loop
description:
• Foothills Nature Preserve charges an entry fee. An annual pass is also available for purchase. Dogs are not allowed on weekends or holidays. For more information, please visit https://www.cityofpaloalto.org/Departments/Community-Services/Open-Space-Parks/Neighborhood-Parks/Foothills-Nature-Preserve



This peaceful trail offers great views of the surrounding mountains and foothills. It is mostly flat and level. Some of the trip follows part of the paved park road. There are many options on this hike to stop and rest. This trail passes by picnic facilities, restrooms, and benches. You will also get a chance to walk around the edge of Boronda Lake and check out the Arborejo Overlook.

name: Coyote Creek and Ogier Ponds Trail
park: Coyote Creek and Ogier Ponds Trail. Bring plenty of water and wear sunscreen and protective clothing.Top trails nearbyArrowhead Loop TrailArrowhead Loop TrailCoyote Valley Open Space Preserve4.6·Moderate·3.9 mi·Est. 1h 46mLos Cerritos TrailLos Cerritos TrailCalero County Park
description: Discover this 4.4-mile out-and-back trail near Morgan Hill, California. Generally considered a moderately challenging route, it takes an average of 1 h 20 min to complete. This is a popular trail for hiking, but you can still enjoy some solitude during quieter times of day. The trail is open year-round and is beautiful to visit anytime.

name: Madera and Bobcat Point via the Arastradero Creek and Coyote Trail
description:
Arastradero Creek trail serves as a connector between the Arastradero Preserve trail system and the Foothills Nature Preserve. This variation will take you to two great views within Foothills Preserve before heading back. 

Dogs are allowed on a leash within the Arastradero Preserve but are only allowed in Foothills Nature Preserve on weekdays and non-holidays. Heads up, this area is also mountain lion habitat, so be prepared to take proper precautions while adventuring on this trail. 

Access this trail from the Gateway building parking area into the Arastradero Preserve. It will lead you across the preserve to some great popular view spots along the Panorama trail. It is possible to travel in reverse on this trail by parking at Foothills Preserve.

name: Flag Hill to Little Yosemite Loop
description: • Parking fee information: There is a fee to park at Sunol Wilderness Regional Preserve on weekends and holidays. For more information, please visit https://www.ebparks.org/parks/sunol

name: Mount Umunhum
description: The gorgeous Mt. Umunhum Trail passes through dense mixed chaparral scrub dominated by shrub species including chamise, big berry manzanita, birch-leafed mountain mahogany, and poison oak (keep an eye out). It passes through Knobcone Pine Woodland and eventually enters the Coastal Woodlands habitat dominated by coast live oak, foothill pine, California bay, interspersed with Pacific madrone. The majority of the trail – approximately the upper 3.0 miles – is enjoyed under the cool canopy of these trees. Eventually, the trail emerges near the top onto steep terrain dominated by cliffs and rocky outcrops including serpentine boulders. Due to the thin soil layer developed on the serpentine bedrock, a low moisture-holding capacity, and a unique chemical composition, the serpentine areas support numerous endemic plant species, including rare flowering plants that continue to reveal themselves each spring.

name: Mendoza and Coyote Ridge Trail
park: Coyote Lake Harvey Bear Ranch County Park
description:
• Parking Fee: Coyote Lake Harvey Bear Ranch County Park charges a fee to enter, except at Mendoza Ranch and Harvey Bear Entrances. There are varying fees depending on if you enter by vehicle, motorcycle, foot, horse, or bike. Please visit https://parks.santaclaracounty.gov/locations/coyote-lake-harvey-bear-ranch-county-park

The Coyote Ridge Trail also takes you through a variety of terrain, including rocky paths and open meadows, with some steeper sections that provide a bit more of a challenge. The higher you go, the more expansive the views become, with the surrounding mountain ranges creating a dramatic backdrop. On clear days, you may even spot Mount Umunhum and the San Francisco Bay in the distance.

name: Ridge, Seubert, and Letters Loop
description: This route starts at Diamond Avenue and goes along Ridge Trail and around the Sign Hill Park area. Some sections are steep and rocky and can be overgrown, so sturdy shoes and long pants are recommended for this hike. You will also be rewarded with stunning sweeping views of the South San Francisco area.

name: Rogue Valley, Wildcat and Upper Wildcat Loop via Lower Meadow Trail
park: Rancho San Antonio Open Space Preserve
description:
This is a fantastic trail near Los Altos, California. At the summit, you can sit on a bench and appreciate the stunning view. 

The trail offers good cover, but it can be sunny in certain areas. Along the path, there's a beautiful stream with several picturesque waterfalls. 

The path can get muddy after rainfall. Keep your eyes open for wildlife such as squirrels, deer, rabbits, goats, and coyotes. 

Due to the area's popularity, parking can be challenging on weekends. Restrooms are available at the trailhead.

name: Lookout Trail and Nature Trail Loop
description:
This magnificent trail takes visitors to the beautiful Villa Montalvo County Park. Visitors will be treated to gorgeous views of the city and mountains, including the Saratoga to the Santa Clara area.

Redwoods shade the path, which can get muddy after consistent rain. Sections of this track are pretty steep, but the vistas at the lookout point make the climb well worth the effort.

name: Best trails inLos Gatos Creek Park
park: Los Gatos Creek Parkbest Trails In Los Gatos Creek Park Best Trails In Los Gatos Creek Park
description:
Want to find the best trails in Los Gatos Creek Park for an adventurous hike or a family trip? AllTrails has 4 great trails for hiking and more. Enjoy hand-curated trail maps, along with reviews and photos from nature lovers like you.

Ready for your next hike or bike ride? Explore one of 3 easy hiking trails in Los Gatos Creek Park that are great for the whole family. Looking for a more strenuous hike? We've got you covered, with trails ranging from 36 to 508 feet in elevation gain. Whatever you have planned for the day, you can find the perfect trail for your next trip to Los Gatos Creek Park.

name: Permanente Creek & Deer Meadow
park: Rancho San Antonio Open Space Preserve
description:
According to the Adventures From A Wheelchair blog (https://irishsea-mark-videos.blogspot.com/2015/05/rancho-san-antonio-open-space-preserve.html):
The Permanente Creek Trail begins with a large meadow on the left side with rolling hills as a background. On the right side is the Permanente Creek. About 0.25 miles down the trail, you can access the 0.80 Deer Meadow Loop Trail by crossing over the bridge on the right side.

The Permanente Creek Trail connects with the Lower Meadow Trail, which will take you to Deer Hollow Farm. The 160 year-old historic farm has cows, sheep, chickens, hogs, a garden, and a nature center.

This route is a path less traveled but a beautiful exploration of the area. A short, about 0.15 mile, section of the trail starting at about 0.4 miles out is along a service road. It is recommended to use caution, lights, flags, and wear a helmet and bright clothing when sharing space with the motor vehicles. 

Accessibility: The trail surface is gravel, compact dirt/grass, and paved trail and typically at least 5 feet wide. The asphalt portions are typically wider, estimated at 8 feet, and have a painted center dividing line which reduces the width.  There may be grass growing into the trail from the edges in sections of the route, especially in the Deer Meadow section. Trail goers using mobility equipment or a stroller may need assistance to navigate the possibly uneven surfaces. The slope is estimated to be mostly gentle (5% grade or less) except for a moderately steep (5 - 8%) downhill portion when heading counterclockwise at about the 1.4 mile mark.

Only the trail up to the farm is wheelchair or stroller friendly. There is also a side connection from the Permanente Creek Trail to the Deer Meadow Trail. It is 0.62 miles long and is wheelchair and stroller friendly. It is one of those hidden trails that many hikers don’t know about.

There are at least 5 designated wheelchair-accessible parking spaces with striped access aisles at the large paved trailhead lot.

name: Skyline to Sweeney Ridge
description:
Sweeney Ridge is a hilly hiking area of ridges and ravines between San Bruno and Pacifica, about a 25-minute drive south of San Francisco. The ridge's 1,200-foot-high summit, covered with coastal scrub and grassland, slopes down to the San Francisco Bay on one side and to the Pacific on the other. Wildlife at Sweeney Ridge includes hawks, deer, and a plethora of both native and introduced spring wildflowers. The sandy coastline and adjacent wind-protected valley of Thornton State Beach are good venues for picnicking, beach walking, surf fishing, and flying remote-control gliders. Views from this site include the Farallon Islands, Mount Tamalpais, Point Reyes, Mount Diablo, the Montara Mountains, and San Pedro Point.

Take the Notch Trail from Skyline College and hike south to the ridge where you can take the Sweeney Ridge Trail further south or head west along Mori Ridge Trail.  You can also begin at the trailhead adjacent to the Shelldance Orchid Gardens near CA-1 and hike up to the ridge using the Mori Ridge Trail.

name: Mission Peak from Ohlone College
description:
Mission Peak gets throngs of hikers but only savvy trekkers take this route to the summit -- an eight-mile out-and-back that stretches out the 2,000-foot ascent to the summit (the most-popular route ascends a similar height in a 5.2-mile out-and-back). This gradual route is a less-strenuous option for hiking to the top of the popular East Bay peak.

It starts from the parking lot at Ohlone College along Mission Boulevard in Fremont, California. Just one trail -- the aptly named Peak Trail -- curves and climbs its way to the 2,517-foot summit of Mission Peak. (From the parking lot, look for a sign pointing to Ohlone Trail).

Abundant parking at Ohlone College on the weekend makes this trailhead a welcome alternative to the Stanford Avenue entrance which fills quickly. There's also a bit more shade on this route compared to other trails to the summit. 

Impressive views of the Diablo Range and San Francisco Bay open up on the way up. Don't be surprised if you see deer and coyotes the ground and raptors and vultures soaring overhead.

Best time to go: Springtime when the hills are green and the wildflowers are blooming. Winter's the next-best time, especially if the peak gets a dusting of snow. Fall is OK; summer's too hot during the day, but many hikers hit the summit at sunset and hike down after dark (best done under a full moon).

NO bikes are allowed on this trail.

name: Mine Hill Trail
description: Head out on this 14.0-mile loop trail near New Almaden, California. Generally considered a challenging route, it takes an average of 6 h 43 min to complete. This trail is great for birding, hiking, and mountain biking, and it's unlikely you'll encounter many other people while exploring. The trail is open year-round and is beautiful to visit anytime. Dogs are welcome, but must be on a leash.

name: Guadalupe River Trail
Deep Gulch, Castillero, Mine Hill, Prospect #3 and Randol Trail Loop
description: Almaden Quicksilver County Park includes over 37 miles of hiking trails, including 30 miles of equestrian trails and 16.6 miles of bike trails. All trails in the park are also open to pet owners to walk their dogs on leash. For more information visit: https://www.sccgov.org/sites/parks/parkfinder/pages/almadenpark.aspx

name: Upper Huckleberry, Lower Huckleberry, and Skyline Trail Loop
description:
This loop provides some outstanding views of the Bay Area. 

Users will need to walk down Skyline Blvd for a short distance to reach the beginning of the Huckleberry Trail from the parking area.

name: Tan Oak Trail, Upper Miller Trail, and Meadow Loop
description: • General fee: Mount Madonna County Park charges a fee to enter. For more information, please visit https://parks.sccgov.org/plan-your-visit/santa-clara-county-park-fees

name: Cooley Landing Trail
park: Cooley Landing Trail is a great place to see wildflowers.Top trails nearbyNorth Bayfront LoopNorth Bayfront LoopBaylands Nature Preserve4.5·Easy·8.5 km·Est. 1h 32mAdobe Creek Trail To Shoreline Lake ParkAdobe Creek Trail To Shoreline Lake ParkBaylands Nature Preserve4.5·Easy·9.5 km·Est. 1h 42mBay Trail: Shoreline LakeBay Trail: Shoreline LakeShoreline at Mountain View Park4.5·Easy·11.9 km·Est. 2h 11mShoreline Park LoopShoreline Park LoopShoreline at Mountain View Park4.6·Easy·2.3 km·Est. 25mStanford Campus WalkStanford Campus Walk4.7·Easy·4.8 km·Est. 54mAdobe Creek Trail to Mayfield SloughAdobe Creek Trail to Mayfield SloughByxbee Recreation Area4.5·Easy·6.0 km·Est. 1h 5mCharleston Slough TrailsCharleston Slough TrailsBaylands Nature Preserve4.6·Easy·18.7 km·Est. 3h 25mByxbee Art HillByxbee Art HillByxbee Recreation Area4.5·Moderate·5.1 km·Est. 1h 2mBol Park Bike PathBol Park
description: Today, the Baylands covers 1940 acres.The preserve includes some of the last remaining salt marsh/mudflat habitats on the West Coast. It is home to the endangered California Clapper Rail and Salt Marsh Harvest Mouse. Unlike other Bay marshes which have plants that grow in distinct zones, the Palo Alto marshes have a mixed plant distribution that includes pickleweed and cordgrass habitats that are interspersed between mudflats.

name: Serpentine, Sylvan, Edgewood, and Sunset Trails Loop
description:
Hikers follow the Serpentine Trail through dense golden grasslands as it winds through the park. These grasslands are the best to see flowers in the springtime since they are heavily covered in vibrant wildflowers. Along this trail, hikers will reach the ridge, with a view of Skyline Ridge with green carpeting. 

The Sunset Trail winds around the base of Edgewood's central hill through twisted and winding grasslands, with sweeping vistas of the power lines and I-280. More wide-open grasslands and breathtaking views of Mount Diablo, the East Bay, and the San Francisco Bay await hikers on this trail.

The Sylvan Trail winds uphill through a California bay and coastal oak woods. This trail climbs sharply to meet the Live Oak Trail but is more rugged and rocky. The Edgewood Trail offers a challenging ascent in a thick, shaded oak forest.

name: Calaveras Ridge Trail and Tularcitos Trail
description: This route starts at Sandy Wool Lake, takes the Calaveras Ridge Trail south, and connects with the Tularcitos Trail to complete the loop. The wide dirt paths and minimal elevation gain make this a great place for passive recreation and bird watching. The views are beautiful, but there is little shade. Bring water and sun protection.

name: Harvey Bear Trail and Ed Wilson Trail
park: Coyote Lake Harvey Bear Ranch County Park
description: • Parking Fee: Coyote Lake Harvey Bear Ranch County Park charges a fee to enter, except at Mendoza Ranch and Harvey Bear Entrances. There are varying fees depending on if you enter by vehicle, motorcycle, foot, horse, or bike. Please visit https://parks.santaclaracounty.gov/locations/coyote-lake-harvey-bear-ranch-county-park

name: Deer Hollow Farm Trail Loop
park: Rancho San Antonio Open Space Preserve
description:
This is a scenic and short walk out to the Deer Hollow Farm. You will enjoy oak woodland and chaparral scrub along the way. This is an excellent spot for bird-watching.

Visitors can hike the loop counterclockwise for a gradual, wheelchair-friendly ascent on a paved road to the farm. After the farm, the loop takes you on a steady climb on a narrower dirt path that ends with a steep decline on a wide, crushed gravel path. Go clockwise for a steep initial ascent and a gradual descent to close the loop.

name: Richards Fire Road
description:
• General fee: Huddart County Park charges a fee to enter. For more information, please visit https://www.smcgov.org/parks/huddart-park

Richards Fire Road Trail circumnavigates Huddart park on the North and East Sides. This all purpose trail is a great way to explore the park and to interact with nature.

description:
This trail is an accessible walk around the historic Santa Clara mission featuring beautifully manicured gardens, impressive recreated mission-era architecture, an olive orchard, and a grape vineyard, as well as the remains of some original adobe structures. There are many paths in the area if you wish to extend your walk and further explore the area.

Accessibility: 

Equipment
This trail is likely accessible for visitors using wheelchairs, mobility equipment, or strollers.

Parking
It is unclear whether designated accessible parking is available near the trailhead.

Surface
The trail surface is paved asphalt, paved concrete, and brick and is typically at least 8 feet wide.

Grade
This trail is estimated to be flat (1% or less).

name: Boccardo Loop Trail via Penitencia Creek Trail
description:
• Partial closure: As of October 2024, part of this route is temporarily inaccessible, but you can still enjoy other sections of this trail. For more information, please visit https://www.sanjoseca.gov/home/showpublisheddocument/110007/638568325940770000
• Parking fee information: There is a fee to park at Alum Rock Park. For more information, please visit https://www.sanjoseca.gov/Home/Components/FacilityDirectory/FacilityDirectory/2088/2028

The trail is a great loop that offers some challenge, and will get your heart pumping!  Expect moderate inclines, but little shade. The trail offers sweeping views throughout most of the adventure, with a fairly wide dirt path. The path is wide enough to walk side-by-side as you travel through rolling hills and meadows. You may even see deer and other wildlife on the trail!

name: Arroyo, Old Spanish, and Toyon Trail
description: This loop is mostly shaded and travels across rolling terrain. Along the way, there are some nice views and benches to stop and rest at. The area is very popular on the weekends, so an early start is recommended since the parking can fill up quickly. Signs are in place at all of the major trail junctions.

name: Regnart Creek Trail
description:
The Regnart Creek Trail offers scenic, traffic-free outdoor recreation and commuting. Adjacent to Regnart Creek, waterfowl and other wildlife are common in the area. The trail starts at Creekside Park and ends at Library Field, with several places to exit along the way.

Accessibility:

Equipment
This trail is likely accessible for visitors using wheelchairs, mobility equipment, or strollers.

Parking
There are 2 designated accessible parking spaces with striped access aisles in the paved parking lot.

Surface
The trail surface is paved asphalt or finely crushed gravel and is typically at least 8 feet wide.

Grade
This trail is estimated to be flat (1% or less).

More Info
Wheelchair accessible restrooms are available near the trailhead. Picnic tables and benches are available along the route for resting.

name: Brushy Peak and West Side Loop
description:
This trail takes you almost to the very top of Brushy Peak, and has some fairly steep sections. Although the terrain is initially grassy and relatively smooth, as the trail climbs, it begins to pass through outcroppings of sandstone that add texture to the landscape. The large ponds at the base of the peak provide habitat for frogs and turtles, as well as the occasional San Joaquin kit fox. At the apex of the climb, you are rewarded with views of the sweeping ranchland and rolling hills that surround the park, as well as the windmills of Altamont Pass. This trail is best when the grasses are green during or just after the wet season.

Trail Directions: From Laughlin Ranch Staging Area, head slightly uphill to find the trailhead marked Brushy Peak Loop Trail. Follow Brushy Peak Loop Trail for 1.16 miles, until you reach a cattle gate. Cross through the gate, and then head west to stay on Brushy Peak Loop Trail for another 2.1 miles. Once you reach the junction with West Loop Trail, take a left and continue downhill to finish the loop. Make sure to keep right around the cattle pond, as there are many branching, small trails. Continue for 0.93 miles, then safely cross Laughlin Road to re-enter Laughlin Ranch Staging Area and finish your hike.

Park Hours: Jan 1 – 31: 8am – 5pm; Feb 1 – Mar 12: 8am – 6pm;
Mar 13 – Apr 17: 8am – 7pm; Apr 18 – Sep 5: 8am – 8pm; Sep 6 – Nov 5: 8am – 7pm; Nov 6 – Dec 31: 8am -5pm

Fees: None

name: Welch-Hurst, Sanborn, and Skyline Trail to Russel Point
description:
• Fee Information: Sanborn County Park charges a fee to enter. For more information, please https://parks.santaclaracounty.gov/locations/sanborn-county-park

Dogs are not allowed in Castle Rock but are allowed to be on-leash in Sanborn Park. If you have your pup with you, you'll have to turn around before crossing into Castle Rock State Park. 

Start on the Welch-Hurst Trail which connects to the Lower Madrone Trail. Then, continue along the Upper Madrone Trail to the Sanborn Trail. You will take skyline trail to visit the many viewpoints along Castle Rock State Park before returning.

name: Coyote Creek Parkway: Hellyer County Park to Silver Creek Valley
park: Coyote Creek Parkway: Hellyer County Park
description:
• General fee: Hellyer County Park charges a fee to enter. For more information, please visit https://parks.sccgov.org/santa-clara-county-park-fees
• Partial closure: The Coyote Creek Trail is closed between Hellyer Park and Embedded Way due to flooding and swiftly moving water, but you can still enjoy other sections of this trail. For more information, please visit https://parks.sccgov.org/closures-updates

This scenic parkway meanders along Coyote Creek for 15 miles. The north portion features a paved multi-use trail popular with cyclists, rollerbladers, and hikers.

Accessibility: There are 4 designated accessible spaces in the paved parking lot off of Hellyer Avenue at the north end of the trail. All of them are van-accessible with striped access aisles. There is 1 paved designated accessible space in the gravel parking lot off of Silver Creek Valley Road at the south end of the trail. It is van-accessible with striped access aisles. 

The trail surface is paved asphalt and smooth. It is typically at least 10 feet wide. There is a painted dividing line along most of the trail which reduces the width. The whole trail is estimated to be in the gentle (3% or less) grade category. This trail will likely be navigable for most wheelchairs/mobility equipment or stroller users. There are benches along the route for resting.

name: Mount Diablo via Summit Trail
description:
This is one of the most popular routes to the summit of Mount Diablo. The trail is a mix of wide dirt road to single-track trail. The trail parallels the road in some areas, and sometimes there can be road traffic noise. There are lovely wildflowers along the trail in the spring. There are restrooms along the way and at the summit. There is drinking water at the summit as well. The summit is a great stop to stop and take in the views and visit the visitor's center.

From the summit of Mount Diablo, you can see many Bay Area landmarks and on a clear day, you can see the Sierra Nevada Mountains. Bring your binoculars to see how many landmarks you can spot. On a clear day, you might even be able to pick out Half Dome in Yosemite National Park!

name: Agua Caliente, Sierra Caliente and Monument Peak
description:
• General fee: Ed R. Levin County Park charges a fee to enter. For more information, please visit https://parks.sccgov.org/plan-your-visit/santa-clara-county-park-fees

There is an out-and-back option that takes the Agua Caliente Trail past several hang-gliding launch locations. Although this trail can be steep in sections, it does offer great views of San Jose and the South Bay from the top. You can watch hang gliders taking off from their launch spots into the sky! The area is very sunny, so getting an early start is nice.

name: Alpine Pond via Ipiwa Trail
description: Ipiwa Trail offers a pleasant walk through the forest to Alpine Pond. This trail is great for people who want to have a nice and casual hike without too many obstacles. While hiking, you can enjoy open spaces and stunning views. You can park at Skyline Ridge Parking Lot, and there is a bathroom in the parking lot.

name: Avenue of the Noble Giants
description:
• Joseph D Grant County Park collects a day-use fee for vehicular entrance year-round. For more information, please see https://parks.sccgov.org/plan-your-visit/santa-clara-county-park-fees#3925188384-3236192913

Hikers and equestrians have access to an extensive 52-mile trail system. Mountain bikes are permitted on nearly half of the park's trails as designated. The diverse trail system at the park makes this a popular place to stage large-scale organized trail events such as equestrian endurance rides, mountain bike events, and foot races. Dogs are also allowed on the trails, picnic, areas, and campgrounds as long as they are on a 6 ft. leash.

name: San Tomas Aquino Creek Trail
description:
• General fee: Sunnyvale Baylands Park charges a fee to enter. For more information, please visit https://parks.sccgov.org/santa-clara-county-parks/sunnyvale-baylands-park

Flat easy trail to walk. No shade, concrete the whole way.

Accessibility: There are at least 4 designated accessible spaces in the paved parking lots off of Caribbean Drive at the north end of the trail. They are van-accessible with striped access aisles. The trail surface is asphalt, brick, cement, dirt, gravel, or wooden bridge (with railings), and typically ranges from 4 to 8 feet wide. 

There is a painted dividing line along most of the trail which reduces the width. There are also metal bollards at road crossings which reduce the width. The estimated grade is mostly gentle (5% or less). All-terrain tires or motorized equipment may be needed for the unpaved areas past 5.5 miles heading southbound. There are benches along the route for resting

name: Santa Clara Valley Open Space Authority Trail
description:
El Toro Peak is on private property. Do not continue along this trail to the top of the peak. 

When passing through private property easements and right-of-ways it is especially important to stay on the path and respect posted guidance. Local officials and private landowners work in partnership to provide public access to this area. Staying on the path while on private property ensures that agreements between local officials and the landowner are upheld and that this trail remains open to the public in the future.

name: San Francisco Bay Trail: Sunnyvale West Pond Loop
park: San Francisco Bay Trail: Sunnyvale West Pond Loop. Bring plenty of water and wear sunscreen and protective clothing.Top trails nearbyBay Trail: Shoreline LakeBay Trail: Shoreline LakeShoreline at Mountain View Park4.6·Easy·7.4 mi·Est. 2h 11mAlviso Slough TrailAlviso Slough TrailAlviso Marina County Park4.3·Easy·8.7 mi·Est. 2h 32mStevens Creek TrailStevens Creek Trail4.5·Easy·4.2 mi·Est. 1h 17mShoreline Park LoopShoreline Park LoopShoreline at Mountain View Park4.6·Easy·1.4 mi·Est. 25mGuadalupe River TrailGuadalupe River Trail4.5·Easy·5.4 mi·Est. 1h 37mSan Francisco Bay Trail - Sunnyvale to Sand PointSan Francisco Bay Trail - Sunnyvale to Sand PointDon Edwards San Francisco Bay National Wildlife Refuge4.6·Moderate·20.0 mi·Est. 5h 50mSunnyvale Baylands Park Guadalupe SloughSunnyvale Baylands Park Guadalupe SloughSunnyvale Baylands Park4.2·Easy·3.4 mi·Est. 1h 0mSan Tomas Aquino Creek TrailSan Tomas Aquino Creek TrailSunnyvale Baylands Park4.4·Easy·12.6 mi·Est. 3h 47mSan Tomas Aquino Creek Trail to SF Bay TrailSan Tomas Aquino Creek Trail to SF Bay Trail4.4·Easy·4.0 mi·Est. 1h 11mBaylands Perimeter LoopBaylands Perimeter LoopSunnyvale Baylands Park4.3·Easy·1.3 mi·Est. 23mAlviso Marina LoopAlviso Marina LoopAlviso Marina County Park4.3·Easy·0.8 mi·Est. 14mSan Francisco Bay Trail at Sunnyvale Baylands ParkSan Francisco Bay Trail at Sunnyvale Baylands ParkSunnyvale Baylands Park
description: The San Francisco Bay Trail makes a detour and follows the perimeter of the two ponds at the Sunnyvale Water Pollution Control Plant. The wide dirt paths offer panoramic views, and the ponds are thriving with wildlife. This is a great place for birders. There is no shade or drinking water along the route; plan accordingly.

name: Best trails inEast Bay Regional Park District Trail Systems
park: East Bay Regional Park District Trail Systemsbest Trails In East Bay Regional Park District Trail Systems Best Trails In East Bay Regional Park
description:
Want to find the best trails in East Bay Regional Park District Trail Systems for an adventurous hike or a family trip? AllTrails has 11 great trails for walking and more. Enjoy hand-curated trail maps, along with reviews and photos from nature lovers like you.

Ready for your next hike or bike ride? Explore one of 5 easy hiking trails in East Bay Regional Park District Trail Systems that are great for the whole family. Looking for a more strenuous hike? We've got you covered, with trails ranging from 111 to 1,443 feet in elevation gain. Whatever you have planned for the day, you can find the perfect trail for your next trip to East Bay Regional Park District Trail Systems.

name: Russian Ridge Trail
description: Easy hike with sweeping views of the entire Peninsula and beautiful wildflowers along the way.

name: Hamms Gulch to Spring Ridge Loop
description: This is a great hike with a mix of microclimates and excellent views. The loop can be hiked in either direction. There is a mix of sun and shade, so bring plenty of water and sun protection. There are lovely wildflowers in the meadows in the spring and early summer.  The trail can get muddy in the winter and early spring.

name: Zinfandel Trail to Lookout Trail and Vista Loop to Maisie's Peak
description:
This trail starts from the parking lot off Montebello Road, where restrooms and a winery are available, and leads to Maisie's Peak in Picchetti Ranch Open Space Preserve. Along the way, look for wildlife, including banana slugs, peacocks, deer, turtles, and salamanders. The trail becomes lush and green during the rainy season, with interesting fungi adding to the scenery.

Be prepared for creek crossings, steep, narrow sections with exposed tree roots, and slippery sandy terrain—sturdy footwear is highly recommended. Your efforts will be rewarded with spectacular views of the valley and Stevens Creek Reservoir.

name: Ulistac Natural Area and Guadalupe River Trail
description: Ulistac Natural Area is a scenic wetlands area along the Guadalupe River. This route starts off Lick Mill Boulevard and follows the Levee Regional Trail south before looping back and heading north along the river. On the way back, cut through the meadow and oak grove. There is limited parking along the road.

name: Hidden Springs to Ohlone Trail to Ridge Trail
description:
• Fee Information: Santa Teresa County Park charges a fee to enter. For more information, please visit https://parks.sccgov.org/plan-your-visit/santa-clara-county-park-fees#3925188384-3236192913

The gravel trail leads to the dirt double-track trail. The trail is level in the beginning but gets steep as you progress. Wildflowers and butterflies can be seen throughout the trail. Turkeys may often be seen grazing nearby, and cows occasionally pass through the area. Along the way, there are many places to catch your breath and take in the breathtaking scenery.

Hikers are rewarded with expansive views of the Santa Cruz Mountains, Mount Tamalpais, Mount Diablo, Mount Hamilton, and the Sierra Nevada on this trail, which offers breathtaking views of the southern Bay Area.

name: Bear Creek Summit via Madrone Knoll Trail and Alma Trail
park: Bear Creek Redwoods Open Space Preserve
description: Hiking and equestrian trail that climbs to the top of Madrone Knoll. This is a beautiful shaded hike under the redwoods. There is quite a bit of climbing along the way, making this trail an excellent workout. There aren't any expansive views along the way, but this trail is excellent if you want a nature experience.

name: PG&E, Wildcat and Coyote Trail Loop
park: Rancho San Antonio Open Space Preserve
description: This loop is easy to follow and has some nice views of the Bay. The scenery is a nice mix of wooded stretches of trail and more open areas. It can be buggy during the summer, so bug spray is recommended during the warmer months of the year. An early start is recommended on the weekends to be the crowds and secure a parking spot.

name: John Nicholas and Peterson Memorial Loop
description:
• Fee Information: Sanborn County Park charges a fee to enter. For more information, please https://parks.santaclaracounty.gov/locations/sanborn-county-park

This route explores the beauty of Sanborn County Park and features beautiful Bay views. The trail is used for hiking and mountain biking, so stay alert and share the space. Most of the path is shaded, making it a good option for the hotter days. 

The incline is mostly gradual, aside from one steeper section with switchbacks. After that, there is a slightly steeper descent back to the parking lot off Sanborn Road. Some areas can get muddy after rain, so wear sturdy footwear.

name: Penitencia Creek Trail
description:
• Parking fee information: There is a fee to park at Alum Rock Park. For more information, please visit https://www.sanjoseca.gov/Home/Components/FacilityDirectory/FacilityDirectory/2088/2028

A meandering 3-mile path alongside the Upper Penitencia River. This is a great trail for the entire family.

It's a good chance that you'll be sharing the trail with other hikers and bikers. Keep an eye out for others on the trail, say hi, and remember that hikers have the right of way (but should keep eyes and ears out for mountain bikers coming quickly down hills or around blind turns).

name: Agua Caliente Trail and Calera Creek Trail
description:
• General fee: Ed R. Levin County Park charges a fee to enter. For more information, please visit https://parks.sccgov.org/plan-your-visit/santa-clara-county-park-fees

This loop trail starts at the parking lot off Downing Road near Sandy Wool Lake, where restrooms, a picnic area, shelter, and the City of Milpitas Dog Park are available. The trail leads into Ed R. Levin County Park, offering beautiful views of the rolling hills, lake, and city. Be prepared for a few creek crossings and very little shade along the way.

name: Castle Rock, Big Basin, and Portola Redwoods State Park Loop
description:
• Partial Closure: The trails leading up to Butano Ride Fire Road are closed indefinitely. For more information, please visit https://www.smcgov.org/parks/pescadero-creek-park-trails
• CZU Lightning Complex Fire : Public access to Big Basin has been severely impacted by the 2020 CZU Lightning Complex Fire and ongoing fire recovery work, but the park is open for limited day-use access. There is currently no access to waterfalls, all camping is closed and skyline to sea trail is open to the north but access to south (towards the ocean) is closed

This may be the longest direct loop hike available in the peninsula. The nearly 30 mile loop covers three State Parks (Castle Rock, Big Basin, and Portola Redwoods), a county park (Pescadero Creek Park), and a Mid Peninsula Regional Open District (Long Ridge Open Space Preserve). This is all made possible by well positioned easements that allow for narrow but critical routes in between the parks. If you're looking for a good weekend hike that loops, this may be your best bet in the South Bay. 

Campsites: There are three nearly equidistant camp sites along the trail; Waterman Gap Trail Camp, Lane Trail Camp, Slate Creek Trail Campground. No matter where you start the hike, you will also have a campground within roughly 10 miles. Reservations are required in advance.

Parking: There are three overnight parking lots; at Big Basin Park HQ, Portola Redwoods Park HQ, and at the main Castle Rock entrance.  Parking at the latter will add a few miles distance. There are also several places where one could get dropped off and hop on the Skyline to Sea trail. 

Historical Sites: There are two historical sites along the way, the Iverson Cabin and the Page Mill Site (original site of Mr. Page's Mill and road). There is not much to see at the sites except a marker and a sign, but it's nice to connect with some of the region's 19th century history.

Variations: If you're looking for a longer route, you can extend this trail by pushing further into either Castle Rock, Big Basin, and even Pescadero Creek Park, as long as you make it to the easement cross points. Pushing further into these parks can easily help you come up with a 50-60 mile loop if you really wanted.

Trail info for the parts encompassing:
- Skyline to Sea: Good trail but proximity to highway 9 causes it to lose some of the isolation charm. Great views of redwoods though. Well trafficked popular trail.
- Basin trail: The relatively higher elevation presents a very different vegetation, with shorter trees and more bushes, where one can capture some nice long distance views.
- Basin trail easement: Second part of the trail felt like it didn't get a lot of foot traffic but was well marked and maintained. 
- Butano ridge trail: Sharp switchbacks take you down almost 1500 feet of elevation. Nice scenery. 
- Summit trail: Sounds like it would be a tough hike based on the name but it was only about a 600 foot elevation climb.
- Slate creek trail: Well maintained and nice trail. Runs by a river for most of the distance.
- Ward road trail: Connect Portola Redwoods state park to the Long Ridge Open Space Preserve... biggest elevation change of the entire trail here. Wide trail that really is more of a road. Something to get through, though there are some nice long views available.
- Hicky Oaks Trail: Best long views of the entire hike here as one can see into the entire valley before re-connecting with the Skyline to the Sea trail. 

Trail is recommended only for experienced hikers. There are several rivers along the way to refill water, but it would be worth planning for those in advance as there are some long stretches with no river access. 

Please post your trip reports and variations!

name: The Ferry Building to Mount Tamalpais Cycle Route
description: Enjoy this 95.8-km out-and-back trail near San Francisco, California. Generally considered a challenging route. This trail is great for road biking, and it's unlikely you'll encounter many other people while exploring.

name: Bay Area Ridge Trail: Purisima Creek Redwoods
park: Purisima Creek Redwoods Open Space Preserve
description:
Five trails in Purisima Creek Redwoods Open Space Preserve link together for a challenging loop through forested canyons and over high ridges with ocean views. Hikers lose more than 1,000 feet of elevation in the first 2 miles and regain it on a steady climb out of the canyon (bicyclists and equestrians have a greater elevation loss and gain). The Craig Britton Trail for hikers is a relatively level trail through a majestic redwood forest. Summer fog sometimes bathes the forested areas, while the open, south-facing ridges may be hot.

For more information, see the Bay Area Ridge Trail page here: https://ridgetrail.org/purisima-creek-redwoods-open-space-preserve/

This trail description is excerpted from the 2019 Guidebook. For details on all of the Bay Area Ridge trails, trailheads and more buy the book from Wilderness Press: https://www.wildernesspress.com/product.php?productid=16685&cat=274&bestseller=Y

Accessibility: Only the first 0.3 miles along the dirt Redwood Trail is considered wheelchair or stroller friendly and is the most accessible portion of this trail. That route can be viewed on its own page here: https://www.alltrails.com/trail/us/california/purisima-creek-redwood-trail-accessible

name: Bay Area Ridge Trail: Vargas Plateau Regional Park
park: Bay Area Ridge Trail: Vargas Plateau Regional Park
description:
Atop the plateau a pastoral landscape predominates, and golden eagles, hawks, deer, bobcats, frogs, snakes and a variety of other animals make their home in the open grasslands, ponds, and steep wooded canyons.

Vargas Plateau sits high on grassy hills overlooking the South Bay. The Ridge Trail, with moderate ascents and descents, runs north/south along the upper ridges of the park and offers sweeping views in all directions. 

The scenic park is a refreshing escape from the urban sprawl below. Visit in the spring, when the green hills are covered in poppies.

For more information, see the Bay Area Ridge Trail page here: https://ridgetrail.org/vargas-plateau-regional-park/

This trail description is excerpted from the 2019 Guidebook. For details on all of the Bay Area Ridge trails, trailheads and more buy the book from Wilderness Press: https://www.wildernesspress.com/product.php?productid=16685&cat=274&bestseller=Y

name: Sign Hill: Iris Hill and Ridge Trail Loop
description: Experience this 0.7-mile loop trail near South San Francisco, California. Generally considered a moderately challenging route, it takes an average of 34 min to complete. This is a popular trail for walking, but you can still enjoy some solitude during quieter times of day. The best times to visit this trail are January through April. Dogs are welcome, but must be on a leash.

name: Rancho San Vicente Extended Loop
park: Rancho San Vicente Open Space Preserve
description: Lisa Killough Trail - North Ridge Trail - Almaden Trail - North Ridge Trail - Lisa Killough Trail - Vista de Oro - Lisa Killough - Cottle Trail - Lisa Killough Trail

name: Año Nuevo and Goat Hill Trail Loop
description:
• General fee: Butano State Park charges a fee to enter. For more information, please visit https://www.parks.ca.gov/?page_id=536

Pretty hike starts with a steep climb and descends into lush redwoods at state park north of Santa Cruz

This is one of the best moderate hikes at Butano State Park. It can start out from the park entrance or from the campground. 

Highlight of the loop is the Año Nuevo Trail, which make a rugged ascent from the park entrance to the Olmo Fire Road. On clear days you can see the Pacific coastline, but often you'll be hiking in coastal fog. 

IF you time your hike to coincide with the fog's burning off, you'll have splendid views of the ocean and the redwood forests rising from the coast. 

The loop then descends under a thick redwood canopy until it reaches the campground, where it's a level walk back to the parking lot. 

Butano is a great place to hike all year, especially during spring wildflower season.

name: Cavallo Point to Slacker Hill
park: GMTExplore near Cavallo Point to Slacker HillActivitiesBirdingHikingHorseback ridingMountain bikingRunningWalkingAttractionsBeachChallengingEasyForestHistoric siteLongModerately challengingNo dogsRiverShortViewsWildflowersWildlifeSuitabilityDogs on leashKid friendlyPartially pavedWheelchair friendlyPoints of interestHill 88Lime PointRodeo LagoonGolden Gate BridgeRodeo BeachHawk HillBattery YatesPoint Bonita LighthouseSlacker HillRodeo CoveTennessee CoveKirby CoveLone Sailor MonumentKirby CoveBattery O'RourkeGolden Gate Bridge LookoutBattery Smith-GuthrieBird Island ArchSwede's BeachHorseshoe BayActivitiesBirdingHikingHorseback ridingMountain bikingRunningWalkingAttractionsBeachChallengingEasyForestHistoric siteLongModerately challengingNo dogsRiverShortAttractionsViewsWildflowersWildlifeSuitabilityDogs on leashKid friendlyPartially pavedWheelchair friendlyPoints of interestHill 88Lime PointRodeo LagoonGolden Gate BridgeRodeo BeachHawk HillBattery YatesPoint Bonita LighthouseSlacker HillRodeo CovePoints of interestTennessee CoveKirby CoveLone Sailor MonumentKirby CoveBattery O'RourkeGolden Gate Bridge LookoutBattery Smith-GuthrieBird Island ArchSwede's BeachHorseshoe BayDownloadOpen mapAllTrailsExploreCountriesRegionsCitiesParksTrailsPoints of InterestTrail FeaturesMapsMy mapsCreate mapPrint mapsRoute converterCompanyAboutJobsPressAmbassadorsAffiliatesInfluencersCommunitySupportGift membershipAllTrails GearExploreCountriesRegionsCitiesPark
description: This route takes you from Cavallo Point—the Lodge at the Golden Gate—along Slacker Trail on a steady, challenging incline and some switchbacks to Slacker Hill. Along the way, you will be rewarded with views of the bay and the Golden Gate Bridge, with Slacker Hill offering stunning 360-degree views of the area.

name: Grizzly Flat Trail to Table Mountain Loop
description: Head out on this 13.2-km loop trail near Palo Alto, California. Generally considered a challenging route, it takes an average of 4 h 28 min to complete. This is a popular trail for hiking, horseback riding, and mountain biking, but you can still enjoy some solitude during quieter times of day. The trail is open year-round and is beautiful to visit anytime. You'll need to leave pups at home — dogs aren't allowed on this trail.

name: Jones, Manzanita, Range, Novitiate Trail Loop
park: St. Joseph'S Hill Open Space Preserve
description:
This is a fantastic trail near Los Gatos, California. The trail has a nice, steady climb and offers terrific views of the surrounding region. 

The trail offers stunning views of the valley and Lexington Reservoir. The path is rugged and wide, and it is well-marked and maintained.

On-street parking is available at the end of Jones Road.

name: Bay Trail: San Francisco Southern Waterfront
park: Golden Gate Bridge4.6·Easy·11.0 mi·Est. 3h 23mPanhandle and Music Concourse LoopPanhandle and Music Concourse LoopGolden Gate Park4.6·Easy·3.7 mi·Est. 1h 8mBay to Breakers Course RouteBay to Breakers Course RouteGolden Gate Park4.7·Moderate·7.5 mi·Est. 2h 30mThe Embarcadero to Oracle Park and McCovey CoveThe Embarcadero to Oracle Park and McCovey Cove4.6·Easy·2.9 mi·Est. 51mRincon Park to Crissy FieldRincon Park to Crissy FieldGolden Gate National Recreation Area4.7·Easy·10.4 mi·Est. 3h 9mFilbert Steps to Telegraph HillFilbert Steps to Telegraph Hill4.6·Moderate·0.5 mi·Est. 25mBernal Heights Park TrailBernal Heights Park TrailBernal Heights Park4.7·Easy·1.0 mi·Est. 24mBarbary Coast Trail Barbary Coast Trail 4.5·Easy·4.2 mi·Est. 1h 28mUpper Market Stairway WalksUpper Market Stairway WalksCorona Heights Park4.6·Moderate·4.5 mi·Est. 2h 18mSalesforce Park LoopSalesforce Park LoopSalesforce Park4.5·Easy·0.6 mi·Est. 11mPrecita Park and Bernal Heights SummitPrecita Park and Bernal Heights SummitPrecita Park
description:
This is a segment of the San Francisco Bay Trail, a 500-mile trail around the Bay. This is the second section of the Bay Trail, which takes hikers along the Southern Waterfront of San Francisco. 

This trail is not entirely complete and parts are currently under construction, so you may have to detour on city streets or sidewalks to complete the route. For more information, visit: https://mtc.ca.gov/operations/regional-trails-parks/san-francisco-bay-trail/bay-trail-navigational-map

name: Jollyman Loop
description: Jollyman Park has an All-Inclusive Playground, a baseball field, and paved paths. This route follows those paved paths around the park's perimeter, offering traffic-free exercising and dog walking. Parking lots are available on every side, and you will likely be sharing the paths as the park is a popular place for the residents in the adjacent neighborhood.

name: Joice, Bernal Hill, Norred Loop
description:
• Fee Information: Santa Teresa County Park charges a fee to enter. For more information, please visit https://parks.sccgov.org/plan-your-visit/santa-clara-county-park-fees#3925188384-3236192913

Hikers will wind up and into the hills, beginning with the Joice Trail. As you ascent, views of Loma Prieta can be seen in the distance. The trail has a steep slope bordered by thistle. The Joice Trail mostly follows a dirt road that winds through a tree-covered valley. You'll continue climbing as you switch to the Bernal Hill Trail, taking in panoramic vistas.

The Norred Trail meanders through the woods along the bank of a drainage canal. Hikers on this section of the trail pass the ruins of an old barn, which deer and turkeys currently use as a habitat. The Norred Trail provides an overview of the city before viewing San Jose.

name: Eagle Rock Loop
description:
• Partial closure: As of October 2024, part of this route is temporarily inaccessible, but you can still enjoy other sections of this trail. For more information, please visit https://www.sanjoseca.gov/home/showpublisheddocument/110007/638568325940770000
• Parking fee information: There is a fee to park at Alum Rock Park. For more information, please visit https://www.sanjoseca.gov/Home/Components/FacilityDirectory/FacilityDirectory/2088/2028

Parking at the front entrance of Alum Rock is closed. Eagle Rock parking is the next option which is in the middle of the trail map. It’s approximately a 0.6-mile steep hike to Eagle Rock from there. There are some narrow sections along the trail, but it has great views of the city and is quiet and peaceful along the way.

name: Todd L. Quick Trail Loop
description:
• Partial closure: As of October 2024, part of this route is temporarily inaccessible, but you can still enjoy other sections of this trail. For more information, please visit https://www.sanjoseca.gov/home/showpublisheddocument/110007/638568325940770000
• Parking fee information: There is a fee to park at Alum Rock Park. For more information, please visit https://www.sanjoseca.gov/Home/Components/FacilityDirectory/FacilityDirectory/2088/2028

This trail starts at the parking lot off Penitencia Creek Road and leads to Alum Rock Park. Along the way, you’ll find the Todd Quick Rest Area, informative placards about the local flora, and beautiful views of San Jose and the valley from the viewpoint. Be prepared for limited shade along the trail and windy conditions at the top.

name: Crittenden Hill
park: HikingEasy to parkNot crowdedDog-friendlyGreat conditionsGreat viewsPark
description: Crittenden Hill is a barren golden hilltop with wide gravel paths winding throughout the park to a high point with panoramic views. The trails are multi-use and open to cyclists, hikers, and leashed pups. There is no shade along the route, so plan accordingly and bring plenty of water. There is plenty of parking from a few access points around the park.

name: Milagra Summit Trail
description:
Take this short paved trail for phenomenal views of the Pacific Ocean. The views make it worthwhile for hikers and walkers of all ages. Feel free to bring your leashed dog or a bike. Bikes are permitted on the paved portion only. There are also some old WWII bunkers that can be found close to the trail. Additional parking can be found at the bottom of the trail. 

Accessibility: There are no designated accessible spaces in the paved street parking lot off of Sharp Park Road at the south end of the trail. There do not appear to be any designated accessible parking spaces within 1.0 miles of the trailhead. The trail surface is paved asphalt and smooth. It is typically at least 10 feet wide. There is a gate across the trail at the start and the estimated width to go around it is 3 feet. 

The majority of the trail is estimated to be in the mostly gentle (5% or less) grade category but there are steeper sections at about __ when going __. Trail goers using wheelchairs/mobility equipment or strollers may need assistance in the steeper sections or to avoid them for safety.

name: Los Gatos Creek to Jones Loop
park: St. Joseph'S Hill Open Space Preserve
description: A great West Valley paved path/trail for biking, mountain biking, jogging, and birding. A good starting point from Campbell Park the paved trail extends through Vasona Park, Downtown Los Gatos, and on to Lexington Reservoir and more challenging dirt road mountain bike climbs. Los Gatos Creek and ponds along the way offer good birding opportunities. The paved path makes a 2 mile loop from Campbell park to a pedestrian bridge at San Thomas Expressway. The east side of the loop has a 1 mile single track trail good for a quick mountain bike ride any time of the year.

name: High Ridge, Meyers Ranch and Dry Creek Trail
description: Enjoy this great trail system that provides hikers with opportunities to explore the natural landscape of Garin Regional Park, passing through wooded sections and offering scenic vistas of the surrounding valleys and hills. It’s a great spot for those seeking a varied outdoor experience close to Union City and Hayward. The trail can be quite muddy after rain, but the hills turn green and vibrant, which makes the dirt worthwhile.

name: Stream, East Ridge, and Canyon Loop
description:
• Fee Information: Reinhardt Redwood Regional Park charges a fee weekends and major holidays April through October at the Redwood Gate entrance. For more information please visit:https://www.ebparks.org/parks/reinhardt-redwood

Groves of trees and creek-side terraces welcome visitors to this hidden redwood forest. The enchanting space is just 15 minutes from downtown Oakland. There is a diversity of wildlife here. Deer, squirrels, and raccoons are common. 

Those with a keen eye might spot a rare golden eagle or an Alameda striped racer from the trail. Rainbow trout migrate seasonally up Redwood Creek. A historical fishway by Redwood Gate assists the fish on their annual migration upstream to spawning grounds. Besides hiking and nature study, park activities include picnic sites with meadows, lawns, and children’s play areas. Equestrian accommodations are found near the east entrances of the park. 

TRAIL HIGHLIGHTS: This loop trail begins along the contours of a meandering creek on the canyon floor. Sun exposure and opportunities for vistas increase as the path rises to the heights of the East Ridge. Water is available at Canyon Meadow, Girls’ Camp, and the Skyline Gate Staging area. Travelers should be prepared with sun protection and water, particularly for the ridge portion of the trail. 

From the Canyon Meadow Staging Area follow the Stream Trail into Reinhardt Redwood Park. This trail is paved for .89 miles before becoming a narrow dirt path for hikers and equestrians. At “Trail’s End,” continue on the Stream Trail for 1.9 miles through the canyon, occasionally crossing the stream at a small bridge. After Girls’ Camp, make a short ascent to the Skyline Gate Staging Area. At the staging area, turn right and enter through the gate onto the East Ridge Trail. Stay on this trail for 2.9 miles along the ridgeline far above the canyon. Turn right on to Canyon Trail and go downhill for .36 miles back into the Canyon Meadow Staging Area by the Quail picnic site.

name: Best trails inPurisima Creek Redwoods Open Space Preserve
park: Purisima Creek Redwoods Open Space Preservebest Trails In Purisima Creek Redwoods Open Space Preserveall Photos Best Trails In Purisima Creek Redwoods Open Space Preserve
description: Hours: half an hour before sunrise to half an hour after sunset

name: Whittemore Gulch and Purisima Creek Loop Trail
park: Purisima Creek Redwoods Open Space Preserve
description:
Starting from Skyline Boulevard, this hike explores beautiful Redwood forest, streams, and the stunning ocean views of Half Moon Bay.

The hike starts out downhill, heading away from Skyline Blvd, and down toward the ocean.  Soon after leaving the trailhead, you head out on top of one of the ocean facing ridges, where you can see the ocean and North Ridge Trail.

Soon after the ocean views, the route heads down and follows the Whittemore Gulch trail.  The trail follows the gulch down to the parking area on the opposite side of the park.  The loop trail then heads up Purisima Creek.

The trail meets up with the Bay Area Ridge Trail, and turns back up the ridge. This trail heads through some more redwood groves, and the ocean views return when the trail meets up with Harkins Ridge Trail.

This is a slightly longer version of the popular Purisima Redwoods Open Space Preserve hike and starts on the eastern trailhead on the coastal side.  The trail begins at the point where 3 of the major tributaries of the Purisima Creek joins into one and continues its flow into the Pacific ocean.

A major part of the hike is in the shades of redwoods. However, towards the latter part with elevation gain the trail opens out to give some good views of the ocean.  If you are looking for a trail located on the western slopes of the peninsula with beautiful views overlooking Half Moon Bay, then this is the hike for you!

name: New Almaden, Mine Hill and Guadalupe Loop
description:
• Partial closure: As of June 2, 2025,  part of this route is temporarily inaccessible, but you can still enjoy other sections of this trail. For more information, please visit https://parks.santaclaracounty.gov/locations/almaden-quicksilver-county-park

Good trail outlining the hills in Almaden. A lot of up and downs. Some technical rocky areas but nothing extreme. Some portions are very sunny but others are quite shaded. Good views of the Almaden area and the west side of San Jose.

Bring plenty of water and plan to arrive early, especially on weekends, as this is a popular trail.

name: Alpine Trail Bike Path
description:
The mostly flat and level Alpine Trail (also known as the Dwight F. Crowder Memorial Bike Path) connects Windy City Open Space Preserve in Portola Valley to the Stanford University and Menlo Park area. The trail surface is not completely paved at the beginning of the trail in Portola Valley, but it is paved for most of the way. As you get closer to Stanford University, the trail turns into a completely paved bike bath. Horses are allowed on the trail within the town of Portola Valley.

This trail is a great option for bike commuting, running, or walking within the area as it connects many neighborhoods and open space areas. The trail begins in Windy City Open Space Preserve but is maintained by both the City of Portola Valley and the County of San Mateo.

name: High Meadow Loop via Lower Meadow Trail
park: Rancho San Antonio Open Space Preserve
description: This loop travels through the woods and open meadows offering nice views. Wildlife such as deer can sometimes be spotted wandering through the open fields. The parking area can fill up quickly on a nice day, so an early start is recommended.  Be mindful that rattlesnakes are sometimes spotted sunning themselves along the trail on warm sunny days.

name: Tafoni Loop
park: El Corte De Madera Creek Open Space Preserve
description: This trail brings you through dense forest and past unique sandstone rock formations. Signage is in place at an overlook near the cave with information about the geology. Banana slugs are often spotted making their way across the trail. The shade makes this a great option during the warm summer months.

name: Mountain Lake Trail to Coastal Trail
description: This beautiful urban trail travels through the southern end of the Presidio of San Francisco. It starts from the Lyon Steps parking lot on the Mountain Lake Trail, which is a wide gravel path. Follow it west to Mountain Lake and pass below Highway 1 before ending at the beach along the Pacific coastline.

name: Esther Clark Park Walk
description: Get to know this 0.8-mile out-and-back trail near Los Altos, California. Generally considered an easy route, it takes an average of 16 min to complete. This is a popular trail for birding, hiking, and running, but you can still enjoy some solitude during quieter times of day. The trail is open year-round and is beautiful to visit anytime. Dogs are welcome and may be off-leash in some areas.

name: Bayview Hill Loop
park: Only challenge is the initial incline and the rest of the trail is a walk in the park.Park
description: This moderately used loop trail is paved. However, it goes from steep to very steep (over 8% grade) much of the time. Trail goers navigating with mobility equipment/a wheelchair or stroller may need assistance throughout this route due to the consistent steep grades and uneven and broken pavement. Observe stunning views and beautiful wildflowers throughout the trail.

name: Cottle Trail to Calero Reservoir and Lisa Killough Trail
park: Rancho San Vicente Open Space Preserve
description:
The trail winds through the grassy hills and wooded areas. The trail goes upstream along a brook to Cottle Rest. Along the trail, you'll come across California poppies, California buttercups, and crimson pimpernel wildflowers.

The Lisa Killough Trail climbs steadily to an observation point and passes among some of the most exquisite jewel flowers. Enjoy pleasant views of Mt. Umunhum in the distance and the surrounding lush green gradually. Also, you can enjoy breathtaking views of Loma Prieta, Mt. Hamilton, and Lick Observatory, as well as views that go all the way to the Diablo Range.

name: Charquin Trail to Ridge Trail Loop
description:
This loop takes you to the Russian Ridge Open Space Preserve. The trail is well-marked and maintained and provides great views of the Bay Area.
It's best to go on a colder day or start your hike early to avoid the heat, as most of the trail is exposed except for short sections with old-growth oak trees. During the spring, you'll see beautiful wildflowers. Parking with restrooms is available at the trailhead.

name: YSC, Panorama and Peak Trail Loop
description: This is a quieter alternative to the popular Peak Trail. It also is a great way of sampling some of the less traveled trails within the Mission Peak Regional Reserve. Expect lovely views! Keep your eye out for cows, as this area features open-range grazing. You may also see wild turkeys on your trip!

name: Bay Trail: San Francisco Northern Waterfront
description:
This is a segment of the San Francisco Bay Trail: a 500 mile long mile trail around the Bay. This is the 1st section of the Bay Trail, taking hikers along the Northern Waterfront of San Francisco

Did you know that nearly the entire San Francisco bayfront is manmade? Beneath your feet lie abandoned ships, excavated hilltops, rotting piers and rubble dumped into the bay after the 1906 earthquake and fire. Above, you will find one of the world's most inviting urban waterfronts. Beginning at iconic Fort Point under the Golden Gate Bridge, follow Marine Drive southeast along the water, passing the Warming Hut. A natural-surface trail hugs the shoreline through Crissy Field along restored wetlands and sand dunes. A paved path is available inland of the marsh along Mason Street. At the yacht harbor, follow the paved trail to the east and proceed as it meanders along the shoreline through Marina Green, or take the spur trail to the east and see if the eclectic wave organ will play for you. Climb the hill into Fort Mason, back down to equally historic Aquatic Park, and continue along the shoreline to Fisherman's Wharf. A gap in the Bay Trail at Fisherman's Wharf means there are no bicycle lanes between Hyde and Powell streets. Head east past Pier 39, follow The Embarcadero promenade along the shoreline and stop at Pier 7 for views of the San Francisco-Oakland Bay Bridge, Treasure Island and Yerba Buena Island. Pass the magnificent Ferry Building, take a trot out to the end of Pier 14, and continue south under the Bay Bridge. The path curves along the edge of South Beach Harbor and follows the shoreline around Oracle Park, home of the San Francisco Giants baseball team. Wathc an inning for free from the stadium's public viewing area. The northern bayfront, as well as the city's ocean shoreline, is almost entirely within the Golden Gate National Recreation Area, the first urban national park in the U.S. See segment #11 for Treasure and Yerba Buena islands.

Side Trip: Bike into Sausalito over the Golden Gate Bridge, see the sights, and then take the ferry back to Pier 41 in San Francisco. To access the Fort Baker Bay Trail from the east sidewalk of the bridge, use the stairs from the Vista Point parking lot and cross under the span.

Walking: Marina Green to Crissy Field, San Francisco

An approximately 2.5 mile walk (each way) from the foot of Fort Mason to the Warming Hut at Crissy Field. This flat shoreline walk features amazing views and both paved and natural surfaces.

Urban: Marina Green Bay Trail, San Francisco

Only slightly less hectic than the Embarcadero, the Marina Green regularly hosts soccer, Frisbee, sporting and food events. Check out the beautiful boats in the marina, and the houses lining Marina Boulevard made famous by the Loma Prieta earthquake in 1989.

History: San Francisco Maritime Historical Museum

Located in the Fisherman’s Wharf neighborhood, San Francisco Maritime National Historical Park offers the sights, sounds, smells and stories of Pacific Coast maritime history. At Hyde Street Pier, you can visit the Park’s historic ships, as well as boats from the Park’s small craft collection.

name: Harbor Bay Lagoon Loop
description: Head out on this 2.9-km loop trail near Alameda, California. Generally considered an easy route, it takes an average of 31 min to complete. This is a popular trail for birding, running, and walking, but you can still enjoy some solitude during quieter times of day. The trail is open year-round and is beautiful to visit anytime. Dogs are welcome, but must be on a leash.

name: Zinfandel Trail
description: This is a nice trail that is not too long or too steep. The trail is well-marked and well-maintained. The trail is located near a cute winery.  Keep an eye out for wildlife on this trail, including banana slugs, peacocks, deer, and salamanders. During the rainy season, the trail is lush and green with interesting fungi.

name: Los Gatos Creek Trail
description:
• Seasonal closure: Vasona Lake County Park is subject to seasonal closure during the wintertime and wet weather due to weather conditions. For more information, please visit https://parks.sccgov.org/closures-updates

This multi-use trail starts at the parking lot off Alma Bridge Road, where a picnic area with views of Lexington Reservoir is available. It then leads to San Jose via the Los Gatos Creek Trail. The trail winds between Los Gatos Creek and Santa Cruz Highway, passing through urban areas with parks and ponds.

name: Chochenyo, Red Hill and Meadowlark Loop
description:
• Partial closure: Part of this route is temporarily inaccessible, but you can still enjoy other sections of this trail. For more information, please visit https://www.ebparks.org/parks/coyote-hills
• Parking fee information: There is a fee to park at Coyote Hills Regional Park. For more information, please visit https://www.ebparks.org/parks/coyote-hills

This loop takes you through a variety of landscapes, from open meadows, marshlands to hilltop views. The trail explores mostly open areas, making this a great trail in the morning or evening. This trail is great for bird watching or enjoying views over the bay. This is a great trail for hiking and biking, but with the well maintained trails and distance, it might be slightly more enjoyable on a bike.

name: McClellan Ranch to Linda Vista Park
park: McClellan Ranch to Linda Vista Park
description:
A short path along a former quarry haul road, recently acquired by the City of Cupertino, links McClennan Ranch with Linda Vista park. 

The path affords views over Deep Cliff golf course towards Stevens Creek.  The park itself features a wide loop that approaches close to Stevens Creek. This path could serve as an extension to the Stevens Creek Trail, since it links up with it at McClennan Ranch.

name: Best trails inWindy Hill Open Space Preserve
park: Windy Hill Open Space Preservebest Trails In Windy Hill Open Space Preserve Best Trails In Windy Hill Open Space Preserve
description: Windy Hill offers sweeping views on the San Francisco Bay from its steep trails. The difference in elevation between its highest and lowest points is about 400 m (1300 ft). Windy Hill's 3 main trails that run roughly in parallel provide equally attractive routes to ascent or descent the park. From this trail network visitors can create various options for loops or out-and-backs: Spring Ridge Trail, mostly straight up through meadows with great views, and Hamms Gulch Trail and Razorback Ridge Trail with both lots of switchbacks mostly through dense forest. At the top of the park these trails are connected by the Bay Area Ridge Trail, and at the bottom by Eagles Trail, connecting to Sequoias Trail and Ridge Trail. The park is a local favorite for hiking, trail running, mountain biking and horse back riding (about 65% of the trails are multi-use). Hours: Open half an hour before sunrise to half an hour after sunset

name: Sanborn Narrows Trail
description:
• Fee Information: Sanborn County Park charges a fee to enter. For more information, please https://parks.santaclaracounty.gov/locations/sanborn-county-park

This short and straightforward trail meanders alongside Aubry Creek. Enjoy making your way through the woods, where you'll be shaded by the gorgeous moss-covered trees. You'll need to cross the creek on some rocks, which can be challenging if the water is high after heavy rain. Parking is limited along Sanborn Road, where the trail begins. Arrive early in the morning to secure a spot.

name: Upper Calaveras Fault Loop via Sierra Vista Trail
description: This loop trail starts from the parking lot off Sierra Road and leads to Sierra Vista Open Space Preserve via the Sierra Vista and Upper Calaveras Fault Trails, passing through rolling hills, green meadows, and forested areas. The well-maintained trail offers views of the valley, San Jose, and the South Bay in the distance. Be prepared for steep sections and minimal shade along the way.

name: Tony Look to Coyote Ridge to Lookout Loop
description: This loop offers beautiful views of Steven's Creek Reservoir as well as the surrounding hills. It is recommended to hike this loop counter-clockwise, as it's mapped here. Bring plenty of water and sun protection. There are many spots along the way to stop and take in the views and rest.

name: Saratoga Toll Road Trail
description:
• General fee: Castle Rock State Park charges a day-use fee to enter. For more information please visit https://www.parks.ca.gov/?page_id=538
• CZU Lightning Complex Fire : Public access to Big Basin has been severely impacted by the 2020 CZU Lightning Complex Fire and ongoing fire recovery work, but the park is open for limited day-use access. There is currently no access to waterfalls, all camping is closed and skyline to sea trail is open to the north but access to south (towards the ocean) is closed

This route combines the Skyline To The Sea Trail, and Saratoga Toll Road Trail beginning near Saratoga Gap. The toll road was first built in the mid-1800s and was the main travel route between the Santa Clara and Santa Cruz Valleys. Water is limited along the way, so pack plenty or bring a water filter along so you can refill.

name: Crystal Springs and Dean Trail
Hill Trail and Coyote Loop
description: This is an easy loop in the Rancho San Antonio Preserve. It follows the Hill Trail to a high point and descends on the Coyote Trail. The hills are a mix of grassland, coastal sage scrub, and chaparral, which offers expansive views. There is little shade, however, so be sure to bring water and sun protection.

name: Doolittle and Arrowhead Marsh Trail
park: The trail may not be certified as compliant with all country-specific accessibility legal standards.Top trails nearbyBay Farm Island Loop TrailBay Farm Island Loop Trail4.5·Moderate·6.0 mi·Est. 1h 45mSan Francisco Bay Trail and Oyster Bay Loop TrailSan Francisco Bay Trail and Oyster Bay Loop TrailOyster Bay Regional Shoreline4.4·Easy·2.2 mi·Est. 42mFaro Point LoopFaro Point LoopMarina Park
description:
Trail Highlights:
Tucked along the San Leandro Bay, the Martin Luther King Jr. Regional Shoreline is a haven for wildlife and nature lovers alike. Wander through lush tidal marshes, where egrets and herons wade gracefully in search of food. The breeze carries the scent of saltwater and the rhythmic calls of shorebirds. An Observation Tower invites quiet reflection, offering views of the bay’s calm waters and the distant city skyline. Bicyclists and walkers share the paths, weaving through native grasses and wildflowers, with peaceful moments around every corner.

Trail Directions:
