From Doolittle Staging Area North, walk toward Shoreline Center to gain access to Doolittle Trail. The trail name changes to Arrowhead Marsh Trail; follow it to Arrowhead Marsh observation tower. Retrace steps back to the parking lot.

Accessibility:
The Martin Luther King Jr. Regional Shoreline offers accessible trails designed for ease of use. The pathways are firm, level, and typically 4 feet wide or more, ensuring smooth travel for wheelchair users and those with mobility devices. Accessible parking is available at key trailheads, with nearby restrooms that include features like grab bars and adequate space for maneuvering. Scenic spots, including waterside views and picnic areas, are accessible, offering both enjoyment and comfort for all visitors. Some trails may require travel on firm dirt or grass.

name: UCSC Upper Campus Trail
description: Experience this 10.5-km loop trail near Santa Cruz, California. Generally considered a moderately challenging route, it takes an average of 2 h 44 min to complete. This trail is great for birding, mountain biking, and walking, and it's unlikely you'll encounter many other people while exploring. The trail is open year-round and is beautiful to visit anytime. You'll need to leave pups at home — dogs aren't allowed on this trail.

name: Agua Caliente Trail
description:
• General fee: Ed R. Levin County Park charges a fee to enter. For more information, please visit https://parks.sccgov.org/plan-your-visit/santa-clara-county-park-fees

Agua Caliente Trail offers a pleasant loop through Ed R. Levine Country Park. The trail climbs up for unbelievable views of the valley floor and San Francisco Bay. Make sure to bring your camera and a sense of adventure! Keep your eyes out for hang-gliders that frequent this area.

Take Tularcitos Trail to Agua Caliente. Climb up to the water trough, then return via the Calera Creek Trail.

name: Dick Bishop, Hassler, Dusky-Footed Woodrat, and Polly Geraci Loop
description: This is a very popular trail for folks with dogs, and a great option if you are looking to get outside in nature with your pup. While many areas allow for dogs to be off-leash, be sure to bring a leash and dog poop bags to clean up after your dog. The trail can sometimes be muddy in the winter and spring and sturdy footwear is recommended.

name: Best trails inBig Basin Redwoods State Park
park: Big Basin Redwoods State Parkbest Trails In Big Basin Redwoods State Parkall Photos Best Trails In Big Basin Redwoods State Park
description: Waterfalls, redwood forest, and miles of serene trails... Big Basin Redwoods State Park has everything to offer, within a short drive from San Francisco, San Jose, and Santa Cruz. This park is California's oldest, spanning more than 18,000 acres, and more than 2,000 feet in elevation. Day Use Annual Passes are accepted here. Dogs are only allowed on the paved trails.

name: Bayview, Alameda Creek, Shoreline, and Apay Way Trail Loop
description: The Bayview, Alameda Creek Shoreline, and Apay Way Trail Loop in California offers a scenic in San Francisco Bay. The loop takes you through wetlands, coastal habitats, and grassy meadows, with great views of the bay and nearby hills. As you walk, you'll pass by Alameda Creek, enjoying the sounds of water and the surrounding birdlife. The trail is relatively flat and easy to follow, making it a great option for a relaxing outdoor experience. This trail is more commonly cycled with the nature of its length, theres a few bumpy sections but otherwise its fairly smooth, this can be hiked too, and theres a shorter loop option on No Name Trail, that might be preferred when hiking. The best time to visit this trail is early in the morning or at sunset as theres little shade, and in the morning less car noise when you get closer to the 84.

name: Milagra Overlook Trail
park: What are some of the facilities available for Milagra Overlook Trail?There is a parking lot off of Sharp Park
description: Take this short paved and dirt trail for phenomenal views of the Pacific Ocean. The views make it worthwhile for hikers and walkers of all ages. Feel free to bring your leashed dog or a bike. Bikes are permitted on the paved portion only. There are also some old WWII bunkers that can be found close to the trail. Additional parking can be found at the bottom of the trail.

name: Old Stage Road, Edgewood and Serpentine Trail Loop
description: Nice short hike with a wooded trail and views from a meadow.

name: Coyote Ridge Trail to Maisie's Peak
description: This is the long and scenic way to the summit of Maisie's Peak. It begins at the north end of the Stevens Creek Reservoir and follows the Coyote Ridge Trail south to the peak. The ridge is gorgeous, surrounded by coastal oaks and scrub, but does not offer shade. Bring plenty of water and sun layers.

name: Prospect #3 to Mine Hill Trail Loop
description: This epic trail through Almaden Quicksilver County Park features many ups and downs and beautiful views of Silicon Valley. The terrain is varied. Some sections are gravel and steeper, some are rocky, and some are narrow and overgrown with tall brush and thorns. Wear long pants to protect your legs. There's a good mix of shade and sun along the way.

name: Best trails inMountain View
park: Top trails1#1 - Bay Trail: Shoreline Lake4.6(1009)•Easy•11.9 km•Est. 2h 11mShoreline Lake Park
description:
Looking for the best walking trails in Mountain View? Whether you're getting ready to hike, cycle, trail run, or explore other outdoor pursuits, AllTrails has 8 picturesque trails in the Mountain View area. Discover hand-curated trail maps, along with reviews and photos from fellow outdoor enthusiasts.

Explore one of 8 easy walking routes in Mountain View, with child-friendly routes for your next family outing. Venture outdoors and learn more about the area's historic sites or take a break from the hustle and bustle along the many tree-lined paths surrounding Mountain View. Perfect for little feet, paws, walkers and outdoor enthusiasts of any skill level.

name: Mount Umunhum Trail via Woods Trail
description: The Mount Umunhum Trail via Woods Trail runs parallel to Mt. Umunhum Road. It provides views of the surrounding environment, including sporadic views over the San Jose metropolitan area, the Santa Clara Valley, and prominent features like Mount Hamilton and Mount Diablo. A small clearing at the top gives you a good view of Mount Umunhum's summit region, including the well-known radar tower.

name: Saratoga Gap Long Ridge Loop Trail
description:
This loop is a good mix of shaded trails and points where you're walking across an open hillside with views. You will even pass a small lake along the way. The parking area is known to fill up quickly on the weekends.

Although dogs are allowed on some trails in this preserve, this particular route uses trails that do not allow dogs.

name: Page Mill, Franciscan and Lost Creek Loop
description: Mostly shaded trail through forest terrain with occasional chaparral and grassy meadows. This loop trail takes you through beautiful landscapes, including shady oak groves, trickling creeks, and open meadows with lovely views of the surrounding area. Along the way, you’ll have the chance to spot local wildlife and enjoy the quiet beauty of the preserve.

name: Monterey Peninsula Recreational Trail and Asilomar Ave Loop
description: Begin near Lover's Point and follow the coastline along Ocean View Boulevard. There are plenty of benches along the path to stop at and enjoy the view from. At points, there are spots you can walk down to explore the rocky shoreline. At the intersection with Lighthouse Ave, begin walking down the sidewalk which leads to Asilomar Ave. Once you arrive back at Ocean View Blvd, head back to the start point.

name: Harkins Ridge, Craig Britton, Purisima Creek Trail
park: Purisima Creek Redwoods Open Space Preserve
description:
A classic Redwoods hike if there ever was one! Doing this hike counter-clockwise, the first section follows peaceful Purisma Creek up an old logging road. Branching off the road after 2.6 miles, you turn onto a wooded pathway and delve into what seems to be the heart of Mother Earth in the deep, dark forest. Then, climb above the treetops to a gorgeous view that takes in the surrounding ridges and mighty Pacific in the distance, and start your way back down. Because the climb up seems so gentle, you'll definitely be testing your knees on the descent. 

Watch your time as these woods get dark well before sunset and mountain lions have been spotted in the area.

name: Crissy Field and the Palace of Fine Arts
park: HikingGood conditionsGood viewsEasy to parkNot crowdedFlat beach jog. My style.Park
description:
According to Access Northern California (http://accessnca.org/access-northern-california/explore/explore-detail-view/?site_id=129): With 100 acres of bayside open space, Crissy Field is a delight for strollers, joggers, windsurfers, cyclists, dog walkers, and people looking to spot birds and even sea lions or dolphins. Spring is a good time to see many native wildflowers in bloom. You can mosey along the Golden Gate Promenade while admiring spectacular views of the Golden Gate Bridge and Strait. Check out the marsh, lagoon, and dune scrub, picnic, or sunbathe at the beach.

This is an easy paved and dirt trail with magnificent views of the SF Bay and Golden Gate Bridge while walking west and cityscape views on the return. Many consider this one of the most beautiful walks in SF. 

Originally a rich salt marsh and gathering ground for native people, Crissy Field was later the landing site of Spanish explorers and traders from Russia, England, and Boston. In 1915, the Panama Pacific International Exposition was held here, and shortly after the area became one of the country's foremost military airfields and part of a U.S. Army post. With generous community support, Crissy Field has been transformed into a spectacular national parkland. The 100-acre site is included within the Golden Gate National Recreation Area and the Presidio of San Francisco. Along with the entire Presidio, it was designated a National Historic Landmark in 1962.

As part of the site restoration effort in 1998-2000, individuals and groups from schools, corporations, and civic organizations put in more than 100,000 native plants to help restore natural systems at Crissy Field. Community volunteers continue to play an important role in sustaining long-term stewardship of this national parkland.

The Palace of Fine Arts was originally constructed for the 1915 Panama-Pacific Exposition in order to exhibit works of art and is a beautiful area to explore. With its towering columns and domed rotunda, the building resembles those of Ancient Rome.

Accessibility: There are at least 11 designated accessible spaces in the paved parking lot off of East Beach Road at the east end of the trail. All of them are van-accessible with striped access aisles. The trail surface is paved or a natural surface (dirt). It is typically at least 6 feet wide. The majority of the trail is estimated to be in the gentle (3% or less) grade category. This trail will likely be navigable for most wheelchairs/mobility equipment or stroller users. 

If you intend to do the entire stretch, the best wheelchair access points are the East Beach parking lot (east end) or the Fort Point or Warming Hut lots (west end). From the East Beach parking lot, the broad, paved trail travels west along the beach. A beach wheelchair is available for loan at Fort Mason. To reserve, contact at least five days in advance by sending an email via the NPS website, or calling 415-561-4958; (800) 877-8339 Federal Relay Service, (877) 877-6280 VCO, (877) 877-8982 Speech to Speech, (800) 845-6136 Spanish, or (866) 893-8340 TeleBraille. Soon you come to a small trail that leads away from the bay and across the marsh on a wooden boardwalk. This protected wildlife area has easy-to-operate gates at both ends of the boardwalk. A spur trail leads down near the water's edge. Back on the main trail, you travel along the large lagoon. To your right, a number of wooden boardwalks extend toward the beach, with benches and space for several wheelchairs alongside. 

Past the lagoon, a large grassy field marks the site of the former airfield. You soon come to the Gulf of the Farallones National Marine Sanctuary Visitor Center, on your right. Follow the sidewalk to the main entrance, then wrap around the building to reach the ramp. If that entrance is locked, ring the buzzer (54 inches high). After the visitor center, you come to the West Bluffs picnic area, with several picnic tables and barbecue grills on concrete pads. The nearby Warming Hut has a small café and shop. Just west of the hut, you can roll out onto Torpedo Wharf (although the surface is very rough and cracked).

Past the wharf, the trail to Fort Point is less appealing, as it becomes a sidewalk with a cross slope and then continues through a parking lot with no safe path of travel. Fortunately, there are often many pedestrians along this route and cars tend to move slowly. Here you are traveling right at the water's edge. At high tide and during storms, waves can splash the roadway along this stretch. After touring the fort, head back along the trail toward your starting point. There are accessible restrooms in the East Beach parking lot.

name: Promenade Trail and Bluff Loop
park: HikingGood conditionsGood viewsEasy to parkBathrooms availableNice breeze and quick workPark
description: Coyote Point Recreation Area has many amenities, including a fitness zone, a playground, beach access, and picnic sites, to name a few. The area is popular for paddle sports, swimming, camping, and hiking. This route follows a partially paved perimeter path, passing a sandy beach and forested bluffs overlooking the San Francisco Bay.

name: Redwood Peak Trail
description: This short trail heads uphill to the top of Redwood Peak which is marked by a USGS badge. There are no views, but the forest is very serene. On the way up you will pass a picnic area which is a great spot to stop and enjoy the forest. The trails are wide, well-defined, and easy to follow starting from Skyline Blvd.

name: Overlook, Round Top, Volcanic, Quarry and Skyline Loop
description:
This trail features a beautiful mix of expansive open views with wildflowers and enclosed forest sections. The terrain is relatively flat most of the way, with a steeper section along the Skyline Trail.

Wear thicker boots with good traction, as parts of the trail can get muddy, especially after rain. The trail begins and ends at the Sibley Volcanic Regional Preserve parking lot off Skyline Boulevard.

name: Courdet Trail
description: A very scenic trail up the Pleasanton Ridge. The well-developed trail predominately travels through trees after early open grasslands. As you make your way up there are nice views of Pleasanton. There are many additional trails at the top of the ridge to explore. Be sure to bring plenty of water with you.

name: Lake Cunningham Shoreline Loop
description: Lake Cunningham Regional Park has a waterpark, a native garden, and scenic walking paths—to name a few amenities. This route starts on the northwest side and follows paved paths along the lake's shoreline. It loops back on a gravel path north of the shore. There are trees in the area, but not much shade along the route. Bring water and sun layers.

name: New Almaden, Randol, Santa Isabel and Hacienda Trail Loop
description: This trail offers breathtaking panoramic views and a diverse landscape. Parking and restrooms are available at the Mockingbird Hill Entrance, where the trail starts. The terrain is mixed with forested areas, open meadows, and rocky paths. Some steep sections along the way make for a good workout. Look for wildlife such as deer, coyotes, and various bird species.

name: Bay Area Ridge, Round Top Loop, and Volcanic Trail Loop
description:
Hikers begin their journey on the Bay Area Ridge Trail and pass through a Monterey pine grove. Hawthorn and blackberry bushes grow abundantly beneath these trees. Hikers are rewarded with vistas of Mount Diablo to the southeast on clear days.
 
The Round Top Loop features a diverse range of rocks, plants, and animals and is close to Sibley's highest point at 1,763 feet. The surrounding terrain was sculpted by erosion and volcanic activity, and Round Top is the remains of a volcano that erupted around 10 million years ago. 

The Volcanic Trail Loop offers expansive views of Volmer Peak in Tilden Park and Mount Tamalpais in Marin County beyond the meadows and eucalyptus groves. This hike offers views of teasels and willows, as well as a heart-shaped cliff that's perfect for picnics. Hikers can see hawks and hummingbirds near the benches.

name: Nike, Bayview, Pelican, No Name, Soaproot Loop
description:
• Parking fee information: There is a fee to park at Coyote Hills Regional Park. For more information, please visit https://www.ebparks.org/parks/coyote-hills

From the starting point, you'll get a panoramic view of this trail before heading down towards the water. The trail then leads you along the levees that extend far into the Bay. The trail is mostly paved, but there are some muddy areas, particularly on the segment of levee parallel to the shore. The trail is wide and well-marked, with spectacular views of the Bay. The birdlife is abundant here. Watch for redtail hawks, turkey vultures, and various ducks and herons.

name: Palo Alto San Francisquito Creek Trail
description:
According to Access Northern California (http://accessnca.org/access-northern-california/explore/explore-detail-view/?site_id=178): The Baylands Nature Preserve, said to be the largest salt marsh preserve on the Bay, encompasses nearly 2,000 acres protected for wildlife, including the endangered clapper rail and salt marsh harvest mouse. The preserve contains a duck pond (formerly a saltwater swimming pool); tidal and freshwater marshes; a sailing station for windsurfers and hand-carried, non-motorized boats; and almost 15 miles of trails, all of which have some wheelchair access. Although quite a few of the trails are along roads or in built-up areas, many are close to attractive sloughs where a wide variety of birds can be seen even without binoculars, and some are out in the marshlands, where a flock of sandpipers or a lonely blue heron may be your only company.

Jackrabbits are frequently seen in the restored wildlands above the high-water line, where gray foxes and burrowing owls are said to breed. But within the preserve you'll also find a sewage treatment plant, an airport, and a former landfill for the city of San Francisco, which is now a grassy garbage mountain named the Bixby Art Hill, home to several very understated pieces of public art. Highway 101 is nearby, as is Palo Alto's golf course.

The difficulty rating for this trail is based on the experience that a wheelchair or stroller user may have due to the gravel surface.

Visitor center: A quarter-mile down the road from the duck pond is the Lucy Evans Baylands Nature Interpretive Center. Inside are displays about the wildlife you might see at the preserve and an ecology laboratory where visitors can prepare their own slides and examine them under microscopes. The microscopes are on a 25-inch-high shelf, but a video microscope that projects slides onto a monitor permits easier viewing. The center also offers videos, nature walks, and a variety of natural history programs for children and adults. On the wooden deck surrounding the nature center, use the low-mounted telescope to zoom in on shorebirds and waterfowl. A long boardwalk extending from the center across Harriet Mundy Marsh may be closed for major renovations. Located at 2775 Embarcadero Road, 650-329-2506.

ACCESSIBILITY: From the nature center you can head northwest on the San Francisquito Creek Trail, which leads out along a levee toward the Palo Alto Airport and the municipal golf course. The crushed-rock surface is dusty but firm in dry weather; during the rainy season parts of the trail may become impassable. The estimated grade is mostly gentle, all 5% or less.

About 0.25 miles out, the surface becomes rough and small rocks slow your travel. Three-quarters of a mile farther, you will be near the north end of the airport runway. The trail climbs a short, moderate incline just before it turns inland along San Francisquito Creek. Past the airport, it intersects with the paved Baylands Bike Trail (still referred to as San Francisquito Creek Trail). Turn left and continue past the golf course for 0.5 miles to the Baylands Athletic Center and then turn around there.

There is designated accessible parking (van accessible), firm, and level or slope no greater than 2% at the Adobe Creek trailhead, where the one designated space is very likely to be occupied. Each of the several small lots along Embarcadero Rd. also has a van-accessible space, and at the sailing station, a gravel lot has several van-accessible spaces. Wheelchair-accessible restrooms with running water are at the nature center (open only when the center is) and Bixby Art Park parking area; porta-potties are at the duck pond and sailing station. Several accessible picnic tables are by the duck pond; all are near the parking lot on firm grass or dirt, and two have shortened benches to provide integrated seating for at least two wheelchairs each. The Visitor Center is wheelchair-accessible.

name: Graham Trail and Roberts Ridge Loop
description:
• Parking fee information: There is a fee to park at this trailhead. There is also a fee per dog. For more information, please visit https://www.ebparks.org/parks/roberts

The Graham Trail and Roberts Ridge Loop meander around Roberts Regional Recreation Area. The short route travels through dense oak woods, passing Pal Camp and a place to get drinking water. The short distance and minimal elevation gain make this an easier route for most, with the opportunity to see wildlife.

name: Shady Slope, Short Ridge and Sand Hill Trail
description:
Trail Highlights: This hike takes place in the Short Ridge section of the park. Though short, this trail is quite steep in sections. It is also almost entirely exposed to the sun. Bring water and be prepared to take lots of breaks as you head up the hill. However, the hard climb is rewarded with views at the top. In the rainy season a strong creek rushes under the bridge on the path.

Trail Directions: From the parking lot on Sherburne Hills Road, head straight towards the hills. Cross through the cattle gate onto Shady Slope Trail and continue for .43 miles. At the next signpost, turn right to continue following Shady Slope Trail. After .18 miles, turn right on Short Ridge Trail. Continue for .51 miles. Keep straight until you reach the signpost for Sandy Hill Trail, then turn right. Take Sandy Hill Trail for .73 miles, then cross through the cattle gate. Follow the path down past the baseball fields until you come to a soccer field, then turn right and follow the paved path along the edge of the field. At the end of the field, turn left on the paved path and walk for about 40 feet, then turn left again to take the stairs back to the parking lot.

name: Bay Area Ridge Trail: Joseph D. Grant County Park
park: Bay Area Ridge Trail: Joseph D. Grant County Park
description:
• Joseph D Grant County Park collects a day-use fee for vehicular entrance year-round. For more information, please see https://parks.sccgov.org/plan-your-visit/santa-clara-county-park-fees#3925188384-3236192913

This segment traces the western boundary of 10,822-acre Joseph D. Grant County Park on a broad trail. Traverse grasslands, remote oak woodlands, and an ancient bay-tree forest to reach a 2,457-foot vista point with outstanding views of the Coast Range high peaks, the Santa Clara Valley, and Halls Valley to the east. Much of the route is in sun, so plan for an early start and carry plenty of water.

There is also a play area in the middle of the park, and picnic tables scattered throughout. Restrooms are available at the starting point.

For more information, see the Bay Area Ridge Trail page here: https://ridgetrail.org/joseph-d-grant-county-park/

name: Golden Gate Bridge from Baker Beach Trail
park: Golden Gate Bridge from Baker Beach Trail is near Baker Beach and Baker Beach (Nudist Area).Top trails nearbyBatteries to Bluffs TrailBatteries to Bluffs TrailPresidio of San Francisco4.8·Easy·3.7 km·Est. 1h 7mBay Area Ridge Trail: The Golden Gate Bridge to Marin HeadlandsBay Area Ridge Trail: The Golden Gate Bridge to Marin HeadlandsGolden Gate National Recreation Area4.7·Easy·2.7 km·Est. 45mPresidio Loop TrailPresidio Loop TrailPresidio of San Francisco4.6·Moderate·9.5 km·Est. 2h 29mFort Point - Baker Beach Coast TrailFort Point - Baker Beach Coast TrailPresidio of San Francisco4.7·Moderate·6.6 km·Est. 2h 2mBlue Heron Lake and Strawberry Hill LoopBlue Heron Lake and Strawberry Hill LoopGolden Gate Park
description:
According to Access Northern CA (http://accessnca.org/access-northern-california/explore/explore-detail-view/?site_id=126): At the northern tip of San Francisco's Presidio, Baker Beach offers spectacular views from outside the Golden Gate. Battery Chamberlin, near the north end of the northern parking lot, is an artillery installation the U.S. Army maintained and frequently remodeled from the late 1800s through World War II. It still has a six-inch "disappearing gun" from the early 1900s, designed to pop up from behind a parapet to fire, then drop down again. The gun is revealed every weekend, weather permitting, and on the first full weekend of each month, from 11 am to 3 pm, park rangers demonstrate how it works. The approach from the parking lot is level but steps prevent close access to the installation.

The boardwalk begins near the southwestern edge of the parking lot and winds first south and then east through the dunes; it undulates as it follows the dune contours, but the slopes are gentle. Along the southern edge of the dunes, behind a fence and a tangle of coast live oaks, is Lobos Creek, the last free-flowing creek in San Francisco and the Presidio's main water source. For the most part it isn't visible from the trail, but you can often hear it as you follow its course eastward.

The northernmost end of Baker Beach is frequented by clothing-optional sunbathers.

ACCESSIBILITY: There are accessible parking spots and restrooms in both the north and south beachfront parking lots at Baker Beach. There are also two in the Lobos Creek Valley parking lot. About the first 0.3 miles of boardwalk to the overlook (take the spur trail to the left to reach it) is considered accessible. This section is typically at least four feet wide and mostly flat with a grade of 5% or less. The observation point has been marked with a waypoint on the map. Beyond that, the boardwalk continues but if you continue all the way to the staircase to the Bridge, users have reported there is not enough room to turn around. Also, the boardwalk sags in the middle or has shrubbery encroachment in places.

There is a wheelchair-accessible ramp leading from the Visitors Center up to the Bridge entrance with handrails and a gentle slope. Once on the Bridge, the path is paved, flat, and typically at least six feet wide. There is a safety barrier protecting pedestrians and cyclists from motor vehicle traffic on the Bridge. There is an additional wheelchair accessible bathroom with grab bars in a separate building across from the Visitor Center at the south end of the Bridge.

Beach wheelchairs are available at Fort Mason if you reserve at least five days in advance and can transport one from there. An accessible bench sits in the northwest corner of the oceanfront parking lot and nearby, behind the restroom, a short path leads to a grassy area where picnic tables are set on pavement and dirt among cypress trees.

name: Sawyer Camp Trail
description:
This is a paved, family-friendly, out-and-back trail that follows along the shoreline of Lower Crystal Springs Reservoir and up to San Andreas Lake. Take the trail on the perimeter of the reservoirs, return via the way you came.

Accessibility: There are 2 designated accessible spaces in the paved parking lot on Skyline Boulevard at the southeast end of the trail. Both of them are van-accessible with a striped access aisle. The trail surface is paved asphalt and smooth. It is typically 3 to 7 feet wide with some wider passing spaces. There is a painted dividing line along the trail which reduces the width. There is a gate across the trail at the start and the estimated width to go through it is 3 feet. 

The majority of the trail is estimated to be in the mostly gentle grade category (5% or less) but there is a steeper section from about 4.6 through 5.7 miles when going northwest. According to the park website, this trail is wheelchair-accessible. Trail goers using wheelchairs/mobility equipment or strollers may need assistance in the steeper section or to avoid it for safety. There are benches and picnic tables along the route for resting. There are wheelchair-accessible bathrooms along the trail.

name: Cuesta Park Loop
description: Cuesta Park is a lovely little neighborhood park with picnic tables, a playground, a dog park, tennis courts, and trails. The park's east side has paved paths, and the west offers dirt trails. There are three parking lots: one in the middle of the park off Cuesta Drive, another on the east end, and the third at the YMCA.

name: Upper Lake Loop
park: Bear Creek Redwoods Open Space Preserve
description:
Beginning at the parking lot, the easy-access Upper Lake Loop Trail features habitat restoration sites and historical artifacts such as Ohlone mortars. Information for a self-guided interpretive tour is included in the brochure map available at the preserve entrance.

Accessibility: There are 3 designated accessible spaces in the paved parking lot off of Bear Creek Road at the south end of the trail. All of them are van-accessible with a striped access aisle. The trail surface is paved (with partial railings) and smooth. It is typically 4 to 6 feet wide with some wider passing spaces.

The entire trail is estimated to be in the flat grade category (1% or less). According to the park website, this trail is accessible for trail goers navigating with mobility equipment. There are benches and picnic tables along the route for resting. There are wheelchair-accessible bathrooms at the east end of the trail.

name: Sweeney Ridge
description: Sneath Lane Trail is the easiest hiking and biking grade up to the crest of Sweeney Ridge. From the ridgetop go south to visit the Portola Discovery Site, or north to the former Radar Control Site for Nike Site SF-51. Nike ground-to-air missile sites protected American Cities from the Soviet Bomber threat during the Cold War from 1955-1974.

name: Indian Joe Creek, Vista Grande, Eagle View, and Canyon View Loop
description:
• Parking fee information: There is a fee to park at Sunol Wilderness Regional Preserve on weekends and holidays. For more information, please visit https://www.ebparks.org/parks/sunol

You'll begin by hiking along Indian Joe Creek and the Indian Joe Trail. Next you'll travel along the following trails to the Vista Grande Overlook: Cave Rocks Road, High Valley Road, and Vista Grande Road. You'll cross the creek again, following Eagle View Trail, Cave Rocks Road, Cerro Este Road, McCorkle, and Canyon View Trail. Downloading offline maps is recommended.

name: Irish Ridge Trail
park: Purisima Creek Redwoods Open Space Preserve
description: Several trails in the Purisma Creek Redwoods Open Space weave through the dense redwood forests. This route starts on Grabtown Gulch Trail and heads north to connect to Bald Knob Trail. It climbs steeply past Bald Knob and descends the Irish Ridge Trail for almost three miles. To avoid a steep ascent on the way back, end the adventure at Bald Knob.

name: Skyline Trail, Travertine Springs Trail, and Saratoga Toll Road Loop
description:
• General fee: Castle Rock State Park charges a day-use fee to enter. For more information please visit https://www.parks.ca.gov/?page_id=538

The Skyline Trail, Travertine Springs Trail, and Saratoga Toll Road Loop in Saratoga, California, offers hikers a diverse and scenic journey through varied terrains. Along the way, hikers can enjoy panoramic views of the Santa Cruz Mountains, traverse through lush forests, and explore unique geological formations. The trail is well-maintained and suitable for hikers of all skill levels, providing a rewarding trip exploring this wilderness area.

name: Upper Market Stairway Walks
description: This route starts at Corona Heights Park by the Randall Museum. The park offers sweeping views of the city and then takes you on a nice urban hike. You pass by Kite Hill Open Space, Seward Mini Park, and Tank Hill, which have some nice benches to sit on and enjoy the views of Mount Olympus before returning to Corona Heights Park. You must tackle several sets of stairs along the way, making for a good workout on this hike.

name: Best trails inUpper Stevens Creek County Park
park: Upper Stevens Creek County Parkbest Trails In Upper Stevens Creek County Park Best Trails In Upper Stevens Creek County Park
description: Hours: 8:00 a.m. – Sunset

name: Fall Creek to Lime Kilns Trail
description:
• General fee: Henry Cowell Redwoods State Park charges a fee to park at the day-use and campground areas. There are varying fees depending on if you enter by vehicle, motorcycle, foot, horse, or bike. For more information, please visit https://www.parks.ca.gov/?page_id=546


This is a great visit to the industrial legacy of the Bay Area amid a lush redwood forest north of Santa Cruz. There is not much left of the 19th-century lime processing industry of the San Francisco Bay Area. Processing lime, a key ingredient in plaster and mortar, was big business in the California boom years after the Gold Rush. 

New technology (namely Portland cement) made lime obsolete early in the 20th century, leaving the uncanny recuperative powers of the coast redwood to reclaim the forest where factories once stood. 

The decaying lime kilns at Fall Creek Unit of Henry Cowell Redwoods State Park are about all that remains of the local industry. This hike lets you explore the old kilns up close.

name: San Bruno Summit via Hillside Blvd
description:
• San Bruno Mountain State Park charges a fee to enter. Fees are per vehicle. This park does not accept the California State Park Annual Day Use Pass. For more information, please visit https://parks.smcgov.org/fees-charges#vehicle.

This hike starts off with a steep uphill section but then levels out into a ridgeline with great views. While the overall rating may be moderate, you might find the first uphill to be challenging! Also keep in mind it can get windy and exposed on the ridge so dress in layers. There are opportunities for birding and taking in the views from up high. Wear sturdy shoes for the up and downhill portions.

name: Badivuku Trail and Caribbean Loop
park: Badivuku Trail and Caribbean Loop. Bring plenty of water and wear sunscreen and protective clothing.Top trails nearbyBay Trail: Shoreline LakeBay Trail: Shoreline LakeShoreline at Mountain View Park4.6·Easy·7.4 mi·Est. 2h 11mAlviso Slough TrailAlviso Slough TrailAlviso Marina County Park4.3·Easy·8.7 mi·Est. 2h 32mStevens Creek TrailStevens Creek Trail4.5·Easy·4.2 mi·Est. 1h 17mShoreline Park LoopShoreline Park LoopShoreline at Mountain View Park4.6·Easy·1.4 mi·Est. 25mGuadalupe River TrailGuadalupe River Trail4.5·Easy·5.4 mi·Est. 1h 37mSan Francisco Bay Trail - Sunnyvale to Sand PointSan Francisco Bay Trail - Sunnyvale to Sand PointDon Edwards San Francisco Bay National Wildlife Refuge4.6·Moderate·20.0 mi·Est. 5h 50mSunnyvale Baylands Park Guadalupe SloughSunnyvale Baylands Park Guadalupe SloughSunnyvale Baylands Park4.2·Easy·3.4 mi·Est. 1h 0mSan Tomas Aquino Creek TrailSan Tomas Aquino Creek TrailSunnyvale Baylands Park4.4·Easy·12.6 mi·Est. 3h 47mSan Tomas Aquino Creek Trail to SF Bay TrailSan Tomas Aquino Creek Trail to SF Bay Trail4.4·Easy·4.0 mi·Est. 1h 11mAlviso Marina LoopAlviso Marina LoopAlviso Marina County Park4.3·Easy·0.8 mi·Est. 14mBaylands Perimeter LoopBaylands Perimeter LoopSunnyvale Baylands Park4.3·Easy·1.3 mi·Est. 23mSan Francisco Bay Trail at Sunnyvale Baylands ParkSan Francisco Bay Trail at Sunnyvale Baylands ParkSunnyvale Baylands Park
description: The Badivuku Trail and Caribbean Trails weave throughout an open hill that rises above the Sunnyvale Water Treatment Plant and offers panoramic views of the San Francisco Bay. The trails are multi-use and open to cyclists and foot traffic. The best place to start is at the San Francisco Bay Trail, and at the end of this route, you will use the trail to get back to the car.

name: Chamise Trail and Bollinger Creek Loop Trail
description:
Las Trampas Regional Wilderness offers 5,342 acres of wilderness and an expanded trail system that allows hikers and horseback riders to enjoy its remote and rugged areas. The park's size and terrain allow visitors a feeling of privacy and escape from urban hustle and bustle. Carry plenty of drinking water. 

Two major Bay Area faults--the Las Trampas and Bollinger faults--account for the uplift and exposure of four well-defined geological formations. The Orinda formation holds remnants of ancient beach and shoreline. The El Sobrante formation consists of several fossil-bearing compressed rock layers. The Pinole Tuff is of volcanic origin.

The trail is not well-marked and downloading offline maps is recommended.

name: Redtail, Portola Pastures, Meadowlark, and Wild Rye Trail
description:
• Seasonal closure: This area is subject to seasonal closure due to weather conditions. For more information, please visit https://www.cityofpaloalto.org/News-Articles/Community-Services/Pearson-Arastradero-Preserve-Seasonal-Trails-Status

This is a fantastic trail that stops by Arastradero Lake. The trail offers nice views and gentle hills. There is minimal shade along the route, so wear sun protection. 

The path can get quite muddy after rain, closing some trail sections. There is a lot of wildlife to spot, including lizards, wild turkeys, coyotes, and gophers. Please be careful of rattlesnakes and go early, as parking is limited. The route can be difficult to navigate, so it's recommended to download the route beforehand.

name: Mine Hill and Deep Gulch Loop
description: Almaden Quicksilver County Park includes over 37 miles of hiking trails, including 30 miles of equestrian trails and 16.6 miles of bike trails. All trails in the park are also open to pet owners to walk their dogs on leash. For more information visit: https://www.sccgov.org/sites/parks/parkfinder/pages/almadenpark.aspx

name: Burleigh Murray Ranch Trail
park: Burleigh H. Murray Ranch Park Property
description:
A nice, historic, and quiet hike through chaparral and coastal biomes . Most likely, you will only encounter a few others.

The trail begins on an old ranch road that follows Mills Creek until it reaches a bungalow from the 1930s. The trail then takes you down to cross the creek and get a look at old historic buildings that Burleigh H. Murray constructed during the gold rush. There is also a roman styled stone bridge. 

Bring Water - None is available in the park. There is a small free gravel parking lot at the trailhead. The trail is open from 8am to sunset.

name: Toyon Trail and Woodrat Trail
description:
The Toyon Trail and Woodrat Trail begin at an artificial lake. The lake is stocked with sunfish, perch, and bass, making it a calm place to fish or just relax by the water. Three docks provide more viewing opportunities.

The trail becomes a granite walkway as you continue. Watch out for animals throughout the trail, including Wild Turkeys, Western Bluebirds, and Dark-eyed Juncos. The trail winds through oak forest habitats, home to California buckeye, madrone, coast live oak, and California laurel. Poison oak is so common in the area.

name: Promenade to Old Mori Road
description:
According to Access Northern California (http://accessnca.org/access-northern-california/explore/explore-detail-view/?site_id=138) If you are a Bay Area fisher, you probably already know about Pacifica Municipal Pier, a 1,140-foot open-ocean pier (41-inch railings). In season, people catch king salmon, surf perch, striped bass, and halibut. You can go out on the pier even if you don't fish. On the lawn near the pier are picnic tables and grills. A wide, paved promenade runs along the waterfront. North of the pier you can travel only a few blocks before the promenade ends, but the route is right at the ocean's edge, with waves crashing on rocks just below you in places. It can be a very dramatic—and wet—spot when the surf is high. Traveling south from the pier, you can extend your hike along a levee trail between Sharp Park Golf Course and the beach, then travel through wetlands on an elevated boardwalk.

ACCESSIBILITY: Two designated accessible parking spots are near the foot of the pier and two are at the end of Beach Blvd (that have a firm surface and 2% or less of cross slope). The wheelchair-accessible restroom at the pier has a very tight turn at the entry. An accessible vault toilet is at the Bradford Way trailhead. Only one of the several picnic tables along the paved promenade is reachable via a concrete pathway; the rest are surrounded by grass.

The route described here is a combination of pavement, boardwalk, and hard-packed dirt and gravel. Some sections may be sandy, while others may be muddy and rutted, with pools of standing water. For a smoother ride you can take the Old Mori Road Trail and bypass the rough levee trail that runs between the beach and Sharp Park Golf Course. From the pier, head south on the paved promenade that travels along Beach Boulevard for a few blocks, to Clarendon Road. From there, if you can manage a short but steep and sometimes sandy slope, you can access a hard-packed dirt and rock levee trail and continue south for another 0.5 miles to the end of the beach at Mori Point. The promenade can be a difficult ride because of windblown sand, standing rainwater, and bird droppings. The levee trail runs between the beach and Sharp Park Golf Course.

As you approach the point you will see Bootlegger Steps heading straight up the bluff. Before you reach them, the berm trail branches and one trail continues to the right, toward the stairs, while the left-hand trail (Old Mori Road) curves eastward. If you’re really adventurous, consider making a side trip along the stretch of Coastal Trail that takes off immediately past the trail to Bootlegger Steps, also on the right. It climbs steeply for a few hundred yards to the blufftop, where the ocean views are spectacular. Assistance may be needed for returning down the hill, as it can be slippery.

Back on Old Mori Road trail, continue to an elevated wooden boardwalk that travels through wetlands south of Laguna Salada, the lake inside the golf course grounds. The wetlands provide habitat for the endangered red-legged frog and San Francisco garter snake. Wood benches and interpretive signs are here and there along the boardwalk. Past the wetlands, the boardwalk ends and a broad, hard-packed dirt and gravel trail continues along the old roadway. A tall wood fence fronts the northern side of the trail, blocking it from the houses along the route. The level path travels through trees and past a marshy creek; standing water and mud can be a problem here during the rainy season.

The trail ends at Bradford Way and Mori Point Road, but if you want to extend your hike, you can follow Mori Point Road to the right (you must travel in the roadway a short distance, but traffic is typically light and slow-moving) to connect to the Pacifica Coastal Trail, which travels south along Highway One through the Calera Creek wetlands and on to Rockaway Beach and Pacifica State Beach (about three miles). The entire stretch from Sharp Park to Pacifica State Beach is about seven miles one way.

name: San Francisco Bay Trail: South San Francisco
description: The San Francisco Bay Trail in South San Francisco offers a scenic walk along the bay, providing views of the water, wetlands, and nearby hills. Starting at the trailhead, the paved path stretches through parks and along the shoreline, offering a peaceful setting for walking, jogging, or cycling. As you move along, enjoy sights of local wildlife and the iconic bay area landscape. This relatively flat trail is a great option for a leisurely outing with easy access to this beautiful area.

name: Castle Rock, Saratoga Gap and Ridge Trail Loop
description:
• General fee: Castle Rock State Park charges a day-use fee to enter. For more information please visit https://www.parks.ca.gov/?page_id=538

Castle Rock, Saratoga Gap and Ridge Trail is an awe inducing trek with views of the Santa Cruz Mountains. Located in Castle Rock State Park, just off highway 35, this route has it all! It provides amazing views of Rock Falls, crosses the San Lorenzo River, passes by the notorious climbing spot at Goat Rock and is conveniently located close to San Jose. 

Starting off on the Castle Rock Trail, you will quickly meet up with the east end of the Ridge Trail and round out with Saratoga Gap Trail. At many points along the route you’ll come across interesting rock formations that are fun to scramble around and explore. On clear days you can see the entirety of the south side of the park.

name: Rambler, Ohlone, Chaparral, Berry, Lake, John Brooks and Finch Loop
description:
This is a terrific trail in Hidden Canyon Park. Visitors can find on-street parking where the trail begins. From here, the route follows an undulating path that crosses several creeks and passes through the beautiful surrounding landscape.

This is a shared-use trail, so watch out for other hikers, bikers, and trail runners, especially when rounding sharp corners. The trail is well-shaded and narrow in sections, with some rocky and slippery parts. The views along the way are spectacular, and the repeated ups and downs make for a fantastic workout.

name: The Mile to San Pedro Mountain Trail to Burnside
description: This narrow trail is steep in many places with great views. This route is a mountain biking trail. It is not recommended to hike this trail. It can be foggy early in the day on this route, so it is a good idea to bring an extra layer. It's also a good idea to download your offline map ahead of time.

name: Tyler Ranch, Sunol Ridge, and Woodside Spring Trail
description:
Park Features: Tyler Ranch is the newest addition to Pleasanton Ridge Regional Park, adding 2,844 acres to the park and over 18 miles of new trails for hiking, biking, equestrians, and dog walking. The park contains a variety of landscapes and ecosystems, with expansive grasslands, shady woodland forests, and deep canyon riparian areas. Each ecosystem is home to a variety of native plants and animals, which makes this park a great location for observing wildlife and viewing wildflower blooms in late winter and early spring. Visitors can enjoy numerous panoramic views from ridgeline trails, scenic overlooks, and Sunol Peak, the highest peak in the park at 2,191 feet.

Trail Highlights: This route takes you up to Sunol Peak by way of the Tyler Ranch and Sunol Ridge Trails. This is a strenuous hike, as you are climbing uphill all the way to the highest point in the park. You will be rewarded with magnificent views of the valley and neighboring ridges as well as Mount Diablo, Brushy Peak, San Antonio Reservoir, Mission Peak, Vargas Plateau, and Niles Canyon. The return trip from the peak ventures into a shady woodland until meeting back up with the trails that descend along the exposed ridge and back down to the Tyler Ranch area.

Trail Directions: Begin at the Tyler Ranch Staging Area at the end of Foothill Road. Take Tyler Ranch Trail from the parking lot. Bear left. Stay on the trail as you continue uphill. Turn left on to Sunol Ridge Trail. Continue all the way up to the ridge top. Make a right on Woodside Spring Trail, then left on Sunol Ridge Trail. Go left on to the Niles Canyon Overlook Trail for incredible views. Turn back and head left onto Sunol Ridge Trail. Then take Tyler Ranch Trail to retrace your route to the staging area

Driving Directions: From I-680 in Pleasanton, exit at Sunol and go west. Turn right onto Koopmann Road and then immediately turn left onto Pleasanton-Sunol Road, towards the town of Sunol. Turn right onto Niles Canyon Road, then make a right onto Main Street. Turn right on Kilkare Road and cross the railroad tracks, then make a left onto Foothill Road. The Tyler Ranch Staging Area is at the end of Foothill Road, on the right.

name: Milagra Ridge Trail Loop
description: There are two trailheads you can use to access this trail, one is off Sharp Park Road, and the other is off Connemara Drive. Some of the endangered species that inhabit the area are California red-legged frogs, Mission Blue, and San Bruno elfin butterflies. The area was originally used for farming in the 1820s after the Mexican Revolution.  In World War II there was a gun battery here to protect the coast. In the 1950s there was a missile launch site.

name: Dumbarton Bridge via SF Bay Trail
park: Dumbarton Bridge via SF Bay Trail is paved.Top trails nearbyAdobe Creek Trail To Shoreline Lake ParkAdobe Creek Trail To Shoreline Lake ParkBaylands Nature Preserve4.5·Easy·5.9 mi·Est. 1h 42mApay Way to Bay View to Red Hill LoopApay Way to Bay View to Red Hill LoopCoyote Hills Regional Park4.6·Moderate·6.4 mi·Est. 2h 26mBedwell Bayfront ParkBedwell Bayfront ParkBedwell Bay Front Park4.3·Easy·3.4 mi·Est. 1h 12mAdobe Creek Trail to Mayfield SloughAdobe Creek Trail to Mayfield SloughByxbee Recreation Area4.5·Easy·3.7 mi·Est. 1h 5mCharleston Slough TrailsCharleston Slough TrailsBaylands Nature Preserve4.6·Easy·11.6 mi·Est. 3h 25mApay Way to No Name to Red Hills LoopApay Way to No Name to Red Hills LoopCoyote Hills Regional Park4.6·Moderate·9.9 mi·Est. 3h 23mNewark Slough TrailNewark Slough TrailDon Edwards San Francisco Bay National Wildlife Refuge4.2·Easy·6.5 mi·Est. 1h 57mByxbee Art HillByxbee Art HillByxbee Recreation Area4.5·Moderate·3.2 mi·Est. 1h 2mBedwell Bayfront Perimeter LoopBedwell Bayfront Perimeter LoopBedwell Bay Front Park
description: This route takes you on a leisurely walk on the Dumbarton Bridge (the southernmost of the highway bridges across San Francisco Bay in California) to get beautiful views of the bay and the East Bay hills. The bridge never received an official name, but it comes from Dumbarton Point, near the east end of the bridge. It can be loud as it is windy and next to traffic.

name: English Camp Loop
description: Almaden Quicksilver County Park includes over 37 miles of hiking trails, including 30 miles of equestrian trails and 16.6 miles of bike trails. All trails in the park are also open to pet owners to walk their dogs on leash. For more information visit: https://www.sccgov.org/sites/parks/parkfinder/pages/almadenpark.aspx

name: Loop Through Monte Bello, Skyline Ridge, Russian Ridge, and Coal Creek
description:
This hike passes through 4 different Mid-peninsula open space preserves. Monte Bello, Skyline Ridge, Russian Ridge, and Coal Creek. Along the way you will get some of the best long range views available on the peninsula.

Begining in Monte Bello, you hike the easy route to the summit of Black Mountain via the Canyon and Bella Vista Trails. If the weather is clear enough, from the summit you can see north to San Francisco and Oakland, east to the Diablo range, South to San Jose, and west to the ocean. Using Indian Creek Trail you descend back down to Steven's Creek and pick up Skid Road to bring you back up to highway 35 and cross over into Skyline Ridge. The Ridge Trail provides great views across the vast conifer habitat to the west. You can spend some time enjoying Alpine Pond and the David C. Danials Nature Center before crossing Alpine Road into Russian Ridge. More really nice panoramic views are waiting atop Borel Hill. You can then hike down to the highway again, and cross over into Coal Creek at Cloud's Rest drive which will provide a return route back to the Monte Bello parking area.

name: Emily Renzel Ponds
park: Emily Renzel Ponds. Always observe wildlife from a safe distance.Top trails nearbyStanford Dish Loop TrailStanford Dish Loop Trail4.7·Moderate·6.0 km·Est. 1h 37mNorth Bayfront LoopNorth Bayfront LoopBaylands Nature Preserve4.5·Easy·8.5 km·Est. 1h 32mAdobe Creek Trail To Shoreline Lake ParkAdobe Creek Trail To Shoreline Lake ParkBaylands Nature Preserve4.5·Easy·9.5 km·Est. 1h 42mBay Trail: Shoreline LakeBay Trail: Shoreline LakeShoreline at Mountain View Park4.5·Easy·11.9 km·Est. 2h 11mShoreline Park LoopShoreline Park LoopShoreline at Mountain View Park4.6·Easy·2.3 km·Est. 25mStanford Campus WalkStanford Campus Walk4.7·Easy·4.8 km·Est. 54mAdobe Creek Trail to Mayfield SloughAdobe Creek Trail to Mayfield SloughByxbee Recreation Area4.5·Easy·6.0 km·Est. 1h 5mCharleston Slough TrailsCharleston Slough TrailsBaylands Nature Preserve4.6·Easy·18.7 km·Est. 3h 25mByxbee Art HillByxbee Art HillByxbee Recreation Area4.5·Moderate·5.1 km·Est. 1h 2mBol Park Bike PathBol Park
description:
Very easy walk around the pond with lots of birds.

Accessibility: There may not be any designated accessible spaces in the small unpaved parking lot off of East Bayshore Road at the north end of the trail. The trail surface is natural dirt and grass and typically at least 5 feet wide. The surface may be uneven. The estimated grade is flat (1% or less) except for a moderately steep (8% or less) section when starting and ending the loop either direction. All-terrain tires or motorized equipment may be needed for the natural surface type and grade.

name: Rogue Valley, Upper Rogue Valley, and High Meadow Loop Trail
park: Rancho San Antonio Open Space Preserve
description:
Beginning on the Rogue Valley Trail, hikers will face a steep climb. This trail is primarily sheltered, with sporadic openings in the canopy that provide breathtaking views of the surroundings. The Upper Rogue Valley Trail starts at the pond at the end of the Rogue Valley Trail. 

Hikers can follow this trail's transition into the High Meadow Trail, which passes via a number of stunning meadows interspersed with oak trees. These meadows offer a calm and beautiful environment. Vibrant wildlife may be found all along the trail. Hikers may encounter coyotes, turkeys, deer, and mountain lions.

name: Best trails inSunnyvale Baylands Park
park: Sunnyvale Baylands Parkbest Trails In Sunnyvale Baylands Parkall Photos Best Trails In Sunnyvale Baylands Park
description:
Want to find the best trails in Sunnyvale Baylands Park for an adventurous hike or a family trip? AllTrails has 4 great trails for hiking and more. Enjoy hand-curated trail maps, along with reviews and photos from nature lovers like you.

Ready for your next hike or bike ride? Explore one of 4 easy hiking trails in Sunnyvale Baylands Park that are great for the whole family. Looking for a more strenuous hike? We've got you covered, with trails ranging from 13 to 216 feet in elevation gain. Whatever you have planned for the day, you can find the perfect trail for your next trip to Sunnyvale Baylands Park.

name: Centennial Trail
park: Centennial Trail is partially paved.Top trails nearbyCourdet TrailCourdet TrailPleasanton Ridge Regional Park
description: The Centennial Trail is a walking path that follows the Arroyo de la Laguna. This gravel path connects several parks, and is a great way to navigate through Pleasanton.

name: Castle Rocks Lower Loop
description:
• General fee: Castle Rock State Park charges a day-use fee to enter. For more information please visit https://www.parks.ca.gov/?page_id=538

This trail traverses through multiple ecosystems and is a mix of open scenery and forested views. On a clear day, you can see the ocean in a few spots. There are a few technical sections, including a short section that is narrow and steep with a cable to hold onto. The trail can get muddy in the winter and spring. Sturdy footwear is recommended.

name: Coastal Trail via Redondo Beach Road
park: Purisima Creek TrailPurisima Creek Redwoods Open Space Preserve
description: This gorgeous trail takes you along stunning views of the coast and the coastal landscape. This route will take you along the coastal bluffs from Redondo Beach to Poplar State Beach and back. The Coastside Land Trust protects this area, which is a beautiful example of a coastal California grassland ecosystem. Keep an eye out for cool bird sightings like Barn Owl, Raven, and White-throated Sparrow.

name: Adobe Creek Trail To Shoreline Lake Park
park: Adobe Creek Trail To Shoreline Lake Park
description:
The Baylands Nature Preserve, said to be the largest salt marsh preserve on the Bay, encompasses nearly 2,000 acres protected for wildlife, including the endangered clapper rail and salt marsh harvest mouse. The preserve contains a duck pond (formerly a saltwater swimming pool); tidal and freshwater marshes; a sailing station for windsurfers and hand-carried, non-motorized boats; and almost 15 miles of trails, all of which have some wheelchair access. Although quite a few of the trails are along roads or in built-up areas, many are close to attractive sloughs where a wide variety of birds can be seen even without binoculars, and some are out in the marshlands, where a flock of sandpipers or a lonely blue heron may be your only company.

Jackrabbits are frequently seen in the restored wildlands above the high-water line, where gray foxes and burrowing owls are said to breed. But within the preserve you'll also find a sewage treatment plant, an airport, and a former landfill for the city of San Francisco, which is now a grassy garbage mountain named the Bixby Art Hill, home to several very understated pieces of public art. Highway 101 is nearby, as is Palo Alto's golf course.

The difficulty rating for this trail is based on the experience that a wheelchair or stroller user may have due to the gravel surface.

Visitor center: A quarter-mile down the road from the duck pond is the Lucy Evans Baylands Nature Interpretive Center. Inside are displays about the wildlife you might see at the preserve and an ecology laboratory where visitors can prepare their own slides and examine them under microscopes. The microscopes are on a 25-inch-high shelf, but a video microscope that projects slides onto a monitor permits easier viewing. The center also offers videos, nature walks, and a variety of natural history programs for children and adults. On the wooden deck surrounding the nature center, use the low-mounted telescope to zoom in on shorebirds and waterfowl. A long boardwalk extending from the center across Harriet Mundy Marsh may be closed for major renovations. Located at 2775 Embarcadero Road, 650-329-2506.

ACCESSIBILITY: This is a nice trail--actually an unpaved service road on a levee--offering choice birdwatching over nearly 3 miles, with sloughs on both sides and a great sense of peaceful isolation, far from human activity. However, the uneven surface makes the 6 miles out and back rough riding in a wheelchair. The estimated slope is gentle though, all 3% or less. 

The best birdwatching is along the mile-long section between Charleston Slough and Adobe Creek, just before the trail reaches Shoreline Park, so if the distance seems too great, starting from there may be a good choice. Consider the weather when planning a visit: There is no shade, but breezes off the water may be chilly. Also take tides into account; you'll see a lot of mud at low tide, but wading birds will be active then. Plenty of benches are provided.

There is designated accessible parking (van accessible), firm, and level or slope no greater than 2% at the Adobe Creek trailhead, where the one designated space is very likely to be occupied. Each of the several small lots along Embarcadero Rd. also has a van-accessible space, and at the sailing station, a gravel lot has several van-accessible spaces. Wheelchair-accessible restrooms with running water are at the nature center (open only when the center is) and Bixby Art Park parking area; porta-potties are at the duck pond and sailing station. Several accessible picnic tables are by the duck pond; all are near the parking lot on firm grass or dirt, and two have shortened benches to provide integrated seating for at least two wheelchairs each. The Visitor Center is wheelchair-accessible.

name: Hayfield Trail to Toyon and Bay View Loop
description: This is a fantastic trail in Fremont Older Open Space Preserve. The viewpoints offer breathtaking city views and abundant wildflowers in spring. Due to minimal shade along the trail, it's crucial to carry enough water and protect yourself from the sun. Parking at the trailhead is limited and fills up quickly on weekends and holidays.

name: West Ridge, Graham, and Dunn Trail Loop
description: This loop walk takes you through Roberts Regional Recreation Area, situated near Oakland, California. It’s a pleasant hike among redwoods, featuring several climbs that get the heart pumping. The trail is well-marked, mostly shaded with a few clearings, and offers numerous viewing points along the way.

name: San Leandro Bay Trail
park: What are some of the facilities available for San Leandro Bay Trail?Park
description:
The Tidewater Staging Area is commonplace for canoes and kayaks to be launched into the bay. This is a nice trail on a wide paved path. On one side is a good view of San Leandro Bay, with plenty of water and birds. The other side is commercial and industrial.

Accessibility: There are 6 paved designated accessible spaces in the gravel parking lot off of Tidewater Boating Center Access Road at the north end of the trail. All of them are van-accessible with striped access aisles. The trail surface is paved asphalt and smooth. It is typically at least 8 feet wide. 

The whole trail is estimated to be in the gentle (3% or less) grade category. This trail will likely be navigable for most wheelchairs/mobility equipment or stroller users. There are benches along the route for resting.

name: Steep Hollow and Los Trancos Trail Loop
description:
• Foothills Nature Preserve charges an entry fee. An annual pass is also available for purchase. Dogs are not allowed on weekends or holidays. For more information, please visit https://www.cityofpaloalto.org/Departments/Community-Services/Open-Space-Parks/Neighborhood-Parks/Foothills-Nature-Preserve



The Steep Hollow and Los Trancos Trail Loop is home to diverse wildlife, including deer and various bird species. The hike begins with a steady incline through a dense forest of oak and redwood trees. As you ascend, you’ll encounter unique rock formations that serve as a highlight of the trail. Eventually, the trail opens to a meadow, offering panoramic views of the surrounding valley.

name: Coyote Point to San Mateo Bridge
park: HikingGood conditionsNot crowdedI recommend parking outside the Coyote Point Recreation Area because parking is $6 to enter. Seal Point Park can access the same trail. There’s also some access from street parking.Park
description:
According to Access Northern California (http://accessnca.org/access-northern-california/explore/explore-detail-view/?site_id=156): The Bay Trail skirts the eastern perimeter of the park, parallel to Coyote Point Drive for much of the way. Starting near the Peninsula Humane Society shelter on Airport Boulevard, you quickly leave the Bay views behind, turning inland to travel past many of the park's amenities. Across Coyote Point Drive is the Poplar Creek Golf Course.

Approximately a half-mile in, a grove of eucalyptus trees atop a nearby hill wafts a sweet aroma into the air and, depending on the time of day, provides a little shade. The Bay Trail briefly touches Coyote Point Marina, then travels south out of the park for 2.5 miles to the San Mateo Bridge. No matter where you are on the trail, you can hear planes circling to land at nearby San Francisco International Airport and shots ringing from the shooting range, but the sounds of songbirds and other small animals provide a calming balance to the manmade racket.

Coyote Point was once an island separated from the mainland by a large salt marsh that was later filled in. Much of the 670-acre park is flat, except for a few knolls among eucalyptus trees that often reveal scenic overlooks of the marina, the remaining marsh, and the Bay. With an outstanding nature museum, several playgrounds, plentiful picnic areas, a beach, large lawns, and an accessible playground at the Eucalyptus Recreation Area, the park makes a great day-long outing for families. Adults can also enjoy a shooting range, marina, yacht club (not wheelchair accessible), and fishing jetty.

Situated on the east side of a tree-shaded knoll in the eastern part of the park, the CuriOdyssey Museum is a top-notch interactive science and education center that allows visitors to observe a variety of native California animals up close. Indoor exhibits include interactive displays, computer activities, videos, and films about Bay Area ecosystems. The open floor plan makes it easy to maneuver. In the outdoor animal habitats you can learn about and get close to various reptiles, amphibians, mammals, and, in the walk-through aviary, nearly two dozen native birds. The butterfly and hummingbird gardens are scenic and peaceful spots in which to rest and watch the wildlife.

ACCESSIBILITY: There is firm, designated accessible parking with a slope no greater than 2% at the marina, trailheads, promenade, museum, and playground. The trail surface is paved asphalt and it is typically at least six feet wide. It is mostly gentle, all estimated to be 5% or less. Most wheelchair and stroller users will find this trail navigable.

The restrooms in the park are partially accessible (most only allow front-transfers, are too shallow to close the stall door, and have no grab bars on the back wall). The most accessible one is by the drop-in picnic area below the museum, which has enough clearance for closing the stall door and pulling alongside the toilet. Numerous picnic areas have accessible tables with a firm and stable path and surface, and at least 27 inches of knee clearance. The most accessible tables are downhill from the CuriOdessey Museum.

name: High Meadow and Upper Wildcat Canyon Loop via Lower Meadow Trail
park: Rancho San Antonio Open Space Preserve
description:
The High Meadow and Upper Wildcat Canyon Loop via Lower Meadow Trail winds through woods and open meadows, providing picturesque vistas and opportunities to see deer, bobcats, and mountain lions. Hikers should be aware of poison oaks and rattlesnakes in the area.

Along its broad trail, this trail offers several climbs and descents. It also has excellent places for a leisurely rest, including a picnic area and a grassy meadow. The vistas from the hill are especially breathtaking.

name: Stream View, Redtail Hawk, and Grey Fox Loop
park: Bishop Ranch Regional Open Space Preserve
description:
Park Features: Bishop Ranch is a serene parkland located on 806 acres in San Ramon. Watch for deer, red-tailed hawks, and turkey vultures while you enjoy lovely views of open skies and Mount Diablo to the northeast. Hiking, jogging, kite flying, dog walking, and picnicking are some of the activities to be enjoyed on this ridgetop refuge.

Trail Highlights: The seasonal creek is active in the winter months and into spring, depending on rainfall. Enjoy the pleasant groves of oak trees sprawling throughout the park. Delight in views of the San Ramon, Dublin, and Pleasanton valleys, with Mount Diablo as the backdrop. There are no restroom facilities, so plan ahead.

Trail Directions: Begin southwest on Grey Fox Trail. Walk .06 miles and take the first right onto Stream View Trail. The trail splits off around the bottom of the seasonal creek: keep to the path left/southwest of the creek (though either route will lead back to the same trail). There is a brief uphill section before the hiker-only section of the Stream View meets the wider multi-use section of Stream View. Take a right at that junction and continue along Stream View above and parallel to the creek. The last section of Stream View Trail heads steeply uphill, away from the creek, gaining an elevation of about 400 feet. Atop this small hill, *turn left onto Redtail Hawk Trail. Follow the trail for .18 miles, turning left onto Grey Fox Trail to finish the loop. This final stretch of the hike will take you back to the start and grace you with sweeping views of Mount Diablo to the northeast.

*If you would like to extend your hike, turn right onto Redtail Hawk Trail. This is an out-and-back hike which adds 1.48 miles total to your hike.

Park Curfew/Hours: 5 a.m. to 10 p.m.

name: Rhus Ridge to Mary Davey and Chamise Trail
park: Rancho San Antonio Open Space Preserve
description:
This is a straightforward trail through the Rancho San Antonio Open Space Preserve. It leads hikers to the Mary Davey Memorial, a lovely place to enjoy a picnic and views of the bay area, delightful meadows, oak woodlands, and Black Mountain. 

The first section is nice and shaded with greenery on both sides, and it is also the steepest part of the hike. After that, the trail flattens out along the ridgeline and is exposed to the sun. Limited parking is available at the trailhead, so get an early start to beat the crowds.

name: Mori Point Loop Trail
description:
To Mori Point for stunning views and back. Takes the bootlegger's steps going down.

Beautiful wildflower blooms are at their peak in the springtime, with the most flowers usually present in April and May.

It’s quite windy on the bluffs, so dress accordingly.

Park on Mori Point Road or Bradford Way or Fairway Drive.

name: Alameda Creek Regional Trail
park: The trail on the south bank provides access to Coyote Hills Regional Park
description:
According to Access Northern CA (http://accessnca.org/access-northern-california/explore/explore-detail-view/?site_id=40): This paved trail along Alameda Creek from Niles Canyon to the bay attracts bicyclists, skaters, runners, and equestrians.  It will lead you west a couple of miles out into the salt flats at the Bay, or east following Alameda Creek to its source ten-miles away in Niles Canyon. At Niles Staging Area, the creek runs over a rocky bed and people picnic or fish (not accessible pier) from willow-shaded banks.

The trail is accessible from several thoroughfares in the Fremont, Union City and Newark areas. Motor vehicles are not allowed on the trail.

For the first four miles heading east, there's no shade or facilities until you reach the Beard Staging Area. Following the creek downstream on the southern trail, you pass under Mission Blvd. and, 0.75 miles further, pass the Alameda County Water District’s three rubber cofferdams. Inflated year-round except during storms, these dams transform the creek into a series of long ponds. In the dry season, they reduce the creek’s flow to a trickle, leaving the exposed streambed covered with cattails. You'll pass residential areas and some sections are partially shaded by locust, pepper, pine, and eucalyptus trees.

The trail on the south bank provides access to Coyote Hills Regional Park. An additional 3.5 mile loop trail making the run west from Niles Canyon along the trail, through Coyote Hills and back again, qualifies in distance for marathon runs. For those who want to clock shorter distances along the trail, markers have been installed at quarter-mile intervals.

ACCESSIBILITY: There is designated, van-accessible parking at the Isherwood, Niles, and Beard staging areas. Sequoia Bridge spans the creek 2.25 miles from Niles Staging Area, providing access to the northern trail and Isherwood Staging Area. If you choose to start your trip from this staging area, it’s best to head upstream to Sequoia Bridge and cross to the southern trail before heading west. The automobile bridge on Isherwood Way has no curb cuts, and the surface of the northern trail makes for a very bumpy wheelchair ride. Continuing on the southern trail, you pass residential backyards for the next two miles before coming to the Beard Staging Area, the last stopping place with amenities before you reach Coyote Hills Regional Park another four miles down the trail. 

The trail has a paved surface and is typically at least four feet wide. It is estimated to be gentle, all 3% or less in grade. Wherever the trail passes under a road, there are steep slopes that may be challenging for manual wheelchair users. 

There are accessible picnic tables at the Beard Staging area with firm & stable path to tables, firm and stable table surfaces, and 27 inches or greater knee clearance.

name: Best trails inSkyline Ridge Open Space Preserve
park: Skyline Ridge Open Space Preservebest Trails In Skyline Ridge Open Space Preserve Best Trails In Skyline Ridge Open Space Preserve
description: Hours: half an hour before sunrise to half an hour after sunset

name: Saratoga Gap and Ridge Loop
description:
• General fee: Castle Rock State Park charges a day-use fee to enter. For more information please visit https://www.parks.ca.gov/?page_id=538

The trail is a true gem. One of the most appealing aspects of this trail is the balance it strikes between shade and sun. While certain stretches provide a cool, dappled respite from the sun's rays, others open up to the brilliant sunshine, bathing hikers in its warm embrace. This dynamic setting ensures the journey remains engaging and diverse.

For those contemplating a weekend hike, this trail is an excellent choice. Its length is ideal - not too taxing, yet long enough to feel accomplished at the end. While weekends do see a good amount of footfall, the hustle and bustle of finding parking isn't as daunting as one might imagine. Patience is the key; there are always fellow hikers arriving and departing, ensuring a steady turnover of parking spots.

All in all, this trail offers an invigorating blend of nature's beauty and convenience. Whether you're a seasoned hiker or a beginner, the vibrant landscape and welcoming community are sure to leave a lasting impression.

Fall is a great time to visit, as the mountain ridge is a riot of colors, oscillating between refreshing greens and fiery reds.

name: Cañada Road Trail
description:
This route can be walked, but is best experienced as a bike ride as most of it is on a road. This pleasant ride through the redwoods is a great trip, with great views, a visit to the Pulgas water temple, and opportunities to grab a bite to eat before or after your ride. 

On Sundays, this 3.8 mile section of Cañada Road closes to vehicle traffic between the Filoli entrance and Highway 92, allowing for non-motorized activities including jogging, bicycling, hiking, roller-skating, and walking. For more information, please see https://parks.smcgov.org/bicycle-sunday

name: Sandy Wool Lake
description: • General fee: Ed R. Levin County Park charges a fee to enter. For more information, please visit https://parks.sccgov.org/plan-your-visit/santa-clara-county-park-fees

name: Lost Trail
description: This route takes you along the side of a ridge that offers some great city views and overlooks. This wooded trail does not take you all the way to the Windy Hill Summit, but it is a great option for exploring the preserve with less elevation gain than a hike to the top. There is a picnic table at the trailhead.

name: Shoreline Stroll Trail
description: This trail follows sidewalks and paved paths along the waterfront in Monterey, offering great views of the ocean and benches to rest. Along the way, you can visit popular attractions such as Cannery Row, Fisherman's Wharf, the Monterey Bay Aquarium, and Monterey State Historic Park. Parking with restrooms is available at the trailhead.

name: Bay Trail: Anza Lagoon to Belmont Slough
description:
This is a segment of the San Francisco Bay Trail: a 500 mile long mile trail around the Bay. This is the 4th section of the Bay Trail, taking hikers from Anza Lagoon in Burlingame to Belmont Slough.

The section of the Bay Trail between Burlingame and Redwood Shores offers long, continuous stretches of shoreline Trail. In Burlingame, begin at Anza Lagoon. Shortly after crossing the wooden bridge, the trail picks up again south of Fisherman's Park and continues into the 670-acre Coyote Point Recreation Area, along the edge of a golf course and through a large eucalyptus grove. Continuing south, the trail connects directly to San Mateo's Shoreline Park, comprised of Ruder Park and Seal Point Park. Ryder Park features an interactive tidal water system, playgrounds, a kayak and windsurf launch, picnic areas and restored wetlands. Across an elegant 105-foot bicycle/pedestrian bridge over San Mateo Creek is Seal Point Park, a former landfill offering expansive bay views and public art. South of the park, the Bay Marshes boardwalk extends from the trail with views of the mudflats. From here, the trail continues into Foster City, passing underneath the San Mateo Bridge, past Sea Cloud Park and along marshes and mudflats adjacent to Belmont Slough. An interior trail along Marina Lagoon snakes along the edge of this linear waterway. The Foster City section of the trail also connects to a bicycle/pedestrian bridge over Highway 101 that's accessed near the Belmont Sports Complex. A blue bicycle/pedestrian bridge near Oracle connects Foster City to Redwood Shores. Veer right to reach Island Park or a tranquil place to rest along the slough. Continue along the trail adjacent to Belmont Slough towards Redwood Shores Ecological Reserve.

name: Bay Trail: Bedwell Bayfront Park to Alviso
description:
This is a segment of the San Francisco Bay Trail: a 500 mile long mile trail around the Bay. This is the 6th section of the Bay Trail, taking hikers from Bedwell Bayfront Park to Alviso.

Beginning at Bedwell Bayfront Park, travel south into the Don Edwards San Francisco Bay National Wildlife Refuge, the first urban national wildlife refuge established in the United States.

From University Avenue, the bicycle/pedestrian path on the Dumbarton Bridge is straight ahead. Near the bridge, a .7-mile spur trail in the Ravenswood Open Space Preserve hugs the edge of restored wetlands. By mid-2020, the trail will connect University Avenue to the southern section of Ravenswood Open Space Preserve and Cooley Landing. 

At the bridge over San Francisquito Creek, the trail splits into two different Bay Trail routes. For the shoreline route, head into the Palo Alto Baylands along the gravel path that leads to the Lucy Evans Baylands Nature Interpretive Center, Palo Alto Baylands EcoCenter and Byxbee Park. For the inland route, continue straight from San Francisquito Creek on the paved path and follow streets to pick up the paved path that extends along the edge of East Bayshore. 

Don't miss Bliss in the Moment, a sculpture dedicated to former Bay Trail Board member and bicycle advocate Bill Bliss. 

In Shoreline at Mountain View, a paved path extends the length of the park past the historic Rengstorff House to the Stevens Creek Nature Study Area. The Stevens Creek Trail extends over 5 miles to downtown Mountain View and beyond. Follow the natural surface path behind Moffett Field for unique views of this former Navy facility and the wetland habitats along its edge.
