Sunnyvale Baylands Park includes acres of seasonal wetlands and grassy uplands that feature grounds for picnicking and several miles of Bay Trail. Dogs are not allowed in Ravenswood Open Space Preserve, Shoreline at Mountain View, behind Moffett Field and in Sunnyvale Baylands Park. 

Alviso Marina County Park, a former marina, has been restored to wetlands but you can still launch a boat here. A 9-mile dry season loop trail extends around the former marina.

name: Coyote, Upper High Meadow, and Stephen E Arbors Loop
park: Rancho San Antonio Open Space Preserve
description: This route offers great views! This route takes you on a loop through the Rancho San Antonio Open Space Preserve. You'll travel along several trails to complete this loop. Your itinerary will include in order: the Coyote, Farm Bypass, Rogue Valley, Wildcat, Upper High Meadow, and Stephe E Arbors trails.

name: Castle Rock Falls
description:
• General fee: Castle Rock State Park charges a day-use fee to enter. For more information please visit https://www.parks.ca.gov/?page_id=538

Follow the Saratoga Gap Trail from the parking area to the base of Castle Rock Falls. The trail travels slightly downhill on the way toward the falls. The forest is dominated by towering moss-covered trees and large boulders. A bridge is in place to help cross over the creek. You will need to scramble up rocks at some points, so wear good hiking shoes.

name: Rincon Park to Crissy Field
description:
This route passes through major landmarks - Pier 39, Fisherman's Wharf, and Ghirardelli square.

Accessibility: There are likely designated accessible spaces in the paved street parking lots off of The Embarcadero at the east end of the trail, but it is unclear where the closest one is. The trail surface is paved concrete or asphalt and smooth. It is typically at least 5 feet wide. 

The majority of the trail is estimated to be in the mostly gentle (5% or less) grade category but there are steeper sections at about 3.3-3.4 miles when going west. Trail goers using wheelchairs/mobility equipment or strollers may need assistance in the steeper sections or to avoid them for safety. There are benches along the route for resting.

name: Mountain Lion Hike (Pathways of Wildlife)
description:
• General fee: Mount Madonna County Park charges a fee to enter. For more information, please visit https://parks.sccgov.org/plan-your-visit/santa-clara-county-park-fees

Which path will you choose? Mt. Madonna Park Rangers have marked out several different hikes for you to choose. The Mountain Lion Hike has red arrows along the route to help guide you on your path. This well marked path has a sign that will allow you to choose the correct corresponding route among the many loops that are here.

name: Fir Trail and Tafoni Trail
park: El Corte De Madera Creek Open Space Preserve
description:
This fantastic trail follows Fir Trail and Tafoni Trail in El Corte De Madera Creek Open Space Preserve. Named after an Italian geologist, the Tafoni is an eroded sandstone formation. 

The trailhead is located just north of the Skeggs Point parking lot. The wide path offers beautiful views of the trees down the steep canyons. The trail winds through towering redwoods and is shaded the whole way.

Along the way, visitors can admire the beautiful moss, trees, and incredible views from the lookout point.  There is ample free parking at Skeggs Point.

name: Best trails inStanford
park: Top parks around StanfordWindy Hill Open Space PreserveRancho San Antonio County ParkRancho San Antonio Open Space PreserveHuddart County ParkEdgewood Park and Nature PreservePulgas Ridge Open Space PreserveEnid Pearson-Arastradero PreserveWunderlich County ParkEl Corte De Madera Creek Open Space PreserveRussian Ridge Open Space PreserveFoothills Nature PreserveBaylands Nature PreserveExplore around StanfordTop citiesPalo AltoMenlo ParkEast Palo AltoLos Altos HillsLos AltosPortola ValleyWoodsideMountain ViewRedwood CityEmerald HillsSan CarlosSunnyvaleBelmontLa HondaNewarkTop parksSand Hill FieldsBurgess ParkSharon ParkEsther Clark ParkMitchell ParkHolbrook Palmer ParkGreer ParkEnid Pearson-Arastradero PreserveByxbee Recreation AreaShoreline at Mountain View ParkBaylands Nature PreserveByrne PreserveRengstorff ParkPalo Alto Foothills ParkRavenswood Open Space PreserveTop trailsStanford Dish Loop TrailStanford Campus WalkSand Hill Fields LoopSuitabilityWheelchair-friendlyPoints of interestWhite Memorial FountainOak Road GardenSuitabilityWheelchair-friendlyPoints of interestWhite Memorial FountainOak Road GardenAllTrailsExploreCountriesRegionsCitiesParksTrailsPoints of InterestTrail FeaturesMapsMy MapsCreate MapPrint MapsRoute converterCompanyAboutJobsPressAmbassadorsAffiliatesInfluencersCommunitySupportGift membershipAllTrails GearExploreCountriesRegionsCitiesPark
description:
Looking for the best walking trails in Stanford? Whether you're getting ready to hike, cycle, trail run, or explore other outdoor pursuits, AllTrails has 3 picturesque trails in the Stanford area. Discover hand-curated trail maps, along with reviews and photos from fellow outdoor enthusiasts.

Explore one of 2 easy walking routes in Stanford, with child-friendly routes for your next family outing. Venture outdoors and learn more about the area's historic sites or take a break from the hustle and bustle along the many tree-lined paths surrounding Stanford. Perfect for little feet, paws, walkers and outdoor enthusiasts of any skill level.

name: Dry Creek Loop
description: This is a pleasant loop trail that travels up to Garin Peak with an elevation of 948 feet. Expect to enjoy scenic vistas as you travel through a variety of California ecosystems. For some great historical fun, make sure to visit the Garin Barn Visitor Center which has a working blacksmith shop. The Visitor Center is especially great for kids.

name: Hassler Loop Trail
description: This is a terrific trail in Pulgas Ridge Open Space Preserve. It follows a wide, paved path with some steep areas. There are beautiful views along the way and a good mix of sunny and shady areas. The trail begins from the parking area off Edmonds Road. Parking can fill up early on weekends and during holidays. Arrive early to secure a spot. The first half of the hike is all uphill, but there is a bench along the way if you need to take a break and catch your breath.

name: Ridge Trail and Blackhawk Loop
description:
• General fee: Mount Madonna County Park charges a fee to enter. For more information, please visit https://parks.sccgov.org/plan-your-visit/santa-clara-county-park-fees

This is a beautiful loop through the forest, starting on Hecker Pass Highway. The trail follows the road north before branching off on the Ridge Trail and steadily climbing to a high point about 1.5 miles in. At the stream in Blackhawk Canyon, the route picks up the Blackhawk Trail and stays close to the stream to loop back.

name: Mallard Slough Trail
park: Mallard Slough Trail [CLOSED]. Bring plenty of water and wear sunscreen and protective clothing.Top trails nearbyAlviso Slough TrailAlviso Slough TrailAlviso Marina County Park4.3·Easy·8.7 mi·Est. 2h 32mGuadalupe River TrailGuadalupe River Trail4.5·Easy·5.4 mi·Est. 1h 37mSan Francisco Bay Trail - Sunnyvale to Sand PointSan Francisco Bay Trail - Sunnyvale to Sand PointDon Edwards San Francisco Bay National Wildlife Refuge4.6·Moderate·20.0 mi·Est. 5h 50mSunnyvale Baylands Park Guadalupe SloughSunnyvale Baylands Park Guadalupe SloughSunnyvale Baylands Park4.2·Easy·3.4 mi·Est. 1h 0mSan Tomas Aquino Creek TrailSan Tomas Aquino Creek TrailSunnyvale Baylands Park4.4·Easy·12.6 mi·Est. 3h 47mSan Tomas Aquino Creek Trail to SF Bay TrailSan Tomas Aquino Creek Trail to SF Bay Trail4.4·Easy·4.0 mi·Est. 1h 11mAlviso Marina LoopAlviso Marina LoopAlviso Marina County Park4.3·Easy·0.8 mi·Est. 14mBaylands Perimeter LoopBaylands Perimeter LoopSunnyvale Baylands Park4.3·Easy·1.3 mi·Est. 23mDon Edwards- Coyote Creek Lagoon TrailDon Edwards- Coyote Creek Lagoon Trail4.2·Easy·3.5 mi·Est. 1h 1mSan Francisco Bay Trail at Sunnyvale Baylands ParkSan Francisco Bay Trail at Sunnyvale Baylands ParkSunnyvale Baylands Park
description:
• Indefinite closure: The Mallard Slough Trail is closed indefinitely due to construction. For more information, please visit https://parks.sccgov.org/sites/g/files/exjcpb961/files/documents/ShorelineProject2024Updates.pdf

According to Access Northern California (http://accessnca.org/access-northern-california/explore/explore-detail-view/?site_id=173): The Don Edwards San Francisco Bay National Wildlife Refuge, the first and largest urban national wildlife refuge in the United States, is just one piece of the larger San Francisco Bay National Wildlife Refuge Complex. Encompassing 30,000 acres, the Don Edwards refuge consists primarily of tidal marsh, salt ponds, mudflats, and seasonal wetlands. Public entry points for visiting Don Edwards are at its headquarters (at the refuge's north end in Fremont) and at this site, which is around the southern tip of San Francisco Bay. The refuge encompasses thousands of acres of restored wetlands, and it is a very fine place to see waterfowl. It's also scenic, with interesting shrubbery along the marshes and wide expanses of blue water, as well as ponds in various shades of yellow and red because of the salt-tolerant microorganisms that flourish where the tide is excluded.

The trails in the Alviso section of the refuge are almost entirely wheelchair accessible since most run atop level levees that double as maintenance roads. Not many people come here, with the exception of school groups and birdwatchers. The Mallard Slough Loop is closed during hunting season, late October to late January. If you want to do the loop in its entirety, be prepared for a day-long outing and a variety of weather conditions along this exposed part of the Bay shoreline.

The Environmental Education Center has displays on the South Bay’s ecology and history, a small bookstore, and replicas of the reed boats and shelters used by the native people. It is used for school programs and other events on weekdays and is open to the public on weekends. The entry door is rather heavy. The visitor center area closes at 4 PM, so please be cautious if you use their parking lot. There is limited parking available just outside of the gated road, which is the start/end point shown on the map for this trail loop. If you have any concerns about the gate closure it may be best to park just outside.

ACCESSIBILITY: There are firm, designated accessible parking spaces with a 2% slope or less behind the education center. When the lot is closed, nose-in parking is permitted outside the gate on a wide, hard gravel strip along the road, but it has no designated accessible spaces. The trail surface is dirt/gravel and it is typically at least four feet wide. It is estimated to have a gentle grade (all 3% or less).

The connector trail from the education center to the Mallard Slough Trail is a bit steep, slightly exceeding a 5% grade in places. The connector trail from the education center is less than 4 feet wide. Firm (hardened soil) for most of the loop. Some spots are uncomfortably soft. It can be bumpy - a manual chair user will need to be strong and may need assistance, especially on the spur which has more gravel. From the education center, you can take a boardwalk to the 5.5-mile Mallard Slough Loop Trail, a gravel and dirt levee path. Following the loop clockwise from the boardwalk, the going gets tougher about two miles out - here the dirt surface becomes more uneven, with large gravel and some soft spots.

A half-mile spur trail extends from the northernmost point of this loop to Coyote Creek; the surface is soft, making travel difficult compared to the main trail, but it may be worth the trouble since the spur takes you to the site of Drawbridge, a small town that flourished in the late 19th and early 20th centuries. There's little left to see of it now, but stop in at the Education Center to look at photos and learn about its history.

As you round the halfway point and head back, traveling should become a little easier. The visitor center is wheelchair accessible. There are accessible restrooms inside the Environmental Education Center but the restroom doors are heavy. There is an accessible porta-potty is in the parking lot near the accessible space. Partially accessible picnic tables are across the parking lot from the Environmental Education Center in a covered open-air pavilion. There isn't enough space at the end of the tables for most wheelchairs to pull under them. Another table is just off the New Chicago Marsh Trail, but is down a steep path on a soft surface and is not accessible without a lot of help.

name: Long Ridge and Ranch Spring Loop
description: The Long Ridge and Ranch Spring Loop offers a scenic hike through California’s rolling hills and woodlands. As you walk, you'll pass through a variety of landscapes, including shaded forests, open meadows, and expansive ridge views. The trail provides a peaceful environment with opportunities to enjoy the natural beauty of the area. Whether you’re walking along the ridge for sweeping vistas or exploring the lush spring areas, this loop is a great option to explore in this area.

name: China Hole Trail Loop
description:
• Henry W. Coe State Park charges an entrance fee. For current rates please visit: https://www.parks.ca.gov/?page_id=561

The essential Henry Coe Hike: 10 arduous miles through the park's demanding mountainous terrain.

China Hole is one of the most popular destinations at Henry Coe State Park. Spring rains create a picturesque swimming hole at the confluence of two creeks, making the nearby backcountry campsite a prized locale for overnight outings.

A day hike to China Hole is a perfect alternative if you hate to sleep on the ground but love to get your heart pumping under the California sun. You'll also descend along the Madrone Soda Springs Trail and the Mile Trail, which passes the decaying remains of an era when the springs were a major tourist attraction. 

Best time to go: spring, when the hills are green and the wildflowers are popping, and early summer, when it's warm enough to swim at China Hole. The water gets more dank as summer progresses -- the puddles remaining after July tend to reek.

name: Halls Valley to Washburn Loop
description:
• Joseph D Grant County Park collects a day-use fee for vehicular entrance year-round. For more information, please see https://parks.sccgov.org/plan-your-visit/santa-clara-county-park-fees#3925188384-3236192913

This is probably the most technical ride in the park. Starting at the Grant Lake Trailhead, cut right down a ravine and then make a left at the McCreery Lake trail. Then at the junction of the Los Huecos and Hall's Valley trails, follow Hall's Valley. If you're a glutton for punishment, you could take the Los Huecos trail, but Hall's Valley is punishment enough for most.

It's two miles up hill and mostly through oak forests and woodlands. At the top, you start to get views of the surrounding hills and mountains and even a glimpse of the San Francisco Bay. The trail Tees into the Canada de Pala trail at the top. Make a left and continue going up. This part of the trail is oak savanna, and you start to get sweeping vistas of the surrounding countryside. You'll come to the Pala Seca Trail; both ends of it. Take the left branch (down for once) and continue until you get to the bottom of the Washburn trail. This area is known as Deer Valley and is rather unique because there is actual running water in places even late in the year.  

The Washburn trail is more up for the first half a mile or so. Keep an eye out for the golden eagles that roost on a tree overlooking the valley near the top. There's a bench at the top that affords one of the best vistas in the park. Sit down and enjoy the view for a minute or two. You've done the hard physical work, now it's time for the mental gymnastics.  

The trail down is steep, rough, and serpentine. Take it pretty slow and it is still a hard. The bottom is actually lower than the trailhead, and there's a 300 foot climb before you glide down to the trail's junction with Mt Hamilton Road. A mile on the pavement and you're back where you started. What a ride!

name: Purisima Creek Trail to Craig Britton Trail
park: Purisima Creek Redwoods Open Space Preserve
description: Begin from the trailhead along Skyline Boulevard. The Redwood Trail accesses the Purisima Creek Trail. This travels through the forest and heads downhill to the junction with the Craig Britton Trail. You will pass some stands of towering Redwood trees as you travel through the forest. E-bikes are not permitted.

name: Hunter's Point via Regnart Trail
description: This is a marvelous trail in Fremont Older Open Space Preserve—the views from Hunter's Point offer excellent vistas of Silicon Valley. There is no shade along this route, so it's important to wear sun protection and stay hydrated. The trail is a wide dirt road all the way, and it involves a steep climb and descent. The journey begins from Fremont Older Trailhead, where limited street parking is available.

name: Toyon Trail and Coal Mine Ridge Loop
park: Coal Mine Ridge Nature Preserve Of Portola Valley Ranch
description:
This trail through the Coal Mine Ridge Nature Reserve of Portola Valley Ranch features beautiful scenery and wildflowers. You'll follow the Toyon Trail for a steady incline before turning onto the Coal Mine Ridge Loop for the gradual return descent. 

There is plenty of shade along the way and benches to sit and enjoy the natural surroundings. The trails are well-maintained and clearly marked. The parking lot at the trailhead can fill up early on the weekends, but there is plenty of parking on the side street.

name: Purisima Creek, Grabtown Gulch, and Borden Hatch Mill Loop
park: Purisima Creek Redwoods Open Space Preserve
description: This trail takes you through a beautiful redwood forest and follows a creek at times. The trail is well-shaded and has many ferns and interesting fungi to see along the way. The loop can be hiked in either direction. There are a few side trails, so downloading offline maps can help you navigate. Keep an eye out for banana slugs.

name: Agua Caliente Trail and Launch Site Viewpoint
description:
• General fee: Ed R. Levin County Park charges a fee to enter. For more information, please visit https://parks.sccgov.org/plan-your-visit/santa-clara-county-park-fees

Ed R. Levin County Park offers multi-use trails through the golden hills above Milpitas. This route starts at the Sandy Wool Lake parking lot and follows the Tularcitos Trail east before turning north on the Agua Caliente Trail. Directly east of the water tower is a singletrack trail that cuts uphill to a high point with panoramic views.

name: San Francisco Bay Trail at Sunnyvale Baylands Park
park: San Francisco Bay Trail at Sunnyvale Baylands Park
description:
• General fee: Sunnyvale Baylands Park charges a fee to enter. For more information, please visit https://parks.sccgov.org/santa-clara-county-parks/sunnyvale-baylands-park

The San Francisco Bay Trail starts at the parking lot in Sunnyvale Baylands Park. This popular multi-use trail winds around the marshes with water views, featuring mostly flat terrain with concrete and gravel surfaces. As you enjoy the scenic surroundings, look for pelicans, ducks, geese, and other wildlife.

name: Short High Ridge Loop
description:
• Parking fee information: There is a fee to park at Dry Creek Pioneer Regional Park. For more information, please visit https://www.ebparks.org/parks/garin-dry-creek

This trail starts at the parking lot off May Road on the outskirts of Union City, where restrooms are available, and leads to Dry Creek Pioneer Regional Park. It winds along the creek, through rolling California hills, and climbs steeply through meadows. At the top, you'll enjoy great views of the bay and the city.

name: Big Canyon Trail
description:
Big Canyon is an out and back style trail with a small loop option. As you hike, keep your eyes out for a plethora of native plants and animals (be aware of poison oak!)

The trail is well marked and easy to follow except where it merges with or departs from jeep roads. Look for orange surveyors tape, orange stakes, orange pipes, or orange discs in such places.After 172 feet, the trail bears to the right, away from the main jeep road, which goes to the site of a house which used to stand there.The trail then crosses a little seasonal stream in a shady place with ferns, then crosses over to another drainage with oak trees and Poison Oak. (Dont touch the Poison Oak which has clusters of 3 green or red leaves.)

name: Best trails inSanborn County Park
park: Sanborn County Parkbest Trails In Sanborn County Park Best Trails In Sanborn County Park
description: Welcome to Sanborn County Park. This lushly wooded park of over 3,688 acres, is nestled in the Santa Cruz Mountains between Saratoga and Skyline Boulevard. This mountain park of redwoods and tan bark oak, offers hiking, camping, RV camping and picnicking opportunities year round. Enjoy your visit today and return often to experience the many features of Sanborn County Park. Sanborn County Park is located on Sanborn Road. From Saratoga, proceed two miles west on Highway 9 to Sanborn Road. Turn left onto Sanborn Road, traveling one mile to the park entrance. The park is open year round from 8:00 a.m. to sunset.

name: Clarkia, Sunset, Serpentine and Edgewood Trail
description:
Edgewood Park is one of the best places on the Peninsula to see wildflowers in the spring, but this hike is nice year-round.

This hike is recommended by https://openspacetrust.org/ as it's one of the most popular ones in the San Mateo/Santa Clara County area.

The serpentine soils of Edgewood Park make it ideal for wildflowers, and in the spring it boasts one of the most intense displays on the Peninsula. This loop hike takes you through the center of the park and is one of the best ways to see the colorful show. At other times of year, it is still a beautiful hike through thick grasslands with lovely views.

Follow the Clarkia Trail to the Sunset, Serpentine, and Edgewood Trails to complete a loop around the entire preserve. Then follow the Clarkia Trail back to the trailhead.

Lookout for deer, coyotes, bobcats, and rabbits are often spotted along these trails. The Bay checkerspot butterfly, which once lived throughout the entire Bay Area, is now a threatened species found only in this and a few other San Mateo and Santa Clara County Parks.

name: Stanford Campus Walk
park: HikingGood conditionsGood viewsBathrooms availableWalk around Stanford as a man who already has a degree elsewhere.Park
description:
Experience one of the most beautiful and tourist-friendly campuses in the world.

Take a walk town Palm Drive as you approach the main Stanford Quad.  Visit the Cantor Arts center with its famous collection of Rodin sculptures (the largest collection outside of France), walk through the Quad and into beautiful Memorial Church, and finish with a tour from the top of Hoover Tower.

name: Filbert Steps to Telegraph Hill
park: The trail is open year-round and is beautiful to visit anytime. You'll need to leave pups at home — dogs aren't allowed on this trail.What are some of the facilities available for Filbert Steps to Telegraph Hill?Park
description: The hike is renowned for its stunning views of the city, the Bay, and the famous Coit Tower perched atop the hill. As you make your way up, you'll encounter vibrant flora, including lush greenery, colorful flowers, and a variety of trees that line the steps. The sound of footsteps echoes off the hill, and as you ascend, the views grow more spectacular, offering panoramic vistas of San Francisco’s skyline, the Golden Gate Bridge, and Alcatraz Island.

name: Golden Gate Park Loop
description:
Come explore the wonders of Golden Gate Park! As the third most visited park in the United States, Golden Gate Park is a large urban park featuring a variety of popular attractions. This park offers a variety of hiking trails for the whole family!

Stop by the Academy of Sciences, Conservatory of Flowers, or the Botanical Gardens as you make your way around the park. (Note that these attractions have specific hours and require a fee.) Other cool attractions include the deYoung Museum and Japanese Tea Gardens.

Golden Gate Park is also home to a variety of flora and fauna such as the California Live Oak, a tree native to this park. Visitors can find these oaks at the northeastern section of the park. Additionally, Golden Gate Park hosts events year-round! So if you're looking for a hike, a picnic area, or a variety of museums and gardens, Golden Gate Park is the place to go.

name: Redwood Trail
description:
• Parking fee information: There is a fee to park at Big Basin Redwoods State Park. For more information, please visit https://www.parks.ca.gov/?page_id=540
• CZU Lightning Complex Fire : Public access to Big Basin has been severely impacted by the 2020 CZU Lightning Complex Fire and ongoing fire recovery work, but the park is open for limited day-use access. There is currently no access to waterfalls, all camping is closed and skyline to sea trail is open to the north but access to south (towards the ocean) is closed

The Redwood Trail at Big Basin Redwoods State Park loop offers easy access to some of the tallest and oldest Redwoods anywhere. The fact that the trail is flat and well-maintained, combined with the well-marked attractions along the way make this a perfect hike for families with young children.

The main attractions along this trail are Father of the Forest (known for its wide circumference), Mother of the Forest (the tallest tree in Big Basin) and The Chimney Tree (whose hollow trunk offers a spectacular view up into the sky).

name: Lower Meadow, High Meadow, Upper Wildcat and PG&E Trail Loop
park: Rancho San Antonio Open Space Preserve
description: This loop through Rancho San Antonio has a lot of variety - a good mix of sun and shade, forest and meadow. It has some significant elevation gain, but also some mellow sections. The Upper High Meadows trail is beautiful. You can do this trail any time of year but it can get particularly hot in the summer months. Fall and winter are great times to hike this trail.

name: Los Trancos Trail to Fern Loop
description:
• Foothills Nature Preserve charges an entry fee. An annual pass is also available for purchase. Dogs are not allowed on weekends or holidays. For more information, please visit https://www.cityofpaloalto.org/Departments/Community-Services/Open-Space-Parks/Neighborhood-Parks/Foothills-Nature-Preserve



This is a beautiful loop ascending through a California Bay Forest over an initial hill before edging around a ledge donned with moss covered oaks. Next you will reach a long climb along Los Trancos Creek before emerging into a grass covered hill with a views of the Bay. There are beautiful wildflowers throughout in the late spring and early summer. Bug spray is recommended.

name: Woodland, Oak, Grove, Meadow, Ridgeline, Thermalito Trails
description:
Park Features: This 5,271-acre Regional Park is well known for its panoramic views of the Tri-Valley area. The extensive trail system provides access for hikers, cyclists, dog owners, and equestrians to gorgeous canyon views, ridgetop vistas, and for viewing a variety of woodland species. 

Trail Highlights: There are many hills to climb during this hike, but the expansive views off the ridge will keep you moving along quickly. Water is available at several locations along this route. There is a restroom and drinking water at the trailhead; bring a light jacket, as the winds tend to pick-up quickly atop these hills. 

Trail Directions: From the parking lot, walk through the cattle gate and turn left to begin an uphill hike for .15 miles. At the next trail junction turn right onto Oak Tree Trail, which follows the ridge with the highway to your right. After .49 miles, turn right to begin Sycamore Grove Trail. After .27 miles, turn left at a 4-way crossing onto Meadow Pond Trail. This shaded trail splits, with both routes leading you back to the same trail; you will see a pond after a few hundred feet. In .50 miles, merge right back onto Oak Tree Trail. After .18 miles turn right to walk through another cattle gate and immediately turn right to begin Ridgeline Trail. Continue on Ridgeline Trail, staying right so as not to merge onto other trails. As the trail begins to narrow, turn left to take the wider trail leading to Thermalito Trail. The trail will curve left towards the tree-covered hills, directing you west. After passing two cattle ponds and hiking .76 miles, turn right to continue on Thermalito Trail. Hike .61 miles continue on Thermalito as you right onto a gravel trail. In .16 miles, turn left onto Ridgeline Trail. After .65 miles, stay right to stay on the trail. In .02 miles you will see the cattle gate on your right, go through this gate and go forward to begin Woodland Trail. After a few hundred feet keep to the right to stay on the trail. This trail will meander downhill for .87 miles; turn right onto the first portion of the route which leads back to the parking lot.

name: Monterey Waterfront City Walk
description:
This walking path follows sidewalks and paved paths along the waterfront in Monterey. It offers gorgeous views of the Pacific. 

Accessibility: 

Equipment
This trail is likely accessible for visitors using wheelchairs, mobility equipment, or strollers.

Parking
There are 2 designated van-accessible spaces with striped access aisles in the paved parking lot off Ocean View Boulevard at the northwest end of the trail. 

Surface
The trail surface is paved asphalt or concrete and smooth. It is typically at least 6 feet wide.

Grade
This trail is estimated to be gentle (3% or less).

More Info
Benches are available along the route for resting.

name: Monument Peak from Ohlone College
description: This challenging trail is mostly open with no shady areas. You will be under the sun 95% of the time. Bring plenty of water - on sunny days, it can get brutal! The terrain is well maintained (packed dirt-or-gravel terrain). Because of the lack of trees and the altitude, you will have beautiful views of San Jose and the Bay Area on a clear day.

name: Redtail Loop Trail
description: Arastradero Preserve offers nice trails for hiking, running, mountain biking and horse back riding. The Redtail Loop is a shortloop  trail that is manageable for all experience levels, including children. This trail offers some nice views on the foothills, the Stanford Dish, Highway 280 and Felt Lake.

name: Wilson Loop
description: Wilson Park has ten acres of family picnic areas, a fitness course, a recreation building, and paths for walking and jogging. The park offers access to the Regnart Creek Trail, which hosts waterfowl and other wildlife. This route makes a loop around the playground and follows a path through the baseball fields. A large parking lot is on the park's west side, off Parkside Lane.

name: Savannah Trail Loop
park: Coyote Lake Harvey Bear Ranch County Park
description:
• Parking Fee: Coyote Lake Harvey Bear Ranch County Park charges a fee to enter, except at Mendoza Ranch and Harvey Bear Entrances. There are varying fees depending on if you enter by vehicle, motorcycle, foot, horse, or bike. Please visit https://parks.santaclaracounty.gov/locations/coyote-lake-harvey-bear-ranch-county-park

This six-mile loop over the rolling hills of Harvey Bear Ranch introduces hikers to the wild terrain of the Diablo Range southeast of San Jose, California. 

Harvey Bear is a section of Coyote Lake County Park, which is popular with campers, boaters and paddlers. As the wide-open trails ascend, expansive views of Silicon Valley to the north and the Santa Cruz Mountains to the west open up. 

Best times to go: The hills turn a shimmering green in February and March, and wildflowers dot the hills throughout the spring. October and November bring the annual tarantula migration, though sightings of the big hairy arachnids can be rare.  Summer is typically too hot.

name: Purisima Creek Trail to Bald Knob Trail Loop
park: Purisima Creek Redwoods Open Space Preserve
description: Start by hiking along Purisima Creek before heading uphill and further into the interior of the forest. You will reach the high point at Bald Knob before retracing the Bald Knob Trail. On the way back you will cross Grabtown Gulch which has a small stream that flows into Purisima Creek. Keep an eye out for banana slugs crawling across the trail.

name: Spring Valley Trail
description:
• General fee: Ed R. Levin County Park charges a fee to enter. For more information, please visit https://parks.sccgov.org/plan-your-visit/santa-clara-county-park-fees
• Partial closure: A section of the Spring Valley Trail is closed indefinitely due to a slide, but you can still enjoy other sections of this trail. For more information, please visit https://parks.sccgov.org/closures-updates

One of the trail's highlights is its proximity to Spring Valley, a serene reservoir tucked within the park. This tranquil water feature provides a picturesque backdrop for your hike, and the surrounding area is a great spot for birdwatching and wildlife observation. The mix of open spaces and shaded sections also adds to the appeal of the trail, offering a variety of environments to enjoy as you move along.

name: Redwood Shores to Sea
description:
• CZU Lightning Complex Fire : Public access to Big Basin has been severely impacted by the 2020 CZU Lightning Complex Fire and ongoing fire recovery work, but the park is open for limited day-use access. There is currently no access to waterfalls, all camping is closed and skyline to sea trail is open to the north but access to south (towards the ocean) is closed

This multi-day trip begins in Redwood Shores Lagoon and ends by taking the Skyline to the Sea trail to Big Basin State Park. If you plan on backpacking the trail, there are several spots to camp in Big Basin as well as camping at Toyon Campground in Huddart Park. All campsites will require prior reservation before hiking and possibly permits depending on what sites you would like to book.

name: Lake Chabot via West Shore, Bass Cove, Brandon, and East Shore Loop
description:
• Parking fee information: There is a fee to park at Lake Chabot Regional Park. For more information, please visit https://www.ebparks.org/parks/lake-chabot

The trail begins along the flat and paved West Shore Trail, which follows Lake Chabot’s scenic shoreline. From this path you can look out across the lake at boaters who have launched from the Marina. The heavily wooded Cascade Trail follows one of Lake Chabot’s feeder steams. There is also a wonderful view of the bay from Towhee Trail. Much of the hike takes place on the Lake Chabot Bike Trail; although hikers have the right of way, be aware of your surroundings.

From the Lake Chabot Marina parking lot, head left, following signs for West Shore Trail. Proceed for 1.82 miles and cross the Lake Chabot dam. Make a right after the dam onto Bass Cove Trail and follow it for 1.33 miles. At the next fork, make a right to stay on Bass Cove Trail, then continue for .46 mile. Keep straight to take Columbine/Cascade Trail 1.5 miles to the Stone Bridge. Make a sharp right at the signpost and follow Brandon Trail (and signs for the Lake Chabot Bike Loop) for .89 mile to Escondido Trail. Make a right on Escondido Trail. After 1.39 miles, make a right to reconnect with Brandon Trail and the Lake Chabot Bike Loop. Continue for 1.37 miles until you reach the day use parking lot. Safely cross Marciel Road and continue straight, following signs for Brandon Trail and Lake Chabot Bike Loop. After .13 mile, make a sharp right to follow Towhee Trail for .27 mile, then turn left onto Live Oak Trail. Follow Live Oak Trail for a little over a mile, continuing to follow signs for the Lake Chabot Bike Loop. Cross the bridge and then head right on the East Shore Trail for 1.65 miles until you return to the Marina. 

Park Hours: 6am to sunset (varies seasonally)

Fees: Parking: $5/vehicle, $4/trailered vehicle, $25/bus. 
Dogs: $2/dog. Guide/service dogs free.

name: Bay Area Ridge Trail: Wunderlich County Park to Huddart County Park
park: Bay Area Ridge Trail: Wunderlich County Park to Huddart County Park
description:
Follow the gently graded Skyline Trail through redwood and Douglas-fir forests just below the crest of the Santa Cruz Mountains. Discover unusual spring wildflowers along one of the few remaining segments of the old California Riding and Hiking Trail, a trail system established in 1954. Take this easy, shaded trail on a summer day when you need a retreat from the valley heat.

For more information, see the Bay Area Ridge Trail page here: https://ridgetrail.org/wunderlich-county-park-to-huddart-county-park/

This trail description is excerpted from the 2019 Guidebook. For details on all of the Bay Area Ridge trails, trailheads and more buy the book from Wilderness Press: https://www.wildernesspress.com/product.php?productid=16685&cat=274&bestseller=Y

name: Limekiln Trail
description: The Limekiln Trail follows Limekiln Canyon and also Limekiln Creek to its headwaters and the intersection of Woods and Priest Rock Trails. This pleasant out and back trail offers a great trail to get a taste of the Lexington Reservoir County Park. Bring lots of water, it can be hot and exposed at times

name: Best trails inVasona Lake County Park
park: Vasona Lake County Parkbest Trails In Vasona Lake County Parkall Photos Best Trails In Vasona Lake County Park
description:
Want to find the best trails in Vasona Lake County Park for an adventurous hike or a family trip? AllTrails has 4 great trails for hiking and more. Enjoy hand-curated trail maps, along with reviews and photos from nature lovers like you.

Ready for your next hike or bike ride? Explore one of 4 easy hiking trails in Vasona Lake County Park that are great for the whole family. Looking for a more strenuous hike? We've got you covered, with trails ranging from 16 to 39 meters in elevation gain. Whatever you have planned for the day, you can find the perfect trail for your next trip to Vasona Lake County Park.

name: Los Gatos Creek Trail to Saint Josephs Hill
park: St. Joseph'S Hill Open Space Preserve
description: Begin by traveling alongside Highway 17 along the Los Gatos Creek Trail. After this, you will wind uphill along the Jones, Manzanita, and Novitiate Trails passing over the summit of Saint Joseph's Hill. A bench is in place at the top of the hill to rest and enjoy the view from. Street parking is available along Main Street to access the trail.

name: Mission Peak and Peak Meadow Loop from Ohlone College
description: This route is a really fun combination of trails. You get to see Mission Peak up close before heading downward and then ascending from the other side. The loop part is pretty exposed; on the out and back section up from Ohlone you get maybe 30% shade - and will also encounter larger crowds. The trail head has a water fountain and toilets. There's also toilets below Mission peak, at the point where the loop begins and ends.

name: Windy Hill via Hamms Gulch and Lost Trail
description:
This beautiful trail explores part of the Windy Hill Open Space Reserve. It leads hikers up to the summit of Windy Hill and back again, with a steady incline all the way to the summit.

There's plenty of shade from the trees and lots of wildflowers in spring. The trail can get muddy in certain areas, so shoes with good traction will help with the inclines.

name: San Francisco Bay Trail and Oyster Bay Loop Trail
park:
Trail width is 4 feet and above.

Park
description:
Trail Highlights: The San Francisco Bay trail loop is mostly paved except for the last half mile, which is hard gravel and dirt with some moderate slopes. The rest of the trail is mainly flat and great for people using mobility devices and/or strollers, dog walkers, and cycling. It is only half-mile to reach the shoreline where you can stroll along and soak up the sun and enjoy breezes from San Leandro Bay. There are many benches along the way but little shade, except by the picnic tables. The only accessible vault toilet is about a quarter-mile in, on the right. Trail width is 4 feet and above.

Park Features: An astonishing diversity of wildlife can be seen at this shoreline park even though it is still under development. Northern harriers, white-tailed kites, red-tailed hawks, and shorebirds abound. Views of the Bay are spectacular. Some new amenities include an 18-hole disc golf course and a quarter-acre garden with 300 plants that flower from fall through winter, providing overwintering Monarchs with nectar to help them survive the winter and migrate in spring. Come with friends and family to enjoy a game of disc golf or picnic at one of the seven group picnic areas (non-reservable).

Trail Directions: From the staging area at the end of Neptune Drive, go through the entrance gate and turn left onto the paved San Francisco Bay Trail. This trail soon reaches the water. Follow the paved trail all along the park’s perimeter. At the far end of the park, make a sharp right turn at the end of the pavement, and then, in a quarter-mile, a left onto Oyster Bay Loop Trail to complete the loop. Please use caution: there may be construction trucks in the park.

According to Access Northern California (http://accessnca.org/access-northern-california/explore/explore-detail-view/?site_id=152): There is plentiful street parking on Neptune Drive but vans with lifts or ramps should park on the west side of the street, where there is a sidewalk. A wheelchair-accessible vault toilet is at the first trail junction, up the hill by the picnic area. There is no sink. Picnic tables near the bathroom are very high, including one that has no benches attached. More are scattered along the inland trail to the Rising Wave sculpture. From the trailhead, you climb a long, gentle hill for several hundred yards to a fork. The inland trails have some slopes that may be greater than 5% (a typical ramp slope). From there you can veer right and travel uphill to a picnic area, where a dirt trail travels inland, or continue on the smoother paved shoreline trail. The shoreline trail continues to wrap around the hillside to a spur that takes you to Roger Berry’s metal sculpture “Rising Wave.” This is a good place to enjoy views of the Bay, San Leandro Marina, and the airport’s control tower. You’ll need to retrace your route to reconnect to the perimeter trail; the other dirt trails from here are too steep to navigate in a wheelchair. The trail curves inland toward a small bay that separates the park peninsula from the airport. You’ll soon come to the Bill Lockyer Bridge (railings are 54” high but are slatted so you can see through them), which crosses the San Leandro Slough and travels a half-mile past a golf course to dead-end at the new BART station for the Oakland Airport. The noise from the trains will likely be very loud. The Bay Trail then travels in either direction, parallel to Airport Drive. The stretch from the bridge to the dead end seemed to be more of a connector route for cyclists than an enjoyable extension of the shoreline trail. If you continue on the perimeter trail instead of crossing the bridge, it ends a few hundred yards at a gravel road which is very bumpy. Once you get past the initial uphill stretch, the perimeter trail is level.

Accessibility: This trail is likely accessible with assistance for visitors using wheelchairs, mobility equipment, or strollers or visitors may need to avoid the steeper or unpaved sections for safety. 

Accessible Parking:
Parking lot surface: paved street parking.
There do not appear to be any designated accessible parking spaces within 1.0 miles of the trailhead.

Trail Details:
Trail surface: paved asphalt, gravel, a natural surface (dirt);
Average trail width: 6 feet;
Estimated average grade category: mostly gentle (5% or less) with steeper sections at about 1.7 and 2.1 miles when going clockwise.

name: Bay Area Ridge Trail, French Trail, Stream Trail, and East Ridge Loop
description:
This trail is an excellent destination for those seeking to avoid the summer heat, as it traverses a forest for the majority of its route. Along this route, you can enjoy a great variety of expansive views, including the city and sprawling forests with redwood groves.

The Old Tunnel Road Staging Area at the trailhead has limited parking. There are restrooms at the trailhead, and there are also restrooms near the Sibely Volcanic Regional Preserve parking lot as you continue up Skyline.

name: Penitencia Creek and Woodland Loop
description:
• Parking fee information: There is a fee to park at Alum Rock Park. For more information, please visit https://www.sanjoseca.gov/Home/Components/FacilityDirectory/FacilityDirectory/2088/2028

This route takes you around the Alum Rock Park area on a well-maintained trail with enjoyable incline changes. This 720-acre park features several picnic areas with Picnic tables, barbecue pits, water, and restrooms. The trail also meanders along the Upper Penitencia Creek, adding to the peaceful charm of the area.

name: Panhandle and Music Concourse Loop
description:
This is a loop along the Panhandle and Golden Gate Park, with the Music Concourse as a highlight at the 1.6 mile mark. Part of this loop is not accessible to bikes. 

Accessibility: 

Equipment
This trail is likely accessible for visitors using wheelchairs, mobility equipment, or strollers.

Parking
There are 4 designated van-accessible spaces with striped access aisles in the paved parking lot off Concourse Drive at the trail's west end. 

Surface
The trail surface is paved asphalt or concrete and smooth. It is typically at least 6 feet wide.

Grade
This trail is estimated to be gentle (3% or less).

name: Anniversary Trail
description: This short yet beautiful hike offers great views of the Open Space Preserve.

name: Stevens Creek Nature Trail to White Oak Trail Loop
description: This trail leads you to Monte Bello Open Space Preserve, winding through forests filled with old oak trees. It crosses streams via bridges and traverses open grasslands with beautiful views of the surrounding mountains. In the spring, the area features vibrant wildflowers. The trailhead offers parking and restrooms.

name: Old Mori Road Trail
description:
According to Access Northern California (http://accessnca.org/access-northern-california/explore/explore-detail-view/?site_id=203): Mori Point is a 105-acre promontory that lies between Sharp Park and Rockaway beaches and consists of coastal bluffs, coastal prairie, and freshwater ponds. When marsh restoration work took place here to help improve the habitat for the endangered San Francisco garter snake and the threatened red-legged frog, it also lead to the creation of an accessible level trail that stretches to the ocean. The network of other trails that course through the park mostly climb a gentle to moderate slope over bumpy terrain–manageable in a motorized wheelchair except for a very steep section that leads to the point. The park is bounded by Laguna Salada Marsh and Sharp Park Municipal Golf Course to the north; by Sweeney Ridge to the east; and by the Calera Creek Wastewater Treatment Plant to the south.

ACCESSIBILITY: There two are designated accessible parking spaces at the start of the trail in the Mori Point parking lot. There is also a wheelchair-accessible bathroom. The Old Mori Trail is basically a linear path to the ocean. The surface is asphalt or boardwalk and typically at least four feet wide. The estimated grade is mostly gentle (all 6% or less).

You’ll start out following alongside some housing but a tall wood fence blocks your view of it. After less than a half-mile you come to Lishumsha Trail on your left. This trail travels closer to the bluffs and in less than a quarter-mile rejoins Old Mori Trail by the ocean; it is more challenging but the views are worth the effort. 

If you stay on Old Mori you can meander around a native plant garden then cross a marsh on a boardwalk. Once at the ocean you can continue uphill to a levee trail that separates Sharp Park Golf Course from the ocean. From this elevated vantage point, you may spot pelicans skimming the water, shorebirds probing the sand and occasionally, sea lions. To the south another 0.5 miles is Pacifica Pier. Although this route requires careful navigation around the ruts and is quite bumpy, the sweeping views are worth the effort.

To extend your visit you could also connect via a sidewalk along Hwy 1 a short distance, to Calera Creek Trail. This paved 0.75 mile trail runs through restored wetlands to Rockaway Beach.

name: Lake Road and John Brooks Trail Loop
description:
Beginning from the Waterdog Lake South Trailhead, this trail explores Waterdog Lake Open Space and suburbia. Most of the trail is well-marked, but some turns are confusing, so keep an eye on your map. Along the way, there is a decent amount of shade, as well as trash cans, port-a-potties, and drinking fountains. 

In spring, visitors will be treated to a lovely display of wildflowers blooming, adding a splash of color to their surroundings. The final stretch leading back to the trailhead travels along suburban streets.

name: McCorkle Trail to Camp Ohlone Road Loop
description:
• Parking fee information: There is a fee to park at Sunol Wilderness Regional Preserve on weekends and holidays. For more information, please visit https://www.ebparks.org/parks/sunol

This trail begins at the parking lot off Geary Road, where restrooms are available. It winds through the forest and along Alameda Creek in Sunol Wilderness Regional Preserve. Near the top, you can see Del Valle and the lake. During the spring, you'll find beautiful wildflowers and butterflies. Be prepared for limited shade along the way.

name: Grizzly Flat Trail South to Canyon Trail
description: Stevens Creek County Park has an extensive network of multi-use trails through the coastal forest. This route starts from Skyline Boulevard and descends switchbacks east to Stevens Creek, ending at Stevens Canyon Road. The creek fosters waterfowl and other wildlife. Prepare for a steep climb back to the car.

name: Bear Gulch and Alambique Trail
description: This loop trail starts at the end of Alambique Road and leads into Wunderlich County Park via the Bear Gulch and Alambique Trails. At the trailhead, you’ll find a parking lot, restrooms, and the Folger Stable Historic Site with Carriage Room Museum. Parking can fill up quickly, so it's best to arrive early. The trail winds through beautiful redwood, oak, and madrone forests and meadows with lovely views. Keep an eye out for deer, rabbits, and other wildlife. Don’t forget to bring bug spray.

name: Winery Road and Saratoga to the Skyline Trail
description:
• Fee Information: Sanborn County Park charges a fee to enter. For more information, please https://parks.santaclaracounty.gov/locations/sanborn-county-park

Winery Road is a pleasant fire road that takes you on a gentle climb to the top of the ridge where Winery Road meets the Saratoga to the Skyline Trail. Saratoga to the Skyline will take you along shady trails to the very top of the ridge. This trail system continues to Haklone Gardens, almost all the way to the town of Saratoga! However, this hike returns you along a gentle grade to where you began.

name: Creekside Park at Cupertino
description: Creekside Park has family picnic areas, a half-court for basketball, two playgrounds, and paved paths around its perimeter. The scenic park is adjacent to Calabazas Creek, which hosts waterfowl and other wildlife. The creek is also lush with shade trees, which is necessary on a summer day in Cupertino.

name: Lonely Trail to Richards Road Loop
description:
• General fee: Huddart County Park charges a fee to enter. For more information, please visit https://www.smcgov.org/parks/huddart-park
• Partial Closure: A portion of this route, the entire Miramontes Trail, is closed until further notice. You can still enjoy other sections of this trail. For more information, please visit https://www.nps.gov/goga/planyourvisit/conditions.htm

This gravel surface trail is the only trail that travels from the top of the park to the bottom. The moderately challenging trail features Redwood, Madrone, and Oak trees. The towering trees offer plenty of shade and relief from the sun on a hot day. There are picnic tables and restrooms near the trailhead.

name: Black Mountain via PG&E, Quarry and Black Mountain Trail
park: Rancho San Antonio Open Space Preserve
description: This is a well-maintained trail with beautiful views. The trail is popular among both hikers and trail runners. This is a great trail for training since there are a lot of ups and downs and lots of elevation gain along the way. The trail can get hot in the summer, so bring plenty of water and sun protection.

name: High Meadow Loop via Coyote Trail
park: Rancho San Antonio Open Space Preserve
description: This trail starts with PG and E Trail and then follows Coyote Trail and High Meadow Trail. It has a gentle incline with good tree coverage. The trail is rich in wildlife, providing opportunities to spot deer and turkeys. At High Meadow Vista Point, you can enjoy amazing views overlooking the valley. A bathroom at the trailhead and one more available along the trail.

name: Matadero Creek Pedestrian Trail
description:
This route takes you on a pedestrian trail up the Arastradero Hill and back. You'll get beautiful views of the valley and the Santa Cruz mountains from the top of the hill. Wildflowers are abundant in late March-early April. Bikes are not allowed on this trail. 

Parking is limited at the beginning of the trail, but there is a small pull-off on Arastradero Road, and a small dirt parking lot across the street from the trailhead. You can also alternately start at the Coyote Hill Road entrance to this trail.

name: Little Yosemite, McCorckle Trail, and Vista Grande Overlook Loop
description:
• Parking fee information: There is a fee to park at Sunol Wilderness Regional Preserve on weekends and holidays. For more information, please visit https://www.ebparks.org/parks/sunol

It is a great hike with varying terrain and paths that keep you interesting. Along this loop, you will hike on: Cannyon View Trail, McCorkle Trail, Welch Creek Rd, Cave Rock Rd, Vista Grande Rd, and etc.The scenery is beautiful in all directions but there is rare shade, so bring a plenty of water and wear sun protection. There are so many overlooks where you can enjoy beautiful views but the main points of interest include these: Alameda Creek Overlook (Little Yosemite), Vista Grande Overlook, Flag Hill Summit. There are plenty of parking along the Geary Rd and bathrooms are available.

name: Toyon Trail and Fire Road Loop
park: Coal Mine Ridge Nature Preserve Of Portola Valley Ranch
description: The Toyon Trail and Fire Road Loop is a scenic path near Portola Valley, offering hikers a chance to explore this beautiful area. The trail meanders through diverse landscapes, including woodlands and open spaces, providing opportunities for wildlife viewing and enjoying the outdoors. The terrain is varied, with sections that may include gentle inclines and uneven surfaces, but there is a good amount of shade along the way, making it a great option on a hot day.

name: Rogue Valley, Chamise, and Mora Trail Loop
park: Rancho San Antonio Open Space Preserve
description:
This trail leads visitors on a steady climb up and along one side of the valley before crossing the West Branch Permanente Creek and heading back along the other side. The trail after Loyola Vista is an incredibly steep descent alongside a road.

This trail has almost no shade, so bring plenty of water and sun protection. Expect beautiful views, green meadows, wildflowers and lots of wildlife, such as turkeys, rabbits, deer, rattlesnakes, coyotes, and foxes.

name: Cottle Trail and Oak Cove Trail
description: Calero County Park is known for the Calero Reservoir, which is popular with both power and non-power vessels. The park also has nineteen miles of multi-use trails and dirt roads. This route traverses north-south on the east side of the park. The parking lot for Rancho San Vicente is the northern terminus and the start of the Lisa Killough Trail. The first half mile is private; follow the road for a half-mile until the junction with the trail. Most of this route allows access to the reservoir.

name: Portola Triangle Loop
park: Robert W. Crown Memorial State Beach
description:
The Robert W. Crown Memorial State Beach and Washington Park are central hubs for outdoor recreation in Alameda. The parks have athletic courts, playgrounds, a dog park, beach access, and trails that link both. This route includes a loop around Portola Triangle Park, Mariner's Lagoon, and the dog park.

Please note that dogs are only allowed on paved paths, lawns, and the dog park. This route does not allow dogs to walk along dirt paths or the beach.

name: California Coastal Trail
park: HikingBathrooms availableDog-friendlyGreat conditionsGreat viewsVery easy trail/bike path..easy walking with very nice views…lots of beach access and lots of dogs to seePark
description:
According to Access Northern California (http://accessnca.org/access-northern-california/explore/explore-detail-view/?site_id=91): Half Moon Bay, the oldest town in San Mateo County, lies along a gently curving, sandy shore that is protected as parkland. Stretching for nearly four miles north to south is Half Moon Bay State Beach, a wide expanse of beach and bluff that includes four beaches: Venice, Roosevelt, Dunes, and Francis, the most wheelchair accessible and most developed. Amenities at Francis Beach include blufftop camping, blufftop picnic tables overlooking the beach, and a small visitor center with displays about local wildflowers, birds, and animals, as well as local history. Beach access for a beach wheelchair is at Roosevelt and Francis Beaches (at the northwest corner of each).

The paved Coastside Trail runs for nearly 3.5 miles behind the beaches, from Mirada Road, one mile south of Pillar Point Harbor, to Poplar Street, 0.5 miles south of Francis Beach. Numerous benches along the trail offer unobstructed ocean views.

This heavily used multi-use trail runs along the eastern boundary of Half Moon Bay State Beach and provides good pedestrian access to all four beaches in the system, as well as the city-owned Poplar Beach, south of Francis Beach. The ocean is not always visible, but when it is you can see the crescent shape of the coastline that gives Half Moon Bay its name. For a lovely outing, you can combine this walk with a meal at one of several trailside cafes at the trail's north end by Magellan Road.

A horse trail parallels the Coastside Trail between Roosevelt and Francis Beaches. The park is open from 8 AM to sunset daily and there is a parking fee.

Accessibility: The route is accessible from any of the Half Moon Bay State Beaches and from Poplar Beach and there is plentiful firm accessible parking in any of the beach lots. There are wheelchair accessible bathrooms at Venice, Roosevelt, Dunes, and Francis Beaches and a porta-potty is in the Poplar Beach parking lot. A beach wheelchair is available for loan at the Francis Beach entry kiosk on a first-come, first-served basis. Chairs can be taken to the other beaches using your own vehicle. There are firm and stable accessible picnic tables with at least 27 inches of knee clearance at Francis and Roosevelt Beaches and along the Coastside Trail just north of Venice Beach.

The trail is paved, typically at least four feet wide, and mostly gentle (estimated 5% grade or less). From Poplar Beach, head south from the parking lot one-quarter mile to a bridge that crosses an outlet to the ocean. On the other side of the bridge, after passing through a small stand of cypress trees, the trail becomes hard-packed dirt and is very rutted. A sign indicates that this blufftop is Wavecrest, a 206-acre park set aside in part to serve as raptor wintering grounds. Although the terrain is very rough and not wheelchair accessible past 20 feet, the views are spectacular—plus, you might spot migrating whales (Nov.-Jan.) and raptors. Retrace your steps and continue north past Poplar Road - check out the view from the bluff at the foot of Poplar.

You will reach Francis Beach in about 0.8 miles, then cross the park entry road to continue along the trail, unless you want to stop in at the small visitor center (weekends only) or picnic on the bluffs. A sign indicates it is another 2.4 miles to the trail's end. The trail parallels the campground access road a short distance, then, once past the developed area, becomes quieter.

Next, you will cross Pilarcitos Creek on a long wooden bridge that's pretty bumpy. Housing is now closer to the trail and scrub obscures the ocean. Soon you will arrive at Venice Beach, where there is no wheelchair access to the beach. Continuing north a few hundred yards there is another extremely bumpy bridge. After crossing this, the trail briefly curves west and a picnic area comes into view, as does the ocean.

About 1.6 miles from Francis Beach you will arrive at Dunes Beach, then Roosevelt Beach. Beyond Roosevelt Beach, the surroundings are more residential. At Mirada Road, it may appear as if the trail ends, but continuing on traffic is sparse and moves slowly because of all the people. In a quarter of a mile, you will reach Magellan Avenue and can follow it a few hundred feet to another trailhead. This new trail travels on the bluffs through Mirada Surf, a 49-acre park that occupies one of the few remaining undeveloped coastal bluffs in the region. Signage indicates that it travels one-third of a mile north to Pillar Point Harbor.

name: Bohol Circle Loop
description: Bohol Circle Immigrant Park offers picnic areas, play areas, restrooms, and paved trails. The park is mostly pavement and offers gorgeous views of downtown Oakland and the Oakland Harbor. You can access the shoreline trail from here, heading east along the estuary. It can get hot here in the summer; bring plenty of water and sun layers.

name: Boccardo Loop Trail
description: Begin from the trailhead along Sierra Rd, there's parking for about 40 vehicles. The trail then heads down and loops through an open area with views of surrounding hills and San Jose. The second half of the hike is a climb back toward the trailhead. Be sure to bring water along since there is no shade.

name: San Andreas Lake Trail
park: HikingGood conditionsBathrooms availableNice trail but next to the freeway so a bit loud. Some shade mostly open.Park
description: A popular destination for joggers and mountain bikers, San Andreas Lake offers access to the paved section of the San Andreas Trail.

name: Dolores Park Loop
description:
Explore Dolores Park - see nice views of San Francisco from the top, and bring your kids along for the playground.

Accessibility: There are likely designated accessible spaces near the street parking lot off of Dolores Street at the east end of the trail, but it is unclear where the closest one is. The trail surface is paved concrete and smooth. It is typically at least 6 feet wide. 

The majority of the trail is estimated to be in the moderately steep (5-8%) and steep (8-12%) grade categories. Trail goers using wheelchairs/mobility equipment or strollers may need assistance along this entire route due to the consistent sections above a 5% grade (especially if using manual equipment). There are benches and picnic tables along the route for resting. There are some staircases in this park as well, but there are ramps available for alternate routes.

name: Los Trancos and Trapper Trail Loop
description:
• Foothills Nature Preserve charges an entry fee. An annual pass is also available for purchase. Dogs are not allowed on weekends or holidays. For more information, please visit https://www.cityofpaloalto.org/Departments/Community-Services/Open-Space-Parks/Neighborhood-Parks/Foothills-Nature-Preserve



Explore the wonders of Palo Alto Foothills Open Space. This hike loops through a mixed grassland and oak habitats. A wonderful afternoon outing for the entire family.

Take the Wild Horse Valley Fire Rd. to Fern Loop Trail to the Costanoan Trail to Lost Trancos to the Trappers Trail. Biking is currently only allowed on paved trails and roads in Foothills Nature Preserve, so it is not recommended to bring bikes on most of this trail.

name: May Trail, High Ridge Loop, Tolman Peak and South Fork Loop
park:
Portions of the trail flank a peaceful creek. Steep inclines give way to  at overlooks that have full 360-degree views of the park and cities nearby.

The hike begins at the Dry Creek staging area. Park
description:
• Partial closure: Part of this route is temporarily inaccessible, but you can still enjoy other sections of this trail. For more information, please visit https://www.ebparks.org/parks/garin-dry-creek
• Parking fee information: There is a fee to park at Dry Creek Pioneer Regional Park. For more information, please visit https://www.ebparks.org/parks/garin-dry-creek

This route offers scenic views of the surrounding region, as you traverse rolling grasslands and shady woods. Portions of the trail flank a peaceful creek. Steep inclines give way to  at overlooks that have full 360-degree views of the park and cities nearby.

The hike begins at the Dry Creek staging area. Park in the lot off May Road, next to the Meyers Cottage and Dry Creek Garden. Begin your hike on May Trail, proceeding through the entrance gate, another gate, and heading uphill. Continue straight past the next trail post to get on the High Ridge Loop Trail. After a third of a mile you will intersect with Tolman Peak Trail. Follow Tolman Peak Trail past a corral and through a cattle gate until it reaches South Fork Trail.

There are two creek crossings along the way. South Fork Trail will lead you down a narrow, shaded path that overlooks a creek. It then ascends rapidly and offers beautiful landscape views of Hayward, Oakland, and the Bay. At the top of the hill, there is a bench to take a break and soak in the view. South Fork Trail loops to meet Tolman Peak Trail again. Turn left onto Tolman Peak Trail and descend the grassy hills. Follow Tolman Peak Trail back the way you came, making a left onto High Ridge Loop Trail and another left onto May Trail back to the parking lot.

Park Hours: 8am to sunset (varies seasonally)
Fees: $5 per vehicle (when kiosk is attended); $4 per trailered vehicle, $25 per bus,
$2 per dog. Guide/service dogs free.

name: Sanborn Trail
description:
• Fee Information: Sanborn County Park charges a fee to enter. For more information, please https://parks.santaclaracounty.gov/locations/sanborn-county-park

Steep uphill. Beautiful scenery. Lots of variation in scenery and trails. Nice shade for nearly all of it.

name: PG&E, Upper Wildcat, High Meadow and Coyote Trail Loop
park: Rancho San Antonio Open Space Preserve
description: This trail takes you from the parking lot at the trailhead to Rancho San Antonio Open Space Preserve, located on the outskirts of San Jose. Most of the route is shaded, with some exposed rolling hills along the way. There are nice views across the bay and wildflowers during the spring. Keep an eye out for deer, turkeys, and other wildlife. Parking can be busy, so it's a good idea to get an early start.

name: Best trails inUvas Canyon County Park
park: Uvas Canyon County Parkbest Trails In Uvas Canyon County Parkall Photos Best Trails In Uvas Canyon County Park
description: Please note: You must have a reservation to access the park on the weekends. Parking is $6. It is possible to pay by credit card or cash using the automated machine at the entrance. Hours: 8 a.m. to sunset

name: Bay Area Ridge Trail: The Golden Gate Bridge to Marin Headlands
description:
This famous bridge span, dedicated in 1937, is one of the world’s most spectacular and visited sites. A trip by foot, bike, or wheelchair offers visitors an excellent opportunity to understand Bay Area geography and the route of the Bay Area Ridge Trail. The bridge can be windy and/or foggy, so wear layers.

For more information, see the Bay Area Ridge Trail site here: https://ridgetrail.org/golden-gate-bridge/

This trail description is excerpted from the 2019 Guidebook. For details on all of the Bay Area Ridge trails, trailheads and more buy the book from Wilderness Press: https://www.wildernesspress.com/product.php?productid=16685&cat=274&bestseller=Y

Accessibility: There is a wheelchair-accessible ramp leading from the Visitors Center on the south end up to the bridge entrance with handrails and a gentle slope. Once on the bridge, the path is paved with cement with steel sections, flat (estimated 1% grade or less), and typically at least 6 feet wide. There is a safety barrier protecting pedestrians and cyclists from motor vehicle traffic on the bridge. There is an infrequent painted center dividing line (reduces the width). There is a wheelchair-accessible bathroom with grab bars in a separate building across from the Visitor Center. There are at least 3 designated wheelchair-accessible parking spaces at either end of the trail.

name: Arastradero Creek and Acorn Trail Loop
description: Some of the trails in this loop are directional. Please follow posted guidance at the trailhead and on the trails!

name: Harvey Bear, Calaveras, Coyote Ridge and Willow Springs Loop
park: Coyote Lake Harvey Bear Ranch County Park
description: • Parking Fee: Coyote Lake Harvey Bear Ranch County Park charges a fee to enter, except at Mendoza Ranch and Harvey Bear Entrances. There are varying fees depending on if you enter by vehicle, motorcycle, foot, horse, or bike. Please visit https://parks.santaclaracounty.gov/locations/coyote-lake-harvey-bear-ranch-county-park

name: Old Trout Farm Loop Trail
description: Old Trout Farm Trail in San Pedro Valley County Park begins at the Trout Farm picnic area. The mostly level road takes you along the South Fork of San Pedro Creek. This is a good bird-watching area. A short climb at the end of the road takes you past the remnants of a residence from the trout farm days. You return to the picnic area through a forest of pine and eucalyptus trees.

name: Limekiln to Kennedy to Priest Rock Loop
description: Discover this 19.0-km circular trail near Los Gatos, California. Generally considered a challenging route, it takes an average of 6 h 27 min to complete. This is a popular trail for birding, camping, and hiking, but you can still enjoy some solitude during quieter times of day. The trail is open year-round and is beautiful to visit anytime.

name: PG&E, Wildcat Loop, and Lower Meadow Trail
park: Rancho San Antonio Open Space Preserve
description:
This trail takes you to Rancho San Antonio Open Space Preserve near San Jose. The first part is uphill and includes some steep sections. The second half offers a more relaxing descent, following a creek with small waterfalls. 
The trail is partly exposed and shady, providing great bay views.

It's recommended to wear proper hiking shoes and bring bug spray.

name: Harvey Bear, Willow Springs, and Townsprings Loop
park: Coyote Lake Harvey Bear Ranch County Park
description:
• Parking Fee: Coyote Lake Harvey Bear Ranch County Park charges a fee to enter, except at Mendoza Ranch and Harvey Bear Entrances. There are varying fees depending on if you enter by vehicle, motorcycle, foot, horse, or bike. Please visit https://parks.santaclaracounty.gov/locations/coyote-lake-harvey-bear-ranch-county-park

This is a lovely loop through grassy hills. Trail conditions can sometimes be overgrown with tall grasses or muddy. Keep an eye out for wildflowers in the late spring and early summer. Watch out for ticks, especially with dogs. The trail offers beautiful views, varying terrain, and some opportunities to spot wildlife.

name: Bay Area Ridge Trail: Mission Peak and Ed R. Levin County Park
park: Bay Area Ridge Trail: Mission Peak and Ed R. Levin County Park
description:
Climb through high grasslands past three lofty peaks that top a rugged ridgeline. You have views of rippling hills, tree-filled canyons, and bayshore marshlands from these exposed and often windy trails. You encounter some very steep segments in the final 4-mile descent to a pretty lake in a quiet valley. 

The side trip to Mission Peak’s summit is on a narrow, steep, and rocky trail; expect to see many people on their way to and from Mission Peak. Get an early start to do the climb before the day warms.

For more information, see the Bay Area Ridge Trail page here: https://ridgetrail.org/mission-peak-regional-preserve-and-ed-r-levin-county-park/

This trail description is excerpted from the 2019 Guidebook. For details on all of the Bay Area Ridge trails, trailheads and more buy the book from Wilderness Press: https://www.wildernesspress.com/product.php?productid=16685&cat=274&bestseller=Y

name: Quicksilver 50K
description: This is the route for the Quicksilver Running Club's 50k event. For more information. Please see https://www.quicksilver-running.com/races

name: Cemetery Overlook Path
description: The Presidio Landmark has a gorgeous loop trail that travels through oak forests and offers beautiful lake views. This route starts at a southern parking lot and travels north on the Park Boulevard Trail before heading west on the Cemetery Overlook Path. A junction with the Lobos Creek Valley Trail in a grove of eucalyptus and oak completes the loop.

name: Bedwell Bayfront Park
description:
A former landfill site, Bedwell Bayfront Park was created after the landfill was closed and capped off in the mid-1980s. The park opened to the public soon afterwards. Bayfronts hilly terrain, specifically designed for passive recreation, now serves as a landmark high point along the edge of San Francisco Bay.

Various development proposals have threatened the parks open space and wildlife, including development of a golf course and playing fields. These proposals have since been withdrawn or defeated by voters, and the park today remains as public open space.

name: Californio, Old Creek, Western Pacific, and Isla Tres Rancheros Loop
description:
• Parking fee information: There is a fee to park at Quarry Lakes Regional Park. Fees are collected on weekends and major holidays from April through October and only at the Redwood Gate entrance. For more information, please visit https://www.ebparks.org/parks/quarry_lakes/

This waterfront trail is flat and beautiful, featuring not only two lakes and a slough, but also a stroll through the fruit tree grove. The trail also passes many of the locations of interest in the park’s botanical scavenger hunt, as well as both the Volunteer Recognition redwood grove and the Bald Cypress Grove. If you want to see the trees fruiting, summer would be a good time to take this trail. However, if you come during spring or fall, you may be able to see the many migratory birds that rest in Alameda Creek, which is a stop along the Pacific Flyway.

Trail Description: From Isherwood Staging Area, head through the entrance gate and take Californio Trail to the right for about 0.4 miles; once on the trail, keep left to stay along the water. Turn left onto Old Creek Trail, following it straight for a short way, and then to the right, across the lake for about a half mile. Turn left on Western Pacific Trail and follow it for .36 mile. Turn left on Isla Tres Rancheros Trail to take the .72-mile loop walk through the rare fruit tree grove. You may wish to leave the trail and wander through the trees. When you are ready to return to Isherwood Staging Area, retrace your steps by turning right on Western Pacific Trail, then right onto Old Creek Trail. After .42 miles turn left, continuing on Wood Duck Trail, and then right onto Californio Trail back to the Staging Area.

Park Hours:  5am to 10pm, unless otherwise posted.

name: Canyon Trail, Indian Creek, Black Mountain
description: Enjoy this 16.8-mile loop trail near Cupertino, California. Generally considered a challenging route. This trail is great for mountain biking, and it's unlikely you'll encounter many other people while exploring. The trail is open year-round and is beautiful to visit anytime.

name: Senator Mine, Guadalupe, Mine Hill, and New Almaden Loop
description:
• Partial closure: As of June 2, 2025,  part of this route is temporarily inaccessible, but you can still enjoy other sections of this trail. For more information, please visit https://parks.santaclaracounty.gov/locations/almaden-quicksilver-county-park

This challenging route covers the entire northern perimeter of Almaden Quicksilver County Park. A mix of service roads and singletrack, the trail passes through forests and California chaparral, offering views of the Guadalupe Reservoir. Senator Mine Trail begins at Whispering Pines Drive. Take caution when parking along the road.

name: Rimer Creek Trail and Rocky Ridge Trail
description:
• Access information: All visitors must obtain a permit before hiking this area. For more information, please visit https://www.ebmud.com/recreation/buy-trail-permit/

A great, easy loop around the San Leandro Watershed that is perfect for those short on time. You'll hike up the Rimer Creek Trail, then connect to the Kings Canyon Loop trail for a short distance, and then return along the Rocky Ridge Trail. This hike is great for bird watching and features beautiful river views.

name: Best trails inHenry Cowell Redwoods State Park
park: Henry Cowell Redwoods State Parkbest Trails In Henry Cowell Redwoods State Park Best Trails In Henry Cowell Redwoods State Park
description: Henry Cowell Redwoods State Park is a state park near Santa Cruz, California that is beloved for it's old growth redwood groves that date back hundreds of years in addition to second-growth redwoods. Other old growth trees such as madrones, oak trees, Douglas fir, and ponderosa pine trees are also on display at this park, as well as iconic wildlife like banana slugs who make their home in this Northern California redwood forest. The Observation Deck Loop is a great place to view these big trees. The tallest tree in Henry Cowell State Park is about 285 feet tall, and about 16 feet wide. You can also see the John C. Fremont tree where Lt. Fremont camped while surveying for the US government prior to California statehood. The oldest redwood trees in the park are about 1400 to 1800 years old. With over 20 miles of hiking trails and a nature center, this Santa Cruz County park makes a great weekend trip from San Francisco or the Monterey Bay. Mountain biking is also super popular on the scenic trails in this park, and visitors can also visit the beautiful Garden of Eden swimming hole. Henry Cowell Redwoods State Park is near Felton on Highway 9 in the Santa Cruz Mountains. The Roaring Camp Railroad also goes through the park and is a delight for kids and adults alike. The Day Use Annual Pass is accepted at this park. Accessibility: Most of the aisles and exhibits in the Nature Center are wheelchair/mobility equipment and stroller accessible, except for the insect displays which have narrow aisles. There are five designated wheelchair accessible campsites and the campground toilets and showers are wheelchair accessible.
