For more accessible trails and facilities information, visit: http://access.parks.ca.gov/parkinfo.asp?park=165&type=0

name: Enriquita Trail to Providencia Pond
description:
• Partial closure: As of June 2, 2025,  part of this route is temporarily inaccessible, but you can still enjoy other sections of this trail. For more information, please visit https://parks.santaclaracounty.gov/locations/almaden-quicksilver-county-park

Almaden Quicksilver County Park has an extensive network of trails through the golden hills and oak woods. This route follows a wide dirt trail from Rimrock Drive, steadily climbing west until a high point at the junction with the Providencia Trail. Follow it to Providencia Pond and continue past the pond until the trail ends.

name: Promenade (All-Access) Trail
park: Promenade (All-Access) Trail is paved.Top trails nearbySawyer Camp TrailSawyer Camp TrailSan Francisco State Fish and Game Refuge4.7·Easy·18.7 km·Est. 3h 46mSugarloaf Hill and Captain Hook ViewpointsSugarloaf Hill and Captain Hook ViewpointsLaurelwood Park
description:
Accessibility:

Equipment
According to the park website, this trail is accessible for visitors using wheelchairs, mobility equipment, or strollers.

Parking
There are 10 designated accessible parking spaces with striped access aisles in the paved parking lot.

Surface
The trail surface is paved asphalt or smooth concrete and typically at least 14 feet wide.

Grade
This trail is estimated to be mostly flat (1% or less).

More Info
Benches are available along the route for resting.

name: Coyote Peak, Hidden Springs and Ohlone Trail Loop
description:
• Fee Information: Santa Teresa County Park charges a fee to enter. For more information, please visit https://parks.sccgov.org/plan-your-visit/santa-clara-county-park-fees#3925188384-3236192913

Come explore the beauty of Ohlone Trail in Santa Teresa County Park. This diverse 1,627 acre park, rich in history, offers spectacular views from its trails above the Almaden and Santa Clara Valleys.

The park is open year round from 8 a.m. until sunset. Vehicle entry fees are collected year-round. Fees are required to reserve the Pueblo Group Picnic Area. For green fees and and other information regarding the golf club, call (408) 225-2650.

The Ohlone trail is a part of a loop you can do from the Pueblo Picnic area. See map for details.

name: Upper San Leandro Reservoir Loop
description:
• Access information: All visitors must obtain a permit before hiking this area. For more information, please visit https://www.ebmud.com/recreation/buy-trail-permit/

Please note that this route uses several trails including: King's Canyon Loop Trail, Rocky Ridge Trail, Ramage Peak Trail, Redtail Trail, and MacDonald Trail. Hikers may also access this loop on the southern end at the Chabot Staging Area. Please also be aware that sections of this trail lead through cow grazing pastures.

All visitors must obtain a permit before hiking this area. More information here: https://www.ebmud.com/recreation/buy-trail-permit/

name: Golden Gate Park Polo Field Loop
description:
This is a gravel running loop around the polo field and stadium. 

Accessibility: There do not appear to be any designated accessible spaces in the paved parking lot off of Middle Drive West at the southwest end of the trail. There do not appear to be any designated accessible parking spaces within 1.0 miles of the trailhead. The trail surface is gravel. It is typically at least 8 feet wide. The whole trail is estimated to be in the flat (1% or less) grade category. All-terrain tires or motorized equipment may be needed for the surface type.

name: Toyon, Stevens Creek, Coyote Ridge, Seven Springs Loop
description: This loop trail offers beautiful views of the Bay Area and Stevens Creek Reservoir. The trail is mostly wide, but there are some narrow sections. There are lots of ups and downs along the way, and the trail has a good mix of sun and shade. You can enjoy gorgeous views from several lookout points, such as Hunter's Point, Inspiration Point, and Nob Hill. The trailhead is at Prospect Parking Area, a small lot.

name: Indian Joe Nature, High Valley, Welch Creek Road, Maguire Peaks
description:
• Parking fee information: There is a fee to park at Sunol Wilderness Regional Preserve on weekends and holidays. For more information, please visit https://www.ebparks.org/parks/sunol

PARK FEATURES: These lands have been ranching lands since the early 1800s. Today, camping, picnicking, hiking, backpacking, and equestrian trails attract thousands of visitors every year. Park naturalists lead programs to teach about the park’s special features. Cave Rocks provides a unique place to explore. Little Yosemite is a scenic gorge on the creek. Cattle also graze within this 6,859-acre wilderness.
 
TRAIL HIGHLIGHTS: This route provides a partially shaded trail that weaves back and forth along creeks as well as grassy hilltops with panoramic views. The Maguire Loop Trail offers views of the San Antonio Reservoir and Mt. Diablo. Restrooms are available at the parking area and at High Valley Camp. Visitors should bring plenty of drinking water. Water is only available at High Valley Camp and the staging area. 

TRAIL DIRECTIONS: From the Visitor Center, cross the footbridge and turn right onto Canyon View. Continue past Hayfield Road, cross the stream-bed, ascend a short hill to the left and turn left at next trail junction, Indian Joe Creek Trail. The trail traverses steeply up the canyon, with several stream crossings (in the rainy season). At the SO24 trail post, shortly past the large Cave Rocks, turn left on Cave Rocks Road and go .49 miles to High Valley Road. You’ll pass by High Valley Camp, a large barn, and water, restrooms, and picnic tables. Follow High Valley Road .41 miles, all the way to the paved Welch Creek Road, and turn right. Use caution, since this is a one-lane, two-way road with traffic and blind curves. Up the road you’ll see marker SO5; cross the creek and continue onto Upper Maguire Peaks Trail. Bear right at marker SO7 to access Maguire Peaks Trail, and right again at marker SO8 onto the Maguire Peaks Loop. Follow the loop trail for almost 3 miles back to marker SO8 for Maguire Peaks Trail. Turn right at SO8, continue to SO7 and turn right (straight) and continue to Welch Creek Road at SO6. Turn left on the road and proceed .18 miles to High Valley Road on the right. Follow High Valley Road past High Valley Camp and down Hayfield Road. At the bottom, you’ll reach the long footbridge over Alameda Creek where you started.

name: San Mateo Japanese Garden
description:
The Japanese Garden, in San Mateo Central Park, is one of the finest gardens in California. It was designed by landscape architect, Nagao Sakurai of the Imperial Palace of Tokyo, and features a granite pagoda, tea house, koi pond, and bamboo grove.

The Japanese Garden is beautiful throughout the year, but be sure to visit in the late Winter and early Spring when the cherry blossoms are in bloom. Sorry, no dogs are allowed in the Japanese Garden.

Hours of Operation:
Monday - Friday: 10:00am-4:00pm
Saturday & Sunday: 11:00am-4:00pm

Accessibility: 

Equipment
This trail is likely accessible for visitors using wheelchairs, mobility equipment, or strollers.

Parking
It is unclear whether designated accessible parking is available near the trailhead.

Surface
The trail surface is paved asphalt and is typically at least 8 feet wide.

Grade
This trail is estimated to be flat (1% or less).

name: Martial Cottle Park Loop
description:
The paved loop is gentle and easy for the whole family!

Accessibility: This asphalt and cement trail is estimated to typically range from 4 to 10 feet wide. The estimated grade is flat (all 1% or less). There is a painted center dividing line along the wider asphalt portions around the perimeter which reduces the width. There are at least 3 designated wheelchair-accessible parking spaces with access aisles at the large paved trailhead lot.

name: Mount Sutro to Twin Peaks
description:
• Partial Closure: Part of this route along the North Ridge Trail is temporarily inaccessible, but you can still enjoy other sections of this trail. For more information, please visit https://www.ucsf.edu/about/locations/mount-sutro-open-space-reserve
• Partial closure: Parts of the Twin Peaks Trail are subject to closure due to construction projects, but you can still enjoy other sections of this trail. For more information, please visit https://sfrecpark.org/634/Twin-Peaks-Trails-Improvement-Promenade-

Begin by making your way over Mount Sutro and then crossing Clarendon Ave. After this, you will cross North Peak and South Peak before traveling past Christmas Tree Point. There are great views of the city at several points. This area is a great place to enjoy the sights and sounds of the forest in the heart of San Francisco.

name: Senador Mine to Mine Hill Loop
description:
• Partial closure: As of June 2, 2025,  part of this route is temporarily inaccessible, but you can still enjoy other sections of this trail. For more information, please visit https://parks.santaclaracounty.gov/locations/almaden-quicksilver-county-park

The Senador Mine to Mine Hill Loop in Almaden Quicksilver County Park is a short drive from downtown Los Gatos and the city of San Jose. The trail offers great views of the Bay Area and Guadalupe Reservoir and is well-marked with gentle rolling hills.

Visitors can park at the Mockingbird Hill Lane entrance to access the trail. There is no parking at the McAbee entrance. Follow the New Almaden Trail to Cinnabar Trail, then head up Mine Hill Trail to Senador Mine Trail and back on Guadalupe Trail. Almaden Quicksilver County Park is the site of over 135 years of mining activities and encompasses over 4,000 acres. This is a popular park for wildflower viewing during spring.

name: Sweeney Ridge Trail via Sneath Lane
park: What are some of the facilities available for Sweeney Ridge Trail via Sneath Lane?-Park
description:
Explore the wonders of Sweeney Ridge. The Ridge Trail offers excellent views of the Pacific Ocean and the San Andreas Reservoir. Of the three different approaches to Sweeney Ridge, the gently ascending paved trail from Sneath Lane is the most forgiving. You may have to share the trail with an occasional cyclist, but you'll appreciate the views over the eastern side of the peninsula as you climb including the long expanse of San Andreas Lake.
 
On top of Sweeney Ridge, you can decide whether to hike north for just under a mile to the Nike missile base or to take a short walk to the Portola discovery site. The trailhead is located at the end of Sneath Lane which is accessed directly from Skyline Boulevard.

name: Best trails nearWindy Hill
description: Alang sa ubang mga dapit sa mao gihapon nga ngalan, tan-awa ang Windy Hill.

name: Chochenyo Trail to Tuibun Trail Loop
description: This route starts at Paseo Padre Pkwy and takes you around Coyote Hills Regional Park, 1,266 acres of marshland and rolling grassland-covered hills. The trail is mostly flat, with some nice views of San Fransico Bay. The marsh area invites several types of bird species, so keep your eyes out for wildlife.

name: Ewing Hill Loop
description:
• Parking fee information: There is a fee to park at Hidden Villa. For more information, please visit https://www.hiddenvilla.org/visit/plan-your-trip/
• Short-term closure: Hidden Villa is closed until August 5th, 2025, while summer camps are in session. For more information, please visit https://www.hiddenvilla.org/

This loop starts out alongside the creek, and there are some ideal places along the route to stop and let kids play a while. There's even a small waterfall for some extra excitement. The trail then leads up to Ewing Hill with a rewarding view, and then through Elephant Mountain (mostly thickets and bushes but still enjoyable) and back down to Hidden Villa.

Heads up, mountain lions are known to frequent the area.

name: Las Trampas Peak
description:
This loop passes through oak and bay forest, chaparral, and grassland, on its way to high grounds with great views.

No bicycles on the Chamise Trail or single-track segment of the Las Trampas Ridge Trail. Bicyclists wishing to ride to Las Trampas Peak must follow the Bollinger Canyon Trail uphill to the multi-use part of the Las Trampas Ridge Trail.

name: Leona and Pyrite Trail
park: Leona Canyon Open Space Regional Preserve
description:
• Partial Closure: Part of the Leona Trail near the Artemisia Trail is temporarily inaccessible, but you can still enjoy other sections of this trail. For more information, please visit https://www.ebparks.org/parks/leona-canyon 

Park Features: Nestled between hillside neighborhoods and Merritt College, Leona Canyon offers a 290-acre sanctuary to those seeking a quick and easy escape into nature. Dog owners and walkers alike adore this park due to its accessible location. With lush groves of trees hanging over the trails and creekside terraces, this park provides just the right amount of space to take a break from your day and breathe some fresh air. There are no developed facilities here and no water provided. Restrooms are available at Merritt College during class hours. Water and restrooms are also located at the Anthony Chabot Equestrian Center, 14600 Skyline Blvd. Park maps and a self-guided trail map titled “Local Indian Uses of Plants” are available at the Leona Canyon trailhead.

Trail Highlights: This route is “easy to moderate” because you can decrease
the distance to make it an easier challenge since it is not a loop trail. The entire hike is 4.28 miles, but you could skip the Pyrite Trail (which is steep and has some storm damage) and make this hike 2.68 miles instead. Halfway up, when the Pyrite Trail hooks right and levels out, you will find two clearings on the left that offer peaceful terraces for resting with overlooks of Leona Canyon. Whether you choose to take the Pyrite Trail or prefer an easier hike by staying on the Leona Trail, it is important to know that both trails are out-and-back routes – just retrace your steps to get back to the parking lot.

Trail Directions: This trail begins at Leona Canyon’s parking lot below Campus Drive. Enter the park and stay on the upper trail to the right to begin Leona Trail. Hike 1.34 miles until you reach the end of the trail at Merritt College. Turn around and hike .61 miles back to find the Pyrite Trail on your right. Take a right to begin the steep, but short, trail, which is .80 miles one way. Once you reach the EBRPD gate marking the park boundary line at the end of the trail, turn around to retrace your steps back to Leona Trail. Turn right here and make your way back to the parking lot.

Access is also available at Merritt College. The lot charges a fee and is unavailable on weekends. AC Transit #54 serves Merritt College weekdays only.

Park Curfew/Hours: 5 a.m. to 10 p.m. 

Fees: None

Website: www.ebparks.org/parks/leona

name: Bayview and Nike Loop
description:
• Parking fee information: There is a fee to park at Coyote Hills Regional Park. For more information, please visit https://www.ebparks.org/parks/coyote-hills

Gentle climbs, scenic bay views, and traces of American Indian heritage await at the west edge of Fremont, California. Coyote Hills Regional Park is a great place to introduce a friend to hiking.

Accessibility: This is the most accessible portion of the Bayview and Meadowlark Trail Loop https://www.alltrails.com/trail/us/california/bayview-and-meadowlark-trail-loop. There are 2 designated accessible spaces in the paved parking lot off of Patterson Ranch Road at the east end of the trail. Both of them are van-accessible with striped access aisles. The trail surface is paved asphalt with some bumps and cracks. It is typically at least 6 feet wide.

The most accessible portion of the trail is the northern loop in the first 2.5 miles. The majority of the trail is estimated to be in the mostly gentle (5% or less) grade category but there are steeper sections at about 1.0 and 2.0-2.2 miles when going counterclockwise. Trail goers using wheelchairs/mobility equipment or strollers may need assistance in the steeper sections or to avoid them for safety.

name: Los Trancos Loop Trail
description:
The San Andreas Fault runs nearly the length of the state. See it up close and personal. 

Most Bay Area residents have felt the earth move-quite literally. You probably know that the San Andreas Fault runs nearly the length of the state. But did you know that you can see the fault for yourself?

As you follow the lines of posts that mark the various fault breaks in the Los Trancos Open Space Preserve, you can find out what's happening when you feel that temblor underfoot. You may be surprised to see some of the effects of earthquakes in this otherwise tranquil Santa Cruz Mountain spot.

name: Borel Hill and Windmill via Ridge and Ancient Oaks Loop
description:
A short yet steep hike that offers panoramic views and pleasant trails through grassland meadows and oak woodlands. First, you'll travel to Borel Hill, a great spot to stop and check out some of the surrounding views. A few miles later, you'll have the option to stop atop the 2205-foot Mindego Hill. There are benches there, and side trails to check out the windmill. This loop starts and ends at the Russian Ridge trailhead off Skyline Ridge Road, but there are other access points available. 

This route travels along the Ridge, Alder Spring, and Ancient Oaks Trails to reach both windmills.

name: Marilyn Murphy Kane and Bernal Loop Trail
Rainbow Knoll and Hunter's Point via Seven Springs Loop
description: This enjoyable trail showcases the natural beauty of the Fremont Older Open Space Preserve. It explores a good mix of forests and open meadows. There is a lot of shade, but the exposed areas get hot. Bring a hat and plenty of water. The trail itself is composed of a dirt path that is rocky in parts and can be muddy in others. Enjoy the incredible views over the valley and across the bay.

name: Yerba Buena Trail to Los Huecos Trail Loop
description:
• Joseph D Grant County Park collects a day-use fee for vehicular entrance year-round. For more information, please see https://parks.sccgov.org/plan-your-visit/santa-clara-county-park-fees#3925188384-3236192913

This loop trail is especially beautiful in spring, with green grass everywhere and wildflowers full of bloom. There are many open areas along the way with views of rolling hills and San Jose. There's nearly no shade, so bring enough water and wear SPF. Grant Lake at the trailhead has a serene and scenic view.

name: Mine Hill Trail Loop
description:
This hike from Almaden Quicksilver County Park in southern San Jose tours the rusting remains of what once was one of the largest mercury-mining operations in the world. 

The Mine Hill region of the park includes English Camp, San Cristobal mine, a short section of mineshaft and the hulk of a large processing plant. 

At over 8 miles with substantial elevation gain, this is a rugged but satisfying hike into the history of the South Bay before it became famous as Silicon Valley.

The park includes over 37 miles of hiking trails, including 30 miles of equestrian trails and 16.6 miles of bike trails. All trails in the park are also open to pet owners to walk their dogs on leash. For more information visit: https://www.sccgov.org/sites/parks/parkfinder/pages/almadenpark.aspx

name: Ferry Building to Marina Green, Crissy Field, and Golden Gate Bridge
description:
See for yourself why San Francisco's waterfront attracts travelers from around the world. Water surrounds San Francisco on three sides, but the shoreline between the Golden Gate and Bay bridges gets all the attention. It's well deserved. 

Something charming or funky or eye-popping pops up every few yards along these miles and miles of San Francisco Bay beachfront. And the best way to see the waterfront is on an urban hike: a 10-mile out-and-back from the Ferry Building to the base of the Golden Gate Bridge. It's all flat, with fog and ocean breezes cooling you the whole way. You can also rent bicycles, and some ride across the Golden Gate Bridge to Sausalito and return via ferry.

name: Best trails inStevens Creek County Park
park: Stevens Creek County Parkbest Trails In Stevens Creek County Parkall Photos Best Trails In Stevens Creek County Park
description: Hours: 8 a.m. - sunset

name: Hickory Oaks, Long Ridge Road, and Peters Creek Trail
description:
The Long Ridge Trail passes through a sunny chaparral region with yerba santa, chamise, and manzanitas. The climb continues through a madrone, tanoak, live oak, and Douglas fir woodland. Before you reach the ridge, you will pass through grassy patches and sandstone stones. You'll be greeted with one of the most beautiful vistas in the South Bay.

The Peters Creek Trail offers a calm, shaded hike beneath the Douglas fir and live oak trees. A bridge crosses the stream, leading to grassy areas home to poison hemlock. After entering a forest, the trail resumes alongside the creek.

name: Little Yosemite via Camp Ohlone, Geary, Backpack and McCorkle Loop
description:
• Partial closure: As of September 2024, the McCorkle Trail is temporarily inaccessible between Cerro Este Road and Backpack Rad, but you can still enjoy other sections of this trail. For more information, please visit https://www.ebparks.org/parks/sunol
• Parking fee information: There is a fee to park at Sunol Wilderness Regional Preserve on weekends and holidays. For more information, please visit https://www.ebparks.org/parks/sunol

This loop takes you to Little Yosemite via Camp Ohlone Road, Gear Road, Backpack Road, and McCorkle Trail. You'll be traveling along Alameda Creek for the first leg of your journey. This route also passes by a spur trail that takes you to several backcountry campsites such as Cathedral, Eagle's Eyrie, and Sycamore.

name: Redwood Grove and Cowell Highlights Loop
description:
• General fee: Henry Cowell Redwoods State Park charges a fee to park at the day-use and campground areas. There are varying fees depending on if you enter by vehicle, motorcycle, foot, horse, or bike. For more information, please visit https://www.parks.ca.gov/?page_id=546


The hike winds through a breathtaking old-growth redwood forest. The wide pathways beneath the ancient forest canopy highlight the best that a redwood forest offers. You'll be rewarded with hundreds of tall trees, fairy rings, and burned-out trunks along the way. Keep an eye out for banana slugs on the trail during the winter.

One of the trail's highlights is the Redwood Family Circle, which comprises smaller trees growing in a circle around a tremendous old redwood. Continuing along, you'll pass The Giant, a massive tree more than 17 feet wide and 270 feet tall. As you progress, the trail features more tall trees, immersing you in the tranquil atmosphere of the forest. Another famous tree on the trail is the Phantom of the Forest, known for its uncommon albino white leaf.

name: Black Mountain via Orchard Glen, Page Mill Trail, and Canyon Trail
description: • Foothills Nature Preserve charges an entry fee. An annual pass is also available for purchase. Dogs are not allowed on weekends or holidays. For more information, please visit https://www.cityofpaloalto.org/Departments/Community-Services/Open-Space-Parks/Neighborhood-Parks/Foothills-Nature-Preserve

name: Purisma Creek, Craig Britton, Whittemore Gulch, and Borden Hatch Mill
park: Purisima Creek Redwoods Open Space Preserve
description: This great combination of trails is an adventurous route in Woodside, California, combining several different trails into one expansive experience. As you hike, you’ll traverse through lush redwood forests, open meadows, and be rewarded with stunning views of the Pacific Ocean and the Santa Cruz Mountains. The terrain varies from peaceful stretches to more challenging sections. Whether you're looking to enjoy the beauty of the forest or tackle a varied landscape, this trail offers it all. Depending on the season, there can be no running water, so make sure to pack plenty, and also have the map downloaded to help keep you on track.

name: Arrowhead Loop Trail
description:
Trails in the preserve are directional, so its a good idea to check posted guidance for updates at the trailhead. 

This pleasant route gives plenty of options to stop for a break or picnic. You'll also cross some interesting bridges along your route. This route takes you through an open area of rolling hills.

name: Coyote Creek Parkway
description:
• Partial closure: The Coyote Creek Trail is closed between Hellyer Park and Embedded Way due to flooding and swiftly moving water, but you can still enjoy other sections of this trail. For more information, please visit https://parks.sccgov.org/closures-updates

This is a multi-use paved path along Coyote Creek. It spans 15 miles between Anderson Lake County Park and Hellyer County Park. The trail switches sides of the creek a few times over wooden bridges. The equestrian trail is a parallel dirt track. There are numerous ponds and lakes along the way. Bring plenty of water and sun protection.

Accessibility: 

Equipment
Visitors using wheelchairs, mobility equipment, or strollers may need all-terrain tires or adaptive/motorized equipment for the surface type and grade.

Parking
There are 2 designated accessible spaces with striped access aisles in the paved trailhead lot.

Surface
The trail surface is asphalt, cement, and wooden bridge and is typically at least 7 feet wide. There is often a painted center dividing line along the path which reduces the width.

Grade
This trail is estimated to be mostly gentle (5% or less), with some steeper sections that may require assistance or need to be avoided.

name: Hidden Villa and Black Mountain
park: Rancho San Antonio Open Space Preserve
description: • Short-term closure: Hidden Villa is closed until August 5th, 2025, while summer camps are in session. For more information, please visit https://www.hiddenvilla.org/

name: Hidalgo Cemetery Via Wood Road Trail
description: Awesome views with some old historic sites along the way.

name: Percolation Pond Trail and Oka Ponds Loop
description: The Oka Ponds provide a scenic place for outdoor recreation and offer dirt paths that circle the wetlands of each pond. This route starts at the junction of Beethoven and East Mozart Avenue and uses the Mozart Pedestrian Floating Bridge to access the ponds. It continues counterclockwise on the Percolation Pond Trail and follows the perimeter of the wetlands.

name: Dusky-Footed Woodrat and Cordilleras Trails
description: This series of well-defined paths explore the hills throughout Pulgas Ridge Open Space Preserve. The first half of the loop climbs up towards the ridge and offers some views. The second half is more wooded. It is recommended to get an early start on the weekends, the parking lot is often full by 9 AM.

name: Best trails inReinhardt Redwood Regional Park
park: Reinhardt Redwood Regional Parkbest Trails In Reinhardt Redwood Regional Park Best Trails In Reinhardt Redwood Regional Park
description: Redwood Regional Park, part of the East Bay Regional Park District, is located in the Oakland Hills just a few miles from downtown Oakland in the San Francisco Bay Area. The main park entrance is located off of Redwood Road. The park is known for the old growth redwood forest that was once an extensive logging operation. This redwood forest is now the largest remaining natural stand of coast redwood in the East Bay. Hiking, trail running, mountain biking, and horseback riding, are popular activities in this park. There are several trail heads that access the park, including the Canyon Meadow Staging Area, Skyline Gate Staging Area, and the Redwood Gate Staging Area. Popular trails in the park include the East Ridge Trail and West Ridge Trail, which allow bikes, the stream trail, and the French Trail. The park has four picnic sites, several group overnight camping areas, and a children's play structure off of the Stream Trail from the Canyon Meadow staging area. The Chabot Space and Science Center is also located within the park. Redwood Regional Park is great for nature watching. The park is home to a variety of species, including some rare species, such as the golden eagle and common species like deer, raccoons, and squirrels.

The south end starts at Elena Road and ends almost a mile later at Taaffe Road. Paths continue across the road, snaking through the Los Altos neighborhood and are open to biking, hiking, and horse back riding.

name: Upper, Basin, and Black Rock Falls via Contour and Waterfall Loop
description:
• All day use requires a reservation. Please go to www.gooutsideandplay.org​ or call 408-355-2201 to make your reservation.​ There is also a fee to park. 

Three waterfalls in one hike! This loop takes you through Swanson Canyon along the aptly named Waterfall Loop Trail. You'll travel along the Contour Trail first encountering Upper Falls and Basin Falls. A short distance after these two falls, you'll see Black Rock Falls. You'll finish your trip by traveling along Swanson Creek and Canyon for the remainder of your trip.

name: Martin Luther King Jr. Shoreline Trail
park: Martin Luther King Jr. Shoreline Trail. description:
All the trails in this shoreline park are paved and suitable for people of any fitness levels. Bikes, strollers, wheelchairs and skaters are welcome on the Bay Trail. As with all EBRPD lands, dogs are not allowed in the marsh areas. They must be on a leash throughout this park (6-foot maximum). Restrooms and water are located at the Tidewater Boating Center as well as the Garretson Point staging area turn around point. 

Look for the paved Bay Trail to the left of the Tidewater Boating Center parking lot. Follow the trail to the left along the Oakland Estuary. As you cross over East Creek Slough bridge, stay to the right and you will continue on the Damon Marsh Creek trail. Stay along the shoreline and the second bridge you will cross will be over Lion Creek. Stay right. In .5 miles you will reach Garretson Point parking area. This is your turn around point. Restrooms, water and a picnic area are around the corner of the Garretson Point parking area.

Accessibility: This asphalt and cement trail is estimated to typically be at least 6  feet wide. The slope is estimated to be gentle (3% grade or less) except for a steep section (8 - 12%) at about 1.5 miles when going south. Assistance may be needed there for wheelchair/stroller users. There are 6 designated wheelchair-accessible parking spaces with access aisles at the large paved trailhead lot on the north end. There are benches along the way for a rest.

name: Sanborn Skyline Park to Castle Rock State Park
park: Sanborn Skyline Park to Castle Rock State Park
description:
• Fee Information: Sanborn County Park charges a fee to enter. For more information, please https://parks.santaclaracounty.gov/locations/sanborn-county-park

This trek takes the best trails at two great parks along Skyline Boulevard southwest of Silicon Valley. 

Start out in the lush redwoods of Sanborn Skyline County Park southwest of San Jose, climb to Skyline Boulevard (Highway 35) and cross over to Castle Rock State Park, where it takes the popular Saratoga Gap Trail and returns to Sanborn Skyline. 

The views of the Santa Cruz Mountains are awesome at Castle Rock. On your way back, check out Indian Rock, just off the Skyline Trail, it's one of many fascinating formations along this route.

Trails on this hike: 

First leg from Sanborn Skyline: Sanborn Trail to the top of the ridge near Highway 35 and Skyline Trail until you see the crossing to Castle Rock State Park.

The second leg from Castle Rock: Saratoga Gap Trail to Trail Camp and Service Road to Loughry Woods Trail and Cross Highway 35

Third leg: Skyline Trail back to Sanborn Trail and San Andreas Trail back to the parking lot at Sanborn Skyline Park.

name: Maguire Peaks Trail
description:
• Parking fee information: There is a fee to park at Sunol Wilderness Regional Preserve on weekends and holidays. For more information, please visit https://www.ebparks.org/parks/sunol

Located in the northwest corner of Sunol Regional Wilderness, Maguire Peak is one of the least visited area in this popular hiking ground. This easy hike provides great solitude and nice views on San Antonio Reservoir for hikers. If you are lucky enough, you might be able to see the herd of Tule Elks wandering somewhere near the reservoir. The trail starts at the 1.28-mile marker on Welch Road (5 to 6 cars can park there). A couple more cars can park at 1.5 miles where Flag Hill road starts. The elevation gain is only 600 feet if you stay on the proper Maguire loop trail.

name: Poison Oak Valley to Saddle Trail
description: This route takes you around the Sugarloaf Mountain Open Space area. It features challenging elevation changes and steep climbs that provide stunning valley views. The route is half-shaded and half-exposed, making for a nice mix of terrain. It can be challenging to navigate, so it is recommended that you download the route beforehand.

name: Vista to Valley View to Sky Trail
description: This marvelous trail explores a lovely part of Heintz Open Space Preserve and Santa Rosa Open Space. It features a few steep sections, which are balanced by fantastic views.  Watch for the abundant poison oak and foxtails along the edges of the trail. There are bathrooms halfway along the route at Belgatos Park.

name: Long Ridge Loop
description:
This hike wanders through a little valley to the headwaters of Peters Creek and then out onto a ridge with striking views almost to the coast. As you move up towards the headwaters, the valley changes from cool and mossy to slightly drier forest, finally reaching one of the few lakes in the Santa Cruz Mountains, a man-made reservoir. The trail goes across the dam (and borders private property, please be respectful).

Leaving the lake, you climb up some switchbacks eventually reaching the preserve's namesake Long Ridge with open views to the southwest, towards some of the biggest redwood parks of the Santa Cruz Mountains. Soon you reach a granite bench dedicated to Wallace Stegner, the Stanford author and conservationist who played an important role in helping save many of these lands from development. In early spring the hillsides can be covered in a profusion of wildflowers.

Just after the bench, the trail forks, one fork seemingly leading along the ridgeline and the other dropping into the forest. The ridgeline trail only goes about 50 yards before running into a 'private property' sign and a fence, so down into the forest you go. From here you wind down towards your start; reaching a 4-way intersection in the middle of the forest. This route goes forward across the intersection, but you can also do a switchback heading down towards the Peters Creek Trail here.

Wander through the quiet forest until a descent drops you back to Peters Creek, and a short ascent back to the noise and bustle of Highway 35.

name: Goat Rock Overlook and High Point via Ridge Trail
description:
• General fee: Castle Rock State Park charges a day-use fee to enter. For more information please visit https://www.parks.ca.gov/?page_id=538

The Ridge Trail is a beautiful singletrack trail that undulates through the dense oak forest to the popular Goat Rock Overlook. It then continues north of the Goat Rock Trail to another unnamed high point with beautiful views. Since most are headed to Goat Rock, there's a chance you will have the second view to yourself.

The inclines can be a challenge and are pretty steep.  When you get to the ridge if it is sunny you will be rewarded with views of the San Francisco Bay on one side and the Pacific Ocean on the other.  If it is not sunny it is still enjoyable and the fog lends quite a bit of solitude to the hike.  There is a monument along the way that commemorates the first time the Spanish saw the Bay (Portola Monument).  The trail can be a bit muddy in spots and there isn't any shade but it's usually pretty breezy up there due to its proximity to the Pacific Ocean.

description: Explore this 11.6-mile point-to-point trail near San Francisco, California. Generally considered a moderately challenging route, it takes an average of 4 h 7 min to complete. This is a very popular area for hiking, running, and walking, so you'll likely encounter other people while exploring. The trail is open year-round and is beautiful to visit anytime.

name: Grizzly Trail Short Loop
description: This is a short and scenic loop through the coastal oak forest of Upper Stevens Creek County Park. It starts from Grizzly Flat Trailhead and begins on a descent, leading in a clockwise loop on the Grizzly Flat Trail North and South. A trail intersection is at the bottom of the hill, with access to other trails in the park.

name: Bear Gulch, Alambique, Meadow and Madrone Trail Loop
description:
Commencing on the single-track Bear Gulch Trail, there are resting benches en route. The trail gently climbs through a mixed forest of California Bay, Douglas fir, tan oak, and madrone trees. The trail has tall bushes such as California coffeeberry, poison oak, and coyote bush.

Benches are along the unpaved Alambique Trail, which winds through several mixed woodlands. As you climb, you will see redwoods, California coffeeberry, California hazelnut, coast live oak, and Douglas fir.

The Meadow Trail offers a distinctive hike through "The Meadows" and features several benches and a vista point with views of half of San Francisco Bay to the south. This trail is surrounded by dense forest and offers expansive, picturesque views. Lastly, the Madrone Trail provides a peaceful rest area amidst the trees along the winding, narrow trail.

description:
• General fee: Mount Madonna County Park charges a fee to enter. For more information, please visit https://parks.sccgov.org/plan-your-visit/santa-clara-county-park-fees
