name: The Embarcadero to Fisherman's Wharf
park: Golden Gate Bridge4.6·Easy·11.0 mi·Est. 3h 23mPanhandle and Music Concourse LoopPanhandle and Music Concourse LoopGolden Gate Park4.6·Easy·3.7 mi·Est. 1h 8mBay to Breakers Course RouteBay to Breakers Course RouteGolden Gate Park4.7·Moderate·7.5 mi·Est. 2h 30mThe Embarcadero to Oracle Park and McCovey CoveThe Embarcadero to Oracle Park and McCovey Cove4.6·Easy·2.9 mi·Est. 51mRincon Park to Crissy FieldRincon Park to Crissy FieldGolden Gate National Recreation Area4.7·Easy·10.4 mi·Est. 3h 9mFilbert Steps to Telegraph HillFilbert Steps to Telegraph Hill4.6·Moderate·0.5 mi·Est. 25mUpper Fort MasonUpper Fort MasonFort Mason4.5·Easy·2.1 mi·Est. 45mBarbary Coast Trail Barbary Coast Trail 4.5·Easy·4.2 mi·Est. 1h 28mLyon Street Steps and Palace of Fine ArtsLyon Street Steps and Palace of Fine Arts4.7·Moderate·1.7 mi·Est. 48mMarina GreenMarina Green4.5·Easy·1.1 mi·Est. 19mSalesforce Park LoopSalesforce Park LoopSalesforce Park
description:
The Embarcadero, which traces San Francisco's eastern shoreline, memorably demonstrates the good that can come from a natural disaster. After the 1989 earthquake, the old freeway was torn down, replaced by a breezy, beautiful promenade. Now you can stroll along the waterfront, past redeveloped piers, all the way to Fisherman's Wharf.

Accessibility: There are designated accessible spaces in the paved parking garage off of The Embarcadero at the southeast end of the trail. All of them are van-accessible with striped access aisles. The trail surface is paved (with partial railings) and smooth. It is typically 4 to 8 feet wide with some wider passing spaces. There are metal bollards along some of the trail which reduces the width temporarily. 

The entire trail is estimated to be in the gentle grade category (3% or less). This trail will likely be navigable for most wheelchairs/mobility equipment or stroller users. There are benches and picnic tables along the route for resting. There are wheelchair-accessible bathrooms along the trail.

name: Tony Lookout, Hayfield and Coyote Ridge Trail Loop
description: Mountain bikers be aware: you are not allowed to bike this entire trail. The first part, close to the reservoir, is for hikers only. Please stay on Steven's Canyon Rd until you pass the reservoir on your left. Then at the Madrone Group Area you will find the Outlook Cut Off Trail which will rejoin with the Lookout Trail and the route on this map that you can share with hikers.

name: Candlestick Point
park: The landscape makes it easy to forget you're in a former industrial zone yet in the background there's Candlestick Park
description:
Candlestick Point: A study in recovery, and urban retreat. At the easily accessible Candlestick Point State Recreational Area, visitors can enjoy panoramic views of the San Francisco Bay, the East Bay Hills, San Bruno Mountain, and downtown San Francisco. 

The entire trip is kid-friendly and on a combination of both paved and well-graded dirt paths. Along the parking areas are a number of access points.

There are several unique features to this park. For one, it's very easy to get to. It's also an experiment in urban recovery. The park is generally on contoured landfills, mounds and vegetation seem designed to provide a wide variety of scenic vignettes, and it's an interesting fusion of grasslands, wetlands, beaches, lawns, and fishing piers, with just a smattering of remnant industrial remains. The landscape makes it easy to forget you're in a former industrial zone yet in the background there's Candlestick Park and Hunters Point Shipyard, making for an interesting contrast. 

Bring along some snacks and pack something warm and wind-resistant, just in case. The park offers a retreat from metropolitan congestion and the opportunity to relax in the peaceful scenery. The location on the shoreline of San Francisco Bay provides a variety of recreational opportunities that include windsurfing, fishing, bird watching, cycling, roller-blading, walking, and picnicking. Individual and group picnic sites, as well as fishing piers and other outdoor activities not easily available in the city, offer a get-away of open space. 

Candlestick Point SRA was the first state park in California developed to bring state park values into the urban setting. Several stories are told of where the point got its name. 

The earliest reference dates from the Spanish DeAnza expedition in 1781 noting a candlestick-shaped rock pinnacle on the point. The point was also referenced in a U.S. Geodetic Survey in 1869. The rock disappeared around 1920.

The more romantic story is that the area was used to burn old and abandoned ships during the early settlers' days. When the wooden ships were burned off the point, the last part sinking into the water resembled a candlestick. 

Another story is that the point was a local hunting ground named after the candlestick bird, the chicken-sized long-billed Curlew known for its delicious meat that was nearly hunted to extinction by the 1950s.

During World War II, Candlestick Point was expanded by 170 acres of fill into the San Francisco Bay to build a shipyard for the Pacific War effort. After the war, the landfill remained and became both a local sewer and garbage dump. Shortly after, the football stadium was built in an effort to halt the blight and move the New York Giants to San Francisco.

On the bayside of the stadium grounds, the abandoned fill sat without purpose but in 1977, the California Legislature voted to develop the land as a state park -- the first urban state recreation area.

Accessibility: There are 4 designated accessible spaces in the paved parking lot off of Donnor Avenue at the west end of the trail. All of them are van-accessible with striped access aisles. The trail surface is paved asphalt or gravel. It is typically at least 6 feet wide. 

The whole trail is estimated to be in the gentle (3% or less) grade category. Trail goers using wheelchairs/mobility equipment or strollers may need assistance in the gravel sections or to avoid them for safety after rain. It is easy to stay on the asphalt paths. There are benches and picnic tables along the route for resting.

name: Mystery Spot
description: Experience this 0.6-mile loop trail near Santa Cruz, California. Generally considered a moderately challenging route, it takes an average of 21 min to complete. This is a popular trail for birding, hiking, and walking, but you can still enjoy some solitude during quieter times of day. The trail is open year-round and is beautiful to visit anytime.

name: Frog Lake Loop Trail
description:
• Henry W. Coe State Park charges an entrance fee. For current rates please visit: https://www.parks.ca.gov/?page_id=561

Henry Coe State Park is all peaks, ridges and valleys, and its reputation for arduous treks is well deserved. Frog Lake Loop is the one shining exception. 

While the hike starts with a 400-foot ascent and continues with a knee-crunching 600-foot descent, the return leg is serene by Henry Coe standards. The midpoint is Frog Lake, a great place to watch for wildlife and listen for the trademark knock of the acorn woodpecker.

Frog Lake Loop is bound to inspire users for further forays into the wilds of Henry Coe. Just bear in mind this is one of the easiest routes in the park. 

Best time to go: Springtime, when the wildflowers are in bloom, and October/November, after the heat of summer has departed. Winter can get too muddy, and summer can be too hot.

name: El Corte de Madera Outer Loop
park: El Corte De Madera Creek Open Space Preserve
description: This great loop explores the outer rim of California’s El Corte de Madera Creek Preserve features redwood groves, fern-lined creeks, and rugged terrain. The trail is shaded the entire way, making it a great spot on a hot day. The trail moderately strenuous due to rocky/rooted paths and steep sections and is popular with mountain bikers. Fog and mud common on trail, but that is made up for with solitude and beautiful forested vistas throughout.

name: Rocky Ridge and King's Canyon Loop
park: Moderate·East Bay Municipal Utility District Lands (EBMUD)10.5kmLength280mElevation gain2h 49mEstimated timeLoop10.5kmLength280mElevation gain2h 49mEstimated timeLoopExplore the Beauty of Upper San Leandro Reservoir. This location offers excellent views and sense of being fully immersed in a natural setting. The trails connect to Anthony Chabot Regional Park and Redwood Regional Park
description:
• Access information: All visitors must obtain a permit before hiking this area. For more information, please visit https://www.ebmud.com/recreation/buy-trail-permit/

Explore the Beauty of Upper San Leandro Reservoir. This location offers excellent views and sense of being fully immersed in a natural setting. The trails connect to Anthony Chabot Regional Park and Redwood Regional Park.

Start on the Rocky Ridge Trail, then continue to the King's Canyon Loop Trail.

name: Wood Road, Castillero Trail, Mine Trail Loop
description:
The trail begins on Wood Road, an old gravel road that gently ascends through the forest to the summit of Jaques Ridge. You will occasionally see the Sierra Azul and the tall peaks of the Santa Cruz Mountains. As you continue, the trail drops into the valley. 

You will reach the old Mine Hill Furnace remains. This section of the trail winds across hills, with sporadic views of deer. After passing the furnace, the trail ascends a steep hill to reach the Castillero Trail. This last stretch features a steep climb from the mining furnace site and a broad vista.

name: Las Trampas Ridge Trail to Del Amigo Trail
description: The Las Trampas Ridge Trail to Del Amigo Trail offers a scenic hike through the rolling hills and oak woodlands just East of the Bay area. Starting from the Elworthy Trail, you'll ascend through lush, green terrain, with panoramic views of the surrounding valleys and distant hills. As you connect to the Del Amigo Trail, the trail continues to wind through open meadows and forested areas, providing a peaceful outdoor experience. This trail is ideal for those looking to immerse themselves in nature, with the added bonus of sweeping views and peace and quiet.

name: Rancho San Vicent North Ridge Trail
park: Rancho San Vicente Open Space Preserve
description:
Discover Rancho San Vicente Open Space Preserve with this fantastic trail. 
The route begins from the Rancho San Vicente Entrance Parking Lot and winds through the beautiful open landscape. There is no shade along this path, so staying hydrated and protecting yourself from the sun is essential. The views throughout this trail are beautiful, with vistas of the surrounding rolling hills and valleys.

name: Los Gatos Creek Trail: Main Street to Vasona Lake
description:
• Seasonal closure: Vasona Lake County Park is subject to seasonal closure during the wintertime and wet weather due to weather conditions. For more information, please visit https://parks.sccgov.org/closures-updates

This is a scenic section along the Los Gatos Creek Trail. The route starts from a public parking lot on Main Street in downtown Los Gatos and heads north along the paved path to Vasona Lake County Park. There are several shady sections, and the trail is close to Los Gatos Creek, which hosts various waterfowl.

Accessibility:

Equipment
This trail is likely accessible for visitors using wheelchairs, mobility equipment, or strollers.

Parking
There do not appear to be any designated accessible parking spaces near the trailhead, but there are several designated accessible spaces available in the Oak Meadow parking lot by the trail's north end.

Surface
The trail surface is paved asphalt and typically at least 8 feet wide. A painted dividing line along most of the trail reduces the width.

Grade
This trail is estimated to be mostly gentle (5% or less).

More Info
Accessible restrooms are available in Oak Meadow Park. Benches are available along the route for resting.

name: San Andreas and Nature Trail Loop
description:
• Fee Information: Sanborn County Park charges a fee to enter. For more information, please https://parks.santaclaracounty.gov/locations/sanborn-county-park

This is an almost entirely shaded trail loop through a redwood and oak forest that crosses Aubrey Creek and passes Walden Pond. Newts can be seen in the ponds and creeks in the winter, and they can even be spotted crossing paved trails so keep an eye out.  Wildflowers can be seen along the trail as well. This trail pops out a few times into the woodlands for a quick peak at some views before heading back down into the cool, shady, towering Redwoods. 

Bathrooms are available near the Sequoia parking lot.  Picnic tables are in many spots near all parking lots. Family friendly walk-in camping is available nearby off of the Sanborn Trail.

Almost all of the trails in Sanborn allow dogs on a leash, but a section of this trail does not allow dogs.

name: Aquinas Trail
description:
• Access information: A permit is required to recreate at El Sereno Open Space Preserve. For more information, please visit https://www.openspace.org/where-to-go/permits

The Aquinas Trail can be accessed from the parking lot at the end of Montevina Road, leading into El Sereno Open Space Preserve. The parking area at the trailhead is small, so arriving early is recommended. The trail features exposed areas with no shade and narrow, steep sections with rocky terrain. Along the way, you’ll find a couple of benches for rest stops. Your effort will be rewarded with sweeping views of the hills, South Bay, and surrounding mountains.

name: Thornton Beach Trail
park: HikingGood viewsEasy to parkNot crowdedwinding trails along the shore with pretty flowersShow activityHit the trail Frequently asked questionsWhat are some of the facilities available for Thornton Beach Trail?Park
description: A gorgeous stretch of sandy beach this walk offers scenic views of the Pacific Ocean.

name: Best trails inPalo Alto
park: Explore one of 20 easy hiking trails in Palo Alto or discover kid-friendly routes for your next family trip. Check out some trails with historic sights or adventure through the nature areas surrounding Palo Alto that are perfect for hikers and outdoor enthusiasts at any skill level.Top trails1#1 - Redtail Loop to Arastradero Creek Loop4.6(2181)•Moderate•5.1 mi•Est. 2h 12mPearson Arastradero Preserve
description:
Looking for the best hiking trails in Palo Alto? Whether you're getting ready to hike, bike, trail run, or explore other outdoor activities, AllTrails has 33 scenic trails in the Palo Alto area. Enjoy hand-curated trail maps, along with reviews and photos from nature lovers like you.

Explore one of 20 easy hiking trails in Palo Alto or discover kid-friendly routes for your next family trip. Check out some trails with historic sights or adventure through the nature areas surrounding Palo Alto that are perfect for hikers and outdoor enthusiasts at any skill level.

name: Chabot to Las Trampas via Ramage Peak
description:
• Access information: All visitors must obtain a permit before hiking this area. For more information, please visit https://www.ebmud.com/recreation/buy-trail-permit/

All visitors must obtain a permit before hiking this area. More information here: https://www.ebmud.com/recreation/buy-trail-permit/

name: Bay Area Ridge Trail: Sierra Azul Open Space to Mt Umunhum Summit
description:
The Mount Umunhum Trail provides an opportunity to experience the mountain’s ecosystem before arriving at the 3,456-foot summit. Most of the well-graded uphill trail is in a bay, oak, and madrone woodland with sections opening up to fantastic views of the Santa Clara Valley. The summit provides unparalleled views of the Bay Area and the ocean, and an opportunity to learn about the mountain’s cultural and natural history through numerous interpretive panels. Be prepared for extreme temperatures and wind on the summit! Starting from the Jacques Ridge parking lot is a much longer and more challenging route.

This trail is 16.4 miles if you hike it out and back.

For more information, see the Bay Area Ridge Trail page here: https://ridgetrail.org/sierra-azul-open-space-preserve-mount-umunhum/

This trail description is excerpted from the 2019 Guidebook. For details on all of the Bay Area Ridge trails, trailheads and more buy the book from Wilderness Press: https://www.wildernesspress.com/product.php?productid=16685&cat=274&bestseller=Y

name: Coyote Creek Trail
description:
• General fee: Hellyer County Park charges a fee to enter. For more information, please visit https://parks.sccgov.org/santa-clara-county-park-fees
• Partial closure: The Coyote Creek Trail is closed between Hellyer Park and Embedded Way due to flooding and swiftly moving water, but you can still enjoy other sections of this trail. For more information, please visit https://parks.sccgov.org/closures-updates

This is a pleasant paved trail for walking, running, and cycling which meanders along creeks, lakes, and ponds. The park offers seasonal fishing.

Accessibility: There is 1 designated accessible space in the paved parking lot off of East William Street at the northwest end of the trail. It is van-accessible with striped access aisles. There are 2 designated accessible spaces in the paved parking lot off Eagle View Drive at the southeast end of the trail. Both of them are van-accessible with striped access aisles. 

The trail surface is paved asphalt and smooth. It is typically at least 8 feet wide. There is a painted dividing line along most of the trail which reduces the width. The majority of the trail is estimated to be in the mostly gentle (5% or less) grade category but there are steeper sections at about 1.5, 6.2, and 6.7 miles when going southeast. Trailgoers using wheelchairs/mobility equipment or strollers may need assistance in the steeper sections or to avoid them for safety. There are benches along the route for resting.

name: Byxbee Art Hill
description:
According to Access Northern California (http://accessnca.org/access-northern-california/explore/explore-detail-view/?site_id=178): The Baylands Nature Preserve, said to be the largest salt marsh preserve on the Bay, encompasses nearly 2,000 acres protected for wildlife, including the endangered clapper rail and salt marsh harvest mouse. The preserve contains a duck pond (formerly a saltwater swimming pool); tidal and freshwater marshes; a sailing station for windsurfers and hand-carried, non-motorized boats; and almost 15 miles of trails, all of which have some wheelchair access. Although quite a few of the trails are along roads or in built-up areas, many are close to attractive sloughs where a wide variety of birds can be seen even without binoculars, and some are out in the marshlands, where a flock of sandpipers or a lonely blue heron may be your only company.

Jackrabbits are frequently seen in the restored wildlands above the high-water line, where gray foxes and burrowing owls are said to breed. But within the preserve you'll also find a sewage treatment plant, an airport, and a former landfill for the city of San Francisco, which is now a grassy garbage mountain named the Bixby Art Hill, home to several very understated pieces of public art. Highway 101 is nearby, as is Palo Alto's golf course.

The difficulty rating for this trail is based on the experience that a wheelchair or stroller user may have due to the gravel surface.

Visitor center: A quarter-mile down the road from the duck pond is the Lucy Evans Baylands Nature Interpretive Center. Inside are displays about the wildlife you might see at the preserve and an ecology laboratory where visitors can prepare their own slides and examine them under microscopes. The microscopes are on a 25-inch-high shelf, but a video microscope that projects slides onto a monitor permits easier viewing. The center also offers videos, nature walks, and a variety of natural history programs for children and adults. On the wooden deck surrounding the nature center, use the low-mounted telescope to zoom in on shorebirds and waterfowl. A long boardwalk extending from the center across Harriet Mundy Marsh may be closed for major renovations. Located at 2775 Embarcadero Road, 650-329-2506.

ACCESSIBILITY: This maze of trails, artistically surfaced with oyster shells, meanders over the garbage mountain; all are considerably steeper than 5% grade (up to 12% in some places) but may be manageable in a strong power chair. In addition to the sense of accomplishment, if you make it to the top, you can get a closer look at the art pieces installed by landscape architects.

There is designated accessible parking (van accessible), firm, and level or slope no greater than 2% at the Adobe Creek trailhead, where the one designated space is very likely to be occupied. Each of the several small lots along Embarcadero Rd. also has a van-accessible space, and at the sailing station, a gravel lot has several van-accessible spaces. Wheelchair-accessible restrooms with running water are at the nature center (open only when the center is) and Bixby Art Park parking area; porta-potties are at the duck pond and sailing station. Several accessible picnic tables are by the duck pond; all are near the parking lot on firm grass or dirt, and two have shortened benches to provide integrated seating for at least two wheelchairs each. The Visitor Center is wheelchair-accessible.

name: Arastradero Lake
description:
Pearson-Arastradero Preserve is a popular hiking, biking, and horse-riding area. The trailhead offers many trail options. This trail is on a flat gravel trail that leads to Arastradero Lake.

Pearson/Arastradero Preserve Parking has ample parking space but fills up quickly since it is a popular trailhead. There is a restroom in the parking lot.

name: Valley Oak Trail at Coyote Lake
park: Coyote Lake Harvey Bear Ranch County Park
description:
• Parking Fee: Coyote Lake Harvey Bear Ranch County Park charges a fee to enter, except at Mendoza Ranch and Harvey Bear Entrances. There are varying fees depending on if you enter by vehicle, motorcycle, foot, horse, or bike. Please visit https://parks.santaclaracounty.gov/locations/coyote-lake-harvey-bear-ranch-county-park

This route starts across the road from the Lake View Campground. This is a great trailhead for youngsters eager for explorations. It's also one of the rare shady hikes in a section of the Diablo Range better known for wide-open expanses dotted by the occasional oak tree. You may also see cows, deer, turkey and wildflowers.

name: Presidio Promenade Trail
park:
The bus has space for two people in wheelchairs. There are designated accessible parking spaces at both ends. There are wheelchair-accessible restrooms at the Golden Gate Bridge Plaza (long lines here) or at the Visitors Center on the Main Post. The Visitors Center is wheelchair-accessible.

The Presidio Promenade's route follows both dedicated pathways and broad sidewalks and is not always clearly signed. The National Park
description:
• Access Information: Part of this route is temporarily closed to dog walking to reduce the potential for coyote/dog conflict, but you can still enjoy other sections of this trail. For information, please visit https://presidio.gov/about/sustainability/coyotes-in-the-presidio

According to Access Northern California (http://accessnca.org/access-northern-california/explore/explore-detail-view/?site_id=127): A U.S. Army post for nearly 150 years, San Francisco's Presidio has been a national park since 1994. Archaeological digs have uncovered remains from some of the city's earliest structures here. More than 5 million people visit the Presidio every year to hike or bike within the park's 1,491 acres. Two wheelchair-accessible trails run east-west through the northern section: the spectacular Golden Gate Promenade, a four-plus mile stretch of the Bay Trail that runs along the waterfront through Crissy Field's restored marshland to Civil War-era Fort Point; and the Presidio Promenade which travels through the heart of the historic Presidio, from the Lombard Street gate past the Main Post and San Francisco National Cemetery to the Golden Gate Bridge. West of the bridge, a short stretch of Coastal Trail brings you to an overlook atop the Presidio's rugged western bluffs; or you can visit Baker Beach and Battery Chamberlin. 

Before setting off to explore the Presidio, you may want to stop at the visitor center at the Main Post (210 Lincoln Blvd.) to orient yourself. The staff here can answer your questions and provide maps and brochures. Interactive exhibits explain the park's fascinating history. Other visitor centers within the Presidio are at the Gulf of the Farallones Marine Sanctuary and Fort Point, along the Golden Gate Promenade; the pavilion at the Golden Gate Bridge Plaza provides visitor information and has a few exhibits, but is primarily a gift shop.

ACCESSIBILITY: An accessible free shuttle bus, PresidiGo, runs through the Presidio, making several stops (not all are accessible). The bus has space for two people in wheelchairs. There are designated accessible parking spaces at both ends. There are wheelchair-accessible restrooms at the Golden Gate Bridge Plaza (long lines here) or at the Visitors Center on the Main Post. The Visitors Center is wheelchair-accessible.

The Presidio Promenade's route follows both dedicated pathways and broad sidewalks and is not always clearly signed. The National Park web page for this trail says that the average grade is 2.9% and the maximum grade is 10.8%. To find your way, it's helpful to download the detailed Presidio map from the park's website or stop by the Visitor Center. Begin your trek along the Presidio Promenade just inside the Lombard Street Gate. The trail heads westward on the sidewalk along Lombard Street, then takes off on a broad asphalt path. On your right is the Letterman Digital Arts Center. Most of the buildings are off-limits to the public, but if you're a fan of the Star Wars films you may want to detour to Building B. Behind the complex, a mostly accessible landscaped park with a manmade lagoon and creek is also open.

Back on the trail, follow the path to a broad sidewalk along Lincoln Boulevard. You soon come to Thompson's Reach, where a portion of a former creek has been restored. A short spur trail on your right leads down a moderate slope to an overlook with interpretive signs about the creek. Return to the main trail, following the sidewalk west a short distance to the Main Post, the heart of the Presidio since 1776. The Walt Disney Family Museum is near the visitor center.

On the Main Post, the Presidio Promenade follows the sidewalk past the transit center and post office, then, as you reach Montgomery Street, takes off on a broad multi-use path that winds behind the visitor center, following the route of the Presidio Parkway (formerly Doyle Drive). Here you have a panoramic view of the Golden Gate Strait through wire fencing. You soon pass the San Francisco National Cemetery, established in 1884. Just past the cemetery the promenade splits off from Lincoln Boulevard and descends a moderate slope to five brick cavalry stables. One still houses U.S. Park Police horses. Behind one of the stables you cross a 55-foot wooden bridge, then begin a gentle climb up to travel along Lincoln Boulevard again.

Passing under Doyle Drive, with its massive stone supports and metalwork painted the same orange hue as the Golden Gate Bridge, you soon come to the Crissy Field Overlook. From here to the Golden Gate Bridge Plaza, where the promenade ends, is about half a mile. Be sure to look for a pullout with interpretive signs and interactive exhibits about the bridge.

El Polin Spring, at the end of MacArthur Avenue in a residential area southeast of the Main Post, has a short accessible loop trail (boardwalk and gravel) around a spring that was a source of freshwater for the native people and early settlers. A portion of the creek has been "daylighted" and native plants restored. This riparian habitat is an especially rewarding place for bird-watching, and picnic areas and parking are accessible.

name: Arrowhead Marsh Trail to Tidewater Center
park: Pacific Flyway and part of the Western Hemisphere Shorebird Reserve

name: Serpentine, Greenstone, Meadowlark, Apay Way, Bay View Trail
description:
• Partial closure: Part of this route is temporarily inaccessible, but you can still enjoy other sections of this trail. For more information, please visit https://www.ebparks.org/parks/coyote-hills

Trail Highlights: This route is fully exposed, but usually gets nice breezes from the bay. The hike has firm terrain with a combination of paved, packed dirt and gravel surfaces and an average trail width of 4 feet and above. For a gentler trail grade follow the lower Meadowlark trail in each direction. There is a $5 parking fee.

Park Features: Located within Coyote Hills Regional Park next to the eastern shore of San Francisco Bay in Fremont, Dumbarton Quarry Campground on the Bay is the District’s first full-service campground, complete with 63 campsites, a camp store, an amphitheater, a playground, Wi-Fi, and picnic areas. Coyote Hills offers diverse lessons in history and many activities. At the Visitor Center, you can learn about Ohlone history, settlers and ranching, salt production, bio-sonar research, and more. Naturalist-led walks, tours of the Tuibun Ohlone Village, and visits to the Nectar Garden are also available. Other park features include picnic areas, Alameda Creek Trail, the marsh boardwalk, the nearby wildlife refuge, and salt evaporation ponds.

Trail Directions: Start your route on the paved connector Serpentine Trail located in the campground behind the Patterson picnic area. Go right, past the picnic site, and turn left onto the paved Greenstone Trail which connects you to Coyote Hills. At the end of this trail go through the gate and make a left back onto the Serpentine Trail. In a little over a quarter-mile, there is an incline; proceed to the right towards the upper and lower Meadowlark trails. Take the lower or right-hand trail for the most accessible route. This trail is very bumpy and wheelchair riders can avoid some of the cross slope by straddling the raised middle sections. The Upper Meadowlark Trail is very steep but can be chosen as an alternate route since it goes to the same place. At the end of Meadowlark, continue on the packed gravel Apay Way Trail for a few yards and take a right onto the paved Bayview Trail. After about a mile on the Bayview trail, you will reach a bench on your right. Turn around here to complete the round trip or continue further to make your hike a little longer. Return to the campground by following the same route you just traveled.

name: Saddle Trail, Old Guadalupe Trail, and Bog Trail Loop
description:
• San Bruno Mountain State Park charges a fee to enter. Fees are per vehicle. This park does not accept the California State Park Annual Day Use Pass. For more information, please visit https://parks.smcgov.org/fees-charges#vehicle.

Explore the Saddle of San Bruno Mountain State Park. This loop option offers nice views and pleasant wooded areas. It is a great loop for hikers of all ages.

San Mateo County Parks maintains this trail network.

Accessibility: 

Equipment
Visitors using wheelchairs, mobility equipment, or strollers may need all-terrain tires or adaptive/motorized equipment for the surface type and grade.

Parking
There are 3 designated van-accessible spaces with striped access aisles in the paved parking lot off Guadalupe Canyon Parkway at the trail's south end.

Surface
The trail surface is gravel or paved asphalt and is typically at least 6 feet wide.

Grade
This trail is estimated to be mostly gentle (5% or less), with some steeper sections that may require assistance or need to be avoided.

More Info
Benches are available along the route for resting. Restrooms are available at the trailhead.

name: California, Alameda Creek, and Western Pacific Trail Loop
description:
• Parking fee information: There is a fee to park at Quarry Lakes Regional Park. Fees are collected on weekends and major holidays from April through October and only at the Redwood Gate entrance. For more information, please visit https://www.ebparks.org/parks/quarry_lakes/

Trail Highlights: 
At Quarry Lakes Regional Park, the California Trail beckons with lakeside paths framed by lush vegetation. Follow the unpaved Alameda Creek Trail to Sequoia Bridge, where the creek's calm waters reflect the natural beauty. The paved Alameda Creek Trail offers an easy route to the Niles Staging Area, a gateway to history and diverse ecosystems. Old Canyon Road leads adventurers through rugged terrain to the unpaved Alameda Creek Trails, where the landscape shifts with each step. The Western Pacific Trail guides you past Isla Tres Rancheros, a rare fruit tree grove that tells a tale of agricultural heritage. A sidewalk along the trail loops back to the Demonstration Garden, showcasing a variety of plants that thrive in harmony with the park’s diverse environment.

Trail Directions: 
From the Quarry Lakes main parking lot go towards the Demonstration Garden, and follow California Trail. As Willow Slough (lake) approaches, take a right through the gate, then a hard left on Alameda Creek Trail (unpaved). Walk upriver to Sequoia Bridge. After crossing the bridge make a left on paved Alameda Creek Trail, walking upriver toward Niles Staging Area. Once in the parking lot walk to Old Canyon Road, go right on Old Canyon Road and over the bridge (Alameda Creek). Turn left on Alameda Creek Trail (unpaved), walking downstream, then right at Niles Gate (Quarry Lakes Regional Park). This is Western Pacific Trail. Stay right up a small hill, then left on Isla Tres Rancheros. Look around the Rare Fruit Tree Grove, then retrace steps back to Western Pacific Trail. Turn left on Western Pacific Trail; follow sidewalk back to Demonstration Garden.

name: Cross Alameda Trail at Jean Sweeney Park
park: Cross Alameda Trail at Jean Sweeney Park
description:
The Cross Alameda Trail runs east-west through Alameda. This tour runs the length of the Jean Sweeney Open Space Park and is popular with walkers, joggers, and cyclists. Parking is on the east end, and the trail runs through an open grassy area. There is little shade along the route. Bring plenty of water and ways to protect yourself from the sun!

Accessibility:  

Equipment  
This trail is likely accessible for visitors using wheelchairs, mobility equipment, or strollers.  

Parking  
There are 3 designated accessible spaces with striped access aisles in the paved parking lot.  

Surface  
The trail surface is paved asphalt and is typically 6 feet wide.  

Grade  
This trail is estimated to be flat (1% or less).  

More Info  
Picnic tables and benches are available along the route for resting.

name: Hacienda Trail to Buena Vista Trail
description: Almaden Quicksilver County Park includes over 37 miles of hiking trails, including 30 miles of equestrian trails and 16.6 miles of bike trails. All trails in the park are also open to pet owners to walk their dogs on leash. For more information visit: https://www.sccgov.org/sites/parks/parkfinder/pages/almadenpark.aspx

name: Lake Merritt
English Camp, Mine Hill, and Randol Loop
description:
The historic site of the worlds second largest mercury mining operation, this scenic land offers hours adventure and exploration. The park includes over 37 miles of hiking trails, including 30 miles of equestrian trails and 16.6 miles of bike trails. All trails in the park are also open to pet owners to walk their dogs on leash. For more information visit: https://www.sccgov.org/sites/parks/parkfinder/pages/almadenpark.aspx

Heads up! This trail is shared by hikers, mountain bikers, and dogs. Keep your eyes out for others out there enjoying the trail. Hikers have the right of way but should be aware of mountain bikers riding around blind corners or downhill. Dogs should yield to everyone else out there on the trail.

name: Skyline-to-the-Sea Trail: Castle Rock Route
description:
• CZU Lightning Complex Fire : Public access to Big Basin has been severely impacted by the 2020 CZU Lightning Complex Fire and ongoing fire recovery work, but the park is open for limited day-use access. There is currently no access to waterfalls, all camping is closed and skyline to sea trail is open to the north but access to south (towards the ocean) is closed

This map shows the full Skyline-to-the-Sea route from the Castle Rock State Park entrance.  Be advised that trail camps may not have trash collection and/or water available; check park conditions before starting out. Reservations are required to use the campgrounds and you may need up to a two month lead time. Call 831-338-8861 for same-day reservations.

name: Quail Hollow Sunset Trail
description: Hike the Quail Hollow Sunset Trail and experience views of Zayante Valley, local quarries, dwarf redwoods, Quail Hollow Ranch. Dwarf redwood trees, manzanita, redwood, chaparral,lizards, wildflowers, valley views and occasional ocean views all in an hour and 45 minutes.  Small amounts of poison oak off-trail.  Temps can reach 100 degrees F in summer.  Visit the park office and pick up a free trail map.

name: Marina Green
park: The trail is open year-round and is beautiful to visit anytime. Dogs are welcome and may be off-leash in some areas.What are some of the facilities available for Marina Green?Park
description:
The Marina Green, located in San Francisco's scenic Marina District, is located along the San Francisco Bay and runs the whole expanse between Fort Mason and the Presidio. This location provides stunning views of the Golden Gate Bridge, Alcatraz, Angel Island, and is surrounded by historic homes.

Located nearby is one of the only remnants of the 1915 Panama-Pacific International Exposition, the Palace of Fine Arts, which can be seen from the Marina Green. Not only is this area an attraction for tourists due to the sights and the history, but it is also a local hangout for runners, athletes, or casual picnickers.

Accessibility: There are 4 designated accessible spaces in the paved parking lot off of Marina Boulevard at the east end of the trail. All of them are van-accessible with striped access aisles. The trail surface is paved asphalt or concrete and smooth. It is typically at least 4 feet wide. 

The whole trail is estimated to be in the flat (1% or less) grade category. This trail will likely be navigable for most wheelchairs/mobility equipment or stroller users. There are benches along the route for resting.

name: Meyers Ranch and High Ridge Loop
description:
• Parking fee information: There is a fee to park at Dry Creek Pioneer Regional Park. For more information, please visit https://www.ebparks.org/parks/garin-dry-creek

The trail begins from the Dry Creek Pioneer Staging Area parking lot on May Road. From here, you'll follow May Trail past a pond and climb up to the High Ridge Loop Trail. Enjoy the beautiful views of the Bay from the ridgeline before gradually descending along Meyers Ranch Trail. Some areas of the trail can become muddy after rain, so come prepared with appropriate footwear.

name: Guadalupe River Park Trail
description:
A paved trail along the Guadalupe River in downtown San Jose, California, might be just what you need to work off some stress or even ride your bike to work.

The Guadalupe River Park starts near the Children's Discovery Museum at the south end of Downtown San Jose and runs northward. It's easily accessible via the Valley Transit Agency's Light Rail and has entrances along all the major cross streets downtown. 

You'll also have chances for bird watching and, of course, people watching along the way. The trail surface is mostly paved and entirely flat. Ambitious walkers (and, more likely, bike riders) can take the trail all the way to the southern edge of San Francisco Bay.

Accessibility: There are 6 designated accessible spaces in the large paved parking lot off of Woz Way at the south end of the trail. All of them are van-accessible with striped access aisles. The trail surface is paved asphalt (with railings at bridges), smooth, and typically at least 6 feet wide. There is a painted dividing line along the trail which reduces the width.

The estimated grade is mostly gentle (5% or less). This trail will likely be navigable for most wheelchairs/mobility equipment or stroller users. There are benches and picnic tables along the route for resting.

name: San Bruno Park to Junipero Serra Park
park: San Bruno Park to Junipero Serra Park
description: This marvelous trail in San Bruno Park winds through coastal live oaks and California bay forest, creating a beautiful blend of sunlight and shade. The trail surface primarily consists of smooth dirt paths. Throughout the trail, some nice scenic viewpoints offer vistas of the surrounding area. The views are especially pretty at sunrise and sunset.

name: Creeks to Peaks Trail
description:
• Partial closure: Parts of the Twin Peaks Trail are subject to closure due to construction projects, but you can still enjoy other sections of this trail. For more information, please visit https://sfrecpark.org/634/Twin-Peaks-Trails-Improvement-Promenade-

This is an awesome trail with a mix of sun and shade, paved and unpaved, city and forest. This trail has a little taste of everything! This is a very popular trail, so expect to encounter others along the way. There are a few sections where you will need to cross busy streets, so be alert and keep children and dogs close.

name: Cavello Point to Kirby Cove
park: GMTExplore near Cavello Point to Kirby CoveActivitiesBirdingCampingFishingHikingHorseback ridingMountain bikingRoad bikingRunningWalkingAttractionsBeachCaveChallengingCity walkEasyForestHistoric siteLakeLongModerately challengingNo dogsRiverShortViewsWildflowersWildlifeSuitabilityDog friendlyDogs on leashKid friendlyPartially pavedPavedStroller friendlyWheelchair friendlyPoints of interestBaker BeachCattle HillHill 88Homestead HillLime PointPortola Discovery Site of San Francisco BayMuir Beach OverlookRodeo LagoonEl Polín SpringBattery ChamberlinRodeo BeachHawk HillBaker Beach (Nudist Area)Muir BeachFort PointBattery YatesPoint Bonita LighthouseSlacker HillSutro BathsWorld War II MemorialActivitiesBirdingCampingFishingHikingHorseback ridingMountain bikingRoad bikingRunningWalkingAttractionsBeachCaveChallengingCity walkEasyForestHistoric siteLakeLongModerately challengingAttractionsNo dogsRiverShortViewsWildflowersWildlifeSuitabilityDog friendlyDogs on leashKid friendlyPartially pavedPavedStroller friendlyWheelchair friendlyPoints of interestBaker BeachCattle HillHill 88Homestead HillLime PointPortola Discovery Site of San Francisco BayMuir Beach OverlookRodeo LagoonEl Polín SpringBattery ChamberlinPoints of interestRodeo BeachHawk HillBaker Beach (Nudist Area)Muir BeachFort PointBattery YatesPoint Bonita LighthouseSlacker HillSutro BathsWorld War II MemorialDownloadOpen mapAllTrailsExploreCountriesRegionsCitiesParksTrailsPoints of InterestTrail FeaturesMapsMy mapsCreate mapPrint mapsRoute converterCompanyAboutJobsPressAmbassadorsAffiliatesInfluencersCommunitySupportGift membershipAllTrails GearExploreCountriesRegionsCitiesPark
description:
This trail takes you past the bridge and marina for some great views. It consists of mostly paved roads and fire roads with a short single track just before the lookout. Expect a mostly flat trail with some gentle inclines. 

From the Parade Ground at Cavello Point make your way towards the Golden Gate Bridge. After crossing under the Golden Gate Bridge you will ascend a few switchbacks before joining the Coastal Trail.

The Coastal Trail will then lead to Kirby Cove Rd and down to the shoreline. On the way back, there are options for great restaurant stops for a bite to eat.

name: Candlestick Point Loop
park: WalkingFirst to reviewTrailhead is a private space. Park at main lot to enter this specific loopPark
description: Candlestick Point State Recreation Area offers a network of trails along the San Francisco Bay. These trails offer incredible views and the opportunity to see waterfowl and other wildlife. This route starts at the main parking lot and makes a family-friendly loop on the park's north end. There is access to the water from the trails.

name: Stevens Creek County Park Canyon Trail
description: For more information, please review the park website https://www.sccgov.org/sites/parks/Pages/Closures.aspx

name: North Rim Trail to Boccardo Trail
description:
• Partial closure: As of October 2024, part of this route is temporarily inaccessible, but you can still enjoy other sections of this trail. For more information, please visit https://www.sanjoseca.gov/home/showpublisheddocument/110007/638568325940770000
• Parking fee information: There is a fee to park at Alum Rock Park. For more information, please visit https://www.sanjoseca.gov/Home/Components/FacilityDirectory/FacilityDirectory/2088/2028

The distance from sprawling, suburban San Jose to wide-open mountain-lion country is remarkably short--if you start out from Alum Rock Park.

This hike will have you walking in the wilderness in about an hour. It starts at the parking lot of Alum Rock Park on the southeast corner of San Jose, climbs steeply to the hills just beyond the city limits, then descends to the section of the park that has drinking fountains, bathrooms, and other civilized amenities. From there it's a flat stroll along the burbling Penitencia Creek back to your car.   

Trails on this hike: Penitencia Creek Trail, North Rim Trail, Weather Loop, Boccardo Trail, Todd Quick Trail, North Rim Trail, Penitencia Creek Trail.

Best times to go: Spring for the wildflowers; winter for the smog-free views after a cleansing rain. Avoid in the summer, when lack of rain and arid terrain create a high risk of wildfires.

name: Priest Rock Trail
description: This hike connects Lexington Reservoir County Park to the Sierra Azul Open Space Preserve. Be prepared for steep sections with gravel and loose rock terrain. You'll be rewarded with great views of Lexington Reservoir and the surrounding mountains. In the spring, the trail features beautiful wildflowers. Since most of the trail is exposed, it's best to hike on a cooler day or start early to avoid the heat. Roadside parking is available at the trailhead.

name: Best trails inFremont Older Open Space Preserve
park: Fremont Older Open Space Preservebest Trails In Fremont Older Open Space Preserve Best Trails In Fremont Older Open Space Preserve
description: The park is open half an hour before sunrise to half an hour after sunset

name: Loop Trail, Bass Lake Trail, and Hotel Trail Loop
description:
• Joseph D Grant County Park collects a day-use fee for vehicular entrance year-round. For more information, please see https://parks.sccgov.org/plan-your-visit/santa-clara-county-park-fees#3925188384-3236192913

The Loop Trail, Bass Lake Trail, and Hotel Trail Loop in California offers a pleasant hiking experience with scenic views of Bass Lake. The trail weaves through forested areas, rocky outcrops, and along the lake’s shoreline, providing ample opportunities for wildlife watching and photography. With varied terrain and panoramic vistas, this loop is perfect for those looking to explore the mix of forest, water in the Sierra National Forest.

name: Lower Huckleberry and Upper Huckleberry Loop Trail
description:
Starting from the Huckleberry Preserve parking lot off Skyline Boulevard, this short loop travels around the two main trails of the preserve.

This route is almost entirely shaded yet still offers a handful of great views throughout.  Parts of the route can be overgrown in the warmer months and poison oak is abundant, so please use caution.

name: John Brooks Trail and Lake Loop Trail
description:
John Brooks Trail and Lake Loop Trail feature wide trails with great views into the Water Dog Open Space. This trail has steep parts, rock gardens, and off-camber curves. It winds through small, forested bay area canyons home to various species, such as deer. The hike also boasts breathtaking views. You can see a long way over the water on a clear day.

Tucked down in a forested gorge, Water Dog Lake features a blocked stream originally walled up to supply Belmont with water. The vegetation in the area is abundant, with poison oak standing out in particular. You can see clematis and buckwheat in the summertime. There are also other plants that you may see, like sticky monkeyflower, coyote brush, and honeysuckle.

name: Ardenwood Historic Farm Loop
Toyon Trail, Arroyo Trail, and Valley Oak Trail Loop
description: This trail begins off Alpine Road and takes you to the Coal Mine Ridge Nature Preserve in Portola Valley Ranch. The parking area at the trailhead is limited, so it's recommended that you arrive early. The trail is mostly shaded, winding through the forest with nice views over Portola Valley and abundant birdlife. During the spring, you'll find beautiful wildflowers.

name: Woodland Star Trail to Meadowlark Trail Loop
description:
• Seasonal closure: This area is subject to seasonal closure due to weather conditions. For more information, please visit https://www.cityofpaloalto.org/News-Articles/Community-Services/Pearson-Arastradero-Preserve-Seasonal-Trails-Status

This easygoing trail explores part of the Enid Pearson-Arastradero Preserve. The route is used by mountain bikers, hikers, runners and dog walkers. There are some beautiful views of the bay and Dumbarton Bridge along the way and a nice bench on top of the hill with a 360-degree view to enjoy. Most of the trail is exposed to the sun, so use sun protection and carry plenty of water in summer. The terrain is a mix of gravel and packed dirt.

name: RIP Loop
description: The RIP Van Winkle Open Space is a rugged and wild oasis in a dense urban environment. Its short network of trails weaves through pine and cypress forests. The park is usually busy with walkers, joggers, and off-leash dogs. There are a few access points; this route starts on the southwest side and makes a loop using perimeter trails.

name: Brandon Skyline, Cameron Loop and Proctor Trail
description: • Parking fee information: There is a fee to park at Lake Chabot Regional Park. For more information, please visit https://www.ebparks.org/parks/lake-chabot

name: Sequoia Bayview Trail
description: The Sequoia Bayview trail is a wide, well-maintained, and very popular trail at Joaquin Miller Park. There you will find lots of joggers, mountain bikers, and dog walkers. You will hike through a few patches of redwood, but the trail is mostly a non-redwood forest. If you’re looking for a shorter-distance route that doesn’t have much elevation gain or loss, this trail is for you. Nonetheless, the Sequoia Bayview Trail connects to many other trails in Joaquin Miller Park and Redwood Regional Park, so you can explore for as long as you want.

name: Bear Creek Redwoods Equestrian Trail
park: Bear Creek Redwoods Open Space Preserve
description: This out and back trail is primarily for equestrian use. Hikers should access this trail from the main parking near the historic Alma College site rather than starting from the Bear Creek Stables as marked on this particular map.

name: Manzanita Trail via Jones Trail
park: St. Joseph'S Hill Open Space Preserve
description:
Explore the beauty of St. Joseph's Hill Preserve along the well-marked Manzanita Trail. Hikers will be treated to views of the surrounding hills, Lexington Reservoir and the bay area as they make their way along this route, which as also shared by cyclists. The best time to visit is during Spring, when an abundance of wildflowers are in bloom.

The trail begins with Jones Trail along a relatively steep paved path, which flattens out slightly as it switches into a moderately wide rocky dirt path. Once you reach the Manzanita trail loop, there are moderate ups and downs and a nice bench at the top to sit and soak up the view.

name: Shorebird Park
description: Shorebird Park is a scenic place for recreation. It offers a kid's play area, bathrooms, bike jumps, and paved paths for walking and jogging. It is beautiful, with expansive views of San Francisco Bay. This route follows the Foster City Levee and makes a loop along a path that borders the bay. Bring water and a sun layer as the route has little shade. Coyotes are common in this area, so be alert.

name: Bay Area Ridge Trail: Stern Grove to San Francisco Presidio
park:
The route takes you through Twin Peaks and Sutro Tower. Be prepared for San Francisco’s foggy and breezy weather.

Restrooms can be found at Larsen Park and Golden Gate Park
description:
• Partial closure: Parts of the Twin Peaks Trail are subject to closure due to construction projects, but you can still enjoy other sections of this trail. For more information, please visit https://sfrecpark.org/634/Twin-Peaks-Trails-Improvement-Promenade-

San Francisco’s spectacular bay and ocean views reward you on gradual climbs along city streets and park paths. Visit a number of parks, playgrounds, and unique residential and commercial neighborhoods. The route takes you through Twin Peaks and Sutro Tower. Be prepared for San Francisco’s foggy and breezy weather.

Restrooms can be found at Larsen Park and Golden Gate Park. 

See the Bay Area Ridge Trail site here for more information: https://ridgetrail.org/stern-grove-to-golden-gate-park/

This trail description is excerpted from the 2019 Guidebook. For details on all trails, trailheads and more buy the book from Wilderness Press: https://www.wildernesspress.com/product.php?productid=16685&cat=274&bestseller=Y

The estimated grade is moderately steep with multiple sections above an estimated 12% grade. Due to the very steep sections, this full route is unlikely to be accessible for wheelchairs/mobility equipment (especially manual) or strollers, although shorter sections of it are.

name: Mori Ridge Trail
park: GMTExplore near Mori Ridge TrailActivitiesBirdingHikingMountain bikingRunningAttractionsHistoric siteLongModerately challengingViewsWildflowersWildlifeSuitabilityDogs on leashPartially pavedPoints of interestCattle HillPortola Discovery Site of San Francisco BayCorridor & Maintenance BuildingGenerator BuildingSF-51C Nike Missile SiteHigh Power Acquisition Radar BuildingReady RoomTarget Ranging RadarGuard ShackTarget Tracking RadarCoast Guard SiteLookoutActivitiesBirdingHikingMountain bikingRunningAttractionsHistoric siteLongModerately challengingViewsWildflowersWildlifeSuitabilityDogs on leashPartially pavedPoints of interestCattle HillPortola Discovery Site of San Francisco BayCorridor & Maintenance BuildingGenerator BuildingSF-51C Nike Missile SiteHigh Power Acquisition Radar BuildingReady RoomTarget Ranging RadarGuard ShackTarget Tracking RadarPoints of interestCoast Guard SiteLookoutDownloadOpen mapAllTrailsExploreCountriesRegionsCitiesParksTrailsPoints of InterestTrail FeaturesMapsMy mapsCreate mapPrint mapsRoute converterCompanyAboutJobsPressAmbassadorsAffiliatesInfluencersCommunitySupportGift membershipAllTrails GearExploreCountriesRegionsCitiesPark
description: The Mori Ridge Trail starts from a parking lot off Cabrillo Highway and steeply climbs uphill to the junction with the Sweeney Ridge and notch trails. The wide dirt path travels through the open grassy hills and coastal sage, offering stunning views of the Pacific Ocean. There is no shade along the route and it gets hot; bring plenty of water.

name: Best trails inEd R. Levin County Park
park: Ed R. Levin County Parkbest Trails In Ed R. Levin County Park Best Trails In Ed R. Levin County Park
description: Welcome to Ed R. Levin County Park, one of Santa Clara County's most unique regional park and recreation areas. This 1,541-acre park combines the traditional features of an urban park such as picnicking, fishing and play areas, with the complex trail system of many regional wilderness parks. Ed Levin's expansive lawn areas make it an ideal spot for family outings, while the rolling grasslands and Oak woodlands are available to visitors looking for a back-to-nature experience. The park's Monument Peak provides a spectacular view of the valley floor and the San Francisco Bay. Enjoy your visit, and return often to enjoy the many unique aspects of Ed R. Levin County Park. Also featured at the park is an expansive off-leash dog park for large and small dogs alike! Owned and operated by the City of Milpitas this dog park is one of the most popular features in Ed Levin County Park. Dogs are also allowed on-leash in parking lots, picnic areas, and all trails north of Calaveras Road. The park is open 8am to sunset.

name: Philosopher's Loop
description: McLaren Park is San Francisco's second-largest, offering many active and passive recreational opportunities. The trail network has over 425 feet of elevation change and gorgeous vista views of the San Francisco skyline, East Bay, and San Bruno Mountain. This route begins at Mansell Street and Visitacion Avenue and heads west on Philosopher's Way before looping back on a southern trail.

name: Seal Point Park
description:
This lovely flat walk follows well-maintained paths along the Bay Marshes. As you walk the path, you can observe wildlife, such as the endangered California Clapper Rail. 

Visitors can enjoy beautiful views of the San Francisco Bay and public art installations, including kinetic sculptures. Public restrooms are available at the start of the trail.

name: Best trails inWilder Ranch State Park
park: Wilder Ranch State Parkbest Trails In Wilder Ranch State Park Best Trails In Wilder Ranch State Park
description: Situated just west of Santa Cruz along the coast, Wilder Ranch State Park boasts miles of trails for hiking, biking, and horseback riding. The coastal trails offer incredible views of the California coastline. The park has a very mild climate, but layered clothing is advised.

name: Maisie's Peak, Hunter's Point via Nob Hill, Coyote Ridge, Hayfield
description: The trail begins through the forest and gradually climbs to emerge into the meadows at the top of rolling hills. Rolling grasses on the lower slopes give way to a shrubby, low forest as you ascend. As you continue higher, you'll be rewarded with expansive views toward the higher ridges of the Santa Cruz Mountains, and on clear days, you can look far to South Bay. This trail offers excellent 360-degree views of Silicon Valley and the surrounding hills.

name: Aquila Loop Trail
description:
This is a pleasant 1-mile trail with very minimal ascent/descent. The trail is very open and offers absolutely no shade, but it does give you some great view of the beautiful rolling hills that surround this area. It makes for a lovely spot to watch sunrise/sunset. 

The trail management has made the trail one way.

name: Tuibun, Bayview, and No Name Trail
description: This route takes you along a well maintained trail in Coyote Hills leading to San Francisco Bay. This can be a wonderful place for birding and observing wildflowers each spring. No Name Trail offers a unique experience as you walk along a gravel travel that leads you in the middle of the middle of the water with stunning views on both sides.

name: High Ridge Loop, Dry Creek and Meyers Ranch
description:
• Parking fee information: There is a fee to park at Dry Creek Pioneer Regional Park. For more information, please visit https://www.ebparks.org/parks/garin-dry-creek

This loop trail starts at the parking lot off May Road and leads into Dry Creek Pioneer Regional Park. You'll also find restrooms and Meyers Dry Creek Gardens at the trailhead. The trail winds through rolling hills, passes a small pond, and follows along a creek. It's best to start your hike early to avoid the heat, as there is no shade along the way. At the top, you’ll be rewarded with beautiful views of the Bay Area.

name: Baylands Perimeter Loop
Salesforce Park Loop
description:
The Salesforce Park Loop is at the 5.4-acre rooftop park open to the sky above the Salesforce Transbay Transit Center. The trail curves along the outer perimeter of the park which is lined with benches, has grassy lawns, dancing fountains, a children’s play area, and an amphitheater. The park contains 13 botanical features with diverse plant ecosystems.

Accessibility: There is street parking and the parking garages surrounding the building have designated accessible spaces with access aisles. You can access the park from two bridges from nearby towers (181 Fremont and Salesforce Tower), 4 elevators, 3 escalators, or a free gondola cable car that can be accessed from Salesforce Plaza on the corner of Mission and Fremont Streets. 

The trail surface is paved, smooth, and typically at least 6 feet wide. The estimated grade is mostly gentle (all 5% or less), so this trail will likely be navigable for most wheelchairs/mobility equipment or strollers. There are benches along the trail for resting.

name: Almaden Lake
description:
Beautiful trail thats perfect for a good relaxing walk. You can bike, scoot, play basketball, and have a picnic. There is ample parking in the lot.

Accessibility: There are 4 designated accessible spaces in the large paved parking lot off of Almaden Expressway at the west end of the trail. All of them are van-accessible with striped access aisles. The trail surface is paved (with railings at bridges), smooth, and typically at least 5 feet wide.

name: Best trails nearMindego Hill
description: Bukid ang Mindego Hill sa Tinipong Bansa. Ang Mindego Hill nahimutang sa kondado sa San Mateo County ug estado sa California, sa habagatan-kasadpang bahin sa nasod, 3,900 km sa kasadpan sa ulohang dakbayan Washington, D.C. 653 metros ibabaw sa dagat kahaboga ang nahimutangan sa Mindego Hill, o 132 ka metros sa ibabaw sa naglibot nga tereyn. Mga 1.3 ka kilometro ang gilapdon sa tiilan niini.

name: Bay Area Ridge Trail: Sanborn County Park and Castle Rock State Park
park: Bay Area Ridge Trail: Sanborn County Park and Castle Rock State Park
description:
• Fee Information: Sanborn County Park charges a fee to enter. For more information, please https://parks.santaclaracounty.gov/locations/sanborn-county-park

Follow the Skyline Trail along the wooded ridgeline of two vast parks: Sanborn County Park and Castle Rock State Park. On the route of old Summit Road, you wind along the protected east side of the crest of the Santa Cruz Mountains through forests of Douglas-fir, oak, and madrone; you pass immense sandstone outcrops and vestiges of early homesteaders’ orchards and dwellings. This fairly level trip, entirely in shade, is ideal for warm days.

For more information, see the Bay Area Ridge Trail page here: https://ridgetrail.org/sanborn-county-park-and-castle-rock-state-park/

This trail description is excerpted from the 2019 Guidebook. For details on all of the Bay Area Ridge trails, trailheads and more buy the book from Wilderness Press: https://www.wildernesspress.com/product.php?productid=16685&cat=274&bestseller=Y

name: Best trails inPalo Alto Foothills Park
park: Palo Alto Foothills Parkbest Trails In Palo Alto Foothills Park Best Trails In Palo Alto Foothills Park4.7(533 Reviews)All Photoswant To Find The Best Trails In Palo Alto Foothills Park
description:
Want to find the best trails in Palo Alto Foothills Park for an adventurous hike or a family trip? AllTrails has 1 great trails for hiking and more. Enjoy hand-curated trail maps, along with reviews and photos from nature lovers like you.

Ready for your next hike or bike ride? We've got you covered, with trails ranging from 413 to 413 feet in elevation gain. Whatever you have planned for the day, you can find the perfect trail for your next trip to Palo Alto Foothills Park.

name: Castle Rock Falls from Castle Rock Parking
park: Castle Rock Falls from Castle Rock Park
description:
• General fee: Castle Rock State Park charges a day-use fee to enter. For more information please visit https://www.parks.ca.gov/?page_id=538

Beginning from Castle Rock State Park Parking, this trail winds through an open grassy area before descending into the forest. Along the way, visitors can see stunning views of Castle Rock State Park and its surroundings.

There is some rock scrambling along some sections of this trail and several parts with uneven terrain. The hike along the creek is particularly beautiful, as are the falls when the creek is flowing.

name: Don Edwards National Wildlife Refuge
park: Don Edwards National Wildlife Refuge. description:
• Partial closure: The Mallard Slough Trail is temporarily inaccessible, but you can still enjoy other sections of this trail. For more information, please visit https://parks.sccgov.org/sites/g/files/exjcpb961/files/documents/ShorelineProject2024Updates.pdf

Easy trails and mass migrations make this one of the best birdwatching locales in the San Francisco Bay Area.

The ducks, geese, pelicans and egrets are only the most visible among the fascinating array of waterfowl hanging out near the Alviso Environmental Education Center of the Don Edwards San Francisco Bay National Wildlife Refuge. 

The trails on this 7-mile track are pretty basic: A section of the Mallard Slough Trail near the Environmental Education Center connected to a section of the Alviso Slough Trail.

The network of levees in this section of the refuge creates nearly boundless variations, depending on how long you plan to hike. 

Migrations are heaviest in the spring and fall.

name: Skyline, Bear Gulch, Alambique and Meadow Loop
description: This route takes you on a beautiful hike through chaparral, redwood forest, eucalyptus, and mixed evergreen forest in Wunderlich County Park. It starts off with an enjoyable descent, and once you pass by the Carriage Room Museum, it features a steady and challenging incline. The trail is well-maintained, wide, and shaded.

name: Sweeney Ridge Trail via Mori Ridge
park: GMTExplore near Sweeney Ridge Trail via Mori RidgeActivitiesBirdingCampingFishingHikingHorseback ridingMountain bikingRoad bikingRunningWalkingAttractionsBeachCaveChallengingCity walkEasyForestHistoric siteLakeLongModerately challengingNo dogsRiverShortViewsWildflowersWildlifeSuitabilityDog friendlyDogs on leashKid friendlyPartially pavedPavedStroller friendlyWheelchair friendlyPoints of interestPirates CoveTennessee BeachBaker BeachBlack Sands BeachHomestead HillMountain LakeThe PointPoint BonitaPoint LobosNational Cemetery OverlookInspiration PointBattery KirbyBattery SpencerBattery CrosbyBattery WagnerBattery LancasterPortola Discovery Site of San Francisco BayObservation DeckRodeo LagoonBattery MendellActivitiesBirdingCampingFishingHikingHorseback ridingMountain bikingRoad bikingRunningWalkingAttractionsBeachCaveChallengingCity walkEasyForestHistoric siteLakeLongModerately challengingAttractionsNo dogsRiverShortViewsWildflowersWildlifeSuitabilityDog friendlyDogs on leashKid friendlyPartially pavedPavedStroller friendlyWheelchair friendlyPoints of interestPirates CoveTennessee BeachBaker BeachBlack Sands BeachHomestead HillMountain LakeThe PointPoint BonitaPoint LobosNational Cemetery OverlookPoints of interestInspiration PointBattery KirbyBattery SpencerBattery CrosbyBattery WagnerBattery LancasterPortola Discovery Site of San Francisco BayObservation DeckRodeo LagoonBattery MendellDownloadOpen mapAllTrailsExploreCountriesRegionsCitiesParksTrailsPoints of InterestTrail FeaturesMapsMy mapsCreate mapPrint mapsRoute converterCompanyAboutJobsPressAmbassadorsAffiliatesInfluencersCommunitySupportGift membershipAllTrails GearExploreCountriesRegionsCitiesPark
description: This hike connects to the Sweeney Ridge which offers excellent views of the Pacific Ocean. This area can often have lots of coastal fog, so be prepared for a variety of temperatures. This is a great trail for a sunset hike. As you descend, you can enjoy watching the sunset over the Pacific Ocean. The unencumbered views are nothing short of stunning.

name: Los Gatos Creek Trail: Campbell Park to Meridian Avenue
park: Los Gatos Creek Trail: Campbell Park
description:
This is a paved path next to Los Gatos Creek. It is a nice family-friendly stroll. For cyclists, it does have a speed limit.

Accessibility: There are 2 designated accessible spaces in the paved parking lot off of Gilman Avenue at the north end of the trail. Both of them are van-accessible with striped access aisles. The trail surface is paved asphalt or a wooden bridge with railings. It is typically at least 8 feet wide. There is a painted dividing line along most of the trail which reduces the width. 

The whole trail is estimated to be in the mostly gentle (5% or less) grade category. This trail will likely be navigable for most wheelchairs/mobility equipment or stroller users.

park: Mori Point LoopGolden Gate National Recreation Area4.6·Hard·13.8 mi·Est. 6h 44mMills Canyon Nature Area Trail LoopMills Canyon Nature Area Trail LoopMills Canyon Park4.2·Easy·1.7 mi·Est. 51mQuail Loop Trail to Live Oak  Nature TrailQuail Loop Trail to Live Oak  Nature TrailJunipero Serra County Park4.5·Easy·1.6 mi·Est. 46mSawyer Camp Trail: San Andreas Lake to Lower Crystal Springs ReservoirSawyer Camp Trail: San Andreas Lake to Lower Crystal Springs ReservoirSan Francisco State Fish and Game Refuge4.5·Moderate·5.4 mi·Est. 1h 56mSan Bruno Park to Junipero Serra ParkSan Bruno Park to Junipero Serra ParkSan Bruno Park4.3·Moderate·2.9 mi·Est. 1h 15mSan Andreas Lake TrailSan Andreas Lake TrailSan Francisco Peninsula Watershed4.1·Moderate·5.4 mi·Est. 1h 53mCoyote Point to San Mateo BridgeCoyote Point to San Mateo BridgeCoyote Point Recreation Area4.5·Easy·10.4 mi·Est. 3h 2mSeal Point ParkSeal Point ParkSeal Point Park4.5·Easy·0.9 mi·Est. 19mSan Francisco Bay Trail: Foster City and San Mateo BikewaysSan Francisco Bay Trail: Foster City and San Mateo BikewaysShorebird Park4.4·Easy·10.6 mi·Est. 3h 5mBayside Park to Robert E Woolley State Park LoopBayside Park to Robert E Woolley State Park
description:
This is a paved walk with great views of arriving SFO flights. From about 1.2-1.5 miles when going east you will need to cut through a parking lot and along a sidewalk to connect to the trail again. Users have noted that the trail is not well maintained and has bumps and cracks. 

Accessibility: There are 10 designated accessible spaces in the paved parking lot off of Old Bayshore Highway at the west end of the trail. All of them are van-accessible with striped access aisles. The trail surface is paved asphalt or concrete with some bumps and cracks. It is typically at least 5 feet wide. The whole trail is estimated to be in the gentle (3% or less) grade category. This trail will likely be navigable for most wheelchairs/mobility equipment or stroller users.

name: Goldenrod Loop, Horseshoe, and Brandon Loop
description:
• Partial closure: Part of the Brandon Trail is temporarily inaccessible, but you can still enjoy other sections of this trail. For more information, please visit https://www.ebparks.org/parks/anthony-chabot

A moderate loop trail with views of the Upper San Leandro Reservoir

name: Lexington Reservoir Trail
description:
This loop trail explores the west side of the Lexington Reservoir and is a great option for the entire family. This trail is multi-use, and can be steep in sections.

Take the Limekiln trail to the junction of Priest Rock Trail. Return via the Priest Rock trail. Walk along the shore line  to return. The loop can be done in either direction.

name: Corona Heights Trail
description: Corona Heights Park is a scenic and hilly park in the middle of San Francisco. This route starts at the Randall Museum and heads north, climbing to Corona Heights, which offers gorgeous views of the city. It descends a trail to the north to complete the loop. Always carry water and sun protection when recreating here.

name: San Francisco Bay Trail: Emeryville to Richmond Inner Harbor
description:
According to Access Northern California (http://accessnca.org/access-northern-california/explore/explore-detail-view/?site_id=215): Emeryville Peninsula, a curling finger jutting out into the bay, was one of the last major landfill projects on the bay. Its marinas and park are connected by two miles of paved Bay Trail. Powell Street leads to the peninsula’s tip, where the small lawns of Marina Park - screened by cypress and pine trees - face the bay.

As a designated site for the San Francisco Bay Water Trail, the marina has accessible launch facilities including an ADA gangway (with transition plates) that lead to a high-freeboard dock.

ACCESSIBILITY: All parking lots in the area reportedly have firm, accessible parking, although the northern lots have the easiest trail access for wheelchairs. The trail surface is paved with asphalt and cement and it is typically at least six feet wide. It is estimated to be mostly gentle in slope.

One can enter the paved Bay Trail at multiple locations but if you start at the pier and head south alongside the marina it ends at a construction site (as of August 2020) in less than 0.5 miles. For a longer hike, start from the pier and head north towards the bay. There are sweeping views of the Richmond–San Rafael Bridge, Mount Tamalpais, the Golden Gate Bridge, San Francisco, and the Bay Bridge. 

Just past China Village restaurant (there’s no easy wheelchair access from the trail to the restaurant) the trail curves inland and parallels Powell St. for one-mile to Frontage Rd. From here turn left to continue on the Bay Trail as it skirts McLaughlin State Park along the bay for another 2 miles to University Ave. in Berkeley by the Berkeley Marina. Please note the trail on this map continues past the Berkeley Marina so where the Access Northern California route ends has been marked on the map with a waypoint.

There are wheelchair accessible restrooms on the marina side of the park and accessible picnic tables with firm and stable paths and surfaces and at least 27 inches of knee clearance throughout the park. There is a sunken group picnic area near the marina members' restroom that is more sheltered from the wind.

name: Bay Area Ridge Trail: Penitencia Creek
description:
This paved urban trail is full multiuse, and makes connections between parks, playgrounds, schools, transit stops, and natural riparian corridor areas.

This 3.7-mile linear parkway trail crosses San José neighborhoods and ends at the eastern edge of the Santa Clara Valley. Mostly paved, the trail follows Penitencia Creek, a tributary of Coyote Creek, which flows down from Sierra Vista Open Space Preserve and Alum Rock Park. 

In total, the parkway covers 134 acres and passes through two sizable parks—Penitencia Creek Gardens and Penitencia Creek Park. It makes an excellent bike ride through urban San José.

For more information, see the Bay Area Ridge Trail page here: https://ridgetrail.org/penitencia-creek/

This trail description is excerpted from the 2019 Guidebook. For details on all of the Bay Area Ridge trails, trailheads and more buy the book from Wilderness Press: https://www.wildernesspress.com/product.php?productid=16685&cat=274&bestseller=Y

Accessibility: This paved or gravel (with wooden bridges) trail is typically at least six feet wide (a painted center dividing line is present along asphalt portions which reduces the width). The estimated grade is mostly gentle, all 5% or less. Overall the trail has a steady downhill when going west. Depending on weather and trail conditions the gravel sections may be difficult to navigate with wheelchairs/mobility equipment or strollers.

There are at least 2 designated wheelchair accessible car parking spots at the paved trailhead on the east side.

name: Ridge Trail, Camp Trail, Merry Go Round Loop
description:
• General fee: Mount Madonna County Park charges a fee to enter. For more information, please visit https://parks.sccgov.org/plan-your-visit/santa-clara-county-park-fees

This trail begins at the Spring Parking area, located next to Spring Lake, and takes you to Mount Madonna County Park. The trail winds through a shaded forest on mostly gravel roads, offering distant views of Big Sur. It’s well-maintained but be prepared for steep sections. During the spring, you'll find beautiful wildflowers.

name: South Rim Trail Via Alum Rock Road
description:
• Parking fee information: There is a fee to park at Alum Rock Park. For more information, please visit https://www.sanjoseca.gov/Home/Components/FacilityDirectory/FacilityDirectory/2088/2028

The trailhead is located at the corner of Canon Vista Avenue and Alum Rock Avenue. The route winds through Alum Rock Park and alongside Upper Penitencia Creek. Facilities dotted along the trail include multiple restrooms, drinking fountains, and picnic areas. 

This trail has lovely scenery and wonderful views as you walk along the South Rim Trail. The loop can be done in either direction. Heading clockwise will mean you head up the steeper switchbacks.

name: Mission Peak Loop from Stanford Avenue Staging Area
description:
Enjoy the spectacular views of the South bay as you climb up to Mission Peak. Although steep, the views of the Bay Area are very rewarding. On a clear day hikers can see the skylines of Oakland, San Francisco and San Jose.

This is a moderate to strenuous trail with a constant uphill climb until you reach the summit. The trail is a well-maintained gravel base until the last half mile. From this point, the trail is hard-packed dirt and rock. Difficulty can increase during the rainy season when the trail can be muddy and slippery.

The Stanford Avenue staging area is also the western access to the Ohlone Wilderness Trail, a 29-mile hiking and riding trail through some of southern Alameda County's most beautiful wilderness, and provides access to Mission Peak's 2,999 acres.

Ensure that you have plenty of water before embarking on this hike, as there are very few spots to locate shade. The trail may be shared with equestrians, and dogs are allowed. There is very limited parking at Stanford Avenue Staging Area. It is best to park at Ohlone College to access Mission Peak: 43600 Mission Blvd to Anza Pine Road. Dogs are allowed on leash in developed areas/under voice command in undeveloped areas of the park.

name: Purisima Creek Redwoods North Ridge Trail
park: Purisima Creek Redwoods Open Space Preserve
description: Explore a section of the Bay Area Ridge Trail and hike through beautiful Redwood groves in the Purisima Creek Redwoods Open Space Preserve. The trail travels downhill before returning uphill on the way back to the trailhead. Some hikers may benefit from using trekking poles to help assist with the descent and ascent.

name: Moraga Steps to Grand View Park
park: Moraga Steps to Grand View Park
description: This short trail takes you to a viewpoint with a gorgeous 360-degree view of San Fransico and the ocean. The trail that leads to the vantage point is mainly made up of steep stairs with railings, known as the Mosaic Stairway. It is a beautiful staircase with handcrafted tiles on the sides of the steps.

name: Sweeney Ridge, Milagra Ridge, and Mori Point Loop
park: Elevation gain6h 44mEstimated timeLoopThis loop is a great mix of natural areas and urban areas near Sharp Park
description: This loop is a great mix of natural areas and urban areas near Sharp Park Beach. You will travel through several slivers of Golden Gate National Recreation Area with views of the coast along the way and walk along the beach. During the spring the rolling hills are typically a lush green color and wildflowers are blooming.
