name: Shoreline Trail: Salt Marsh Overlook
description:
Trail Highlights: This is a paved, mixed-use trail (hikers and bikers). Along Shoreline Drive to Park Street inter - section, there is a sandy beach portion of the trail and there are several woven fiber mats laid on top of sand for easier access to the beach. 

Trail Directions: You will travel out and back along the same trail so you can turn around at any point during your trip. Begin at the park's McKay Avenue entrance and follow the paved Shoreline Trail past the Visitor Center to the left (south) of your route. Enjoy a small pond, habitat to ducks and dragonflies, on your left as you stroll along. As you round the large oval field, stay to the right. The 8th Street/Otis Drive parking lot will be to your left. Continue on the Shoreline Trail which will take you down to Broadway, ending at the Elsie Ro - emer Bird Sanctuary, home to the endangered clapper rail and salt marsh harvest mouse. Turn around and retrace your steps to return to the starting point

This trail has scenic views of the shallow bay waters and the far cities and hills, as well as easy beach access and moderate temperatures. From the Crab Cove Visitor Center, head south on the Shoreline Trail and follow it to Salt Marsh Overlook. The beach will be on your right and the city on your left. There are multiple beach access points, as well as many bathrooms and water fountains. The route ends at Salt Marsh Overlook. There is a nice viewing area for shorebirds here and you may want to bring binoculars.

From the late 1880s until just before World War II, Alameda Beach was the largest beach in San Francisco Bay and a popular amusement park. Now it is operated by the East Bay Regional Park District and no longer has rollercoasters and rides. It is now used for swimming, kayaking, beachcombing, and birdwatching. There are over 2.5 miles of shoreline with beach access. The Crab Cove Visitor Center has interesting exhibits on life in the San Francisco Bay, including an 800-gallon aquarium. The Elsie Roemer Bird Sanctuary is at the far end.

Accessibility: There are several designated accessible spaces in the large paved parking lot off of Westline Drive at the northwest end of the trail. All of them are van-accessible with striped access aisles. The trail surface is paved asphalt or a wooden boardwalk (with railings). The route optionally uses a bike lane on the side of the road marked with a painted line.

The entire trail is estimated to be in the gentle grade category (3% or less). This trail is accessible for people using mobility devices and/or strollers. The average trail width is four feet and above, and it is hard asphalt; the typical grade is level. There are benches and picnic tables along the route for resting. There are wheelchair-accessible bathrooms along the trail. The visitor center is wheelchair-accessible.

Park Features: The paved Shoreline Trail runs adjacent to San Francisco Bay with sweeping views and sandy beaches. Tides move from high to low twice a day, so every visit may offer a new vista. At Crab Cove parking lot there are four accessible parking spaces, not van accessible, and there are also two reservable accessible picnic sites, Neptune and City View with wheelchair accessible picnic tables. There are two accessible restrooms at Crown Beach and one accessible restroom at Shoreline Drive at Grand Street. Restroom hours can vary as to when they are open to the public.

$5 parking, May-September

name: South Ridge, Middle Ridge, and Meadow Trail Loop
description:
A beautiful, quiet trail with many different personalities and no shortage of challenge. Some sections are flat, wide, and open, while others are narrow, rugged, and hilly. Overall, an excellent and pleasantly unpredictable hike that will leave you feeling invigorated!

This trail travels near private property in many spots. Please take care to stay on marked trails and respect private property signage when encountered.

name: Stevens Creek Trail
description:
Featuring the Stevens Creek Trail in Cupertino this is an out and back with a small loop in Linda Vista Park. This trail follows the newly opened section above the Deep Cliff Golf Course to connect from the McClellan Ranch to Linda Vista Park.

Accessibility: There are 5 designated accessible spaces in the paved parking lot off of Stevens Creek Boulevard at the north end of the trail. All of them are van-accessible with striped access aisles. The trail surface is paved concrete and smooth. It is typically at least 6 feet wide. The whole trail is estimated to be in the gentle (3% or less) grade category. This trail will likely be navigable for most wheelchairs/mobility equipment or stroller users.

name: Quail Loop Trail to Live Oak  Nature Trail
description:
• Junipero Serra County Park requires a fee to park. For more information, please visit: https://parks.smcgov.org/junipero-serra-park

This trail starts at the parking lot off Crystal Spring Road, where restrooms, a picnic area, and a playground are available. It then loops through Junipero Serra County Park, which features another playground, a picnic shelter, and lookout points with views of San Bruno and the bay. The trail provides a good mix of sunshine and shade.

name: Bay Farm Island Loop Trail
park: WalkingEasy to parkBathrooms availableDog-friendlyGreat conditionsResidential trail along and through a neighborhood. The trail weaves around and over the water. Easy trail with no elevation.Park
description: This is a great a nature walk. First half, along the water, passes by houses and little parks with views of the city and the rest of Alameda. The airport and industrial parts are not very scenic. You will get a cool perspective of SF skyline. It is fairly well trafficked with families, joggers and dog walkers

name: Sugarloaf Hill via Salson Trail, Comb Over, and Laurelwood Park Trail
description:
• Partial Closure: Part of this route near the San Juan Canyon Trailhead is temporarily inaccessible, but you can still enjoy other sections of this trail. For more information, please visit https://www.belmont.gov/Home/Components/FacilityDirectory/FacilityDirectory/96/509

Starting on a broad grassy hill, the hike to Sugarloaf Hill via the Salson, Comb Over, and Laurelwood Park Trail becomes a steep trail that climbs to the summit. The trail meanders across grassland speckled with coyote brush. Buckeye and oaks provide shade over the wide trail. As you climb, you'll follow winding trails through patches of scrub, grasslands, and forests.

Upon reaching the summit of Sugarloaf Hill, you will be treated to expansive vistas. On clear days, you can see the East Bay hills, the Santa Cruz Mountains, and San Francisco. Expect to come across chamise, bush lupine, and sagebrush along the trail. Watch out for poison oak and wood rat nests.

name: Stuart Ridge Trail and Ohlone Trail
description:
This is a beautiful wooded hike with a steady elevation gain the whole way. On the way up, there are a few views of Saratoga and beyond. The trail itself is in great shape and features a section along a gravel road. 

Several benches along the way allow you to stop and take in the surroundings. Once you reach the pretty little Sanborn Creek, you can turn around and return via the same route. Parking is available at the Trailhead in Saratoga Quarry Park.

name: Lake Road, Lake Loop, and John Brooks Trail
description: This trail begins at the end of Lake Road, where street parking and restrooms are available. It loops through the Water Dog Lake Open Space, offering a good mix of shade and sun. The trail takes you to Water Dog Lake, provides lovely water views, and follows along Belmont Creek. There are a few benches where you can sit and relax.

name: Tafoni Sandstone Formation via Tafoni, Fir, and Methuselah Loop
park: El Corte De Madera Creek Open Space Preserve
description:
• Access information: The Methuselah Trail from Manzanita to Fir is temporarily closed to equestrians. For more information, please visit https://www.openspace.org/preserves/el-corte-de-madera-creek#trail-closures 

This is a gorgeous trail with interesting sandstone rock formations along the way. The trail has lots of shade, making it a great spot to escape the heat during the summer months. There are some steep sections, but the views are worth your effort. Keep an eye out for mountain bikers on certain sections of the trail.

name: Stevens Creek Reservoir to Maisie’s Peak
description:
This trail explores several parks and preserves to the east of Stevens Creek. The first half follows the shoreline along a beautiful narrow path. It can be overgrown with poison ivy here, so protective clothing is recommended. 

The second half is more demanding, with more elevation changes. There are several intersecting trails that allow you to cut this loop short or add a detour up to Maisie's Peak. Enjoy the impressive view of the reservoir and lakes.

name: San Andreas and Sanborn Trails to Skyline Trail
description: • Fee Information: Sanborn County Park charges a fee to enter. For more information, please https://parks.santaclaracounty.gov/locations/sanborn-county-park

name: Hidden Lake Foot Path
description: Explore this 0.6-km loop trail near Milpitas, California. Generally considered an easy route, it takes an average of 7 min to complete. This trail is great for birding, running, and walking, and it's unlikely you'll encounter many other people while exploring. The trail is open year-round and is beautiful to visit anytime. Dogs are welcome, but must be on a leash.

name: Bay Area Ridge Trail: Windy Hill Open Space Preserve
park: Bay Area Ridge Trail: Windy Hill Open Space Preserve
description:
Follow the Windy Hill ridgeline through a sheltered forest and across rolling grasslands on a narrow footpath and broad wagon road. Enjoy sweeping views of the San Mateo Coast and Santa Clara Valley. True to its name, strong winds are possible in this preserve, as is coastal fog. Since this is a relatively short trip, hikers and equestrians may want to do the 6.6- or 6.2-mile round-trip. Bicycles are only allowed on a short 0.5-mile section.

For more information, see the Bay Area Ridge Trail page here: https://ridgetrail.org/windy-hill-open-space-preserve/

This trail description is excerpted from the 2019 Guidebook. For details on all of the Bay Area Ridge trails, trailheads and more buy the book from Wilderness Press: https://www.wildernesspress.com/product.php?productid=16685&cat=274&bestseller=Y

name: Mission Peak via Peak Meadow Trail
description:
The trail features peaceful wooded areas and passable steep sections, including the significant hill crossing. The wide gravel road gets narrower and steeper as you get closer to the top. You may see various species throughout the trail, including birds, turkeys, and cows. 

Once you reach the summit, you can take in a 360-degree panorama of the whole Bay Area. Views of the Santa Cruz Mountains, the Sierra Nevada Mountains, Mount Tamalpais, Mount Hamilton, Mount  Diablo, and the San Francisco and San Jose skylines are visible from this peak.

name: Bay Area Ridge Trail: Alum Rock Park to Sierra Vista Open Space
park: Bay Area Ridge Trail: Alum Rock Park
description:
• Partial closure: As of October 2024, part of this route is temporarily inaccessible, but you can still enjoy other sections of this trail. For more information, please visit https://www.sanjoseca.gov/home/showpublisheddocument/110007/638568325940770000
• Parking fee information: There is a fee to park at Alum Rock Park. For more information, please visit https://www.sanjoseca.gov/Home/Components/FacilityDirectory/FacilityDirectory/2088/2028

Begin in a creek corridor and climb to high ridges on the east side of the Santa Clara Valley for a bird’s-eye view of nearby San José, the South Bay, and the Peninsula. The steep trail winds up a grassy, southwest-facing hillside. Because of the sun exposure, the trip is best done with an early start on cool spring days or midday in winter, when skies are clear after rains.

Restrooms are available at the starting point of this route.

For more information, see the Bay Area Ridge Trail page here: https://ridgetrail.org/alum-rock-park-and-boccardo-trail-corridor/

name: Joseph D Loop Trail
description: • Joseph D Grant County Park collects a day-use fee for vehicular entrance year-round. For more information, please see https://parks.sccgov.org/plan-your-visit/santa-clara-county-park-fees#3925188384-3236192913

name: Monument Peak Trail
description:
• General fee: Ed R. Levin County Park charges a fee to enter. For more information, please visit https://parks.sccgov.org/plan-your-visit/santa-clara-county-park-fees

A beautiful and challenging hike up to the summit of Monument Peak. If you are looking for a memorable adventure, this hike is for you. Watch out for soaring hang gliders, as you take in stunning views of the valley and the Bay Area. Bring water and sunscreen, as this hike can get hot.

Connect the Agua Caliente trail to Monument Peak Trail, after summiting return via the Agua Caliente trail and Calera Creek Trail.

name: Diablo Vista Loop
description:
• Parking fee information: There is a fee to park at this trailhead. There is also a fee per dog. For more information, please visit https://www.ebparks.org/parks/roberts

The Diablo Vista Loop is a short, easy route. After a brief walk through oak and redwood trees, it leads to a viewpoint. The rest of the loop follows paved paths around the park, known as the Redwood Bowl. There are several drinking fountains, but it gets hot here in the summer, so it is a good idea to bring sun protection.

This trail isn't wheelchair-friendly, but Roberts Park has a barrier-free, wheelchair accessible children's play area. The swim complex is also fully accessible, including the bathhouse and an accessible lift into the pool.

name: Crystal Springs and Campground Trail
description:
• General fee: Huddart County Park charges a fee to enter. For more information, please visit https://www.smcgov.org/parks/huddart-park
• Partial closure: As of September 2024, the Campground Trail is temporarily inaccessible between markers 19 and 24, but you can still enjoy other sections of this trail. For more information, please visit https://www.smcgov.org/parks/news/huddart-park-closures

Crystal Springs and Campground Trail is a beautiful shaded trail in Huddart Country Park. The route follows a dirt path through towering forest, passing by creeks and over wooden bridges.

Along the way, there are a few nice view points through the trees, and in the wetting months, lots of interesting fungi line the path. The trailhead has parking, a water refill station, a playground, and restrooms.

name: Vasona Lake Loop and Los Gatos Creek Trail
description:
• Seasonal closure: Vasona Lake County Park is subject to seasonal closure during the wintertime and wet weather due to weather conditions. For more information, please visit https://parks.sccgov.org/closures-updates

Explore Vasona Lake County Park either on foot or on wheels. This trail helps you explore the surroundings of the park including the lake, bridge, boating area, children's play area, a train track, carousel, and several picnic areas. This trail is suitable for all age groups for walking, running, and cycling. The park is open year-round from 8:00 a.m. until sunset.

Accessibility: There are 3 designated accessible spaces in the paved parking lot off of Blossom Hill Road at the south end of the trail. All of them are van-accessible with striped access aisles. The trail surface is paved concrete or asphalt and smooth. It is typically at least 6 feet wide. There is a painted dividing line along some of the trail which reduces the width. 

The whole trail is estimated to be in the mostly gentle (5% or less) grade category. This trail will likely be navigable for most wheelchairs/mobility equipment or stroller users. There are benches and picnic tables along the route for resting.

name: Upper White Oak Trail
description: This trail is very narrow most of the way. There are nice views and wildflowers each spring.

name: Monte Bello Preserve Loop
description:
Monte Bello Preserve Loop is a moderate to difficult loop through Monte Bello Open Space Preserve and a portion of Rancho San Antonio Open Space Preserve as it summits Black Mountain. The well-maintained route offers beautiful rolling hills, spectacular views from Santa Cruz to the Bay, and a number of wildlife and wildflower viewing opportunities, especially in late March and early April. There is limited shade on the ascent but plenty of tree cover on the way down. There is no drinkable water so bring plenty of liquids and a snack or lunch for the top of Black Mountain. Dogs are not allowed on this route so keep them at home. 

Start at the parking lot on Page Mill Road across from the Los Trancos Open Space Preserve and head out on the White Oak Trail until you reach the Skid Row Trail. Follow this on to the Stevens Creek Nature Trail and then Canyon Trail. When you hit the fork, head left on the Indian Creek Trail until it merges with Monte Bello Road Trail, and continue on this up to the summit of Black Mountain. It’s a bit of a scramble but worth the climb. Head back down the same way and then take a right on Old Ranch Trail. Follow this and continue on Bella Vista Trail, Canyon Trail, and Stevens Creek Nature Trail back to the parking lot.

name: Pomponio Loop Trail
description:
Explore this extended trail network that is accessible near the Memorial Park campground! This trail has some great spots to stop and have a picnic. 

You'll climb up to the Pomponio Creek Overlook (995') for stunning views of the surrounding area. Keep on the lookout for poison oak along the trail, as it is known to grow in this area.

name: Volcanic Peak via Quarry Road and Volcanic Trail
description: This route takes a series of fire roads and dirt trails to the 1,634-foot summit of Volcanic Peak. Quarry Road steeply climbs to the peak and levels out to follow the ridgeline south. Once on the ridge, there are panoramic views of the San Francisco Bay and East Hills. However, there is no shade or water along the route, so be sure to plan accordingly.

name: Hellyer County Park Loop
description:
• General fee: Hellyer County Park charges a fee to enter. For more information, please visit https://parks.sccgov.org/santa-clara-county-park-fees
• Partial closure: The Coyote Creek Trail is closed between Hellyer Park and Embedded Way due to flooding and swiftly moving water, but you can still enjoy other sections of this trail. For more information, please visit https://parks.sccgov.org/closures-updates

name: Rengstorff Park Loop
description: Try this 1.1-mile loop trail near Mountain View, California. Generally considered an easy route, it takes an average of 19 min to complete. This is a popular trail for walking, but you can still enjoy some solitude during quieter times of day. The best times to visit this trail are January through October. Dogs are welcome, but must be on a leash.

name: Upper Fort Mason
park: Golden Gate Bridge. The trail’s entrance from the foot of Van Ness Avenue (near Aquatic Park
description:
According to Access Northern California (http://accessnca.org/access-northern-california/explore/explore-detail-view/?site_id=130): Fort Mason, a former Army post dating from the Civil War era, is divided into Upper and Lower Fort Mason with the Great Meadow sandwiched between. The main draw to the 50-acre upper section is the expansive lawns of the Great Meadow where on most days you will see picnickers (no picnic tables), people throwing Frisbees, dog walkers, and even sunbathers on rare warm days. Its location on a bluff-top provides some nice views of the bay, including Golden Gate Bridge, but it also means that it can be windy here. There is level access onto the lawn throughout, however, less so at its eastern end. Wide, paved, gently sloping paths circumnavigate the meadow winding past a few statues. 

Inside the fort complex, you can visit a community garden, stay at the accessible Fisherman's Wharf Hostel, and take a self-guided history tour. Lovely views of the Bay, Alcatraz Island, and the municipal pier are at the backside of the complex and from the Bay Trail (aka MacDowell Rd.).

Lower Fort Mason, on the waterfront, is home to the Fort Mason Center, a thriving cultural and educational complex with theaters, galleries, museums, a gourmet vegetarian restaurant, classrooms, exhibition spaces, and nonprofit organization offices including Environmental Traveling Companions that offers guided whitewater rafting, kayaking, and ski programs to people with disabilities and disadvantaged youth.  A farmers market takes place every Sunday, 9:30 am-1:30 pm.

After exploring Fort Mason, you can extend your trip to the west by taking the Golden Gate Promenade along the Marina Green, through Crissy Field, and still further to Fort Point. Be sure to check out the Wave Organ, a wave-activated sound sculpture on a jetty jutting into the bay at the marina.

The Wave Organ is a stone "sound sculpture" built with chunks of old monuments and buildings from the 1915 Panama Pacific International Exposition, which was held in this area (the Marina Green was formerly a marsh, filled to accommodate the Exposition, in part using debris from the 1906 earthquake). 

ACCESSIBILITY: Wheelchair-accessible entrances to Upper Fort Mason are on Bay Street at Franklin Street, MacArthur Avenue, and Van Ness Avenue. Accessible entrances to the Great Meadow are at the Bay Street parking lot, the west end of MacArthur Avenue, and at Laguna Street. Of the two Laguna Street entrances, the one closest to Bay Street has a gentle grade. The one closer to Marina Boulevard is steep. There is firm designated van-accessible parking with a slope no greater than 2% at the west end of MacArthur Avenue by the Great Meadow, in front of and behind the GGNRA offices, on Franklin Street across from the church, by General’s Residence, and within the quad. There is also a lot of parking spaces in the fee lot by the south end. The accessible parking at the trailhead is paved, has a striped access aisle, and is a paid spot.

The trail surface is paved. It is typically at least four feet wide. All of the sidewalks in the upper fort complex have curb ramps. Both manual and motorized wheelchair users will be able to easily explore accessible highlights of Upper Fort Mason. 

However, manual wheelchair users and others with reduced mobility may find the sloping topography around the meadow, and getting from lower Fort Mason to upper Fort Mason requires effort. The majority of the trail is estimated to be in the mostly gentle (5% or less) grade category but there are steeper sections at about 0.1 and 0.3-0.4 miles when going east. At the western side of the meadow, look for signage that indicates the accessible route to Lower Fort Mason. The steeper but more direct route may be manageable to some wheelchair users.

A section of the Bay Trail runs along a cliff at the backside of Upper Fort Mason. It’s lined with eucalyptus and cypress trees but still affords views of lower Fort Mason, the Bay, and the Golden Gate Bridge. The trail’s entrance from the foot of Van Ness Avenue (near Aquatic Park Municipal Pier) is very steep. Alternatively, you can also reach the trail from the Great Meadow and then travel a few hundred feet further before it travels steeply downhill towards Van Ness Avenue. Adventurous and skilled wheelchair users may be able to travel this section––assistance may be required.

In Upper Fort Mason, to reach the vista point of the Bay and remnants of Black Point Battery and an authentic cannon, follow the sidewalk towards the water at Franklin Street to its end.

The visitor's center is wheelchair accessible. There are accessible bathrooms on the south side of the Great Meadow, in lower Fort Mason, and (while not considered public restrooms) within pier 2 (lower level of building C, and at the Conference Room at 308). Accessible picnic tables can be found by the hostel with nice views of the Great Meadow. The accessible chapel can be rented.

name: San Pedro Valley Park Loop
description: This route is a long loop connecting almost all the trails in San Pedro Valley Park. There are great views, small waterfalls, and interesting flora along the way! There are beautiful wildflowers in the late spring and early summer. The hike has two big climbs, the second one being a bit steeper than the first. Both ascends have nice gradual descents.

name: Bay to Breakers Course Route
description: Cross the full width of San Francisco while following the route of the world famous Bay to Breakers race, the oldest consecutively run footrace in the world!

name: Lake Chabot Loop via West, Bass, Columbine, Honker, East Shore Trails
description:
• Parking fee information: There is a fee to park at Lake Chabot Regional Park. For more information, please visit https://www.ebparks.org/parks/lake-chabot

This is a beautiful hiking area with both paved and dirt trails that are moderately steep and lovely views of the water. If desired, you can avoid a large portion of the paved East Shore Trail by taking the southern Cameron Loop after crossing the Honker Bay bridge, Ten Hills Trail, and Indian Cove Trail, leaving a very short paved section to the Marina.

Dogs must be on leash in developed areas/under voice command in undeveloped park areas.

Accessibility:

According to Access Northern California (https://accessnca.org/access-northern-california/explore/explore-detail-view/?site_id=238): Lake Chabot is a popular destination for families and bustles on weekends. Among the many amenities you can find are multiple picnic areas, a grassy play area, fishing, an outdoor fitness zone with interactive exercise machines (one is designed for wheelchair access), and miles of lakefront trails. The Marina has a café, tackle and bait shop, rental boats, and seasonal lake tours aboard the tour boat "Chabot Queen." The ramp to the boats is accessible but quite steep. To board the tour boat, a portable ramp is available.

The paved West Shore and East Shore trails around the lake offer some access, although their steep terrain may deter some with limited mobility. They are worth the effort if possible because it feels as though you’re far from the nearby bustling cities.

Although paved, the West Shore Trail has numerous steep grades throughout as it travels high above the lake, passing in and out of shade provided by oaks, bay laurel, willow, and cottonwood trees. Poison oak is plentiful, as well as vetch, blackberries, and blue-eyed grass. A few interpretive panels about the dam’s history are towards the end of this 2-mile route. Benches are scattered throughout, although most have a steep grade to reach them.

name: Best trails inRancho San Antonio Open Space Preserve
park: Rancho San Antonio Open Space Preservebest Trails In Rancho San Antonio Open Space Preserve Best Trails In Rancho San Antonio Open Space Preserve
description: Rancho San Antonio County Park is a popular park in the South Bay Area that offers 29 miles of hiking, trail running, cycling, and equestrian trails that connect to the nearby San Antonio Ranch Open Space Preserve. Several challenging trails through this park lead to Black Mountain, whose summit is located in adjacent Monte Bello Open Space Preserve. The trail system goes through a variety of diverse environments including valleys, creeks, and ridges. The park is best suited for hiking and trail running. The PG&E Trail is a popular trail for runners. This trail stretches along rolling hills and electricity towers and provides a good cardio workout. Other popular trails include Wildcat Canyon Loop, Coyote Trail, Deer Hollow Farm Trail, which is great for kids, and the various trails that lead to Black Mountain, from Hidden Villa Trailhead and Rhus Ridge Trailhead. The park also provides opportunities for bikers and equestrians with cycling and equestrian trails and there is a large equestrian staging area. Bikes are only permitted on paved trails such as the Rancho San Antonio Trail. Horses are limited to the staging area the Coyote Trail, a;though horses are permitted on most trails within the Open Space Preserve. The South Meadow area adjacent to the staging area has a water trough for horses. The North Meadow area, across Permanente Creek from the parking area, has four tennis courts, a few picnic tables, and barbecues. Deer Hollow Farm, managed by the City of Mountain View, has farm animals, making it a great family activity. There are multiple parking lots in the park, however the parking lot can get crowded on weekends so it is best to get there early. Dogs are not allowed in the park. Hours: 8:00 a.m. – Sunset

name: Alpine Pond to Horseshoe Lake
description:
This is one of the prettiest places in the string of open-space preserves along Highway 35, also known as Skyline Boulevard. A nature center looks out over the lake. While it's possible to hike more than 20 miles at a stretch in the interconnected preserves of the Mid-peninsula Open Space District, it's also nice to keep it simple with an easy stroll around a pond, and this not-too-difficult hike to the hillsides nearby. 

This hike starts near Alpine Pond, moves on to the Ipewa Trail then loops back toward the pond via the Sunny Jim Trail. If you feel like exploring more, look for the Ohlone Indians' mortars behind a few rocks southwest of Alpine Pond. The Ohlones used these mortars to grind acorns into flour.

This full trail has too many steep sections over 8% and an unpaved surface to be marked as wheelchair/mobility equipment or stroller-friendly. The most accessible portion of the trail is the Alpine Pond Loop. This trail has its own trail page located here: https://www.alltrails.com/explore/trail/us/california/alpine-pond-loop

name: Tuibun, Red Hill, Bayview, and Chochenyo Trail Loop
description:
The Tuibun, Red Hill, Bayview, and Chochenyo Trail Loop meanders across rolling hills covered in grassland and marshlands in Coyote Hills Regional Park. The trail from the Chochenyo Trail passes boardwalks and offers excellent views of the marsh and Coyote Hills. Wildlife sightings are frequent. The salt evaporation ponds can be seen from the Bayview Trail.

At the summit of Red Hill, the highest point in Coyote Hills Regional Park, you'll be rewarded with breathtaking 360-degree vistas, a picnic table, and some fascinating rocks. A large portion of the Bay Area, including Mt. Diablo, Mission Peak, Mt. Hamilton, Loma Prieta, Mt. Umunhum, and Mt. Tamalpais, is seen from this viewpoint.

name: Mori Point Trail
park: Length170ftElevation gain41mEstimated timeOut & backBegin near Sharp Park
description: Begin near Sharp Park Beach and travel south along the Promenade towards Mori Point. The trail is mostly flat before climbing up and down a small hill to the point. From this point, there are amazing views of the coastline. Be sure to relax at the beach after you've finished the hike! There are also picnic tables near the parking area.

name: Cora Older Trail and Creekside Trail Loop
description: This trail begins at the parking lot off Prospect Road, where restrooms are available, and takes you to Fremont Older Open Space Preserve. The parking area at the trailhead is limited, so it's recommended that you arrive early. The trail winds through groves and open meadows, offering beautiful views of the San Jose metropolitan area and rolling hills. During the spring, you'll find beautiful wildflowers and butterflies.

name: Stanford Dish Loop Trail
park: Stanford Dish Loop Trail. Bring plenty of water and wear sunscreen and protective clothing.Top trails nearbyRedtail Loop to Arastradero Creek LoopRedtail Loop to Arastradero Creek LoopEnid Pearson-Arastradero Preserve4.6·Moderate·5.1 mi·Est. 2h 12mOhlone Trail to Arastradero Creek TrailOhlone Trail to Arastradero Creek TrailEnid Pearson-Arastradero Preserve
description:
The Stanford Dish loop is a popular route for Stanford University students as well as Silicon Valley professionals. The area is named after the giant radio telescope that is hard to miss. Its steep paved trail is suitable for running, walking, and hiking. Bicycles are not allowed. 

Opening hours vary depending on the month of the year:
January: 6:30 am-5:00 pm
February: 6:30 am-5:30 pm
March: 6 am-6:30 pm
April - August: 6 am-7:30 pm
September: 6:30 am-7:00 pm
October: 6:30 am-6:00 pm
November - December: 6:30 am-5:00 pm

The route periodically closes for Red Flag Warnings, maintenance, or educational events. To see current information, please see https://dish.stanford.edu/

Accessibility: Visitors using wheelchairs, mobility equipment, or strollers may need all-terrain tires or adaptive/motorized equipment for the surface type and grade. There are 2 designated van-accessible parking spaces on Stanford Avenue in the street-side parking area. The trail surface is paved asphalt and smooth, typically at least 8 feet wide. This trail is estimated to be mostly gentle (8% or less), with some steeper sections that may require assistance or need to be avoided. Benches are available along the route for resting.

name: Hunter's Point and Older Pet Cemetary Loop
description: This route heads north from Prospect Road to Hunter's Point, a gorgeous lookout with panoramic views. The Hayfield Trail is a wide dirt path that steadily climbs among the golden hills and chaparral that California is known for. After enjoying the high point, you can take the Creekside Trail past the Pet Cemetary or stay on the Cora Old Trail.

name: Peak, Panorama and Spring Valley Trail
description: A very good beginner trail despite the steep hike to begin with. Great views!

name: Circle Corral and Bass Lake Loop
description: • Joseph D Grant County Park collects a day-use fee for vehicular entrance year-round. For more information, please see https://parks.sccgov.org/plan-your-visit/santa-clara-county-park-fees#3925188384-3236192913

name: Rancho Canada Del Oro via Serpentine Loop Trail
park: Rancho Cañada Del Oro Open Space Preserve
description: This trail starts from the parking lot off Casa Loma Road and meanders through Rancho Cañada del Oro Open Space Preserve. Visitors will be treated to wonderful scenery and breathtaking views. The trail is mostly exposed and rocky, although there are some shaded spots too. You'll encounter multiple varieties of wildflowers on the hillsides, creating a colorful display. Be mindful of rattlesnakes along the trail.

name: Little Llagas Creek, Bald Peaks, and Mayfair Ranch Loop
park: Rancho Cañada Del Oro Open Space Preserve
description: A great hike with seasonal wildflowers. Mayfair Ranch Trail starting from the staging area in Canada del Oro, up and down the ridge, Longwall Canyon Trail up the hill and continuing along Bald Peaks Trail all the way down to your starting point. On a clear day you will have good views of San Francisco and beyond.

name: Knibbs Knob Trail
description:
• All day use requires a reservation. Please go to www.gooutsideandplay.org​ or call 408-355-2201 to make your reservation.​ There is also a fee to park. 

This route takes you first to the waterfall in Swanson Canyon before taking you up Nibbs Knob trail and back. You can take an optional side trip to the summit of Nibbs Knob, but this mapped route takes you up the ridge only. You'll still get most of the steep climb and amazing views as you hike along the trail.

name: Vista Trail and Valley View Trail Loop
description: This trail begins from Ramohs Way, where there is a parking area on the side of the road. It is mostly shaded and winds through Heintz Open Space Preserve. The path is very slippery and steep at the top, with lots of loose dirt. Some sections are narrow. Vegetation often encroaches. So, check yourself for ticks.

name: North Peak via Montara Mountain Trail
description: North Peak via Montara Mountain Trail is a popular hike just outside of Pacifica in San Pedro Valley County Park. There is a parking lot at the trailhead along with bathrooms. This partly shaded route is well-maintained and easy to navigate. Follow Montara Mountain Trail to North Peak Access Road and then return on Brooks Creek Trail and Old Trout Farm Loop Trail once you descend. The route offers incredible views of the Pacific/Montara area and of San Francisco on a clear day. There are a number of other great hiking trails in the area if you are looking to add some more mileage to your day.

name: Little Yosemite and Indian Joe Creek Loop
description:
• Parking fee information: There is a fee to park at Sunol Wilderness Regional Preserve on weekends and holidays. For more information, please visit https://www.ebparks.org/parks/sunol

This trail offers gorgeous vistas, wildflowers, and rock formations. Heading clockwise, you go uphill with lots of shade and downhill via exposed slopes. If heading out later in the day, bring plenty of water and sun protection. 

The views at the top of the hill are magnificent, making the steep climb well worth the effort. The trailhead is a short distance south of the visitors center and can be accessed via Geary Road. There are many side trails, so downloading offline maps is helpful to stay on the right path. Parking and restrooms are also available at the beginning of the trail.

name: Heron's Head and India Basin
description:
Heron's Head and India Basin Shoreline Parks are two community green spaces that offer outdoor education, recreation, bird watching, and community events. A connector trail makes it easy to link and enjoy both parks. The views of India Basin in the San Francisco Bay are gorgeous, and this area is a hot spot for birds and other wildlife.

Accessibility:

Equipment  
This trail is likely accessible for visitors using wheelchairs, mobility equipment, or strollers.

Parking  
There are 3 designated accessible spaces with striped access aisles in the paved parking lot.

Surface  
The trail surface is concrete, paved asphalt, or firmly packed crushed stone, typically 5 to 8 feet wide.

Grade  
This trail is estimated to be mostly gentle (5% or less).

More Info  
Accessible restrooms are available at the parking lot. Picnic tables and benches are available along the route for resting.

name: Fir Trail to Methuselah Trail to Sierra Morena Trail Loop
park: El Corte De Madera Creek Open Space Preserve
description: The Fir Trail to Methuselah Trail to Sierra Morena Trail Loop meanders through creekside, surrounded by redwood forests. You'll be treated to stunning ocean views as you navigate the loop and encounter rare sandstone formations. The trail winds through tanoak, huckleberry, and Douglas fir trees. The narrow trail runs along the side of a hill.

name: Best trails inUniversity of California Santa Cruz
description:
Want to find the best trails in University of California Santa Cruz for an adventurous hike or a family trip? AllTrails has 10 great trails for hiking and birding and more. Enjoy hand-curated trail maps, along with reviews and photos from nature lovers like you.

Ready for your next hike or bike ride? Explore one of 9 easy hiking trails in University of California Santa Cruz that are great for the whole family. Looking for a more strenuous hike? We've got you covered, with trails ranging from 22 to 682 feet in elevation gain. Whatever you have planned for the day, you can find the perfect trail for your next trip to University of California Santa Cruz.

name: Coyote Trail
description:
• Foothills Nature Preserve charges an entry fee. An annual pass is also available for purchase. Dogs are not allowed on weekends or holidays. For more information, please visit https://www.cityofpaloalto.org/Departments/Community-Services/Open-Space-Parks/Neighborhood-Parks/Foothills-Nature-Preserve



This route takes you along Coyote Trail, which has a steady and manageable incline and a nice mix of sun and shade. Once you reach Madera Point, you'll be rewarded with sweeping views of Foothills Nature Preserve. This area has beautiful flora you can enjoy, but be careful because Poison Ivy is also found here. 

Note: Dogs are permitted on weekdays only (except holidays). They must be on a leash.

name: Tennis and Community Park to Arroyo del Valle Loop
description: Try this 3.8-mile loop trail near Pleasanton, California. Generally considered an easy route, it takes an average of 1 h 8 min to complete. This is a popular trail for running and walking, but you can still enjoy some solitude during quieter times of day. The trail is open year-round and is beautiful to visit anytime. Dogs are welcome, but must be on a leash.

name: Blue Heron Lake and Strawberry Hill Loop
description:
The Stow Lake Loop offers a pleasant stroll around a beautiful lake. A popular spot for joggers and bird watchers. Explore The island and walk past Huntington Falls.

Accessibility: 

Equipment
Visitors using wheelchairs, mobility equipment, or strollers may need all-terrain tires or adaptive/motorized equipment for the surface type and grade.

Parking
There are 3 designated van-accessible spaces with striped access aisles in the paved parking lot off Stow Lake Drive at the trail's north end.

Surface
The trail surface is pavement, packed gravel, or natural surface, and typically at least 4 feet wide.

Grade
This trail is estimated to be mostly gentle (5% or less), with some steeper sections that may require assistance or need to be avoided.

More Info
The most accessible portion of the trail avoids the staircase and very steep areas near the falls. Picnic tables and benches are available along the route for resting. There are designated wheelchair accessible bathrooms at the trail's north end with a turnaround space, grab bars, and sinks that are at least 32 inches off the ground for knee clearance.

name: Table Mountain via Long Ridge
description: Took the trail counter clockwise, going on Peter Creek Trail over Long Ridge, before crossing Skyline to descend into the canyon toward Table Mountain and then out through Grizzly Flat trail. The trails west of Skyline are exposed and consist of rolling hills and wild turkeys.  It was super foggy and cool. East of Skyline, enjoy the initial descent through chaparrals before hitting Table Mountain. The water level of the stream crossings were high, and required some creativity to cross. The last ascent on Grizzly Flat trail out of the canyon was dull, and on a steep, muddy fire road.

name: Bay Area Ridge Trail: Sierra Azul Open Space to Lexington Reservoir
description:
You are rewarded with panoramic views of Mount Umunhum, the Santa Clara Valley, and the Inner and Outer Coast Ranges on this long trek through the Midpeninsula Regional Open Space District’s largest preserve. Beginning along the lower wooded slopes of Mount Umunhum, the trail climbs to a chaparral landscape up Mount El Sombroso. The remainder of the route undulates northwest over rugged hills and makes a long 3.9-mile descent to Lexington Reservoir. Choose a cool day to hike or ride this exposed fire road.

For more information, see the Bay Area Ridge Trail page here: https://ridgetrail.org/sierra-azul-open-space-preserve/

This trail description is excerpted from the 2019 Guidebook. For details on all of the Bay Area Ridge trails, trailheads and more buy the book from Wilderness Press: https://www.wildernesspress.com/product.php?productid=16685&cat=274&bestseller=Y

Dogs are allowed on leash except for the section of the Woods Trail.

name: Maisie's Peak and Nob Hill from Prospect  Parking
park: Maisie's Peak and Nob Hill from Prospect  Park
description:
This loop offers great views from Maisie's Peak and also reaches the top of Nob Hill. The trail travels over rolling terrain and mostly through open, sunny areas. Be sure to bring plenty of water.

Keep an eye out for poison oak growing alongside the trail. The parking area is small, so getting an early start on the weekend is recommended.

name: Toyon Trail, Old Spanish Trail and Coal Mine Ridge Loop
description:
This is a lovely shaded trail that travels to some picturesque lakes. The trail has a few manageable inclines but is otherwise a gentle hike through beautiful large oak and eucalyptus trees. There are a few benches positioned along the path as well as a swing. 

Parking is limited at the trailhead, although additional parking is available along the side streets.  The area is known to have quite a few ticks, so it's recommended to wear bug spray.

name: Canyon View Trail to Little Yosemite
description:
• Parking fee information: There is a fee to park at Sunol Wilderness Regional Preserve on weekends and holidays. For more information, please visit https://www.ebparks.org/parks/sunol

A great way to see the East Bay hills; nature abounds just minutes from civilization. Sunol Regional Wilderness will make you forget you're just five miles from the nearest Interstate highway. The 6,858-acre park in the East Bay hills north of Silicon Valley has rolling hills, heart-healthy trails, remarkable rocks and abundant wildlife. To go there is to see what this part of California looked like hundreds of years ago.

Sunol is best suited for hikers, birders, and naturalists, though the large corral near the park HQ attracts a fair number of equestrians. There are no easy paths to the tall hills surrounding the HQ, but if you've got the legs and heart for a good workout, you'll find astounding vistas when the climbing is done.

Winter and spring are the best times to go. It gets a bit too hot in July and August, but early autumn is a great time to see randy tarantulas on the hunt for mates (oddly enough, a spider the size of your fist in the wilderness is not nearly as frightful as the one the size of a dime in your bathroom).

name: Apay Way to No Name to Red Hills Loop
description: This trail has a great mix of hills and flatlands, offering lovely views of rolling hills and the bay. Some parts are dirt, while others are asphalt. During spring, the hills are filled with wildflowers, and the area is teeming with birds and wildlife. The trail has minimal shade, so remember to protect yourself from the sun and bring ample water.

name: SCA Trail to Engagement Hill
park: Length161mElevation gain1h 19mEstimated timeOut & backThe SCA Trail passes through the east side of Marin Headlands State Park
description: The SCA Trail passes through the east side of Marin Headlands State Park and offers breathtaking views of the San Francisco Bay. This route starts at the Morning Sun Trailhead and heads south to Engagement Hill, which is a popular viewpoint. There is little shade along the route; bring water and sun protection when recreating here.

name: John Nicholas Trail
description:
• Fee Information: Sanborn County Park charges a fee to enter. For more information, please https://parks.santaclaracounty.gov/locations/sanborn-county-park

The trail is a wide road grade leading to Lake Ranch Reservoir. After this, the trail is more narrow and climbs through the woods to the junction with the Skyline Trail. The trail is mostly wooded offering shade on warm days. It is popular with hikers and mountain bikers, so  anticipate seeing cyclists traveling downhill quickly.

name: Seal Slough Trail
description: Seal Slough is a continuing wetland restoration project focused on enhancing wildlife habitats. A scenic paved path follows the slough's east bank for four miles. This route starts at Los Prados Park, which offers parking, and follows the path around the south end of the slough before turning north and ending at Shoal Drive.

name: Berry Creek Falls Loop
description:
• Parking fee information: There is a fee to park at Big Basin Redwoods State Park. For more information, please visit https://www.parks.ca.gov/?page_id=540
• CZU Lightning Complex Fire : Public access to Big Basin has been severely impacted by the 2020 CZU Lightning Complex Fire and ongoing fire recovery work, but the park is open for limited day-use access. There is currently no access to waterfalls, all camping is closed and skyline to sea trail is open to the north but access to south (towards the ocean) is closed

Berry Creek Falls is one of the most visited routes in Big Basin Redwoods State Park and for good reason. While the intensity of the falls varies depending on the time of year, these falls are beautiful and visit worthy year round! The area has an abundance of giant ferns, moss, and small streams as well as lots of local fauna. 

The moderately hard hike travels through the lush groves of old-growth redwood trees and giant sequoias of the beautiful Santa Cruz mountains. The route also visits Silver Falls, and Cascade Falls just a mile upstream as well as giving hikers a chance to see many species of butterflies during the right time of year! 

From the park headquarters, take the Sunset Trail and then return via the Skyline to the Sea Trail. This is a single-track counter-clockwise route. You can also hike this loop clockwise, but most people elect to hike it counter-clockwise. The elevation gain is slow and steady and it is recommended that visitors bring plenty of water.

name: Firth Canyon to Ridge Loop
description:
• San Bruno Mountain State Park charges a fee to enter. Fees are per vehicle. This park does not accept the California State Park Annual Day Use Pass. For more information, please visit https://parks.smcgov.org/fees-charges#vehicle.

Firth Canyon is a forested park with picnic areas and turtle sightings. It is also an access point to the San Bruno Mountain trails. Follow a trail south until it intersects with another trail heading east-west. Choose a direction and start climbing to the ridgeline, which has gorgeous panoramic views of San Francisco. Some of these routes are on informal trails; download the map to help guide you.

name: Graham Trail
description: This trail has nice views looking across an open hillside with views of the bay. After this, you will hike through a more wooded area that offers shade on a hot day. The trail ends at the junction with the West Ridge Trail. At this point, there is a picnic area with tables to sit at and relax before retracing the route back to the start.

name: Santa Rosa, Sky Lane and Valley View Trails
description:
This trail takes you through Santa Rosa Open Space and Heintz Open Space Preserve, offering great views of San Jose and the valley. Be prepared for steep, narrow sections with roots and slippery, loose dirt—sturdy footwear is recommended.

Parking is available at both ends of the trail. Families with kids will enjoy the local playground at the beginning of the trail.

name: Mount Madonna Loop
description: • General fee: Mount Madonna County Park charges a fee to enter. For more information, please visit https://parks.sccgov.org/plan-your-visit/santa-clara-county-park-fees

name: Barbary Coast Trail
park: Coit Tower; Fisherman's Wharf; SF Maritime National Historical Park
description:
The Barbary Coast Trail is a walking tour connecting 20 historic sites and local history museums in San Francisco, California. Approximately 180 bronze medallions and arrows embedded in the sidewalk mark the trail.

The historic sites of the Barbary Coast Trail relate primarily to the period from the California Gold Rush of 1849 to the Earthquake and Fire of 1906, a period when San Francisco grew from a small village to the busiest port on the West Coast.

Sites along the trail include the Old Mint, a national historic landmark; Union Square; Maiden Lane; Old St. Mary's, first Catholic cathedral West of the Rockies; T'ien Hou temple, first Asian temple in North America; Wells Fargo History Museum; Pony Express headquarters site; Jackson Square Historic District, which contains the last cluster of Gold Rush and Barbary Coast-era buildings in San Francisco; Old Ship Saloon, once a shanghaiing den; Coit Tower; Fisherman's Wharf; SF Maritime National Historical Park, which maintains a large collection of historic ships; and Ghirardelli Square.

Each end of the Barbary Coast Trail is connected by the Hyde-Powell cable car line, itself a national historic landmark.

name: Viri O. Norton, Hacienda, English Camp and Randol Trail Loop
description: Enjoy this 10.8-km loop trail near New Almaden, California. Generally considered a moderately challenging route, it takes an average of 3 h 32 min to complete. This is a popular trail for birding, hiking, and horseback riding, but you can still enjoy some solitude during quieter times of day. The trail is open year-round and is beautiful to visit anytime. Dogs are welcome, but must be on a leash.

name: Pine Lake Loop
description: • Partial closure: Part of this route is temporarily inaccessible, but you can still enjoy other sections of this trail.

name: Black Mountain via Old Ranch, Bella Vista and Canyon Trail
description: This trail offers beautiful views of the surrounding mountains and the Bay Area as it ascends to the summit of Black Mountain. Along the way, visitors can spot hawks, ravens, crows, and various birds of prey. You may also get to see coyotes and deer. There is no shade along this trail, so bring plenty of water and wear sun protection. There is a large parking area at the trailhead and restrooms.

name: San Francisco Bay Trail - Sunnyvale to Sand Point
park: San Francisco Bay Trail - Sunnyvale to Sand Point as good for kids and families.Top trails nearbyBay Trail: Shoreline LakeBay Trail: Shoreline LakeShoreline at Mountain View Park4.6·Easy·11.9 km·Est. 2h 11mAlviso Slough TrailAlviso Slough TrailAlviso Marina County Park4.3·Easy·14.0 km·Est. 2h 32mStevens Creek TrailStevens Creek Trail4.5·Easy·6.8 km·Est. 1h 17mShoreline Park LoopShoreline Park LoopShoreline at Mountain View Park4.6·Easy·2.3 km·Est. 25mGuadalupe River TrailGuadalupe River Trail4.5·Easy·8.7 km·Est. 1h 37mSunnyvale Baylands Park Guadalupe SloughSunnyvale Baylands Park Guadalupe SloughSunnyvale Baylands Park4.2·Easy·5.5 km·Est. 1h 0mSan Tomas Aquino Creek TrailSan Tomas Aquino Creek TrailSunnyvale Baylands Park4.4·Easy·20.3 km·Est. 3h 47mSan Tomas Aquino Creek Trail to SF Bay TrailSan Tomas Aquino Creek Trail to SF Bay Trail4.4·Easy·6.4 km·Est. 1h 11mAlviso Marina LoopAlviso Marina LoopAlviso Marina County Park4.3·Easy·1.3 km·Est. 14mBaylands Perimeter LoopBaylands Perimeter LoopSunnyvale Baylands Park4.3·Easy·2.1 km·Est. 23mSan Francisco Bay Trail at Sunnyvale Baylands ParkSan Francisco Bay Trail at Sunnyvale Baylands ParkSunnyvale Baylands Park
description: This is a fantastic section of the San Francisco Bay Trail. Starting near Carl Road the trail extends from Sunnyvale to Sand Point. Follow the clearly marked signs for the bay trail. Although you will encounter some industrial buildings and highways, they do not diminish the trail’s natural beauty. The trail's surface is a mix of paved, dirt, and gravel and has minimal elevation gain.

name: San Tomas Aquino Creek Trail: Souza Park to Agnew Road
park: San Tomas Aquino Creek Trail: Souza Park

name: Stile Ranch and Fortini Loop
description:
• Fee Information: Santa Teresa County Park charges a fee to enter. For more information, please visit https://parks.sccgov.org/plan-your-visit/santa-clara-county-park-fees#3925188384-3236192913

Stile Ranch Trail comes up often in any discussion of the best places to see wildflowers in the hills rimming Silicon Valley. The trail zigzags up the southern edge of Santa Teresa County Park, a hilly slice of the south end of San Jose, California. 

The trail's steep terrain and southern exposure make it a prime habitat for the California poppy, but many more species color this route as you go along. 

This 2.5-mile route is a nice introduction to Santa Teresa Count Park, which has a good trail network that is well-marked and easy to navigate.

Springtime, of course, is the best time to try this hike, though the hiking will also be nice in the winter as long as the trails aren't too muddy.

name: Spring Ridge Trail, Windy Hill, Lost Trail, and Razorback Ridge Loop
description:
Windy Hill gets its name from the wind that covers its grassy summit. This loop meanders alternates between open grassland slopes and thick forests with redwood, fir, and oak trees.

You'll come across poppies, mustard, and thistles along the sunny, exposed ridges as you hike. The trail is excellent for spotting coyotes, raptors, and songbirds. Hikers will be rewarded with expansive vistas of the South Bay and far-off sights, including Mt. Tamalpais, Mt. Diablo, and Mt. Hamilton.

name: Purisima Creek Redwood Trail
park: Purisima Creek Redwoods Open Space Preserve
description:
This natural surface trail is a great family trail. It is thoroughly shaded and has several picnic tables and areas where you can pick huckleberries. The difficulty rating on this trail page is based on what the experience may be like for a manual stroller or mobility equipment user.

Accessibility: The trail surface is natural surface (dirt/gravel) and typically at least three feet wide. The estimated grade is mostly gentle (up to 5% grade) except for one very steep section. Wheelchair/mobility equipment, especially manual, or stroller users may need assistance at about 0.1 miles when going north. There is a round wooden edge barrier about five inches high along the edge of the trail.

There are at least 2 designated wheelchair accessible car parking spots without striped access aisles at the small unpaved, packed soil trailhead lot at the south end.

name: Lake Elizabeth
description:
This is a popular paved trail all the way around the lake, good for the whole family.

Accessibility: There is at least 1 designated accessible space in the paved parking lot off of Sailway Drive at the west end of the trail. It is van-accessible with striped access aisles. The trail surface is paved concrete and smooth. It is typically at least 8 feet wide. 

The whole trail is estimated to be in the flat (1% or less) grade category. This trail will likely be navigable for most wheelchairs/mobility equipment or stroller users. There are benches along the route for resting.

name: Stevens Canyon Trail
description: This loop offers views of Stevens Creek Reservoir and the surrounding hillsides. This trail can get hot, so starting early and bringing plenty of water is recommended. If you hike the loop counterclockwise, the steep incline sections will be shaded. Keep in mind that temporary closures may be in effect for trails in this loop during wet weather.

name: Best trails inShoreline at Mountain View Park
park: Shoreline At Mountain View Parkbest Trails In Shoreline At Mountain View Park Best Trails In Shoreline At Mountain View Park
description: Hours: 6:00 a.m. until 30 minutes after sundown

name: Coyote Lake to Mummy Mountain Loop
park: Coyote Lake Harvey Bear Ranch County Park
description: • Parking Fee: Coyote Lake Harvey Bear Ranch County Park charges a fee to enter, except at Mendoza Ranch and Harvey Bear Entrances. There are varying fees depending on if you enter by vehicle, motorcycle, foot, horse, or bike. Please visit https://parks.santaclaracounty.gov/locations/coyote-lake-harvey-bear-ranch-county-park

name: Maisie’s Peak via Coyote Ridge Trail
description: The Fremont Older Open Space Preserve has over 700 acres of trails and dirt roads for hikers, equestrians, and cyclists. Maisie's Peak has various ways to its 1,181-foot summit. This route starts at the north end of the park and follows the Coyote Ridge Trail to the top. There is little shade and no water along the route; plan accordingly.

name: Bobcat Trail to Rodeo Valley Trail Loop
description: From the Morning Sun Trailhead follow the Alta, Bobcat, and Rodeo Valley Trail to loop around the rolling hills. During the spring the hills are green and there are flowers. At points, the bay will be visible. The trails are well maintained and easy to follow but can be muddy if it has recently rained.

name: Los Trancos Trail via Steep Hollow Trail
description:
• Foothills Nature Preserve charges an entry fee. An annual pass is also available for purchase. Dogs are not allowed on weekends or holidays. For more information, please visit https://www.cityofpaloalto.org/Departments/Community-Services/Open-Space-Parks/Neighborhood-Parks/Foothills-Nature-Preserve



Well shaded trail with great views of the bay area.

name: Precita Park and Bernal Heights Summit
description: This route is a great city and nature hike through the Mission. It begins at Precita Park and continues along Folsom Street to Bernal Heights Park, where you can enjoy 360-degree views from the summit of Bernal Heights. There, you'll enjoy stunning city views. Some places can be steep and have some loose gravel, so proper footwear is recommended.

name: Best trails inButano State Park
park: Butano State Parkbest Trails In Butano State Parkall Photos Best Trails In Butano State Park
description: Miles of trails, beautiful redwood forests, babbling creeks, and solitude... If this sounds like heaven, then Butano State Park is a must-see for you. This beautiful park is situated in the Santa Cruz Mountains half way between Santa Cruz and Half Moon Bay. The Day Use Annual Pass is accepted at this park.

name: Rainbow Lake Loop
description:
• Parking fee information: There is a fee to park at Quarry Lakes Regional Park. Fees are collected on weekends and major holidays from April through October and only at the Redwood Gate entrance. For more information, please visit https://www.ebparks.org/parks/quarry_lakes/

This trail is nice and wide and has pretty views of the water. There is not a lot of shade so be sure to bring water, sunscreen, etc.

Accessibility: There are 2 designated accessible spaces in the paved parking lot off of Isherwood Way at the west end of the trail. Both of them are van-accessible with striped access aisles. The trail surface is paved asphalt or gravel.  It is typically at least 6 feet wide. 

The whole trail is estimated to be in the gentle (3% or less) grade category. This trail will likely be navigable for most wheelchairs/mobility equipment or stroller users. There are benches and picnic tables along the route for resting.

name: Dunn, Graham, West Ridge and Baccharis Loop
description:
With its vast expanse of more than 1,800 acres, Redwood Regional Park offers varied terrain. It features meadows, ridge trails, and trails dotted with redwoods descending into the valley. The park has multiple entrances and picnic and camping areas.

The Dunn Trail starts flat and connects to the Graham Trail. The hike is picturesque, with many redwood trees providing shade as it runs alongside a stream. In the winter, hikers may come upon masses of ladybugs covering logs, bushes, and trees. The Graham Trail is a wide, open space with a water fountain that is primarily an uphill road. Hikers might spot corvids, squirrels, and wildflowers on this trail.

The West Ridge Trail features both sunny and shaded sections. While it is mainly surrounded by towering trees and bushes, such as coffeeberry, madrone, and eucalyptus, it does provide some views of Mount Diablo. A vantage point of the redwoods and a massive redwood stump may be found along the trail. Creambush and hazelnut are especially noticeable in late spring, and currant bush is visible throughout the winter.

name: Ohlone Trail to Arastradero Creek Trail
description:
• Seasonal closure: This area is subject to seasonal closure due to weather conditions. For more information, please visit https://www.cityofpaloalto.org/News-Articles/Community-Services/Pearson-Arastradero-Preserve-Seasonal-Trails-Status

The Ohlone Trail to Arastradero Creek Trail takes your up to the to top of the Pearson Arastradero preserve, where you will find some great views and mountain biking bowls. The trail will join up with the Arastradero Creek Trail, going along the creek to a lake and back to the parking lot. Part of the trail is single track and part is gravel. You must park in the parking lot and are not allowed to park along Arastradero Rd or on Page Mill Rd. Be aware of snakes, ticks, and poison oak. 

Pearson Arastradero Preserve has 10 miles of trails and is located in Palo Alto, California. The loop trail offers great birding opportunities and the trails are used by hikers, cyclists and equestrians. Some trails are closed seasonally due to wet conditions.

The preserve has 10.25 miles of trails for hiking, biking and horseback riding. Most of the trails (6.6 miles) are open year-round. Some trails (3.6 miles) are designated as "seasonal" and are closed at the trailhead after heavy rain. When the ground is firm enough to ride and hike on without causing erosion damage, the trails are re-opened by preserve rangers.

Please be courteous to other trail users. Always yield to equestrians. Bikes must also yield to hikers. When in a group, avoid blocking the trail. Help preserve the land by staying on trails. 

For daily trail condition updates please check the bulletin board in the preserve parking lot, or call 650-329-2423 and ask for the for the latest trail conditions in the Pearson Arastradero Preserve.

name: Welch Hurst Trail, Upper Madrone, Sanborn, and Skyline Trail
description: This is a challenging and fun trail that travels the length of Sanborn County Park. Starting in the north on the Welch Hurst Trail, the route steadily climbs through a dense redwood forest until it reaches Skyline Boulevard. Below the canopy of trees, look out for a thriving wildlife habitat. You can hike this as a point-to-point or a longer out-and-back.

name: UCSC to the Sea
description: Experience this 19.1-mile out-and-back trail near Santa Cruz, California. Generally considered a challenging route, it takes an average of 7 h 22 min to complete. This trail is great for hiking and mountain biking, and it's unlikely you'll encounter many other people while exploring. The trail is open year-round and is beautiful to visit anytime. You'll need to leave pups at home — dogs aren't allowed on this trail.

name: Alviso Slough Trail
description:
• Partial closure: Part of the Alviso Slough Trail is temporarily inaccessible, but you can still enjoy other sections of this trail. For more information, please visit https://parks.sccgov.org/sites/g/files/exjcpb961/files/documents/ShorelineProject2024Updates.pdf

According to Access Northern CA (http://accessnca.org/access-northern-california/explore/explore-detail-view/?site_id=172): Alviso Marina County Park is the gateway to the Don Edwards San Francisco Bay National Wildlife Refuge. You can picnic and launch your small boat in this 20-acre park along Alviso Slough, at the southern end of San Francisco Bay, but the big draw is the many miles of levee trails that wrap around adjacent salt ponds. It’s an ideal place for spotting migratory birds and numerous resident birds, including northern harrier hawks, killdeer, song sparrows, and great egrets. You can easily spend all day here if you explore trails in the adjacent Don Edwards San Francisco Bay Wildlife Refuge.

The Environmental Education Center has displays on the South Bay’s ecology and history, a small bookstore, and replicas of the reed boats and shelters used by the native people. It is used for school programs and other events on weekdays and is open to the public on weekends. The entry door is rather heavy.

The town of Alviso was once envisioned as the bustling boating and shipping port of San Jose, but that prospect was diminished by a series of events, including the completion of the railroad, the relocation of the state capital from San Jose to Sacramento, and winter flooding and muddy conditions. Sparsely populated today, the town is listed in the Santa Clara County National Register of Historic Places.

Accessibility: There is designated, van-accessible parking at the park entry, although the boat launch lot has no designated parking. The trail surface is partially boardwalk and partially dirt and it is typically at least four feet wide. It has an estimated gentle grade of 3% or less. There is a gentle slope by the trailheads. There is an accessible bathroom by the parking lot but not on the trail. There is an accessible picnic area near the parking lot with a firm and stable surface to the tables, firm and stable surfaces, and at least 27 inches of knee clearance.

name: Rocky Shore Loop
park: Robert W. Crown Memorial State Beach
description:
The Robert W. Crown Memorial State Beach and Washington Park are central hubs for outdoor recreation in Alameda. The parks have athletic courts, playgrounds, a dog park, beach access, and trails that link both. This route starts at the Doug Siden Visitor Center and makes an easy loop out to the end of the peninsula. The views of San Francisco Bay are beautiful, and it is common to see various bird species.

Please note that dogs are only allowed on paved paths, lawns, and the dog park. This route does not allow dogs to walk along dirt paths or the beach.

name: Presidio Promenade, Coastal Trail, and Park Loop
park: Length351ftElevation gain1h 34mEstimated timeLoopThis is an incredibly scenic urban tour in the Presidio of San Francisco. Starting from Presidio Tunnel Tops Park
description:
• Access Information: Part of this route is temporarily closed to dog walking to reduce the potential for coyote/dog conflict, but you can still enjoy other sections of this trail. For information, please visit https://presidio.gov/about/sustainability/coyotes-in-the-presidio

This is an incredibly scenic urban tour in the Presidio of San Francisco. Starting from Presidio Tunnel Tops Park, the loop stays on paved multi-use paths and passes multiple points of interest and viewpoints. Battery Lancaster at Fort Scott and the Golden Gate Bridge Overlook are a few of the points along the route.

Accessibility:

Equipment
Visitors using wheelchairs, mobility equipment, or strollers may need all-terrain tires or adaptive/motorized equipment for the surface type and grade.

Parking
There are several designated accessible parking spaces in the pay-to-park lot just south of the trailhead, between Anza Ave and Montgomery St.

Surface
The trail surface is either paved asphalt or crushed gravel, typically at least 6 feet wide.

Grade
This trail is estimated to be mostly gentle (5% or less), with some moderately steep sections (5-8%) and steep sections (8-12%) that may require assistance or need to be avoided.

name: Crystal Springs Trail
park: HikingEasy to parkNot crowdedTrail was fine and a good place to train for short hikes. There’s a bit of a climb but I either missed the scenic / vista points or there werent many along the route.Park
description: Enjoy this 3.9-mile out-and-back trail near Redwood City, California. Generally considered a moderately challenging route, it takes an average of 1 h 34 min to complete. This trail is great for hiking, running, and walking, and it's unlikely you'll encounter many other people while exploring. The trail is open year-round and is beautiful to visit anytime.

name: Redondo Beach via Coastal Trail Loop
description: This stunning coastal hike begins at the Smith Field Little League Park baseball diamonds parking area, and takes you on a loop through protected grassland and coastal scrub. Keep an eye out for kestrels, ravens, and barn owls on your trip. The return leg of this loop features a quick spur trip down to Redondo beach. Bring your camera, the views are spectacular!

name: Chaparral, Ohlone, Rambler, and Canyon Creek Loop
description: Hidden Canyon Park has a network of scenic trails through coastal sage scrub and dense oak forests. This route makes a loop along the flanks of the hills in an area of dense oaks. It spends the first half-mile climbing to a high point with beautiful views. The rest of the route is a gradual descent along the Rambler and Canyon Creek Trail. The trailhead has bathrooms and a drinking fountain.

name: Rose Peak From Sunol
description:
• Parking fee information: There is a fee to park at Sunol Wilderness Regional Preserve on weekends and holidays. For more information, please visit https://www.ebparks.org/parks/sunol

Rose Peak (3,817 ft.), the highest peak in Alameda County, is remotely located in Ohlone Wilderness and can only be accessed by foot for the public. This 18-mile round-trip hike, gaining almost 4,000 feet in elevation change, takes you there and back from Sunol Regional Park in one day. The trail is well-marked with trail posts along the way. Each post has a unique number assigned to it. Just follow the numbers and you can get to the peak easily. This trip is also a perfect training for the famous Half Dome hike in Yosemite because of their similarity in distance and elevation gain.

name: Penitencia Creek and North Rim Loop
description:
• Partial closure: As of October 2024, part of this route is temporarily inaccessible, but you can still enjoy other sections of this trail. For more information, please visit https://www.sanjoseca.gov/home/showpublisheddocument/110007/638568325940770000
• Parking fee information: There is a fee to park at Alum Rock Park. For more information, please visit https://www.sanjoseca.gov/Home/Components/FacilityDirectory/FacilityDirectory/2088/2028

This popular loop travels along Upper Penitencia Creek for over half of its length, continuing onto the North Rim Trail after passing the Alum Park Science and Nature Center. There are plenty of park facilities along the Penitencia Creek Trail section, giving hikers options for picnicking, rest stops, and bathroom breaks. Expect views along the North Rim Trail section.

name: Alameda Creek Trail: Isherwood Staging Area
park:
This hike is accessible for people using mobility devices and/or strollers but you can always hike the paved side only from Isherwood by crossing the bridge near the staging area first and heading back in reverse. 

Trail Directions: Begin trip at Isherwood Staging Area in Fremont. Head towards the two accessible por - ta-potties and stay to the right of them on the unpaved trail. Hike 0.8 miles to the Sequoia Bridge. There is a small incline before you cross the bridge. Make a right onto the bridge. (the bridge is accessible and paved for persons using mobility devices and/or strollers). At the end of the bridge make another right onto the paved side of the Alameda Creek Trail and go until you reach Isherwood Bridge. Make another right onto the bridge sidewalk and cross back over and make your last right back into Isherwood Staging Area to complete the route.

Park
description:
Trail Highlights: This route is in full sun with partial shade from trees along the trails and is a great location for birding. There are benches spaced throughout the route on both the unpaved side, which is packed gravel, and the paved side of the trail, providing rest stops with views of the creek and wildlife. Isherwood Staging area has limited parking and there is high usage in the mornings; afternoon tends to have less usage with more parking available. 

Accessibility: There is one van accessible and one accessible parking space, in addition to other parking, two accessible porta-potties, and a water fountain at the staging area. The typical width of the trail is 4ft and above, the grade is gentle, and it is level with slope no greater than 2%. This hike is accessible for people using mobility devices and/or strollers but you can always hike the paved side only from Isherwood by crossing the bridge near the staging area first and heading back in reverse. 

Trail Directions: Begin trip at Isherwood Staging Area in Fremont. Head towards the two accessible por - ta-potties and stay to the right of them on the unpaved trail. Hike 0.8 miles to the Sequoia Bridge. There is a small incline before you cross the bridge. Make a right onto the bridge. (the bridge is accessible and paved for persons using mobility devices and/or strollers). At the end of the bridge make another right onto the paved side of the Alameda Creek Trail and go until you reach Isherwood Bridge. Make another right onto the bridge sidewalk and cross back over and make your last right back into Isherwood Staging Area to complete the route.

Park Features: Alameda Creek is Alameda County's largest creek and is home to a host of birds and other wildlife. Its rushing waters provided a valuable resource for the Ohlone Peoples who first settled in camps and villages along its banks.

name: North Rim Trail To Sierra Vista Point Loop
description:
• Parking fee information: There is a fee to park at Alum Rock Park. For more information, please visit https://www.sanjoseca.gov/Home/Components/FacilityDirectory/FacilityDirectory/2088/2028

This fantastic trail explores Sierra Vista Open Space Preserve and Alum Rock Park. It offers a peaceful backdrop with stunning panoramic views of the Bay Area. Starting from Minerals Spring Parking, the trail features challenging uphill sections and rocky terrain. Hikers should be prepared for limited shade and bring sunscreen and water.

name: Mission Peak from Ed Levin Park
park: Mission Peak from Ed Levin Park
description:
• General fee: Ed R. Levin County Park charges a fee to enter. For more information, please visit https://parks.sccgov.org/plan-your-visit/santa-clara-county-park-fees

Hiking to Monument Peak from Ed Levin County Park, huffing it over to Mission Peak, and returning is a true test of mettle for San Francisco Bay Area trekkers. 

If you're up for it, this is a great way to summit Mission Peak and skip the crowds and parking hassles at the popular Stanford Avenue entrance to Mission Peak Regional Preserve. 

Instead, take a southern tack from Ed Levin County Park just east of Milpitas. The long, steep hike up from Ed Levin is one of the toughest in the South Bay, but it has some of the best vistas in the region.

As you near the Monument Peak summit, watch for the mysterious stone walls: some believe they were built by indigenous peoples who inhabited these hills for centuries before European settlers arrived. 

The best time to go is in the springtime when the wildflowers are out in force and the hills are a shimmering shade of green. Winter's nice, too, especially after the hills have been dusted with snow. Summer is brutal and fall is bone-dry.

On your return from Mission Peak, you can turn right at the Agua Caliente Trail near the transmission tower at Monument Peak; note this is an extremely steep descent in places. Retracing your original route might be preferable if downhills punish your knees.

name: Golden Eagle Trail to View Point
description:
Park Features: This stunning 1,249-acre regional park provides tremendous views from the tops of the East Bay hills. The plateau rises quickly and steeply from the bay plain and towers over one thousand feet above the cities below, overlooking Niles Canyon, Fremont, Union City, Newark and the San Francisco Bay beyond. Atop the plateau a pastoral landscape predominates, and golden eagles, hawks, deer, bobcats, frogs, snakes and a variety of other animals make their home in the open grasslands, ponds and steep wooded canyons. These characteristics make the park a great place for outdoor recreation and nature appreciation on the urban/ wildland edge.

Trails Highlights: Vargas Plateau is one of the more recent District parks to open to the public. The scenic trail slowly wraps up to the top of a lookout point, offering panoramic views of the surrounding cities (San Jose and Loma Prieta to the south, Mission Peak, Mt Hamilton and Rose Peak to the southeast, Sunol ridge to the north and San Bruno Mt, Twin Peaks and San Francisco to the west).
