You will notice from the trail posts that the trail you are following is part of the Bay Area Ridge Trail. Vargas Plateau is an open range park so be watchful for roaming cows. Parking and rest rooms available at the Vargas Plateau Staging Area.

Trail Directions: Park at the Vargas Plateau Staging Area, and follow the trail past the restrooms, continuing through the gate. Keep going straight onto Golden Eagle Trail, past the next trail post. Golden Eagle Trail will contour around the hill and continue through another gate. At the second trail, pass through the gate to follow the Upper Ranch Trail. At the next trail post, stay to the left for the View Point Trail. The View Point Trail will ascend to the top of the hill. Take a break at the top of the plateau and enjoy the views. To return to the staging area, retrace your steps, turning right onto Golden Eagle Trail and following it back to the staging area.

name: Los Gatos Creek Park and Lexington Reservoir via Los Gatos Creek Trail
description:
• Seasonal closure: Vasona Lake County Park is subject to seasonal closure during the wintertime and wet weather due to weather conditions. For more information, please visit https://parks.sccgov.org/closures-updates

Los Gatos Creek Park to Lexington Reservoir. 

Keep your eyes open for newts, deer, and wildflowers along the trail.

name: Bay Area Ridge Trail: Saratoga Gap to Skyline Ridge Open Space
description:
Travel through moist evergreen forests, oak–madrone woodlands, and high grasslands along the crest of the Santa Cruz Mountains. You experience stunning coastal mountain views on this route through three open-space preserves and one county park. Trail width and surface varies from narrow paths to wide roads—soft in forests and along creekbeds, and firm and bare through grasslands. Be prepared for wind and fog on exposed ridgetops, and for heat on west- and south-facing slopes.

Got a little hiker? Try the Peter’s Creek section of this trail for a flat 2-mile hike with a splash in the creek. More info here: https://www.openspace.org/preserves/long-ridge

For more information, see the Bay Area Ridge Trail page here: https://ridgetrail.org/saratoga-gap-open-space-preserve-to-skyline-ridge-open-space-preserve/

This trail description is excerpted from the 2019 Guidebook. For details on all of the Bay Area Ridge trails, trailheads and more buy the book from Wilderness Press: https://www.wildernesspress.com/product.php?productid=16685&cat=274&bestseller=Y

Accessibility: The most wheelchair/mobility equipment and stroller friendly portion of this trail is the dirt/gravel loop around Horseshoe Lake at the north end of the trail. There are three parking lots you can use to access this loop. The trail page just for the Horseshoe Lake Loop can be viewed here: https://www.alltrails.com/trail/us/california/horseshoe-lake-trail-loop

name: San Tomas Aquino Creek Trail to SF Bay Trail
park: HikingGood conditionsNot crowdedDog-friendlyStreet parking and it was free. Park
description:
A short paved trail. Pretty flat and a good venue for taking your kiddo for a bike ride. Bonus feature is there's a nice play area at the beginning of the trail as well. You can park along the street at the beginning of the trail for free street parking. 

Accessibility: There are at least 10 designated accessible spaces in the large paved parking lots off of Agnew Road at the south end of the trail. All of them are van-accessible with striped access aisles. The trail surface is paved (with railings at bridges), smooth, and typically at least 6 feet wide. There are painted dividing lines and metal bollards along the trail which reduces the width. 

The estimated grade is mostly gentle (5% or less). This trail will likely be navigable for most trail goers using wheelchairs/mobility equipment or strollers. There are benches and picnic tables along the route for resting.

name: Purisima Creek, Craig Britton and Skyline Trail Loop
park: Purisima Creek Redwoods Open Space Preserve
description: Great hike through the redwoods. Hikers should be prepare for a short hike along Skyline Blvd on the way back to the trailhead.

name: Lisa's Lookout via Lisa Killough Trail
park: Rancho San Vicente Open Space Preserve
description: This is a beautiful, scenic trail to Lisa's Lookout in Rancho San Vicente Open Space Preserve. The views throughout this hike are spectacular, providing vistas of rolling hills and nearby mountains. There is no shade along the way, so wear sun protection and bring enough water for the journey. The trail begins from Rancho San Vicente Entrance Parking Lot, where there are restrooms.

name: Courdet, Ridgeline, Shady Creek, North Ridge, Sinbad Creek Trail
description:
Trail Highlights: The steep climb begins on the Courdet Trail through oaks and bays. At the top, the landscape opens up as you walk along the ridgeline. From here you can see across the valley to Sunol Ridge to thewest. On the Sinbad Creek Trail, you will experience the tranquil Kilkare Canyon, where majestic old-growth oaks
drip with lichen. California buttercups, blue-eyed grass, Ithuriel’s spear and other flowers flourish in spring. This loop can be made shorter by taking any of the trails that lead up to Ridgeline trail, before reaching the north end of Sinbad Creek Trail.

Park Features: Pleasanton Ridge is an oak-studded ridge overlooking several valleys below. The landscape is characterized by open, rolling hills and deep, heavily wooded creek canyons. Many native species flourish here, and the more remote parts of the park provide important habitat for bobcats, coyotes, and mountain lions. You may see Western bluebirds or meadowlarks in the grasslands, or red tailed hawks and golden eagles soaring above. Parking at the Castleridge staging area is on the street. There are accessible restrooms and a drinking fountain here. Bicycles are allowed on the trails that make up this loop.

Trail Directions: Start at the Castleridge Trailhead on Foothill Road. From here, take the Courdet Trail up hill. In about two miles, turn left, go about two hundred feet, and then turn right onto Ridgeline Trail. After about .4 miles, turn right onto Shady Creek Trail. In a little less than a half-mile, go left on North Ridge Trail. Be sure to follow signs for North Ridge Trail, as it diverges from the wide dirt path about .2 miles later. Pass Loop Trail, continuing on North Ridge Trail. Pass through a cattle gate, and, after about .4 miles, turn left onto Cowing Trail. In about .7 miles, turn left onto Sinbad Creek Trail which leads through Kilkare Canyon. Follow Sinbad Creek Trail for about 3.5 miles. Where the trail splits (at marker 23), go left and follow Sinbad Creek Trail uphill. There is a drinking fountain at the top of the hill. Take a
left on Ridgeline Trail. Follow Ridgeline Trail until you reach Courdet Trail. Turn right on Courdet Trail and descend two miles back to the trailhead

name: Best trails nearSunnyvale Mountain
description: Want to check out Sunnyvale Mountain from the trail? Good news: 4 trails will you get you there, including hiking trails. Whether you're looking to hike, bike, run, or explore the outdoors in other ways, AllTrails has 2 scenic trails in the Sunnyvale Mountain area. Plan your trip with hand-curated trail maps, along with reviews and photos from nature lovers like you. Looking for a challenge? Choose from 4 moderate or hard routes. No matter how you like to get out in nature, the trails through Sunnyvale Mountain are perfect for hikers and outdoor enthusiasts at any skill level.

name: Sprig, Merry-Go-Round, and Tan Oak Loop
description:
• General fee: Mount Madonna County Park charges a fee to enter. For more information, please visit https://parks.sccgov.org/plan-your-visit/santa-clara-county-park-fees

Hike past redwoods and the ruins of a land baron's mansion at this park south of San Jose. Mount Madonna County Park is one of the most popular camping destinations in Santa Clara County, and this route is one of the best ways to see all the park has to offer. 

Sprig Lake trail passes all three of the park's major campgrounds and makes a scenic ascent (or descent) through one of the prettiest stands of redwoods in the park.  Another section of this route passes a pen of captive white fallow deer, then continues through the ruins of the summer house of Henry Miller, a Gold Rush-era land baron whose properties stretched from the Bay Area to Mexico.

name: Restless Sea and China Rock
park: Restless Sea viewpoint before turning south toward China Rock. It continues south and ends at Bird Rock Park
description: This is a very short section of the California Coastal Trail along the scenic Pacific coastline. It starts at one of the several parking lots along 17 Mile Drive and briefly heads north, passing the Restless Sea viewpoint before turning south toward China Rock. It continues south and ends at Bird Rock Park.

name: Berryessa Creek Trail
description:
The Berryessa Creek Trail is a scenic path that follows Berryessa Creek. This route starts from Hidden Lake Park and travels southeast to Peter T. Gill Park. The creek fosters a thriving waterfowl habitat, and wildlife is common along the water. Be mindful of others recreating on the trail, including bikes.

Accessibility:

Equipment
This trail is likely accessible for visitors using wheelchairs, mobility equipment, or strollers.

Parking
There is 1 designated accessible parking space with striped access aisles in the paved parking lot.

Surface
The trail surface is paved asphalt and is typically at least 8 feet wide.

Grade
This trail is estimated to be flat (1% or less).

name: Best trails inRussian Ridge Open Space Preserve
park: Russian Ridge Open Space Preservebest Trails In Russian Ridge Open Space Preserve Best Trails In Russian Ridge Open Space Preserve
description: Hours: half an hour before sunrise to half an hour after sunset

name: Marilyn Murphy Kane Loop
description: Check out this 6.0-km loop trail near Pleasanton, California. Generally considered an easy route, it takes an average of 1 h 5 min to complete. This is a very popular area for road biking, running, and walking, so you'll likely encounter other people while exploring. The trail is open year-round and is beautiful to visit anytime. Dogs are welcome and may be off-leash in some areas.

name: Whittemore Gulch and Harkins Ridge Loop Trail
park: Purisima Creek Redwoods Open Space Preserve
description:
A pleasant loop through the Purisma Creek Redwoods. This hike allows you to enjoy both the lush valleys and views on the open ridgeline. Pay attention to signs because bikes are allowed on specific trails only.

The preserve is located on the western slopes of the Santa Cruz Mountains overlooking Half Moon Bay. The open space features not only redwoods but ferns, wildflowers, coastal scrub, and several babbling brooks that can grow to sizable creeks in the winter. The elevation descends almost 1600 ft from Skyline Blvd and depending on your route, some sections can be rather steep. Make sure to bring water!

name: Page Mill Loop
park: California2.3kmLength66mElevation gain38mEstimated timeLoop2.3kmLength66mElevation gain38mEstimated timeLoopThis is a loop in the Los Altos Hills Pathway System that follows the perimeter of grassy fields and neighborhoods. It starts at the Page Mill Park
description: This is a loop in the Los Altos Hills Pathway System that follows the perimeter of grassy fields and neighborhoods. It starts at the Page Mill Park and Ride and heads north along Arastradero Road until a dirt trail leads south. Pick up the Page Mill to Saddle Court Path which forms the south end of the route before heading north along Matadero Creek and finishing the loop.

name: San Pedro Mountain via Old San Pedro, Burnside, and Boyscout Loop
description:
This trail area is maintained by volunteers. There are no trail signs or markings, and there are many variations of this route possible. It is a good idea to download your map ahead of time before heading out. This is a popular mountain biking route, so keep a heads up for others out there on the trail.

Your route itinerary will consist of Old San Pedro Road, Sand Pedro Mountain Trail, Burnside, and Boyscout Trail.

name: Mount Madonna Meadow Trail Loop
description:
• General fee: Mount Madonna County Park charges a fee to enter. For more information, please visit https://parks.sccgov.org/plan-your-visit/santa-clara-county-park-fees

The Meadow Trail passes the pen holding the park's small herd of white fallow dear - a crowd-pleasing locale for youngsters. 

The park south of San Jose, California, has three popular campgrounds that might leave parents wondering where to work off some of their kids' energy. 

While some kids are up for much longer hikes, this 2.5-miler is a great choice if you're not sure how much the little tykes can handle. 

When you're done, wander over to the Henry Miller House site and explore the ruins of the summer house he built here during the 19th century. The white fallow deer were given to his heirs by William Randolph Hearst, the famous newspaper baron.

With its abundance of shade, this is a great all-season hike.

name: Priest Rock, Limekiln and Kennedy Trail Loop
description: This loop trail is a great place to work out, with beautiful vistas along the way. The trail has constant uphills, with some very steep sections. It is on a dirt path with loose gravel and is mostly exposed, so you'll want to bring sunscreen, a hat, or water. You can add some extra miles to hike to the top of Mt El Sombroso. Kennedy Road Sierra Azul Trailhead has very limited parking.

name: Riche Loop Trail
description:
• Access information: All visitors must obtain a permit before hiking this area. For more information, please visit https://www.ebmud.com/recreation/buy-trail-permit/

All visitors must obtain a permit before hiking this area. More information here: https://www.ebmud.com/recreation/buy-trail-permit/

name: Best trails inThe Forest of Nisene Marks State Park
park: The Forest Of Nisene Marks State Parkbest Trails In The Forest Of Nisene Marks State Park Best Trails In The Forest Of Nisene Marks State Park
description: Situated just east of Santa Cruz, centered around the Aptos Creek Canyon, the Forest of Nisene Marks State Park is a semi-wilderness with miles of trails for hiking, biking, and nature viewing. Rising all the way from sea level to 2,600 feet, visitors find lush forests covering steep coastal mountains. There is an $8 parking fee. Accessibility: Information for wheelchair/mobility equipment or stroller users can be found on the park website: http://access.parks.ca.gov/parkinfo.asp?park=192&type=0

name: Villa Montalvo Lookout Point, South Orchard, Creek Trail Loop
description: This is a short but beautiful hike through a Eucalyptus forest to a beautiful lookout. There are signs located along the entire trail that have positive affirmation quotes on them.  There are also an art center, theatre, and garden in the area. This route is shaded for most of the way, and is often crowded, especially on weekends.

name: Sanborn Loop to Indian Rock
description:
• Fee Information: Sanborn County Park charges a fee to enter. For more information, please https://parks.santaclaracounty.gov/locations/sanborn-county-park

Excellent hike through the redwoods just west of Saratoga and south of San Jose, California. It starts on the San Andreas Trail and takes a vigorous march up the hillside west of the park. The trail can be steep in places, but you'll be covered in a canopy of redwoods that'll shade you from the sun and help you forget that you are close to the city.

The trail turns south after about three miles at the intersection with Sanborn Trail -- from here it's a couple miles back, all downhill. 

Sanborn Trail passes through the park's excellent walk-in campgrounds. The walk-in part discourages a lot of potential campers, leaving a fair number of open campsites for those who don't mind hauling their tents, food, and gear uphill. Those with the legs for it can enjoy some of the nicest campsites in the Bay Area.

Once you get through the campgrounds, a park trail returns to the parking lot. To avoid crowds, hike this trail on a weekday.

name: Alambique, Skyline, Meadow and Bear Gulch Trail Loop
description: This is a great for hikers or trail runners. Dogs and bikes are not allowed on any of these trails.

name: Sierra Azul Open Space Preserve Loop
description:
This is a great park with expansive trails that connect to the Almaden Quicksilver Park and the Lexington Reservoir Trails, including St. Joseph's Hill Open Space Preserve.  The trails have great vistas and many parts are shaded.

While dogs are allowed in parts of the preserve, they are only allowed on certain designated trails and may not be allowed on this entire trail route. For more information, visit: https://www.openspace.org/where-to-go/what-to-do/dogs

The Sierra Azul Open Space Preserve is the district's largest preserve, encompassing 18,831 acres. This park property is a bit of a jigsaw puzzle as the plots of land that were purchased are not contiguous, but the trails are long and it is possible to travel all the way to Lexington Reservoir.  

The park includes some of the great vista points in the south bay, including Mt. Umunhum (closed to the public), Bald Mountain (2,387 ft), Mount El Sombroso (2,999 ft). 

The trails are well groomed and marked and many parts are shaded.

name: Huckleberry Preserve Short Loop
description: Firestation to Huckleberry Preserve Loop is a popular hike with lots of varying landscapes. It goes through endemic red manzanita groves and offers many views of the surrounding hills. Trail can be muddy after rain but remains accessible except in case of large floods. There is limited parking at the trailhead.

name: Los Prados Loop
description: Experience this 1.0-km loop trail near San Mateo, California. Generally considered an easy route, it takes an average of 10 min to complete. This is a very popular area for running and walking, so you'll likely encounter other people while exploring. The trail is open year-round and is beautiful to visit anytime. Dogs are welcome, but must be on a leash.

name: Lover's Rock and the John McLaren Loop
description: In the middle of a dense neighborhood, The Crocker Amazon Playground and the John McLaren Park offer an extensive network of trails and serve as an oasis for outdoor recreation. This loop passes Lover's Rock and moderately climbs to great views of the bay. There are many access points; this route starts from the parking lot on Geneva Avenue.

name: Philosopher's Way
description: Looping around the perimeter of John McLaren Park in southeastern San Francisco, the Philosopher’s Way is a unique trail meant to inspire contemplation. The route is laid out onto existing park trails, but with the addition of fourteen “musing stations”. These stone markers are meant to “highlight the interrelationships between the area’s ecology, geography, and history.”

name: Castle Rock, Goat Rock, and Indian Rock Loop
description:
• General fee: Castle Rock State Park charges a day-use fee to enter. For more information please visit https://www.parks.ca.gov/?page_id=538

This popular trail offers amazing views, a chance to check out a waterfall, and options to explore the interesting rock formations that give Castle Rock its name. 

These trails start wide but turn into narrow single-track trails. It is a good idea to download your map ahead of time. This loop accesses the Castle Rock Trail Camp. A permit is needed for backpacking here and can be found at: https://www.parks.ca.gov/?page_id=26658

There is little water available on this hike, so it is recommended to pack plenty.  
The rock formations offer fun scrambles for the whole family. You may see technical rock climbers out on some of the boulders. 

This area is extremely popular on weekends, so be prepared to come early to find a parking spot, especially if you are preparing to backpack.

name: Baquiano Trail
park: HikingNot crowdedGreat conditionsIncline all the way up!Park
description: Take the Baquaiano Trail up to the San Francisco Bay Discovery Site. Along the way enjoy picturesque views of the bay and coastal scrub habitat. The ridge climbs up to 1200'. Interpretive signs are in place at the discovery site. There is no shade, so bring water and sun protection along if you're going on a sunny day.

name: Best trails inSaratoga Quarry Park
park: Saratoga Quarry Parkbest Trails In Saratoga Quarry Park Best Trails In Saratoga Quarry Park
description:
Want to find the best trails in Saratoga Quarry Park for an adventurous hike or a family trip? AllTrails has 2 great trails for hiking and more. Enjoy hand-curated trail maps, along with reviews and photos from nature lovers like you.

Ready for your next hike or bike ride? We've got you covered, with trails ranging from 465 to 1,797 feet in elevation gain. Whatever you have planned for the day, you can find the perfect trail for your next trip to Saratoga Quarry Park.

name: Ancient Oaks Trail
description: Try this 2.2-mile out-and-back trail near La Honda, California. Generally considered an easy route, it takes an average of 54 min to complete. This is a very popular area for hiking and running, so you'll likely encounter other people while exploring. The best times to visit this trail are January through June. You'll need to leave pups at home — dogs aren't allowed on this trail.

name: Montgomery Hill
description:
Montgomery Hill is an idyllic spot with beautiful views of the city and hills. This trail travels to the top of the hill following a nice wide path. This trail has no shade, so plan accordingly and bring water and sun protection.

Depending on recent rainfall, you might find some sections muddy and slippery. The route does feature some inclines, but none are severe, and the elevation gain is minimal. Montgomery Hill Park is a great place for wildlife spotting. Keep an eye out for rabbits, prairie dogs, and eagles. The surrounding rolling hills are littered with colorful wildflowers in spring.

name: Bay Trail: Shoreline Lake
description:
Shoreline Lake Park was originally a landfill, but the city of Mountain View turned it into a 750-acre recreation area with an 18-hole golf course and driving range, a 50-acre artificial lake filled with water pumped from the Bay, and nearly eight miles of trails, many of them along sloughs and marshes. You can hike, golf, boat on the saltwater lake, fly a kite, let your dog run free at the off-leash dog park, eat at the lakeside café, or loll around on lawns. Benches are plentiful throughout. At the restored, accessible Rengstorff House (ca. 1876) you can take a free docent-led tour of one of the finest examples of Victorian Italianate architecture remaining on the West Coast. 

A string of parks and preserves allows hikers to explore the Bay to the north and south. The undeveloped areas east and north of the lake are crossed by a couple of miles of pleasant, unnamed paved and hard gravel paths, including a more than 2-mile paved section of the SF Bay Trail. This trail connects to the Adobe Creek Loop Trail in the Palo Alto Baylands. Shoreline and Baylands parks harbor lots of wildlife, and you may see common birds.

ACCESSIBILITY: Three locations with wheelchair-accessible parking spaces offer good starting points for short strolls around the lake or longer outings along the salt ponds and marshes: Terminal Boulevard on the northern boundary, Shoreline Boathouse in the middle of the park, and the longer route from the kite-flying lot in the park’s southern section. Accessible restrooms are at the boathouse, near the Terminal Blvd. entrance, and at Michael’s café. Accessible portable toilets are in the kite-flying lot and at the dog park.

The trail surface is paved asphalt or dirt and it is typically at least five feet wide. It is mostly gentle with an estimated grade of 5% or less. Near the entrance to the lot, a paved trail connects to a service road that leads southeast for about 0.25 miles past a gravel-surfaced overflow lot for the amphitheater, passing a dog park on the right. At the first fork, stay right to wind around the Crittenden Pump Station, where the trail dips and then climbs to a fork. Turn left toward the Bay and follow along the western side of Stevens Creek Tidal Marsh. After a few hundred feet you come to a bridge to the paved Stevens Creek Trail. Here a right turn will take you south for more than three miles along the creek and through marshlands to Yuba Drive. If you turn left toward the Bay, you travel for 0.5 miles to the paved trail’s end at a fenced levee and a large salt pond. Where the pavement ends at the fenced levee, there is a hill with uneven surfaces and clumps of small rocks that might be challenging in a manual wheelchair, whether traveling uphill or down. From here, go left on the wide dirt trail (impassable in wet weather) that leads west along the shoreline to an intersection where you rejoin the paved trail. A salt pond is on your right.

The Shoreline Golf Links come into view as you near the restored Mountain View Tidal Marsh. Veer left at the marsh to a viewing platform (steep approach). You can then continue around the marsh, traveling north toward the lake, or return to the kite-flying lot via a trail alongside the park’s main entrance road. If you continue, you will cross Permanente Creek near its inlet into the marsh, and soon arrive in the parking lot that serves the boathouse and lakeside café. Both the dock and the beach launching area are accessible.

A paved trail leads north from the boathouse. Where it splits, stay left to travel along the lakeshore. Past the sailing scow play structure, the trail surface changes to decomposed granite. The trail ends on the lake’s northeastern side. If you go right instead of left at the split, you travel toward the Bay alongside Mountain View Tidal Marsh. This trail veers left at the Bay, leading more than 0.5 miles along the shore of another large salt pond to the Coast Casey Forebay, a flood control basin, and Charleston Slough. The accessible viewing platform extending over the slough provides excellent birding opportunities. From the platform, you can extend your trip several miles on the hard-packed dirt-and-gravel Adobe Creek Trail winding through Palo Alto Baylands.

Continuing past the viewing platform, you arrive at the Terminal Boulevard entrance to the park. You can return to the boathouse lot via the paved service road that leads to the right. It cuts through the middle of the golf course and crosses Permanente Creek after 0.8 miles. On the other side of the bridge you can turn left onto the Permanente Creek Trail, which winds for 0.25 miles back to

name: Purisima Creek Trail to Skyline Blvd
park: Purisima Creek Redwoods Open Space Preserve
description: This trail runs between Purisima Creek and Skyline Boulevard. The trail travels through dense forest and crosses some rushing streams. Banana slugs are often spotted making their way across the trail. The tree cover offers shade and makes this an excellent spot to hike during the warm summer months.

name: Grabtown Gulch to Purisima Creek Loop
park: Purisima Creek Redwoods Open Space Preserve
description: This loop follows the Grabtown Gulch, Purisima Creek, and Borden Hatch Mill Trail. The forest is filled with redwood trees, ferns dotting the forest floor, and banana slugs are often spotted alongside the trail. The area is open to hikers, bikers, and runners, so you can expect to see many different user groups on the trail.

name: East Shore and Ridgeline Loop
description:
• Parking fee information: There is a fee to park at Del Valle Regional Park. For more information, please visit https://www.ebparks.org/parks/del-valle

This is an amazing trail with scenic views of hills and Lake Del Valle. Along the trail, you will see cows grazing in open areas and wildflowers blooming. You might also see some birds around the lake. The trail has little shade, so start early if you want to avoid the sun. There is a big parking lot with a restroom at the starting point. There is a limited cell service, so download a map in advance.

name: Baquiano, Sweeney Ridge, and Mori Ridge Trail
description: One of the most scenic trails in the Bay Area. Best enjoyed on days with good visibility and no coastal fog. There is no shade during the entire hike so bring a hat a put sunscreen on. Some sections of the trail are steep and rocky and trekking poles and sturdy footwear are recommended.

name: Bol Park Bike Path
description:
This is a nice gentle paved multi-use path with parallel dirt options that go along the sports fields behind the high school and through Bol Park.

Accessibility: 

Equipment
This trail is likely accessible for visitors using wheelchairs, mobility equipment, or strollers.

Parking
There is 1 designated accessible parking space in the paved street parking off of Laguna Avenue at Bol Park.

Surface
The trail surface is paved asphalt and smooth. It is typically at least 8 feet wide. A painted dividing line along most of the trail reduces the width.

Grade
This trail is estimated to be gentle (3% or less).

More Info
Benches are available along the route for resting.

name: Granuja Falls, Upper Falls, and Basin Falls via Waterfall Loop Trail
description:
• All day use requires a reservation. Please go to www.gooutsideandplay.org​ or call 408-355-2201 to make your reservation.​ There is also a fee to park. 

This route takes you three waterfalls in Swanson Canyon. You'll visit Upper Falls, Basin Falls, and a viewpoint of Black Rock Falls. The best time to visit to see the cascades is during the rainy season, especially during the spring months. There are plenty of options to increase your mileage in this park,

name: Sibley Volcanic Regional Preserve and Huckleberry Path
description: This route links Sibley and Huckleberry Regional Preserves via Skyline road and trail. Expect a beautiful variety of East Bay hills environments. There can be lots of mud near the creeks in early April. Some parts of the loop do not allow dogs. Dogs are not allowed within the boundaries of the Huckleberry Preserve.

name: Redtail Loop to Arastradero Creek Loop
description:
• Seasonal closure: This area is subject to seasonal closure due to weather conditions. For more information, please visit https://www.cityofpaloalto.org/News-Articles/Community-Services/Pearson-Arastradero-Preserve-Seasonal-Trails-Status

Pearson Arastradero Preserve has 10 miles of trails and is located in Palo Alto, California. The loop trail offers great birding opportunities and the  trails are used by hikers, cyclists and equestrians. Some trails are closed seasonally due to wet conditions.

The preserve has 10.25 miles of trails for hiking, biking and horseback riding. Most of the trails (6.6 miles) are open year-round. Some trails (3.6 miles) are designated as "seasonal" and are closed at the trailhead after heavy rain (see table below). When the ground is firm enough to ride and hike on without causing erosion damage, the trails are re-opened by preserve rangers.

Please be courteous to other trail users. Always yield to equestrians. Bikes must also yield to hikers. When in a group, avoid blocking the trail. Help preserve the land by staying on trails. 

For daily trail condition updates please check the bulletin board in the preserve parking lot, or call 650-329-2423 and ask for the for the latest trail conditions in the Pearson Arastradero Preserve.

name: Ridge, Blackhawk and Sprig Trail Loop
description:
• General fee: Mount Madonna County Park charges a fee to enter. For more information, please visit https://parks.sccgov.org/plan-your-visit/santa-clara-county-park-fees

This is a gorgeous scenic hike in Mount Madonna County Park. The route follows a shady trail through tall oaks and redwoods and passes by tranquil creeks. If you go clockwise, the trail starts with a steep hill, followed by a long descent. 

Mount Madonna Park is home to a variety of wildlife, including bobcats, Pileated Woodpeckers, several bird species, reptiles, skunks, and foxes. On weekends and holidays, parking at the trailhead can fill up quickly. Additionally, picnic tables are available near the summit of this loop trail.

name: Mount Sutro Loop
description:
• Partial Closure: Part of this route along the North Ridge Trail is temporarily inaccessible, but you can still enjoy other sections of this trail. For more information, please visit https://www.ucsf.edu/about/locations/mount-sutro-open-space-reserve

Explore this nook of wilderness that is near the UCSF campus, this greenbelt has a native garden and is a great respite from busy urban life of the city. Although this loop can be accessed from several locations, the mapped route on this page begins along the Historic Trail at the intersection of 17th and Stanyan. Street parking is also available on Clarendon Avenue near Johnstone Drive.

Starting along the Historic Trail, turn left at the wooden carving to get on the Fairy Gates Trail. Using the East Ridge Trail to reach the peak of Mt. Sutro, you will descend back down to the Historic Trail, which will wind you through the woods and back to the starting point.

name: Silicon Valley Metric Century
description: This is one of the best long routes available in the South Bay. More than half of the ride follows paved pathways that are separate from cars and roads, while the remainder is made up of well marked bike lanes. Riding through the Peninsula's hills and through Portola Valley offers a stark contrast against the sections that pass through Redwood City and Palo Alto. Some of the best sections are along the Bay Trail and through Coyote Hills, where you get great views of the bay and there is none of the incessant noise of cars and roadways, providing for some peaceful time in nature. Coyote Hills and Alameda Creek offer an abundance of habitat for birds, so watch out for birdwatchers when you're zipping through this park. There are two stretches of gravel track in the Coyote Hills, which could be a little disheartening on thinner tires.

name: Hazelnut Trail and Weiler Ranch Loop
description: This route offers great views. The trail has multiple switchbacks and can be steep in sections. The Hazelnut Trail is a good mix of wooded stretches of trail and sections where it is open with views. At points, you will be able to see the ocean. The Weiler Ranch Trail is a flat crushed gravel path that leads back to the trailhead.

name: Mount Misery via Rawhide Trail [PRIVATE PROPERTY]
park: Mount Misery via Rawhide Trail [PRIVATE PROPERTY]. Bring plenty of water and wear sunscreen and protective clothing.Top trails nearbyMontgomery HillMontgomery HillMontgomery Hill Park4.6·Moderate·1.6 mi·Est. 42mAvenue of the Noble GiantsAvenue of the Noble GiantsJoseph D Grant County Park4.6·Hard·10.9 mi·Est. 5h 13mYerba Buena Trail to Los Huecos Trail LoopYerba Buena Trail to Los Huecos Trail LoopJoseph D Grant County Park4.6·Moderate·5.9 mi·Est. 3h 2mDutch Flat and Dairy TrailsDutch Flat and Dairy TrailsJoseph D Grant County Park
description:
You must be a member of the village country club to access this trail.

In the hills southeast of San Jose is an extensive network of trails that travel among the golden hills and coastal sage that California is known for. The views of the Pacific Ocean are beautiful, and the hills are steep, offering an array of outdoor recreation. This loop heads uphill on Rawhide Trail to the ridgeline, staying high until reaching the summit of 2,464-foot Mount Misery. Loop back around on the Tower Trail. Bring plenty of water and layers to block the sun.

name: Castle Rock Nature Trail
description:
• General fee: Castle Rock State Park charges a day-use fee to enter. For more information please visit https://www.parks.ca.gov/?page_id=538

This trail loops through the forest and between large sandstone rock formations. The boulders are popular with rock climbers to test themselves on, so expect to see climbers with bouldering pads scattered throughout the forest. The forest is very peaceful with its moss-covered rocks and towering trees.

name: Del Amigo Trail to Madrone and Virgil Williams Trail
description: Take the Del Amigo trail to the Madron Trail. This will lead you to the Eugene O'Neill National Historic Site.

name: Bayside Park to Robert E Woolley State Park Loop
park: Bayside Park to Robert E Woolley State Park
description: This trail goes along the bay and  Anza Lagoon, offering beautiful bay views. It is a great trail for walking dogs, running, or just relaxing strolls. The trail is paved, with a restaurant, a cafe, and hotels around. Since the park is near the airport, you will see many planes landing and taking off.

name: Las Cumbres Loop [PRIVATE PROPERTY]
description:
The Las Cumbres area has several social trails that cut through the forested neighborhoods, offering scenic commuting or outdoor recreation. This route makes a short and steep loop on the west side of Skyline Boulevard. It descends to a small seasonal creek before turning southeast and climbing back up to the road. The last section of the loop is along the road, so be mindful of passing cars. 

These informal trails do not have proper trailheads, and street parking is limited. It is best to live nearby and walk to the trails.

name: Best trails inMonte Bello Open Space Preserve
park: Monte Bello Open Space Preservebest Trails In Monte Bello Open Space Preserveall Photos Best Trails In Monte Bello Open Space Preserve
description: Hours: half an hour before sunrise to half an hour after sunset

name: Maisie's Peak via Parker Ranch
description: This is a really nice hike. Great views and well-maintained trails.Maisie’s Peak is the highest point in Fremont Older Open Space Preserve, so there are panoramic views of the Santa Cruz Mountain foothills and valley from up there. You can make a loop out of this hike by taking the Bay View trail back, or lots of other potential modifications to increase the duration of this hike.

name: John McLaren Outer Loop
description: In the middle of a dense neighborhood, The Crocker Amazon Playground and the John McLaren Park offer an extensive network of trails and serve as an oasis for outdoor recreation. This loop covers the perimeter of both parks, passing the most scenic features—including Lover's Rock, Joan's Oasis, and McNab Lake.

name: Summit Loop Trail and Ridge Trail
description:
• San Bruno Mountain State Park charges a fee to enter. Fees are per vehicle. This park does not accept the California State Park Annual Day Use Pass. For more information, please visit https://parks.smcgov.org/fees-charges#vehicle.

Looming large over San Francisco and the northern peninsula, the wilderness preserve of San Bruno Mountain State and County park is home to several rare and endangered species of flora, fauna and wildlife, including the elfin butterfly. The San Bruno Mountain Summit Loop and Ridge Trail offers stunning views of the Pacific Ocean, San Francisco and the Central Bay Area as well as numerous wildlife and plant viewing opportunities.

San Bruno Mountain can often be windy and covered in clouds and fog so check the weather forecast before heading out if you’re looking to enjoy the views. Paid parking is available inside the State Park entrance off Guadalupe Canyon Parkway. Dogs and pets are not allowed on this route. Once you park, take the Summit Loop Trail to Ridge Trail and follow it as far as it goes. On your way back, take a right back onto the Summit Loop Trail and return to the parking lot.  

The Summit Loop Trail can be overgrown so best to wear pants and closed-toe shoes on this hike.

name: Belgatos Park Loop
description:
The scenic trail winds through the hillside, offering breathtaking views of San Jose and the surrounding area. Over half of the trail is shaded and made of gravel and asphalt. 

At the beginning of the trail, there is a lovely shaded playground with picnic tables, a small library, and restrooms. Visitors will find ample parking on the street and around ten parking spots at the trailhead.

name: Saratoga-To-The-Skyline Trail to Viewpoint
description: Skyline-To-The-Sea Trail travels east-west for thirty miles through the Santa Cruz Mountains. This section starts in Saratoga off Big Basin Way and heads west, gradually climbing to a high point. The high point is under dense forest and does not offer views, but you can walk a bit further west and enter the powerline, where the sky opens for some scenic views.

name: Best trails inMission Peak Regional Preserve
park: Mission Peak Regional Preservebest Trails In Mission Peak Regional Preserve Best Trails In Mission Peak Regional Preserve
description: Mission Peak, one of the most popular East Bay hikes, is a great workout with 2,000 feet of climb in two miles and spectacular views of San Francisco Bay and the Diablo Range once you reach the summit.

name: Overlook and Round Top Loop
description:
Park Features: One of the East Bay Regional Park District’s original parks, Sibley Volcanic Regional Preserve is home to a rich geological history, including the now dormant volcano Round Top, highlighted in the unstaffed visitor center near the entrance. The park is filled with breathtaking views of the East Bay throughout its trails, which include a segment of the Bay Area Ridge Trail and Skyline Trail. Wildflowers delight in springtime, wildlife flourish in the hills and creek sides, and visitors enjoy discovering the labyrinth found at the Quarry Pit off the Round Top Loop Trail.

Trail Highlights: Make sure you plan to stop at one of the many benches on this hike for some of the best views of the area. Very nice mix of fire trails and a single track trail makes the hike challenging and fun. You can extend this hiking event by enjoying one of the many other trails along the way. 

Trail Directions: From Sibley Staging Area, take the Overlook Trail. Adjacent to the backpacker campsite, you will see the large water tank. Follow the Overlook Trail to the left to Round Top Loop Trail. Keep left. After 0.41 miles, turn right on Volcanic Trail. Keep right at 1.1 miles. Just up the hill you will see a couple of benches with tremendous views. Head back to the trail sign and continue on Round Top Loop Trail. You will soon come full circle around the water tank and reconnect to the Overlook Trail. Follow the Overlook Trail back to the parking lot. 

Driving Directions: From Highway 24 take the Fish Ranch Road immediately east of the Caldecott Tunnel. Continue 0.8 miles to Grizzly Peak Boulevard. Turn left and go 2.4 miles on Grizzly Peak to Skyline Boulevard. Turn left and drive 0.1 mile to the preserve entrance on the left.

name: The Embarcadero to Oracle Park and McCovey Cove
description:
A lovely scenic waterfront trail along the Embarcadero with a great variety of shops and food. It is about a 1.5 mile walk from the Ferry Building to Oracle Park.

Accessibility: There are designated accessible spaces in the paved parking garage off of The Embarcadero at the north end of the trail. All of them are van-accessible with striped access aisles. The trail surface is paved (with partial railings) and smooth. It is typically 4 to 8 feet wide with some wider passing spaces. There are metal bollards along some of the trail which reduces the width temporarily. 

The entire trail is estimated to be in the gentle grade category (3% or less). This trail will likely be navigable for most wheelchairs/mobility equipment or stroller users. There are benches and picnic tables along the route for resting. There are wheelchair-accessible bathrooms at the north end of the trail.

name: Senador Mine Trail, Guadalupe Trail, and Mine Hill Loop
description: This route starts at McAbee Road and follows McAbee Creek at the Senador Mine Trail. The trail climbs to a high point and connects to the Guadalupe Trail, which travels east through the golden hills and sagebrush. Just over 1.5 miles, take the Mine Hill Trail to complete the loop. Stay alert for others on the trail.

name: Bernal Hill Loop
description: Bernal Heights Park offers panoramic views of the San Francisco Bay and Golden Gate Bridge and a network of trails that wind around its flanks. This loop climbs to the top of Bernal Hill and covers an inner perimeter trail. Parking is available at the end of Bernal Heights Boulevard, and drinking water is available.

name: High Ridge Loop Trail
description:
• Parking fee information: There is a fee to park at Dry Creek Pioneer Regional Park. For more information, please visit https://www.ebparks.org/parks/garin-dry-creek

The route also provides impressive views of the San Francisco Bay and the nearby East Bay Hills; expect to see raptors, deer, and the occasional coyote.

Trails on this route: High Ridge Loop Trail, Spur to Gossip Rock loop, Tolman Peak Trail, South Fork Trail, High Ridge Loop Trail. Skip the Tolman Peak section to slice three miles from the hike.

Best times to go: Early to late spring, when the hills green up and the wildflowers put on their annual show. Winter is fine, too, though bear in mind the trails get very muddy. Give them a few days to dry out after a passing storm system blows through. Summer's too hot, but cooler weather in the autumn makes the hiking pleasant.

name: Spring Valley to Los Coches Ridge Trail Loop
description:
• General fee: Ed R. Levin County Park charges a fee to enter. For more information, please visit https://parks.sccgov.org/plan-your-visit/santa-clara-county-park-fees

Ed R. Levin County Park is a great place to spend time with family or enjoy a pleasant walk. This short loop on a grassy hill offers beautiful vistas of grassland. You can see many fauna, such as deer and turkey. Along the way is a little gazebo with a bench where you can sit and relax. There is a large paid parking lot at the trailhead.

name: Fall Creek and Lost Empire Trail Loop
description:
• General fee: Henry Cowell Redwoods State Park charges a fee to park at the day-use and campground areas. There are varying fees depending on if you enter by vehicle, motorcycle, foot, horse, or bike. For more information, please visit https://www.parks.ca.gov/?page_id=546


The Fall Creek trail follows Fall Creek up the drainage. Explore this beautiful babbling creek and the natural surroundings of Henry Cowell Redwood State Park. The elevation gain is almost entirely along the first half of the loop. Once you reach the Big Ben Tree you will travel downhill on the way back to the trailhead.

name: Deep Gulch and English Camp Trail Loop
description:
From the parking lot you start about 450 elevation level. Take the Mine Hill Trail up and about .4 mile turned left on the steep English Camp Trail. You slowly climb the rocky and sunny trail. You get the the third electric tower and that is the 1 mile marker which is about 600 feet in elevation gain from the parking lot. You climb a little further and the trees shade you which is really nice because it’s another 150 feet to the next trail head, Deep Gulch.

About 20 min later, you will get to where the trail meets Castillero/Wood Road Trail on the Mine Hill Junction. You will also pass through English Camp and you’ll pass the flag pole too. If you start early in the day you’ll see some really nice clouds that look pretty milky. It’s always nice to start long hikes early in the cool mornings.

name: Byxbee Marshfront Trail
description:
According to Access Northern California (http://accessnca.org/access-northern-california/explore/explore-detail-view/?site_id=178): The Baylands Nature Preserve, said to be the largest salt marsh preserve on the Bay, encompasses nearly 2,000 acres protected for wildlife, including the endangered clapper rail and salt marsh harvest mouse. The preserve contains a duck pond (formerly a saltwater swimming pool); tidal and freshwater marshes; a sailing station for windsurfers and hand-carried, non-motorized boats; and almost 15 miles of trails, all of which have some wheelchair access. Although quite a few of the trails are along roads or in built-up areas, many are close to attractive sloughs where a wide variety of birds can be seen even without binoculars, and some are out in the marshlands, where a flock of sandpipers or a lonely blue heron may be your only company.

Jackrabbits are frequently seen in the restored wildlands above the high-water line, where gray foxes and burrowing owls are said to breed. But within the preserve you'll also find a sewage treatment plant, an airport, and a former landfill for the city of San Francisco, which is now a grassy garbage mountain named the Bixby Art Hill, home to several very understated pieces of public art. Highway 101 is nearby, as is Palo Alto's golf course.

The difficulty rating for this trail is based on the experience that a wheelchair or stroller user may have due to the gravel surface.

Visitor center: A quarter-mile down the road from the duck pond is the Lucy Evans Baylands Nature Interpretive Center. Inside are displays about the wildlife you might see at the preserve and an ecology laboratory where visitors can prepare their own slides and examine them under microscopes. The microscopes are on a 25-inch-high shelf, but a video microscope that projects slides onto a monitor permits easier viewing. The center also offers videos, nature walks, and a variety of natural history programs for children and adults. On the wooden deck surrounding the nature center, use the low-mounted telescope to zoom in on shorebirds and waterfowl. A long boardwalk extending from the center across Harriet Mundy Marsh may be closed for major renovations. Located at 2775 Embarcadero Road, 650-329-2506.

ACCESSIBILITY: The trail parallels the north side of Embarcadero Road between Bixby Art Hill and the sailing station for about half a mile, with views across the slough and a pickleweed marsh. It is not paved, and the estimated slope is gentle, all 3% or less. Interpretive panels provide information along the way. Traffic on the road is light and slow-moving, and you will never be far from a restroom. The trail has some access problems, including a soft surface in places and some small hills, but a bike lane next to the level road can serve as an alternate route if the trail poses a problem. Opposite the duck pond, this trail has a very rough section with a couple of small rises and some soft surfaces. In some places the surface is dirt and likely to be muddy in wet weather.

There is designated accessible parking (van accessible), firm, and level or slope no greater than 2% at the Adobe Creek trailhead, where the one designated space is very likely to be occupied. Each of the several small lots along Embarcadero Rd. also has a van-accessible space, and at the sailing station, a gravel lot has several van-accessible spaces. Wheelchair-accessible restrooms with running water are at the nature center (open only when the center is) and Bixby Art Park parking area; porta-potties are at the duck pond and sailing station. Several accessible picnic tables are by the duck pond; all are near the parking lot on firm grass or dirt, and two have shortened benches to provide integrated seating for at least two wheelchairs each. The Visitor Center is wheelchair-accessible.

name: Upper Quarry Park Trail
description: Quarry Park is as it sounds—an old quarry now a lush forest, with trails open to outdoor recreation. This route follows the Saratoga Quarry Trail and gradually ascends the Upper Quarry Park Trail to a high point with beautiful panoramic views. This is a great place to turn around, and side trails will lead you to other areas of the park if you want to extend the trip.

name: Centennial Trail: South San Francisco BART to San Bruno BART
Ridge Trail, Peters Creek, and Canyon Trail Loop
description:
This 15-mile loop passes through five parks that promise some of the best hiking in the San Francisco Bay Area.

The route passes a bucolic pond, forests of oak and Douglas fir, and wonderful vistas overlooking the Santa Cruz Mountains west of San Jose and south of San Francisco. 

While many tourists are content to enjoy the views from Skyline Boulevard from the comfort of their cars, this hike demonstrates why the best things always happen after you park the car and set out on foot. 

If you are mountain biking, this is a pretty challenging trail, especially around Table Mountain (due to the single track uphill/switchback rife with rocks and roots, and quite a bit of poison oak) and Charcoal Road. Table Mountain is only allowed uphill (from North to South on this map) so you can only do this route clockwise. 

Parks in this trek: Skyline Ridge and Long Ridge Open Space Preserves; Upper Stevens Creek County Park; Monte Bello Regional Open Space Preserve.

name: Jones and Flume Trail
description: This trail leads from Los Gatos to the Lexington Reservoir and the James J. Lenihan Dam. It winds through the forest and along a creek, offering a mix of shaded and exposed sections with a few steep and rocky areas. In spring, you'll find beautiful wildflowers along the trail. Remember to bring bug spray to keep mosquitoes away. Parking is available at both ends of the trail.

name: Dunn, Graham and West Ridge Loop
description: Reinhardt Redwoods Regional park is known for its 150+ foot tall coast redwoods that tower above the trails. You'd never guess that this 1,833 acre park was once the site of a bustling logging operation before it was preserved. There are plenty of beautiful redwood trees that provide a canopy of shade on this route. This hike takes you through a variety of different ecosystems in the park. There are many nice spots to stop under the trees for a picnic.

name: Bay Area Ridge Trail: Coyote Lake-Harvey Bear Ranch County Park
park: Bay Area Ridge Trail: Coyote Lake-Harvey Bear Ranch County Park
description:
• Parking Fee: Coyote Lake Harvey Bear Ranch County Park charges a fee to enter, except at Mendoza Ranch and Harvey Bear Entrances. There are varying fees depending on if you enter by vehicle, motorcycle, foot, horse, or bike. Please visit https://parks.santaclaracounty.gov/locations/coyote-lake-harvey-bear-ranch-county-park

Explore miles of scenic ridgeline through this vast park in Santa Clara County.

After a short access trail from Coyote Dam, climb the Ojo de Agua Trail before continuing south on a relatively level route high in the hills. Enjoy sweeping views of Coyote Lake, the surrounding foothills, Santa Clara Valley, and the Coast Range. 

This hike or ride pairs well with a picnic or camping at nearby Coyote Lake. The trail is mostly exposed, so plan your visit during cooler weather or earlier in the day.

You can also access this route from the Harvey Bear Ranch Entrance to the west or the Mendoza Ranch Entrance to the south, offering many options to create your own loops with other park trails.

For more information, see the Bay Area Ridge Trail page here:
https://ridgetrail.org/coyote-lake-harvey-bear-ranch-trail/

This trail description is excerpted from the 2019 Guidebook. For details on all of the Bay Area Ridge trails, trailheads and more buy the book from Wilderness Press: https://www.wildernesspress.com/product.php?productid=16685&cat=274&bestseller=Y

name: Sprig and Ridge Loop
description:
• General fee: Mount Madonna County Park charges a fee to enter. For more information, please visit https://parks.sccgov.org/plan-your-visit/santa-clara-county-park-fees

The Sprig and Ridge Loop meanders through mixed redwood forest. As you climb a ridge, the trail presents steep sections with breathtaking views of the steep-sided valley of Blackhawk Canyon. As you continue, the trail eventually levels out and becomes flat. Along the way, you may encounter occasional picnic tables. Keep an eye out for deer and other wildlife inhabiting this serene environment.

name: Saratoga Creek Park Trail
description: This is a scenic paved path adjacent to the Lawrence Expressway. Saratoga Creek is on the west side of the highway and not along this route, but the path is lined with shade trees and surrounded by open grassy areas, so it is still a scenic, traffic-free opportunity for outdoor recreation. Street parking is available at both ends of the trail.

name: Mine Hill and Providencia Loop
description: The Mine Hill and Providencia Loop is located in Almaden Quicksilver County Park. The first part of the loop goes around the Guadalupe Reservoir. The trails are nice and wide. The hike is a bit challenging at the beginning when going up the hill and then it proceeds downhill. Most of the hike isn't shaded (2/3).

name: Los Gatos Creek Trail and Camden Ponds Loop
description: Los Gatos Creek County Park is a wetland wonderland surrounded by ponds, meadows, and Los Gatos Creek. This route makes a perimeter loop, first heading northeast and crossing Camden Avenue before heading south and following the creek. The route crosses a bridge at the Oka Ponds to complete the loop. Always use the crosswalks at the road crossings.

name: Best trails inSanta Teresa County Park
park: Santa Teresa County Parkbest Trails In Santa Teresa County Park Best Trails In Santa Teresa County Park
description: Santa Teresa County Park is located in the Santa Teresa Hills ten miles south of downtown San Jose. This diverse 1,627 acre park, rich in history, offers spectacular views from its trails above the Almaden and Santa Clara Valleys. The secluded upland valleys of the park provide a quiet interlude for exploring the natural environment minutes away from the surrounding developed areas. Santa Teresa County Park is located at the southern end of the Santa Teresa Hills. The park may be accessed from either Almaden Valley or Santa Clara Valley. From Santa Clara Valley, take US 101 or Highway 85 to the Bernal Road exit. Proceed west 1.3 miles on Bernal Road and cross Santa Teresa Boulevard toward the Santa Teresa Hills. Bernal Road continues past the park's Santa Teresa Golf Club, winding up into the hills. The Pueblo Day Use Area is located off Bernal Road in a small open valley in the hills. Limited parking and trailhead access are available from Almaden Valley. From San Jose, follow Almaden Expressway until it ends. Turn right onto Harry Road, then turn left onto McKean Road. Travel approximately 1.3 miles to Fortini Road. Turn left onto Fortini Road toward the Santa Teresa Hills. At the end of Fortini Road, turn left onto San Vicente Avenue. A ten car parking area is located on the right about 500 feet from Fortini Road. Public transit is available to Santa Teresa County Park. Hours: 8 a.m. - sunset

name: Lower Meadow, Rogue Valley, Wildcat, High Meadow, and Farm Bypass Loop
park: Rancho San Antonio Open Space Preserve
description: This route begins along the Lower Meadow trail, taking you past Ohlone Village and the historic exhibits to the Rogue Valley Trail, which runs along the West Branch of Permanente Creek. Wildcat Loop Trail will take you up a series of switchbacks to the High Meadow Trail. Upper Wildcat Canyon will begin to take you back towards the parking area, traveling along Ohlone Creek back to the Wildcat Loop Trail. You'll turn on to Wildcat Loop, back to High Meadow. Finally, you'll end on the Farm Bypass Trail.

name: Lookout, Redwood, Orchard, Creek Trails
description: The Lookout Trail is moderately steep and leads to Lookout Point and a great view of the Santa Clara Valley.  The Redwood Trail is also moderately steep in places. There are hundreds of young redwoods, ferns, trillium, and huckleberry.  The Orchard Trail is the most exposed to the sun along the Northern perimeter of the park.  The trails can get crowded on the lower slops on the weekends.  There is parking in a paved lot as well as bathrooms at the trailhead in lot 4.

name: Calaveras Ridge Regional Trail
description:
The park features rolling, grassy hills with oak and bay woodlands along the small drainages. The ridgeback trail meanders to its terminus at the small peak of the Calaveras Ridge Regional Trail. This completely exposed trail doesn’t provide any shade, dress accordingly. There is a drinking fountain at the Donlon Point Staging Area parking lot; make sure to  ll your water containers before starting the hike.

Park at the Donlon Point Staging Area. Pass through the gate behind the restrooms to access the Calaveras Ridge Regional Trail. You will follow this trail the whole way. The trail winds up the hill. Continue straight through the next cattle gate, and straight again past the next trail post, remaining on Calaveras Ridge Regional Trail. At the fork, take the trail closest to the fence line and continue straight past trail post #5. Keep heading uphill and at the fork stay on the trail to the slight left, passing trail post # 9. Keep going straight passing large water trough and follow the trail for just under 1 mile all the way up to the top of the hill. At the top of the hill, enjoy the view, and retrace your steps to return to the staging area.

Park Hours: 8am - varies seasonally

name: Raymundo Trail
park: AKA Highway 35. Parking is free in a smattering of lots on the west side of Highway 35 on the fringe of Purisima Creek Redwoods Open Space Preserve
description:
Phleger Estate is a gorgeous swath of second-growth redwoods in the Santa Cruz Mountains just west of Silicon Valley. 

It's a remote section of Golden Gate National Recreation Area that gets few visitors, making it a prime getaway if you need a break from civilization. 

This route starts on Skyline Boulevard, AKA Highway 35. Parking is free in a smattering of lots on the west side of Highway 35 on the fringe of Purisima Creek Redwoods Open Space Preserve. 

Best time to go: this is all shaded so it's nice year-round. It will be fairly warm in the summer, but not nearly as hot as it can get in the valley.

name: Courdet, Shady Creek, Sinbad Creek, and Ridgeline Loop
description: The Courdet, Shady Creek, Sinbad Creek, and Ridgeline Loop offer enjoyable views throughout the hike. Most of the trail is shaded, allowing you to stroll beneath beautiful old oak trees. The trail includes a steep climb. Once you reach the top, you’ll be treated to stunning views across the valley, including Sunol Ridge.

name: SF Peninsula Traverse
description: This is a strenuous multi-day mountain bike adventure that usually takes about 3 days. It takes visitors through the best of the San Francisco Peninsula and is surely one of the most epic bikepacking trips available in the Bay Area. The distance reflected on this page is one way to plan accordingly.

name: Oakland Estuary Shoreline Trail
park: Shoreline Park before ending at Bohol Circle Immigrant Park
description:
This is a beautiful shoreline trail along the Oakland Estuary. The paved path begins at a large parking lot near Wind River Systems and heads northwest, passing through Shoreline Park before ending at Bohol Circle Immigrant Park. The route is incredibly scenic, with views of the estuary, and Bohol Park offers front-row views of downtown Oakland.

Accessibility:

Equipment
This trail is likely accessible for visitors using wheelchairs, mobility equipment, or strollers.

Parking
It is unclear whether any designated accessible parking spaces are available near the trailhead.

Surface
The trail surface is paved asphalt or smooth concrete bricks and pavers and is typically 6-10 feet wide.

Grade
This trail is estimated to be gentle (3% or less).

More Info
Picnic tables and benches are available along the route for resting.

name: Apay Way Trail
Palo Alto Duck Pond Trail
description:
According to Access Northern California (http://accessnca.org/access-northern-california/explore/explore-detail-view/?site_id=178): The Baylands Nature Preserve, said to be the largest salt marsh preserve on the Bay, encompasses nearly 2,000 acres protected for wildlife, including the endangered clapper rail and salt marsh harvest mouse. The preserve contains a duck pond (formerly a saltwater swimming pool); tidal and freshwater marshes; a sailing station for windsurfers and hand-carried, non-motorized boats; and almost 15 miles of trails, all of which have some wheelchair access. Although quite a few of the trails are along roads or in built-up areas, many are close to attractive sloughs where a wide variety of birds can be seen even without binoculars, and some are out in the marshlands, where a flock of sandpipers or a lonely blue heron may be your only company.

Jackrabbits are frequently seen in the restored wildlands above the high-water line, where gray foxes and burrowing owls are said to breed. But within the preserve, you'll also find a sewage treatment plant, an airport, and a former landfill for the city of San Francisco, which is now a grassy garbage mountain named the Bixby Art Hill, home to several very understated pieces of public art. Highway 101 is nearby, as is Palo Alto's golf course.

Visitor center: A quarter-mile down the road from the duck pond is the Lucy Evans Baylands Nature Interpretive Center. Inside are displays about the wildlife you might see at the preserve and an ecology laboratory where visitors can prepare their own slides and examine them under microscopes. The microscopes are on a 25-inch-high shelf, but a video microscope that projects slides onto a monitor permits easier viewing. The center also offers videos, nature walks, and a variety of natural history programs for children and adults. On the wooden deck surrounding the nature center, use the low-mounted telescope to zoom in on shorebirds and waterfowl. A long boardwalk extending from the center across Harriet Mundy Marsh may be closed for major renovations. Located at 2775 Embarcadero Road, 650-329-2506.

ACCESSIBILITY: This short unpaved gravel loop trail around a small pond busy with ducks and geese might be pleasant after a picnic, but for about half the distance it wanders away to overlook a nameless slough with little bird activity. The whole trail is estimated to be in the flat (1% or less) grade category. This trail will likely be navigable for most wheelchairs/mobility equipment or stroller users.

There is 2 designated accessible parking (van accessible), firm, and level or slope no greater than 2% at the Adobe Creek trailhead. Each of the several small lots along Embarcadero Road also has a van-accessible space, and at the sailing station, a gravel lot has several van-accessible spaces. Wheelchair-accessible restrooms with running water are at the nature center (open only when the center is) and Bixby Art Park parking area; porta-potties are at the duck pond and sailing station. Several accessible picnic tables are by the duck pond; all are near the parking lot on firm grass or dirt, and two have shortened benches to provide integrated seating for at least two wheelchairs each. The Visitor Center is wheelchair-accessible.

name: Fortini Trail to Stile Ranch Trail
description:
• Fee Information: Santa Teresa County Park charges a fee to enter. For more information, please visit https://parks.sccgov.org/plan-your-visit/santa-clara-county-park-fees#3925188384-3236192913

The Fortini Trail to Stile Ranch Trail has steep and rough terrain. After winding through a verdant setting, it leads to the Stile Ranch Trail, well-known for its continuous ascent through a rugged, uneven dirt trail. 

Stile Ranch Trail's first summit may offer a sweeping view. After descending to the first summit, the trail climbs back up to a second summit. Enjoy breathtaking views of the Diablo Range and the Lick Observatory atop Mount Hamilton from these summits.

name: Ecology Trail and Lovers' Lane Loop
description: This is a popular urban trail with a bit of forest scenery. The Ecology Trail is not as well marked as the Lover's Lane Loop, which is paved. You will travel through densely wooded areas, open areas with views, past art installations, and athletic fields. At one point you will need to cross the road, so use caution.

name: Dean Trail and Campground Trail
description:
• General fee: Huddart County Park charges a fee to enter. For more information, please visit https://www.smcgov.org/parks/huddart-park
• Partial closure: As of September 2024, the Campground Trail is temporarily inaccessible between markers 19 and 24, but you can still enjoy other sections of this trail. For more information, please visit https://www.smcgov.org/parks/news/huddart-park-closures

To get into the San Mateo County Park - Huddart Park

Easy-to-moderate look hike provides a shady getaway from festivities at the popular park

Huddart County Park west of Woodside, Calif., has popular picnic areas that attract noisy crowds; fortunately the hoots of hollering kids fade into the tweets of singing birds within minutes of hitting the trails. 

Huddart has a nice mix of redwoods and mixed evergreen forests plus a few expanses of open chaparral. This hike has a just-right mix of shady forest, moderate distance and tolerable ascents. A great one to take the kids on.    

Trails on this hike: Dean Trail, Crystal Springs Trail, and Campground Trail.

Huddart has over 24 miles of trails; this hike should be just enough to get you interested in more extended explorations. Crystal Springs Trail is especially scenic, and the Miramontes Trail over to Phleger Estate is always worth a look. Pick up a park map at the entrance kiosk for more ideas.

Best times to go: With its abundance of shade, this is a nice all-year park, though summer might be a bit warm. The rest of the year it'll quite comfortable. Spring wildflowers will be memorable.

name: Skyline-to-the-Sea Trail: Saratoga Gap Route
description:
• CZU Lightning Complex Fire : Public access to Big Basin has been severely impacted by the 2020 CZU Lightning Complex Fire and ongoing fire recovery work, but the park is open for limited day-use access. There is currently no access to waterfalls, all camping is closed and skyline to sea trail is open to the north but access to south (towards the ocean) is closed

Two of the Bay Area's most popular hiking locales -- Castle Rock and Big Basin Redwoods state parks -- promise one of the region's top backpacking experiences. A three-day, 25-plus-mile hike through these parks from the crest of the Santa Cruz Mountains to the Pacific Ocean shows off everything to see in the South Bay woods, from the old growth redwoods towering above to the banana slugs creeping along the forest floor.
 
A popular version of this hike begins at the eastern terminus of the Skyline-to-the-Sea Trail, at the intersection of Highways 9 and 35 (Saratoga Gap). The first third of Skyline-to-the-Sea tracks along a highway and is otherwise unremarkable, so a superior option is to start from the Castle Rock State Park headquarters a few miles south of the gap on Highway 35. Castle Rock offers wonderful vistas of the mountains stretching to the sea, and a safe overnight parking lot.
 
The second and third days of the hike traverse ancient redwoods in Big Basin Redwoods State Park, passing the impressive Berry Creek Falls and ending at the edge of America at Waddell Beach on the Pacific Ocean.

name: Seven Springs Loop
description:
This is a nice trail with a lot of greenery. This route is mostly shaded, but there are some sunny, exposed sections. Sun protection and water are recommended. It is recommended to come in the early morning or afternoon because the small parking lot can fill up quickly.

Heads up! This trail is shared by hikers, mountain bikers, and dogs. Keep your eyes out for others out there enjoying the trail. Hikers have the right of way but should be aware of mountain bikers riding around blind corners or downhill. Dogs should yield to everyone else out there on the trail.

name: Horseshoe Lake, Alpine Pond, and Borel Hill
description:
This is a very pretty place in the string of open-space preserves along Highway 35 also known as Skyline Boulevard. A nature center looks out over the lake. 

While it's possible to hike more than 20 miles at a stretch in the interconnected preserves of the Mid-peninsula Open Space District, it's also nice to keep it simple with an easy stroll around a pond and a not-too-difficult hike to the hillsides nearby.

name: Bay Area Ridge Trail: Sweeney Ridge
park: HikingGreat viewsBeautiful hike with views of the Bay and up to San Francisco. Plenty of sun on the trail even while the coast was fogged in.  Park
description: This route takes you along coastal bluffs and ridgetops, past the San Francisco Bay Discovery former Nike missile site. The views are non stop and the wildflower viewing is awesome when the flowers are in season. Be prepared for variable weather, this area can go from sunny to windy or foggy quite quickly. Be aware that the Notch Trail does not allow bikes or horses. Bathrooms can be located near Sweeney Ridge and Sneath Lane junction.

name: PG&E Trail, Upper High Meadow, and Upper Rogue Valley Loop
park: Rancho San Antonio Open Space Preserve
description: The trails feature several climbs and descents along the wide trail. Many wildlife, such as turkeys, deer, salamanders, tarantulas, bobcats, and mountain lions, may be seen as you hike around the loop. A picnic place and a grassy meadow along the trail are ideal for a relaxing respite. It also goes around the base of a vast California bay tree. Reaching the summit rewards you with breathtaking views of the surrounding valleys and the Bay Area.

name: San Francisco Bay Trail: Sunnyvale East Pond Loop
park: San Francisco Bay Trail: Sunnyvale East Pond Loop. Bring plenty of water and wear sunscreen and protective clothing.Top trails nearbyBay Trail: Shoreline LakeBay Trail: Shoreline LakeShoreline at Mountain View Park4.6·Easy·7.4 mi·Est. 2h 11mAlviso Slough TrailAlviso Slough TrailAlviso Marina County Park4.3·Easy·8.7 mi·Est. 2h 32mStevens Creek TrailStevens Creek Trail4.5·Easy·4.2 mi·Est. 1h 17mShoreline Park LoopShoreline Park LoopShoreline at Mountain View Park4.6·Easy·1.4 mi·Est. 25mGuadalupe River TrailGuadalupe River Trail4.5·Easy·5.4 mi·Est. 1h 37mSan Francisco Bay Trail - Sunnyvale to Sand PointSan Francisco Bay Trail - Sunnyvale to Sand PointDon Edwards San Francisco Bay National Wildlife Refuge4.6·Moderate·20.0 mi·Est. 5h 50mSunnyvale Baylands Park Guadalupe SloughSunnyvale Baylands Park Guadalupe SloughSunnyvale Baylands Park4.2·Easy·3.4 mi·Est. 1h 0mSan Tomas Aquino Creek TrailSan Tomas Aquino Creek TrailSunnyvale Baylands Park4.4·Easy·12.6 mi·Est. 3h 47mSan Tomas Aquino Creek Trail to SF Bay TrailSan Tomas Aquino Creek Trail to SF Bay Trail4.4·Easy·4.0 mi·Est. 1h 11mAlviso Marina LoopAlviso Marina LoopAlviso Marina County Park4.3·Easy·0.8 mi·Est. 14mBaylands Perimeter LoopBaylands Perimeter LoopSunnyvale Baylands Park4.3·Easy·1.3 mi·Est. 23mSan Francisco Bay Trail at Sunnyvale Baylands ParkSan Francisco Bay Trail at Sunnyvale Baylands ParkSunnyvale Baylands Park
description: The San Francisco Bay Trail makes a detour and follows the perimeter of the two ponds at the Sunnyvale Water Pollution Control Plant. The wide dirt paths offer panoramic views, and the ponds are thriving with wildlife. This is a great place for birders. There is no shade or drinking water along the route; plan accordingly.

name: Vista Slope
description: Vista Slope is a barren golden hilltop wedged between Charleston and Shoreline Parks. The wide gravel path winds throughout the park and to the summit of Vista Slope. Enjoy panoramic views from the top, and take a different way down to make a loop. There is no shade along the route, so plan accordingly.

name: French, Bridle and Stream Trail Loop
description:
This combination of East Bay hills trails includes the French Trail, the Bridle Trail, and the Stream Trail to form a lovely loop through Redwood Regional Park. The route is long enough to be a solid day hike but also located conveniently close to the East Bay Area. This makes for a great escape to nature.

The beginning of this route is located at the top of Skyline Blvd. and starts off relatively flat with great views of the Bay Area. Eventually, it descends down towards the creek and through groves of redwood trees. These coast redwoods provide lots of shade year-round making this a nice hike in both the rainy months and the warmer summer months. Once you reach the Bridle and Stream Trails, the path flattens out again and is even paved in a few areas. There are several picnic tables to stop at and rest before you continue the trek back up to the parking lot.

This is a great place for a long dog walk or a challenging trail run. While the trails in this area can get a bit busy on the weekends, there are enough trails and combinations to feel like you get your own piece of the redwood forest. There are many staging areas in the area so please be aware of equestrians and their horses.

name: Big Basin and Castle Rock Loop
description:
• General fee: Castle Rock State Park charges a day-use fee to enter. For more information please visit https://www.parks.ca.gov/?page_id=538

A very nice hike that is mostly shaded. There are amazing views of the valley along the route. Keep an eye out for poison oak. Since this is a mostly bike-friendly trail, there is a section that goes through a residential neighborhood where you need to walk along the road and look out for cars. There are beautiful fall colors in the fall.

name: Best trails inMount Madonna County Park
park: Mount Madonna County Parkbest Trails In Mount Madonna County Park Best Trails In Mount Madonna County Park
description: Welcome to Mt. Madonna County Park, one of the most majestic of Santa Clara County's regional park and recreation areas. This 3,688 acre park is dominated by the redwood forest so characteristic of the Santa Cruz Mountain range. To the east, the park overlooks the Santa Clara Valley, to the west, Monterey Bay. As the slopes of Mt. Madonna descend toward the valley, the landscape changes from redwood forest to oak woodland, dense chaparral and grassy meadows. Park visitors may learn about areas where Ohlone Indians hunted and harvested, and will understand why cattle baron Henry Miller spent his summers here. Enjoy your visit today, and return often to the pristine redwood forest of Mt. Madonna County Park. Mt Madonna Stables offers horseback trail rides, it is a wonderful way to explore the beauty of this park. The park is located on Highway 152 (Hecker Pass Highway), ten miles west of Gilroy. From the east, use Highway 101, and take the Highway 152 West exit. From the west, use Highway 1, and take the Highway 152 East exit. The entrance to the park is located at the summit of Highway 152 at Pole Line Road. Hours: 8:00 a.m. – Sunset

name: Soda Springs Road from Alma Bridge Road
description: A great workout from Alma Bridge Road up to the gate at the top of Soda Springs Road, where it is closed to the public.

name: Valley View, Weiler Ranch and Hazelnut Trail Loop
description:
Beginning with the Hazelnut Trail, you'll go through thick foliage and take in a range of views, such as deep views of the Montara Mountain side, striking views of the ocean, Sweeney Ridge, and the park's vast valleys. This trail climbs through coastal scrub, where you may spot mule deer after passing past a grove of eucalyptus trees.

The Weiler Ranch Trail takes you along the edge of a stream after crossing a bridge. This trail section is home to wildflowers, including California blackberry, coyote mint, and sticky monkey flower. An excellent place to rest is the picnic area along the trail, sheltered by various trees, including walnut, buckeye, and coast live oak.

name: Stevens Creek Reservoir
park: Stevens Creek Reservoir.
