description: This route follows the Tony Look Trail from the northern parking lot to the Madrone Picnic area, featuring views of Stevens Creek Reservoir along the way.

name: Half Moon Bay Coastal Trail
park:
HMB. 

An easy 99% paved trail along the coast with gorgeous views of the water on one side and the Ritz on the other. Park
description:
Great views of the Pacific coastline. This trail is partially paved and goes through a golf course, the Ritz Carlton Hotel, and Manhattan Beach.

Accessibility: 

Equipment
Visitors using wheelchairs, mobility equipment, or strollers may need all-terrain tires or adaptive/motorized equipment for the surface type and grade.

Parking
There are at least 2 designated van-accessible spaces with striped access aisles in the paved parking lot off Miramontes Point Road at the Ritz Carlton. 

Surface
The trail surface is paved concrete with some cracks. It is typically at least 8 feet wide.

Grade
This trail is estimated to be mostly gentle (5% or less), with some steeper sections that may require assistance or need to be avoided.

More Info
Beaches may only be accessible by stairs.

name: Rhus Ridge Trail
park: Rancho San Antonio Open Space Preserve
description:
The Rhus Ridge Trail offers valley vistas and chances to spot native fauna. The trail emerges onto a dirt road after passing through open forests with many oak and bay laurel trees. This section gets very steep and gravelly as it climbs through scrub, which provides very little shade. Hikers can enjoy a few pleasant views of Los Altos while hiking along the trail. 

Visitors are rewarded with breathtaking views of Silicon Valley from Palo Alto to Mountain View. The vista across Rancho San Antonio is especially striking from the summit of Rhus Ridge.

name: Red Hill Trail and Nike Trail
description:
• Parking fee information: There is a fee to park at Coyote Hills Regional Park. For more information, please visit https://www.ebparks.org/parks/coyote-hills

Offering 360-degree views that extend from San Francisco to the Santa Cruz Mountains, this park contains an extensive brackish marsh, habitat for waterfowl and shorebirds.

name: Nob Hill Trail
description: One of the key highlights of the Nob Hill Trail is the stunning 360-degree view from the top of Nob Hill, the trail's namesake. From the summit, hikers are treated to expansive vistas of the Santa Clara Valley, the San Francisco Bay Area, and the surrounding hills and valleys, offering a glimpse of the urban landscape juxtaposed with the natural beauty of the region. On clear days, you can see as far as Mount Hamilton and the Santa Cruz Mountains in the distance.

name: Round Top Loop Trail to Volcanic Trail Loop
description:
The trail begins with rolling hills and winds through pine, oak, and bay woods. It leads you to a shady eucalyptus forest. You'll be hiking over rugged terrain. Along the trail, you might also come across a cow guard fence and labyrinths. One of the highest peaks in the region, Round Top, is made of lava and volcanic debris from a volcano that erupted 10 million years ago. 

You'll pass by the volcanic craters as you reach the Volcanic Trail. Be cautious of the sharp drops into the pits. This section of the trail offers breathtaking sweeping views of the surrounding hillsides and deep woodland. Siesta Valley, Mt. Tamalpais in Marin County, and Volmer Peak at Tilden Park are all visible here.

name: San Andreas and Madrone Loop
description:
• Fee Information: Sanborn County Park charges a fee to enter. For more information, please https://parks.santaclaracounty.gov/locations/sanborn-county-park

This variation of the many possible loops in Sanborn County Park takes you on a tour of the towering and shady redwood forests, with the addition of a short climb. You will climb up a steep section on the Madrone trail through more shady redwood forest. After the trail's high point, you'll descend gently, crossing Todd Creek as you head back to the San Andreas trail. This popular section of trail is accessed by a parking area that has restrooms and picnic facilities. Nearby, there is family-friendly walk-in camping available along the Sanborn Trail.

name: Coyote Peak and Ridge Trail Loop
description:
• Fee Information: Santa Teresa County Park charges a fee to enter. For more information, please visit https://parks.sccgov.org/plan-your-visit/santa-clara-county-park-fees#3925188384-3236192913

Coyote Peak is the must-visit point in Santa Teresa County Park in southern San Jose, California. This loop to the peak is a good way to get there: steep enough to provide a good workout and scenic enough to reward your efforts. 

Coyote Peak looks out over the southern expanse of Silicon Valley, with great views of both the Diablo Range to the east and the Santa Cruz Mountains to the west. Admittedly, this park is not the sexiest hiking locale in the South Bay, but it's extremely accessible if you're in the neighborhood. And let's face it: few city parks have hills with this much elevation gain.  

Bear in mind that the park is very popular with mountain bikers, so come prepared to share the trails. 

This hike starts out at the Pueblo Day Use Area; you have to pay to park here, but the amenities (bathrooms, water, picnic tables, lots of parking spaces) are usually unavailable at the free trailheads around the park.  

Best time to come: If you come early in the morning before it gets too hot, you can hike here all year. Springtime wildflower season is very scenic, and winter offers the best views from Coyote Peak after a strong rain cleans up the smog. Summer and fall will be hot and dry with significant wildfire risk.

name: Meadowlark and Ohlone Trails Loop
description:
• Seasonal closure: This area is subject to seasonal closure due to weather conditions. For more information, please visit https://www.cityofpaloalto.org/News-Articles/Community-Services/Pearson-Arastradero-Preserve-Seasonal-Trails-Status

The moderate loop trail is a nice trail for beginners mountain biking, hiking, and trail running. The trail consists of varying slopes and a mix of wider gravel and rougher single-trail areas. The first half of the trail offers several view points of the South Bay. This trail can get muddy depending on weather so dress accordingly.

name: Bay Area Ridge Trail: Sanborn County Park John Nicholas Trail
park: Bay Area Ridge Trail: Sanborn County Park
description:
• Fee Information: Sanborn County Park charges a fee to enter. For more information, please https://parks.santaclaracounty.gov/locations/sanborn-county-park

Opened in 2014, this well-designed singletrack wooded trail is a popular mountain biking route with a significant ascent or descent. Lake County Reservoir provides a scenic resting spot. Parking at the ends of both connector trails is extremely limited, so consider doing this route as a round-trip from the Sunnyvale Mountain staging area.

For more information, see the Bay Area Ridge Trail page here: https://ridgetrail.org/sanborn-county-park-john-nicholas-trail/

This trail description is excerpted from the 2019 Guidebook. For details on all of the Bay Area Ridge trails, trailheads and more buy the book from Wilderness Press: https://www.wildernesspress.com/product.php?productid=16685&cat=274&bestseller=Y

name: Calaveras Trail to Coyote Ridge Trail Loop
park: Coyote Lake Harvey Bear Ranch County Park
description:
• Parking Fee: Coyote Lake Harvey Bear Ranch County Park charges a fee to enter, except at Mendoza Ranch and Harvey Bear Entrances. There are varying fees depending on if you enter by vehicle, motorcycle, foot, horse, or bike. Please visit https://parks.santaclaracounty.gov/locations/coyote-lake-harvey-bear-ranch-county-park

Take this trail for a scenic trip along Coyote Lake. Parts of this trail are under the shade of oak trees, but a large amount of the trip is exposed to the sun. This hike is one of the "Magnificent 7" hikes recommended by Santa Clara County Parks as part of their #PixInParks Challenge. You may encounter wildlife or wildlife tracks on the trail. Coyotes and deer are often sighted in this park.

name: Newark Slough Trail
park: Conditions: WildflowersShow activityHit the trail Frequently asked questionsWhat are some of the facilities available for Newark Slough Trail?Park
description: The Newark Slough is nice loop around the berms of Don Edwards National Wildlife Refuge. As this area is a stopover for many migratory birds, users recommend bringing binoculars to enjoy the view.

name: Wildcat Canyon Loop
park: Rancho San Antonio Open Space Preserve
description:
Escape the crowds and take in the sights on this loop at the popular park west of Cupertino. Upper Wildcat Canyon is one of the prettiest sections of the park. The trail also climbs to impressive vistas looking out over the South Bay from the Rogue Valley sections of the loop.

This route at Rancho San Antonio County Park and Open Space Reserve ventures beyond the popular sections of the park to offer a diverse introduction to the terrain on the eastern side of the Santa Cruz Mountains. 

Rancho, as the locals call it, draws big crowds with its abundance of flat trails and attractions at Deer Park Farm, but few visitors venture deeper into the wilds of this park seen on this loop hike. 

Best times to go: Spring wildflowers and winter vistas are the most inviting; autumn will have a touch of fall color; summer will be hot in the exposed areas, but fairly cool in the covered canyons.

name: Braly Park Loop
description: This trail is a paved loop around Braly Park. This trail is great for your daily walk or run. There are also picnic tables, benches and drinking fountains along the path. There is a playground for the kids to play before or after your walk. There is also a pond. This trail is great for the whole family.

name: Best trails inCastle Rock State Park
park: Castle Rock State Parkbest Trails In Castle Rock State Park Best Trails In Castle Rock State Park
description: Within a short drive from Santa Cruz, San Jose, and San Francisco, miles of hiking trails, and coastal redwoods as far as you can see... What more could you ask for? Castle Rock State Park is a great place for a hike or some rock climbing. There are picnic areas and restrooms onsite.

name: Tony Look Trail to Stevens Creek Reservoir
description: Follow the Tony Look trail to a peninsula overlooking Stevens Creek Reservoir. You will have views of the water for almost the entirety of the hike. The first stretch is more shaded, the trail along the lake is much sunnier. Bug spray is recommended during the summer months. The trails are all well defined and easy to follow.

name: Sunny Jim and IPIWA Loop
description: The Sunny Jim and Ipiwa Loop takes hikers through a mix of rugged cliffs, and grassy meadows, with stunning views of the surrounding countryside along the way. This hike takes you past Horseshoe lake as well as the Gene Sheehan Overlook. This is a great hike to explore in the bay area! Make sure to pack plenty of water as theres not a lot of shade on this trail.

name: San Bruno Mountain via Summit Loop and Dairy Ravine Trail
description:
• San Bruno Mountain State Park charges a fee to enter. Fees are per vehicle. This park does not accept the California State Park Annual Day Use Pass. For more information, please visit https://parks.smcgov.org/fees-charges#vehicle.

Hike to the summit of San Bruno Mountain (1,314 feet). Enjoy picturesque views of the entire Bay Area from the top.

Travel counterclockwise and take the Summit Loop trail for the most gradual way to the summit. There is very little shade, so getting an early start is recommended during the summer when it is hot out.

name: South Arroyo, North Arroyo, and Shadow Cliffs Loop
park:
Water Slide Trail and follow it to the right back towards the entry kiosk.

Park
description:
• Parking fee information: There is a fee to park at Shadow Cliffs Regional Recreation Area. For more information, please visit https://www.ebparks.org/parks/shadow-cliffs

The land at Shadow Cliffs was formerly a gravel quarry. Trails are graveled or dirt and are mostly flat and wide. There are no markers for these trails so be sure to pick up a park map before you begin your hike. The trail offers views of the marsh and lake area, as well as a variety of habitats. Walk the Arroyo for a chance to glimpse, or hear, hawks, quail, heron, mallards and other bird species. The trail runs along the shoreline; during the rainy season, it can be very wet. Water and restrooms are located at the picnic sites, and benches are located along the trail.

Trail Directions: Starting at the entry kiosk, head west towards the restroom and
picnic area. Walk along the paved path past the pollinator garden and continue onto Water Slide Trail. Continue around to the right side of the marsh. The path runs parallel to Stanley Boulevard, looping around the marsh. At an intersection before the BMX park, take the Levee Trail to the left. When you reach the junction, cross over the water on the cement bridge to the right. After the bridge, head uphill on the middle path, then turn to the left. Take the South Arroyo Trail for 0.15 miles, then cross back over the bridge and turn right onto the North Arroyo Trail. Head east on the trail as it takes you back along the waterline to a shaded, tree-­‐lined area.
The North Arroyo Trail will come out of the woodland and loop back around to the Levee Trail. Once you reach the Levee Trail, turn left and head back to the intersection towards Water Slide Trail and follow it to the right back towards the entry kiosk.

Park/Gate Hours: Varies monthly (check website for times)
Fees: $6 per vehicle, $5 per trailered vehicle
$2 per dog. Guide/service dogs free.
Website: http://www.ebparks.org/parks/shadow_cliffs

name: El Corte De Madera Loop- Fir Trail and Methuselah
park: El Corte De Madera Creek Open Space Preserve
description: This route takes you along several trails in the Corte de Madera Cree Open Space Preserve. Along the way, you'll be able to enjoy some impressive and unique sandstone formations and some giant redwoods and ocean views. There are over 34 miles of multi-use trails, allowing you to extend your hike if you want.

name: Saratoga Gap Trail to Achistaca Trail Loop
description:
The Saratoga Gap Trail to Achistaca Trail Loop is well-marked and runs close below the crest. It alternates between woodland sections and open regions with spectacular mountain vistas. Along the trail, you'll come across deep ravine chasms, and the forested areas are usually wet and shaded. 

Enjoy expansive views of the San Lorenzo River Basin and the Santa Cruz Mountains from various vantage points. Hawks are frequently spotted circling below. As you continue, the terrain gets more rugged, and a grove of little redwoods lines a gully.

name: SF Bay Trail: Interpretive Center to Hayward Landing
park: SF Bay Trail: Interpretive Center to Hayward Landing. Bring plenty of water and wear sunscreen and protective clothing.Top trails nearbyQuail and Bayview LoopQuail and Bayview LoopCoyote Hills Regional Park4.7·Easy·4.8 km·Est. 1h 2mBayview and Meadowlark Trail LoopBayview and Meadowlark Trail LoopCoyote Hills Regional Park4.7·Easy·7.9 km·Est. 1h 41mBayview and Nike LoopBayview and Nike LoopCoyote Hills Regional Park4.7·Easy·3.9 km·Est. 48mRed Hill Trail and Nike TrailRed Hill Trail and Nike TrailCoyote Hills Regional Park4.6·Easy·2.3 km·Est. 42mEast Avenue and Ward Creek Trail LoopEast Avenue and Ward Creek Trail Loop4.5·Moderate·5.8 km·Est. 1h 39mSF Bay Trail: Cogswell Marsh to Roberts LandingSF Bay Trail: Cogswell Marsh to Roberts Landing4.5·Easy·8.4 km·Est. 1h 31mBayview to Alameda Creek TrailBayview to Alameda Creek TrailCoyote Hills Regional Park4.7·Easy·4.5 km·Est. 57mSF Bay Trail: Roberts Landing to Marina ParkSF Bay Trail: Roberts Landing to Marina Park
description:
Dogs are not allowed on some parts of the Bay Trail to protect wildlife. Find the list of dog-friendly segments here: http://www.walking-the-bay.com/p/dog-friendly-bay-trail-segments.html

According to Access Northern California (http://accessnca.org/access-northern-california/explore/explore-detail-view/?site_id=189): The 1,700-acre Hayward Regional Shoreline provides habitat to hundreds of species of birds and other wildlife. Along the regional shoreline the Bay Trail extends for 8 miles, past marshes and creeks to the San Leandro Marina, with its popular park and jogging course. The shoreline trail is almost level and mostly firm with a gravel or pavement surface. There are four entry points to the trail, so you can take a long ride, watching the light change the look of the Oakland and San Francisco skylines, or make it a short trip. There is no shade along the way, so bring a hat.

Changes in weather can alter this shoreline dramatically. Sometimes cold, fierce winds blow and the water is gray; at other times it ripples and glints in the sun. At low tide, mudflats stretch for yards, while high tides bring acres of open water. Time your visit for a receding tide to see crowds of wading birds foraging at the water’s edge. With marsh views to the east and the Bay to the west, there is always plenty to marvel at.

Park Hours: Between 5 AM and 10 PM unless otherwise posted

Accessibility: The southernmost entrance at Breakwater Ave. has no off-street parking, but several wheelchair-accessible spaces are in front of the interpretive center. West Winton Ave. has no designated disabled parking spaces in the two large lots with gravel surfacing. The Grant Ave. lot has designated accessible spaces on level asphalt. An accessible portable toilet is at the trail’s start on Breakwater Ave. The next accessible public restroom on the shoreline is 7 miles away at the San Leandro Marina - there are no other wheelchair-accessible restrooms along the entire route. The slope of this route is mostly gentle (all 5% grade or less).

The interpretive center is a great starting point for exploring 5 miles of gravel trail, either on your own or with one of the many ranger-led programs. At a little over a mile out you can add to your excursion and take the 1.2-mile loop around Cogswell Marsh, a salt marsh restoration project that was completed in 1980. After another half-mile, you reach a landfill loop. The paths that climb this low, flat hill are steep enough to deter most wheelchair riders, but the adventurous may enjoy the view from the top, where a nearly level trail travels out to overlook the Bay and other hikers passing along the trail. Back on the shoreline trail, you reach Hayward’s Landing in half a mile. The landfill loop paths are 30 inches to 4 feet wide. The main trail is a gravel levee service road closed to cars. The landfill loop is likely to be muddy in wet weather.

name: Coyote Creek Trail Loop
description: Coyote Creek Trail Loop is a great trail for a casual walk or bike ride. Half of the trail that follows the creek is on a paved road, and the other half is on dirt. The trail also has a good mix of shaded and exposed parts. The bathroom is available near the parking lot, and there's lots of parking at the trailhead.

name: Bobcat to Miwok to Coastal to SCA Loop
description: This loop begins from the Morning Sun Trailhead and rewards hikers with rolling hills, travels across Bodea Beach, and has views of the Golden Gate Bridge, San Francisco, and Black Sands Beach. At points, you will be walking along the road and pass several trailheads with bathrooms in place. You will also pass the Marin Headlands Visitor Center.

name: Crazy Pete’s and Alpine Road Loop
description: Enjoy this 2.8-mile loop trail near Redwood City, California. Generally considered a moderately challenging route, it takes an average of 1 h 28 min to complete. This is a popular trail for hiking and running, but you can still enjoy some solitude during quieter times of day. The trail is open year-round and is beautiful to visit anytime.

name: Sawyer Camp Trail: San Mateo Creek Bridge to Skyline Boulevard
park: Sawyer Camp Trail: San Mateo Creek Bridge to Skyline Boulevard. Always observe wildlife from a safe distance.Top trails nearbySawyer Camp TrailSawyer Camp TrailSan Francisco State Fish and Game Refuge4.7·Easy·11.6 mi·Est. 3h 46mJohn Brooks Trail and Lake Loop TrailJohn Brooks Trail and Lake Loop TrailWater Dog Lake Open Space4.6·Easy·2.9 mi·Est. 1h 18mJohn S Brooks Memorial Trail LoopJohn S Brooks Memorial Trail LoopWater Dog Lake Open Space4.5·Moderate·5.5 mi·Est. 2h 34mLake Road and John Brooks Trail LoopLake Road and John Brooks Trail LoopWater Dog Lake Open Space4.5·Moderate·4.1 mi·Est. 1h 51mSugarloaf Hill and Captain Hook ViewpointsSugarloaf Hill and Captain Hook ViewpointsLaurelwood Park
description: The Sawyer Camp Trail is a segment of the Crystal Springs Regional Trail. It starts on Hillcrest Boulevard and ends at Crystal Springs Road. The trail is marked for two-way traffic and has restrooms near the northern and southern access points and about the halfway point. This route starts at a parking lot north of the bridge over San Mateo Creek and ends at the Skyline Road crossing. Bring plenty of water and prepare for a lot of sun.

name: Bobcat Point via Panorama Trail
description:
• Foothills Nature Preserve charges an entry fee. An annual pass is also available for purchase. Dogs are not allowed on weekends or holidays. For more information, please visit https://www.cityofpaloalto.org/Departments/Community-Services/Open-Space-Parks/Neighborhood-Parks/Foothills-Nature-Preserve



Visit this trail in the springtime and you may get excellent looks at wildflowers, deer, and wild turkeys displaying. Take this trail from the parking area near Vista Hill and follow it as it winds through oak woodlands. Expect many great views peeking out from between the trees.

Dogs are allowed on leash only on weekdays and not on any city holidays. For more information, visit: https://www.cityofpaloalto.org/Departments/Community-Services/Open-Space-Parks/Open-Space-Preserves/Dogs

name: Castillero, Mine Hill, Randol Loop
description: Almaden Quicksilver County Park includes over 37 miles of hiking trails, including 30 miles of equestrian trails and 16.6 miles of bike trails. All trails in the park are also open to pet owners to walk their dogs on leash. For more information visit: https://www.sccgov.org/sites/parks/parkfinder/pages/almadenpark.aspx

name: Sugarloaf Hill via Salson and Saddle Trail
description: • Partial Closure: Part of this route near the San Juan Canyon Trailhead is temporarily inaccessible, but you can still enjoy other sections of this trail. For more information, please visit https://www.belmont.gov/Home/Components/FacilityDirectory/FacilityDirectory/96/509

name: Vasona Reservoir via Los Gatos Creek Trail
description:
• Seasonal closure: Vasona Lake County Park is subject to seasonal closure during the wintertime and wet weather due to weather conditions. For more information, please visit https://parks.sccgov.org/closures-updates

The Vasona Reservoir via Los Gatos Creek Trail is a scenic route that gradually climbs, with certain sections becoming more steep as you approach the hill. The trail follows along the eastern shore of Vasona Lake, providing lovely water views. Along the way, you'll encounter flowering plants. As you continue, the trail offers a rewarding view of Lexington Dam.

name: Senador Mine Trail, Mine Hill Trail, and Castillero Trail
description:
Begin at the McAbee entrance and continue straight past the porta potties to Senador Mine Trail. You will go about 3 miles, you’ll reach the  Mine Hill Trail Loop near the reservoir and instead of turning left on the loop, continue straight up above and along the reservoir. The views are very beautiful up there.

Stay on Mine Hill Trail and you will soon be looking at the reservoir and downtown San Jose from a different view. Sometimes the clouds will be below you! You will also see Mt. Umunhum since it will be closer and other trails just below too.

Once you reach the top of Mine Hill and Castillero junction, this will be 6 miles, take a look around and you’ll see an old and large mine shaft.
Walk a little further and you’ll see a picnic bench and on that side you’ll see Calero Reservoir as well. 

The views up there are spectacular!

name: Mazzariello Labyrinth via Round Top and Skyline Trail
description:
This trail begins from the Sibley Volcanic Regional Preserve parking lot. From here, you'll head along the Skyline Trail, then turn onto the Round Top Loop Trail and go up to the Mazzariello Labyrinth. Most of the trail is relatively easygoing before a final steep uphill climb to reach the labyrinth. 

There are many trail options in the area, so you can make your hike as long as you like. It's best to wear hiking boots for this one, especially after rain, as the first half can become quite muddy.

name: Meadow and Oak Loop [PRIVATE PROPERTY]
park: Top trails nearbyMontgomery HillMontgomery HillMontgomery Hill Park4.6·Moderate·1.6 mi·Est. 42mAvenue of the Noble GiantsAvenue of the Noble GiantsJoseph D Grant County Park4.6·Hard·10.9 mi·Est. 5h 13mYerba Buena Trail to Los Huecos Trail LoopYerba Buena Trail to Los Huecos Trail LoopJoseph D Grant County Park4.6·Moderate·5.9 mi·Est. 3h 2mDutch Flat and Dairy TrailsDutch Flat and Dairy TrailsJoseph D Grant County Park
description: In the hills southeast of San Jose is an extensive network of trails that travel among the golden hills and coastal sage that California is known for. The views of the Pacific Ocean are beautiful, and the hills are steep, offering an array of outdoor recreation. This loop heads uphill to the ridgeline, staying high on Upper Meadow Trail before descending on Oak Trail. Bring plenty of water and layers to block the sun.

name: Los Alamitos Creek Trail
description:
This is a pleasant paved trail by the creek that is frequented by runners, walkers, and cyclists with partial tree cover providing some shade.

Accessibility: 

Equipment
This trail is likely accessible for visitors using wheelchairs, mobility equipment, or strollers.

Parking
There is 1 designated van-accessible space with striped access aisles in the paved parking lot off Camden Ave. 

Surface
The trail surface is paved asphalt and smooth. It is typically at least 8 feet wide. A painted dividing line along most of the trail reduces the width.

Grade
This trail is estimated to be gentle (3% or less).

name: Homestead Flat Trail
description: The Homestead Flat Trail heads west from Azalea Flat Campground and stays close to Pescadero Creek. The scenic trail is flat and easy for most as it snakes through the dense forest and along the creek, fostering an abundance of wildlife. The trail ends at Homestead Flat Youth Camp. If you are not part of the youth camp, starting this trail from the east is best.

name: Ramage and Chabot to Garin Regional Trail
description:
• Access information: All visitors must obtain a permit before hiking this area. For more information, please visit https://www.ebmud.com/recreation/buy-trail-permit/

All visitors must obtain a permit before hiking this area. More information here: https://www.ebmud.com/recreation/buy-trail-permit/

name: Rhus Ridge and Creek Trail Loop
park: Rancho San Antonio Open Space Preserve
description:
• Short-term closure: Hidden Villa is closed until August 5th, 2025, while summer camps are in session. For more information, please visit https://www.hiddenvilla.org/

This loop travels across open hillsides and through some shaded areas. There are views of the bay at points along the way. The grass can be very tall during the summer months, so wearing long pants is recommended. The parking area can fill up quickly on the weekends, so an early start is recommended.

name: Hetch Hetchy Linear Park
description:
The Hetch Hetchy Linear Park is a greenbelt through the suburbs of Milpitas. The paved path travels north-south and passes through several smaller neighborhood parks. This route starts at Peter T. Gill Park and ends at Sandalwood Park. A parking lot is on the south end, while the north has limited street parking only.

The City of Milpitas maintains this trail.

Accessibility:

Equipment
This trail is likely accessible for visitors using wheelchairs, mobility equipment, or strollers.

Parking
There are 2 designated van-accessible parking spaces with striped access aisles in the paved parking lot.

Surface
The trail surface is paved asphalt or smooth concrete and is typically at least 4 feet wide.

Grade
This trail is estimated to be flat (1% or less).

More Info
Take caution when crossing roadways; designated crosswalks are present. Expect traffic noise on portions of this route.

This trail has little shade, so it is recommended that you wear appropriate sun protection. Picnic tables and benches are available along the route for resting, and public restrooms are available at the trailhead.

name: Round Top, Volcanic and Skyline Loop
description:
Not many Bay Area residents know that they have a volcano nearby but Sibley Volcanic Regional Preserve is home to one! This volcano, Round Top, dates to about 10 million years ago and is the source of all the volcanic rock in the park. The unstaffed visitor center provides a thorough geological history of the park through display panels and specimens.

The trail starts out in a forested understory, then opens into rolling grassland hills, and finally concludes on the shaded Skyline Trail, bringing you back to the staging area. Round Top Trail offers panoramic views of the surrounding hills, valleys, and cities far below. The Volcanic Trail is lined with different types of volcanic rock that help tell the story of the formation of the landscape and how it has changed over time. Pick up a park brochure before you begin your hike to learn more.

Park at the Sibley Staging Area and walk up towards the visitor center. Start on the paved Overlook Trail to the left of the visitor center and continue past the interpretive panels. Go past the trail post to the Backpack Camp, and at the next trail post, make a left and immediately at the next trail post bear left on the Round Top Loop Trail. Follow the directions for Volcanic Trail, staying on the gravel trail and continuing through the gate. In .4 miles, make a left at the fork onto Volcanic Trail. You will immediately pass a lookout bench and trail post #3. At the next fork, make a right on the trail that heads uphill; here there is a trail post marked #5-11. Stay to the left at the next fork and follow the Volcanic Trail until it meets with the paved Quarry Road; turn left onto Quarry Road. Stay on Quarry Road as it descends nearly .6 miles to the gate. Stay left and immediately make another left through another gate to access Skyline Trail. Skyline Trail will take you back to the Sibley Staging Area, climbing somewhat steeply along the creek as you cover .87 miles.

Park Hours: 7am to 6pm Nov-Feb; 7am to 10pm Mar-Oct 
Fees: No fees

name: Lower Meadow Trail to Farm Bypass Loop
park: Rancho San Antonio Open Space Preserve
description:
This picturesque route explores a series of trails in the Rancho San Antonio Open Space Preserve. The terrain is partially paved and primarily gentle, apart from one small hill by the farm. Parts of the trail are nicely shaded through the woods, and others are exposed, offering beautiful views. The trails are used for hiking, running and mountain biking. Watch for wildlife such as deer, ducks, wild turkeys and blue herons. 

Accessibility:  

Equipment  
Visitors using wheelchairs, mobility equipment, or strollers may need all-terrain tires or adaptive/motorized equipment for the surface type and grade.  

Parking  
There are 4 designated van-accessible parking spaces with striped access aisles in the paved parking lot.  

Surface  
The trail surface includes gravel, natural surface (dirt, rocks, roots), or paved asphalt and is typically at least 4 feet wide.  

Grade  
This trail is estimated to be mostly gentle (5% or less), with some steeper sections that may require assistance or need to be avoided.

More Info
The most accessible portion of the route is the northern half of the loop.

name: Indian Joe and Hayfield Road Trails
description: • Parking fee information: There is a fee to park at Sunol Wilderness Regional Preserve on weekends and holidays. For more information, please visit https://www.ebparks.org/parks/sunol

name: El Corte de Madera Creek - Resolution Trail
park: El Corte De Madera Creek Open Space Preserve
description: The trails oscillate up and down a lot. At the base of the Vista Point detour, there is a placard with information about the flight that crashed there in 1953. A beautiful tree-covered hike, a perfect destination for a hot day. Lots of mountain bikers, but the trails are wide enough to give them some space to pass. Keep an eye out for banana slugs along the trail.

name: Mills Canyon Nature Area Trail Loop
description:
A short walking trail, this is most often used by locals, and can offer a nice oasis in the surrounding residential area. A great spot for birds and wildflowers.

Not suitable for strollers or bikes.

name: Skyline and Lonely Loop
park: Purisima Creek Redwoods Open Space Preserve
description: Start at the trailhead for the Purisima Creek Trail, and take caution when crossing Skyline Boulevard to connect with the Skyline Trail heading northwest. The singletrack stays close to the road as it undulates among the towering redwood trees, an understory of ferns, and several creek crossings.

name: Clipper Ridge and French Trail Loop
description: The French Trail Loop and Clipper Ridge feature an initial steep climb. Enjoy breathtaking views of Pillar Point Harbor, Half Moon Bay, and the enormous Pacific Ocean as you ascend. As you continue, you'll encounter steep inclines and more gentle ascents. There is hardly much shade along the trail. The trail continues with sections through weedy pampas grass that you can see growing along the hills. You can come across crows, ravens, and turkey vultures during your hike.

name: Willow Springs Trail to Harvey Bear Trail Loop
park: Coyote Lake Harvey Bear Ranch County Park
description:
• Parking Fee: Coyote Lake Harvey Bear Ranch County Park charges a fee to enter, except at Mendoza Ranch and Harvey Bear Entrances. There are varying fees depending on if you enter by vehicle, motorcycle, foot, horse, or bike. Please visit https://parks.santaclaracounty.gov/locations/coyote-lake-harvey-bear-ranch-county-park

The Willow Springs Trail to Harvey Bear Trail Loop is a 6.5-mile hike located in the beautiful Santa Clara County, California, within the Coyote Valley Open Space Preserve. This trail takes you through rolling hills, open meadows, and oak-studded woodlands, offering stunning views of the surrounding valleys and nearby hills. The terrain is on a gradual inclines for the first half of the trail, but the views get better as you go.  There are lots of cows roaming on this trail, so please keep dogs leashed. 
With its proximity to San Jose and its tranquil setting, the Willow Springs to Harvey Bear Loop is a fantastic choice for those looking for a scenic day hike with varied terrain and panoramic views.

name: PG&E, Wildcat, High Meadow and Lower Meadow Trail Loop
park: Rancho San Antonio Open Space Preserve
description: Coyote to Wildcat Loop (Vista Point) to High Meadow to Lower Meadow to S. Meadow

name: Camden Pond Loop
park: I felt so energized by the peaceful atmosphere that I decided to continue on to Vasona Creek Park
description: Camden Pond, located in Campbell, California, is a little park where people can relax in the city. On this loop trail, you can enjoy a great leisure walk around the ponds and creek. You will see many people who are enjoying biking, running, fishing, and dog walking, too. You will also see some birds, geese, and turtles around the pond. Most parts of the trail is paved.

name: Charleston Slough Trails
description:
This is a popular destination for birdwatchers, families on bikes, and joggers. 

Accessibility: There are at least 5 designated accessible spaces in the paved parking lots off of Farber Place at the northwest end of the trail. All of them are van-accessible with striped access aisles. The trail surface is paved asphalt or gravel. It is typically at least 8 feet wide. There is a painted dividing line along some of the trail which reduces the width.

The most accessible portion of the trail is the paved portion in the first about 2.2 miles. The majority of the trail is estimated to be in the mostly gentle (5% or less) grade category but there is a steeper section at about 9.6 miles  when going counterclockwise. Trail goers using wheelchairs/mobility equipment or strollers may need assistance in the steeper section or to avoid it for safety. All-terrain tires or motorized equipment may be needed for the surface type and grade in the unpaved portions. There are benches along the route for resting.

name: Old Mori Road to Timigtac Trail Loop
description: This loop starts at Old Mori Trail and then follows Lishumsha Trail and Coastal Trail to the point. After this, you will head down to the beach back to Old Mori Trail. The stretch of trail from The Point and then along the Bluff Trail is especially impressive and has outstanding views of the rugged coast.

name: Bay Area Ridge Trail: Skyline and Russian Ridge Open Space Preserves
park: Bay Area Ridge Trail: Skyline and Russian Ridge Open Space Preserve
description:
Enjoy the Peninsula’s finest views and most spectacular spring wildflower displays on these ridgeline trails through Skyline Ridge and Russian Ridge Open Space Preserves. Climb through open grasslands to high knolls with gradual elevation gains and loses. The route has narrow hiking trails and wide ranch roads on duff-covered to gravelly or rocky surfaces. These exposed ridgetops can be foggy and windy; trails on south- and west-facing slopes offer only intermittent shade.

For more information, see the Bay Area Ridge Trail page here: https://ridgetrail.org/skyline-ridge-and-russian-ridge-open-space-preserves/

This trail description is excerpted from the 2019 Guidebook. For details on all of the Bay Area Ridge trails, trailheads and more buy the book from Wilderness Press: https://www.wildernesspress.com/product.php?productid=16685&cat=274&bestseller=Y

Accessibility: Just the loops around Horseshoe Lake and Alpine Pond are considered wheelchair and stroller friendly, not this whole route. Both loops have a dirt/gravel surface and vary from two to five feet wide. The Horseshoe Lake Loop trail can be viewed on its own page here: https://www.alltrails.com/trail/us/california/horseshoe-lake-trail-loop and the Alpine Pond Loop can be viewed here: https://www.alltrails.com/trail/us/california/alpine-pond-trail-loop

name: Western Pacific Trail
description:
• Parking fee information: There is a fee to park at Quarry Lakes Regional Park. Fees are collected on weekends and major holidays from April through October and only at the Redwood Gate entrance. For more information, please visit https://www.ebparks.org/parks/quarry_lakes/

Explore the trail network around Quarry Lakes Regional Park. Enjoy jogging, birding, or fishing around the lakes. There are numerous options and variations of which trail to take.

Accessibility: In the parking lot off of Isherwood Way there are designated accessible parking spaces with one striped access aisle. The trail surface is gravel and typically at least six feet wide. The estimated grade is mostly gentle (all 6% or less). There are benches along the way for resting.

name: Communications Hill Trail
park: HikingDog-friendlyGreat conditionsGreat viewsVery family friendly trail! Easy inclines with beautiful views of the cityPark
description: The Communications Hill Trail is a short urban loop on the outskirts of San Jose. It starts from Cassellino Drive, where street parking and access to the Grand Staircase are available. The trail is short but be prepared for no shade along the way. At the top, you'll enjoy lovely city views, making it a popular spot to catch the sunset. During the spring, you'll also find beautiful wildflowers.

name: Perimeter Loop Hike
description:
• Joseph D Grant County Park collects a day-use fee for vehicular entrance year-round. For more information, please see https://parks.sccgov.org/plan-your-visit/santa-clara-county-park-fees#3925188384-3236192913

This loop hike across parallel ridges of Joseph D. Grant County Park offers sweeping views of the wild, mountainous terrain nearby and occasionally looks out over the southern end of Silicon Valley to the west. 

You'll see the usual Grant County Park attractions -- wildflowers in spring, tarantulas in the fall, raptors and coyotes all year -- while joining the elite few who have  finished one of the Bay Area's most strenuous hikes. 

Best done in winter when the weather's cool but the trails aren't muddy (provided you can hike this many miles before sunset). Next-best time is spring, when the hills are green and the wildflowers are out. It's too hot in summer, and probably not worth risking in fall if you can't carry enough water for the entire day.

This route goes to Antler Point, highest in the park; climbs Washburn trail, steepest in the park; and follows a long stretch of the Bay Area Ridge Trail, which has some of the best views.

name: Old Creek to Western Pacific Trail
High Ridge, Vista Peak, Ziele Creek, and Garin Woods Loop
description:
• Partial closure: Garin Woods and Ziele Creek Trail are temporarily inaccessible due to storm damage, but you can still enjoy other sections of this trail. For more information, please visit https://www.ebparks.org/parks/garin-dry-creek

Though Garin Regional Park is not that far off the beaten path, the contours of its valley and the quality of its scenery makes it feel secluded and wild. Newt Pond Trail in particular is narrow and has heavy vegetation, for which long pants may be necessary. Zielle Creek Trail is shaded by lush oaks and bays, and the creek usually runs well after the rainy season. Although the trail does not pass directly by Garin Peak, you’ll reach elevations high enough to see the bay as well as the Coyote Hills in the distance. 

From the Garin Barn Visitor Center, head straight, following signs for High Ridge Loop Trail. Cross through the cattle gate and take the right-hand path for .48 mile. At the next signpost, make a left and continue for about 100 feet until you come to a sign for Newt Pond Trail. The trail is immediately to your right, and is small enough to look like a cattle trail. Take Newt Pond Trail for .38 mile, then cross the stream and turn right at the fork to head up to Vista Peak Loop. After .25 mile, turn right at the signpost and continue on Vista Peak Loop for .78 mile. Make sure to keep left at the Bailey Ranch Trail signpost to stay on Vista Peak Loop. When you come to the junction with Zeile Creek Trail, turn right. Follow Zeile Creek Trail for .59 mile, then head left at the next fork to take Garin Woods Trail for .23 mile. At the next fork, turn right to follow the lower trail. The lower and upper trails reconnect after .36 mile. Turn left onto Zeile Creek Trail. In .17 mile, turn left on Vista Peak Loop Trail. Stay on this trail, keeping right at the intersection after .44 mile. Head straight at the next intersection, after .80 mile, then turn left onto Old Homestead Trail. After .08 mile, turn right onto Newt Pond Trail, and follow it uphill to High Ridge Loop Trail. Turn right on High Ridge Loop Trail and follow it downhill for about a half mile back to the Garin Barn Visitor Center.

Park Hours: 8am to sunset (varies seasonally)
Fees: $5/vehicle; $2/dog.

name: Artemas Ginzton Path and Byrne Preserve
park: Artemas Ginzton Path and Byrne Preserve
description:
The Artemas Ginzton Path and Byrne Preserve meanders through steep hills and lush greenery. As you traverse the trail, you'll be greeted by beautiful views and frequent wildlife sightings, including coyotes, foxes, and birds. The trail winds through bay and oak woodlands, where you'll notice woodrat nests nestled beneath the trees.

The trail climbs out of a canyon, leading to a grassy hilltop with even more stunning views. As you descend, you'll encounter various flora, including mushrooms and the colorful bay leaves scattered along the trail. One of the trail's highlights is a massive tree perched atop a hill, providing a fantastic panoramic view that stretches to the bay. Be mindful of the poison oak in the area.

name: Adobe Creek Trail to Mayfield Slough
description:
According to Access Northern California (http://accessnca.org/access-northern-california/explore/explore-detail-view/?site_id=178): The Baylands Nature Preserve, said to be the largest salt marsh preserve on the Bay, encompasses nearly 2,000 acres protected for wildlife, including the endangered clapper rail and salt marsh harvest mouse. The preserve contains a duck pond (formerly a saltwater swimming pool); tidal and freshwater marshes; a sailing station for windsurfers and hand-carried, non-motorized boats; and almost 15 miles of trails, all of which have some wheelchair access. Although quite a few of the trails are along roads or in built-up areas, many are close to attractive sloughs where a wide variety of birds can be seen even without binoculars, and some are out in the marshlands, where a flock of sandpipers or a lonely blue heron may be your only company.

Jackrabbits are frequently seen in the restored wildlands above the high-water line, where gray foxes and burrowing owls are said to breed. But within the preserve you'll also find a sewage treatment plant, an airport, and a former landfill for the city of San Francisco, which is now a grassy garbage mountain named the Bixby Art Hill, home to several very understated pieces of public art. Highway 101 is nearby, as is Palo Alto's golf course.

Visitor center: A quarter-mile down the road from the duck pond is the Lucy Evans Baylands Nature Interpretive Center. Inside are displays about the wildlife you might see at the preserve and an ecology laboratory where visitors can prepare their own slides and examine them under microscopes. The microscopes are on a 25-inch-high shelf, but a video microscope that projects slides onto a monitor permits easier viewing. The center also offers videos, nature walks, and a variety of natural history programs for children and adults. On the wooden deck surrounding the nature center, use the low-mounted telescope to zoom in on shorebirds and waterfowl. A long boardwalk extending from the center across Harriet Mundy Marsh may be closed for major renovations. Located at 2775 Embarcadero Road, 650-329-2506.

ACCESSIBILITY: For some reason, Adobe Creek Trail has two branches; this one runs south along Mayfield Slough and Matadero Creek all the way to Highway 101, skirting the garbage mountain and providing a view of more Bixby art. It is fairly wheelchair-accessible, but it's not a very interesting walk unless you want to see the hillside art. The hard, fine gravel is not well spread over the entire distance, although the slope is estimated to be gentle (all 3% or less). Benches are provided frequently along the first half-mile, but they are placed down from the trail by the water and so are difficult for people with mobility disabilities to use.

There is designated accessible parking (van accessible), firm, and level or slope no greater than 2% at the Adobe Creek trailhead, where the one designated space is very likely to be occupied. Each of the several small lots along Embarcadero Rd. also has a van-accessible space, and at the sailing station, a gravel lot has several van-accessible spaces. Wheelchair-accessible restrooms with running water are at the nature center (open only when the center is) and Bixby Art Park parking area; porta-potties are at the duck pond and sailing station. Several accessible picnic tables are by the duck pond; all are near the parking lot on firm grass or dirt, and two have shortened benches to provide integrated seating for at least two wheelchairs each. The Visitor Center is wheelchair-accessible.

name: Mill Valley to Sausalito Path
park: Northwestern Pacific Railroad route from Sausalito to Mill Valley. Along the way it crosses Bothin Marsh Open Space Preserve
description:
According to Access Northern California (http://accessnca.org/access-northern-california/explore/explore-detail-view/?site_id=134): A wide, level asphalt section of the Bay Trail known as the Mill Valley-Sausalito Path, popular with cyclists, runners, and rollerbladers, follows the old Northwestern Pacific Railroad route from Sausalito to Mill Valley. Along the way it crosses Bothin Marsh Open Space Preserve, 112 acres of open space and restored salt marsh with dirt trails that may be accessible during the dry season. The marsh attracts more than 400 species of migratory birds in winter, as well as providing habitat for native birds and other wildlife. By continuing north on the trail, you will reach Bayfront Park in Mill Valley.

If starting from the Pohono Street trailhead by the Shoreline Office Center (wheelchair accessible access point), the trail travels under the Richardson Bay Bridge, then follows the edge of the marsh, crossing four small wooden bridges that rise over creeks and channels. When bicycle traffic is light, these are great places to watch for marine life as the tide surges in or out, but they may be flooded during very high tides, especially after heavy rains. Shorebirds abound and interpretive panels give historical and ecological information about Richardson Bay. On a clear day, Mount Tamalpais looms to the north as you travel this stretch of trail.

About 1.5 miles out, you come to 14-acre Bayfront Park, which surrounds a quiet inlet at the northernmost tip of Richardson Bay. The western side of the park contains an off-leash dog run, sports fields, a skateboard park, and picnic tables. A bridge with a two-inch ledge at both ends leads to the park's eastern side, with a playground, softball field, and more sports fields. From the east-side parking lot, a paved trail leads south a few hundred yards. At the "Public Shoreline" sign, follow the decomposed-granite trail uphill to an overlook with a view of the lagoon below. Steps lead down from the crest of the hill to a 0.25-mile trail that hugs the shoreline, traveling behind a landscaped condominium complex.

ACCESSIBILITY: A portion of this trail is considered wheelchair and stroller friendly - the suggested parking area (Shoreline Office Center) and suggested area to turn around (Bayfront Park) have been marked on the map with waypoints. There is firm, designated, van-accessible parking with a slope of less than 2% at the Shoreline Office Center at the south end of the trail and by Bayfront Park at the north end in the Mill Valley Middle School parking lot or parking lots off of Hamilton Dr.

The trail has a smooth, paved surface and is typically at least six feet wide. It is estimated to be flat, with a grade all 1% or less. The decomposed-granite path on the hill at Bayfront Park may be too steep for manual wheelchairs without assistance. To reach the shoreline trail at the bottom of the hill and avoid the stairs with a wheelchair, you need to backtrack to the shoreline sign and continue on the sidewalk, turning onto Shelter Bay Avenue where it dead-ends at the trail.

There are accessible restrooms at Bayfront Park on the eastern side in the northernmost parking lot off Hamilton Dr. The picnic tables on the western side of Bayfront Park near the dog park are on a firm, level surface but do not have knee clearance, unfortunately.

name: Glen Canyon Park Loop
description: Glen Canyon offers incredible spring wildflower displays, dramatic rock (chert) formations, and Islais Creek, one of the few remaining free-flowing creeks in San Francisco. This 60 acres of wilderness, formerly referred to as the San Miguel Hills, not only provides critical habitat for a wide array of wildlife but serves as a relaxing sanctuary from the city’s urban bustle. An extensive network of hiking trails leads through a variety of habitats.

name: Skyline-Kings Mountain Trail and Teague Hill Loop
description: This is a beautiful route through the woods in the Teague Hill Preserve. The loop begins at Skyline Boulevard and heads west on the Kings Mountain Trail. Be cautious when crossing the road in this section. Almost two miles in, the loop steadily ascends to a high point known as Teague Hill before finishing on the Skyline Trail. The trail can be overgrown in sections with some poison oak throughout, so make sure you come prepared with long pants and proper shoes. You'll have to tackle some steep sections that are shared with bikers, so make sure you stay alert.

name: Alum Rock South Rim Trail
description:
• Parking fee information: There is a fee to park at Alum Rock Park. For more information, please visit https://www.sanjoseca.gov/Home/Components/FacilityDirectory/FacilityDirectory/2088/2028

This is a great hot summer day hike, as this trail provides plenty of shade relief. The trail starts paved, then turns to dirt pack. Coming out of the trail brings you along Alum Rock, and back to the trailhead. Some portions of the trails are shared with both bicycles and equestrians.

Check out the remnants of the Mineral Springs Spa along the way. In the late 1800s through the 1930, the park operated as a health resort that attracted many rich and famous people in search of youth and healing in the hot and cold sulfur, soda and magnesia springs.

name: Don Edwards- Coyote Creek Lagoon Trail
description: Scenic tidal pools and a beautiful cruise along the Coyote Creek Lagoon make this the perfect trail for a ride, run, hike, or birding outing. The flat dirt path winds south along the bay and connects with Fremont blvd to complete a loop, or you can turn around and take the trail back. Because of the abundant wildlife, pets are not allowed.

name: Best trails inSan Jose
park: Senador Mine to Mine Hill Loop4.6(5618)•Hard•22.0 km•Est. 6h 14mThe Senador Mine to Mine Hill Loop in Almaden Quicksilver County Park
description:
Looking for the best walking trails in San Jose? Whether you're getting ready to hike, cycle, trail run, or explore other outdoor pursuits, AllTrails has 122 picturesque trails in the San Jose area. Discover hand-curated trail maps, along with reviews and photos from fellow outdoor enthusiasts.

Explore one of 54 easy walking routes in San Jose, with child-friendly routes for your next family outing. Venture outdoors and learn more about the area's historic sites or take a break from the hustle and bustle along the many tree-lined paths surrounding San Jose. Perfect for little feet, paws, walkers and outdoor enthusiasts of any skill level.

name: Lake Merced Loop
description: A paved loop, this trail is popular with cyclists, dog walkers, and especially joggers. A beautiful walk for a nice day.

name: Hacienda and Mine Hill Loop
description: Almaden Quicksilver County Park includes over 37 miles of hiking trails, including 30 miles of equestrian trails and 16.6 miles of bike trails. All trails in the park are also open to pet owners to walk their dogs on leash. For more information visit: https://www.sccgov.org/sites/parks/parkfinder/pages/almadenpark.aspx

name: Serpentine Trail
description:
This trail takes you to Edgewood Park and Nature Preserve. It’s a pleasant hike through hills and grasslands, which are best for seeing vibrant wildflowers in the springtime. There's little shade, but you'll be rewarded with nice bay views at the top.

Look for deer, rabbits, and other wildlife along the way. The trailhead has two parking lots with restrooms.

name: Golden Gate Park, Lands End and Presidio Loop
description: This trail connects several beautiful parks in northern San Francisco, including Golden Gate Park, Lands End, the Presidio, and Mountain Lake Park. A highlight is the stunning views of the Golden Gate Bridge from various lookouts and coastal sections, as well as access to several beaches. The trail offers a diverse terrain, from pavement to dirt and sand. Be prepared for windy conditions and wear layers, as the weather can change quickly in this area.

name: Bay Area Ridge Trail: Coyote Creek Parkway North
park: Bay Area Ridge Trail: Coyote Creek Park
description:
• Partial closure: The Coyote Creek Trail is closed between Hellyer Park and Embedded Way due to flooding and swiftly moving water, but you can still enjoy other sections of this trail. For more information, please visit https://parks.sccgov.org/closures-updates

Coyote Creek travels 31 miles from the Diablo Range to San Francisco Bay. On this trail segment, follow the creekbed through shady riparian cover, parks, developed areas, and open fields to Metcalf Park’s freshwater lagoons, the habitat for many year-round and migratory bird species. The wide paved trail travels a nearly level course and is an excellent bike ride, popular with families on bicycles, especially on weekends.

Picnic areas and restrooms are located along the way at Stonegate Park, Hellyer County Park, and Metcalf Park.

For more information, see the Bay Area Ridge Trail page here: https://ridgetrail.org/coyote-creek-parkway-north/

Accessibility: There are two designated, accessible parking spaces in the trailhead parking lot off Tully Road, with one striped access aisle. There is additional designated accessible parking at Hellyer County Park, with multiple striped access aisles. 

The trail surface is smoothly paved asphalt (with a painted divider that splits it into two lanes), cement, and wooden bridge, and typically at least six feet wide. In the first 3.3 miles the slope is typically mostly gentle (5% grade or less). However, there are estimated very steep (over 12% or less) up and downhill between about the 1.9 and 2.4 mile marks. Then the grade becomes more gentle (typically 3% or less) past the 2.5 mile mark. The most accessible portion of the trail is from the 3.3 mile mark to the end so equipment users may want to start from the south end.

name: Washington Park Loop
description:
Washington Park is a central hub for outdoor recreation in Alameda. The park has athletic courts, playgrounds, a dog park, and a paved fitness trail popular with walkers and joggers. This route makes a loop around the perimeter of the park and can be linked with other dirt trails that lead to the shores of the San Francisco Bay. 

Accessibility:

Equipment
This trail is likely accessible for visitors using wheelchairs, mobility equipment, or strollers.

Parking
There is at least 1 designated accessible space with striped access aisles in the paved parking lot.

Surface
The trail surface is paved asphalt (with bumps and cracks) and typically at least 6 feet wide. 

Grade
This trail is estimated to be mostly gentle (5% or less).

More Info
Picnic tables and benches are available along the route for resting.

name: Crab Cove Visitor Center to USS Hornet: SF Bay Trail
park: Robert W. Crown Memorial State Beach
description:
Park Features: Bay Area locals and neighborhood friends have long loved the shores of Alameda. This 2.5-mile stretch of shoreline (once known as the “Coney Island of the West”) is commemoratively named for the late Assemblyman Robert W. Crown. Today the shoreline lacks the roller coasters and thrill rides it once had, but the beaches are popular for swimming, board sports, kayaking and more. Private equipment rentals and lessons are available during the summer season. The shoreline is an important habitat for native birds and sea creatures. At low
tide, visitors explore the abundant wildlife that exists below the water’s surface. The Crab Cove Visitor Center offers extensive knowledge about the shoreline to the public and charter groups. Interpretive programs are offered on the weekends, and on weekdays by reservation.

Trail Highlights: This featured route follows the SF Bay Trail to Encinal Beach. From Encinal Beach continue for about a half mile to the USS Hornet Museum, which is open daily for tickets, tours, and a comprehensive history exhibit. The trail is mostly paved (gravel just before Encinal Beach). Parts of this route utilize city streets, so double check your understanding of the route before taking off.

Trail Directions: Portions of this route are on city streets. Turn right on the paved trail at the end of McKay Ave. (in front of large park office building). Follow through a small gate (this gate and the one at Central Avenue remain open from dawn to dusk). Continue for .4 miles, passing by the private residences of Crown Harbor toward Central Avenue. Upon meeting Central Avenue turn left. Follow the sidewalk for .6 miles. After passing in front of Encinal High School, turn left down the road marked SF Bay Trail and Encinal Boat Ramp to Encinal Beach; this is a long, straight stretch to the parking lot – be aware of cars as you head to the shore. After passing though the parking lot, turn right on the SF Bay Trail and continue for about a half mile to the USS Hornet Museum. Explore the exhibit or retrace your steps back to the Crown Cove Visitor Center.

Park Curfew/Hours: 5 a.m. to 10 p.m.
Fees: $5 parking fee (when attended)

name: Rocky Ridge View and Elderberry Loop Trail
description:
Take a stroll around the tall rolling grassy hills east of San Francisco in the Las Trampas Regional Wilderness. You climb almost 1000 feet in the first mile, but then it’s an easy amble along the ridge with stunning views in every direction. 

Wildflower lovers will love the springtime scenery of Las Trampas Regional Wilderness, but when the blooms have faded this East Bay park still has plenty to marvel at. Eagle-eyed hikers in autumn and winter will spot birds of prey amongst the gliding turkey vultures, and there's also the chance of a golden eagle sighting.

name: The Peak via Lake Ranch and John Nicholas Trail
description:
• Fee Information: Sanborn County Park charges a fee to enter. For more information, please https://parks.santaclaracounty.gov/locations/sanborn-county-park

The trailhead has very limited parking and tends to fill up. It is recommended to arrive early or go during the week. This is a popular trail for both hiking and mountain biking. Keep your eyes out for others out there enjoying the trail. Hikers have the right of way but should be aware of mountain bikers riding around blind corners or downhill.

name: Hippie Hill, Conservatory of Flowers, and Blue Heron Lake Loop
description: Academy of Science, Hippie Hill, AIDS Memorial, Conservatory of Flowers, Stow Lake, and Outdoor Music Hall.

name: Elderberry, Rocky Ridge View, Devil’s Hole and Sycamore Trail Loop
description:
Dogs are allowed on the trail however they are NOT allowed in the Devil's Hole.

With a variety of shaded forests, open grassland, rock formations, and a wind cave, this route contains very steep grades throughout and can be very muddy in the rainy season. Be sure to bring the essentials to beat the heat in summer. Equestrians are not permitted on the Sycamore Trail and should not go on Devil’s Hole Trail; try a detour on Cuesta or Rocky Ridge View Trails back to the staging area when you reach this point of the route.

From the staging area on Bollinger Canyon Rd., begin the Elderberry Trail by going through the nearby gate; follow Elderberry Trail and turn right, following uphill at Corral Camp for a steep but pleasant climb through woodland to ridge. Make a sharp right onto Rocky Ridge View Trail and climb about 1/3 mile more to an elevation of 1,893 feet; pay attention to rock formations on the ridge, which contain remnants of prehistoric sea life; look for markers here as you hike along the Alameda and Contra Costa county line. Veer left onto Devil’s Hole Trail and descend 700 feet; look for the wind cave to the left off the trail and enjoy wildflowers in the spring. After the descent but before the creek crossing, look for Sycamore Trail on your right, though the signpost is easy to miss; make the beautiful-yet-strenuous climb on this rocky trail through chaparral and unique rock formations. Make a left on Rocky Ridge View Trail and continue for 0.75 miles; then make a sharp right and continue about 0.8 miles back to the parking lot.

name: Mount Hamilton Ride
description:
• Joseph D Grant County Park collects a day-use fee for vehicular entrance year-round. For more information, please see https://parks.sccgov.org/plan-your-visit/santa-clara-county-park-fees#3925188384-3236192913

Challenging climb to highest peak overlooking Silicon Valley.

Mount Hamilton is a perfect escape from the sprawl of Silicon Valley. The view on the way up is out of this world, which is fitting, because the scientists at the summit spend lifetimes gleaning knowledge from tiny specks of light in the far reaches of space. 

Lick Observatory at the summit (the world's first mountaintop observatory) is a logical goal, but the journey outshines the destination. Though short walks are available at the summit, this is one adventure best experienced on wheels. Whether you drive or ride, it'll be unforgettable.

name: Hacienda, Randol, and Buena Vista Trail Loop
description:
Beautiful trail with lots of trees and views in the middle of an urban area. Bring plenty of water in the summer, as the temperatures can be quite warm. The loop can be hiked in either direction. There are many spots along the way to stop and take a break.

There are a wide variety of wildflowers in the late spring and early summer. Iris, lupine, some Indian paintbrush, and many others.

name: Boronda Lake Loop via the Chamise Trail
description:
• Foothills Nature Preserve charges an entry fee. An annual pass is also available for purchase. Dogs are not allowed on weekends or holidays. For more information, please visit https://www.cityofpaloalto.org/Departments/Community-Services/Open-Space-Parks/Neighborhood-Parks/Foothills-Nature-Preserve



To access this loop, you have many options for starting points within the Foothills Nature Preserve. Park at Vista Hill or at Foothills Park. This trail is mostly paved, flat, and level. It is perfect for a relaxed, low key walk.  This trail can get busy on weekends, and a portion of it is on park roads that are shared with vehicles. Keep an eye out for wildlife in the lake, and explore the island by walking across the boardwalk.

name: Dutch Flat and Dairy Trails
description:
• Joseph D Grant County Park collects a day-use fee for vehicular entrance year-round. For more information, please see https://parks.sccgov.org/plan-your-visit/santa-clara-county-park-fees#3925188384-3236192913

A great loop hike for wildlife and wildflower scouting at the park in the hills east of San Jose.

This hike gives a nice overview of Joseph D. Grant County Park, passing through its distinctive oak-woodland ecosystem but sparing you from the brutal ascents and descents that characterize so many of the hikes in this park.

Grant County Park (often called "Grant Ranch" because the land was once owned by prominent ranchers of the same name) does not have the waterfalls or rock formations that popularize many parks in the Bay Area, but it was vast swaths of open, wild terrain.

The wildness manifests itself in a wonderful wildflower bloom every spring along with a wide range of animals you'll rarely see outside a zoo: coyotes, turkeys, bobcats, tarantulas and the occasional rattlesnake or mountain lion.

Scan the skies for raptors (red-tailed hawks are common; golden eagles fly by, too) and watch for old dead trees where acorn woodpeckers have stowed future meals.

Trails on this hike: Dutch Flat Trail, Dairy Trail, Brush Trail, and San Felipe Trail.

This is also a nice kid-friendly day hike if you're camping at the park.

Spring is naturally the best time to go, followed by fall and winter. Summer's just too hot to enjoy a hike here.

name: Monte Bello, Stevens Creek to Black Mountain
description:
• Short-term closure: Hidden Villa is closed until August 5th, 2025, while summer camps are in session. For more information, please visit https://www.hiddenvilla.org/

This ride from Steven's Creek Reservoir, up Steven's Creek, and to the top of Black Mountain is a 2,000 elevation gain in 13 miles.  Not easy, but the ride down is fun.  Most the the trail is moderate, but some areas are steep and challenging.

name: Little Yosemite via Canyon View Trail
description:
• Parking fee information: There is a fee to park at Sunol Wilderness Regional Preserve on weekends and holidays. For more information, please visit https://www.ebparks.org/parks/sunol

This trail starts at the parking lot off Geary Road, where the visitor center and restrooms are available, and winds through Sunol Wilderness Regional Preserve to Alameda Creek Overlook, formerly known as Little Yosemite. At the end of this trail, you will reach Alameda Creek, which has little waterfalls.

name: San Bruno Mountain Bog Trail
description:
• San Bruno Mountain State Park charges a fee to enter. Fees are per vehicle. This park does not accept the California State Park Annual Day Use Pass. For more information, please visit https://parks.smcgov.org/fees-charges#vehicle.

Parking fee $6. Entry fee waivers may be available - please check with the park's website.

The Bog Trail in San Bruno Mountain State and County Park is loop trail that connects back at the trail head. The trail is a dirt trail with some sections with gravel. There are several benches to sit and enjoy some quite time. The trail has two small wooden bridges over Colma Creek. Mixture of shady and sunny sections.

name: Ridge, Coyote Peak and Hidden Springs Trail Loop
description:
• Fee Information: Santa Teresa County Park charges a fee to enter. For more information, please visit https://parks.sccgov.org/plan-your-visit/santa-clara-county-park-fees#3925188384-3236192913

This route combines a series of trails within Santa Teresa County Park. It's a good option if you're short on time, and it is even more beautiful at sunset. The terrain features a decent amount of elevation changes with many rolling hills.

Along the way, there is a good mix of sun and shade and some incredible views of the valley. Parts of the trail are rocky, and others can become muddy after rain, so wear proper hiking shoes. Watch for wildlife such as turkeys, quail, pigs, deer, and coyotes.

name: San Andreas Trail to Peterson Memorial Trail
description:
• Fee Information: Sanborn County Park charges a fee to enter. For more information, please https://parks.santaclaracounty.gov/locations/sanborn-county-park

This is a popular trail that is mostly shaded with beautiful views. The trail is popular among both hikers and trail runners. This trail is very steep, so bring plenty of water, and maybe some trekking poles. This is a great workout or training hike. The loop can be hiked in either direction. Bug spray is recommended in the early summer.

name: Dutch Flat Trail to San Felipe Trail Loop
description: • Joseph D Grant County Park collects a day-use fee for vehicular entrance year-round. For more information, please see https://parks.sccgov.org/plan-your-visit/santa-clara-county-park-fees#3925188384-3236192913

name: Mayfair Ranch Trail to Serpentine Loop Trail
park: Rancho Cañada Del Oro Open Space Preserve
description:
Steep trails lead to excellent vistas at Rancho Canada del Oro Open Space Preserve, which covers a swath of the rugged foothills of the Santa Cruz Mountains. 

The high ridges look out over much of Silicon Valley; on clear days you can see the white domes of the telescopes atop Mount Hamilton. It's difficult to imagine such rough country so close to civilization till you actually get out there. 

Rancho Canada del Oro Open Space Preserve borders nearby Calero County Park, opening broad opportunities for all-day hikes. 

This hike is more of a half-day outing covering the main trails at Rancho Canada del Oro. It has two significant climbs on the first half of the loop and is all downhill on the second half. You'll get a good workout.

Spring wildflower season is the best time to visit when the hills are still vivid green. Winter hikes after a storm system washes away the smog can be spectacular (though potentially muddy). Autumn will be dry but temperate. summer will be too hot, typically.

name: Twin Peaks: Eureka Peak and Noe Peak
description:
• Partial closure: Parts of the Twin Peaks Trail are subject to closure due to construction projects, but you can still enjoy other sections of this trail. For more information, please visit https://sfrecpark.org/634/Twin-Peaks-Trails-Improvement-Promenade-

A very short hike to the tops of Twin Peaks. Spectacular views to the city and the bay. The best view is about halfway up the road, but the whole park is small enough to provided gorgeous views from all areas. Not too much traffic on the actual peaks. Everyone seems to stick to the concrete viewing areas. San Francisco, looks gorgeous in the sunlight.

name: Los Trancos, Trappers Fire Road, and Steep Hollow Loop
description:
• Foothills Nature Preserve charges an entry fee. An annual pass is also available for purchase. Dogs are not allowed on weekends or holidays. For more information, please visit https://www.cityofpaloalto.org/Departments/Community-Services/Open-Space-Parks/Neighborhood-Parks/Foothills-Nature-Preserve



This trail begins with a steady climb to the top of the hills within Foothills Nature Preserve. The trail is a mix of shady, forested areas and open areas with nice views. In the late spring and early summer, there are beautiful wildflowers throughout. The trail is well-signed and well-maintained. The loop can be hiked in either direction.

name: Penitencia Creek Park Loop
Golden Eagle, Deer Gulch, Cliff Trail
description:
Trail Highlights: This route is an out and back with lots of steep up and down. With nearly a thousand feet of elevation gain and loss, the trail drops down to the edge of the city at the foot of the hills. Up high, the plateau offers spectacular views of
the surrounding region. The terrain is mostly open and exposed.

Park Features: Vargas Plateau towers over a thousand feet above the bay and distant cities below. You may see hawks and golden eagles soaring overhead, and perhaps deer or a bobcat in the hills. There is a restroom at the staging area, along with two accessible parking spaces. Bring plenty of water as it is not always available.

Trail Directions: From the staging area, begin on the Golden Eagle Trail. In about three-quarters of a mile, turn left onto Deer Gulch Trail. At the next intersection, continue straight onto the Cliff Trail. Follow this trail to the bottom of the park until you reach the gate. Retrace your steps back up to the staging area. Please note: as an alternate return route, you may choose to turn left and head uphill on
Morrison Canyon Rd. It is closed to vehicle traffic and also leads to the staging area.

name: Guadalupe Creek Trail
description:
This is a scenic walk along the Guadalupe River Trail, a paved path along the Los Capitancillos Ponds. Chris Hotts Park has a few parking spaces, and the route leads to the south side of the ponds. The path to the north is private; please stay on public trails. Bring plenty of water and sun protection and keep an eye out for the waterfowl that thrive along the ponds.

Accessibility:

Equipment
This trail is likely accessible for visitors using wheelchairs, mobility equipment, or strollers.

Parking
There do not appear to be any designated accessible parking spaces near the trailhead, but some may be available in commercial lots nearby.

Surface
The trail surface is paved asphalt and is typically at least 12 feet wide.

Grade
This trail is estimated to be flat (1% or less).

name: Crystal Springs, Summit, Chinquapin and Dean Loop
description:
• General fee: Huddart County Park charges a fee to enter. For more information, please visit https://www.smcgov.org/parks/huddart-park

This is a peaceful and perfectly lit trail at most times of the year. This trail has quite a good amount of incline, and visitors should know that there is not a viewpoint at the top. There is a nice grade, great trail markings, and smooth trail with minimal obstructions. There are plenty of birds and Redwood trees to enjoy.

name: Mount Umunhum via Alamaden Quicksilver County Park
park: Mount Umunhum via Alamaden Quicksilver County Park
description: This is a point to point trail ending at Mount Umunhum. You will need to be picked up at the top. The trail winds through a mix of historical mining remnants, lush forests, and open grasslands, providing a diverse hiking experience. As you ascend, you’ll encounter various scenic overlooks, making it a great spot for photography and wildlife observation.

name: Roberts Ridge and Graham Trail Loop
description: The Roberts Ridge and Graham Trail Loop take you through the redwood grove. As you meander through the towering redwoods, the serene beauty of the forest surrounds you. As the trail climbs uphill, you'll be rewarded with expansive views of the surrounding hills. Notable sights include Mount Diablo, the ridges of Las Trampas, Pleasanton Ridge, and Mount Rose. A well-placed bench along the Graham Trail offers a perfect spot to rest.

name: Turtle Rock via Saratoga Gap Trail
description: Starting from Congress Springs Rd, this route takes you along Saratoga Gap Trail, which has a nice mix of terrain: mostly wooded and some exposed sections with nice elevation changes. This route takes you to Turtle Rock, where you will be rewarded with stunning sweeping views of the area. The trail can be overgrown in some areas, so wearing long pants is recommended.

name: Lake Ranch Trail to John Nicholas Trail
description:
• Fee Information: Sanborn County Park charges a fee to enter. For more information, please https://parks.santaclaracounty.gov/locations/sanborn-county-park

This is a fairly easy out and back trail from Black Road  to Sanborn Road and back. There are a few sections of uphill, but the remainder of the hike is 99% flat with minor inclines along the way. Perfect hike for the kids, with moderate traffic along the way. Quite a few bikers, but the trail itself is more like a fire road as it's very wide and there is lots of room.

name: Golden Eagle Trail to Upper Ranch Trail
description:
This hike begins with tremendous views from the tops of the East Bay hills, overlooking Fremont, Union City, Newark, and the San Francisco Bay beyond. To the southeast are views of Mission Peak. As you traverse the northeast part of the park, the Upper Ranch Trail offers views of the steep canyon below including Niles Canyon and Highway 84. You will notice from the trail posts you will be following part of the Bay Area Ridge Trail. Vargas Plateau is an open range park so be watchful for roaming cows. Parking and rest rooms available at the Vargas Plateau Staging Area.

Park at the Vargas Plateau Staging Area, and follow the trail past the restrooms, continuing through the gate. Keep going straight onto Golden Eagle Trail, past the next trail post. Golden Eagle Trail will contour around the hill and continue through another gate. At the second trail, pass through the gate to follow the Upper Ranch Trail. As you continue, the Park Residence will be to your right. At the next trail post, stay to the right to continue on the Upper Ranch Trail. The next mile and half loop will descend towards the canyon before climbing back uphill along the Bay Area Ridge Trail and reconnecting with the Golden Eagle Trail.
