Retrace your steps, turning right onto Golden Eagle Trail and follow it back to the staging area.

name: Antler Point from Twin Gates
description:
• Joseph D Grant County Park collects a day-use fee for vehicular entrance year-round. For more information, please see https://parks.sccgov.org/plan-your-visit/santa-clara-county-park-fees#3925188384-3236192913

If you like sweeping vistas and wildflowers, this is a hike you should consider.  At ten miles, its relatively lengthy, but starting at Twin Gates eliminates some of the elevation gain and makes it a little easier in that regard.
 
The Canada de Pala trail goes up from the parking lot, past the upper end of the Yerba Buena trail and crests at a place with a large fallen oak; a very nice place to stop and take in the view. A tall remnant of the long dead tree juts like a tooth at the crest of the hill.  On a clear day you can see the bay as far north as the Dunbarton, and even on a foggy day the observatory looms above you from the peak of Mount Hamilton to the Southeast.

The trail then dips down and crests again, just a little higher before it drops down and passes the upper ends of the Los Huecos and Halls Valley trails.  In the springtime this trail is littered with a fantastic variety of flowers, but even in the winter, with a brisk wind clearing out the smog at the southern end of the San Francisco Bay, the views are awesome.
 
Antler Point,  is at the end of a 0.3 mile single track that cuts off of the main trail.  The view is fantastic on a clear day down in the bay area.
 
There's another beautiful overlook up there but it looks down into the Smith Creek canyon.

name: Wilder Ridge Trail
description:
• Parking fee information: There is a fee to park at Wilder Ranch State Park. For more information, please visit https://www.parks.ca.gov/?page_id=549

The Wilder Ridge Trail is known for its diverse wildlife, and it's not uncommon to spot deer, foxes, rabbits, and a variety of bird species, including hawks and California quails. The area is also home to a rich array of plants and flowers, adding to the beauty of the trail throughout the seasons. The coastal breeze adds an element of freshness and helps keep the hike comfortable even on warmer days.

name: Sunol Wilderness to Mission Peak
description:
• Parking fee information: There is a fee to park at Sunol Wilderness Regional Preserve on weekends and holidays. For more information, please visit https://www.ebparks.org/parks/sunol

The start of the trail is across from the Visitor Center (not behind it).

This back-door route to Mission Peak is a wilder, quieter alternative to more popular trails.

This is one of the longest approaches to the Mission Peak summit and arguably the best. It follows the Ohlone Wilderness Trail westward to the popular East Bay peak. 

Stretching the ascent to the peak across five miles, the route climbs through oak woodland on a peaceful, little-used stretch of up the Ohlone Wilderness Trail. You'll pass the remains of a settler's cabin and see expansive vistas looking out over the Diablo Range. Sightings of deer, coyotes, vultures, and raptors are common.

Hiking the Ohlone Trail requires a permit/map ($2, available from the Sunol headquarters). Start at Mile 12, and sign the trail register at the trail board near the corral across the road from the park HQ. 

The trail climbs steeply out of Sunol Wilderness, crosses Calaveras Road and continues toward the peak; at the last approach to the summit, the trail takes a Y, where you can go left or right; left is a bit shorter, and offers a chance to rest at the Eagle Spring campsite. 

The best time to go is springtime when the hills are green and the wildflowers are blooming. Winter's the next-best time, especially if the peak gets a dusting of snow. Fall is OK; summer's too hot during the day, though you might beat the heat with a very early morning start.

name: Alpine Pond Loop
description:
This is a beautiful short hike with great views of a little pond and a nature center.

Accessibility: The trail surface is packed dirt or gravel (with wooden bridges) and typically at least 3 feet wide. The slope is estimated to be mostly gentle (all 5% grade or less) uphill and down. There is a wheelchair-accessible pit toilet and a wheelchair-accessible viewing platform. There is at least 1 designated wheelchair-accessible car parking spot without a striped access aisle at the small packed gravel trailhead lot at the north end.

name: Quail Red Hill Bayview Loop
description:
• Parking fee information: There is a fee to park at Coyote Hills Regional Park. For more information, please visit https://www.ebparks.org/parks/coyote-hills

This trail features picturesque views of the San Francisco Bay, marshes, and the surrounding hills. The trail surface is a mix of paved asphalt and natural dirt. The gradient is mostly gentle, with some steeper sections along the way. Wildlife in the area includes waterfowl, birds of prey, and jackrabbits. 

Throughout the journey, there are also public art installations and scenic spots. Carry water and wear sun protection because this trail has little to no shade.

name: Skyline Trail
description:
• Fee Information: Sanborn County Park charges a fee to enter. For more information, please https://parks.santaclaracounty.gov/locations/sanborn-county-park

There is limited parking at the trailhead, so an early start is recommended. The trailhead also serves as the trailhead for climbers accessing Castle Rock. This section of the Skyline Trail travels between Indian Rock Parking Area and the Sunnyvale Mountain Trailhead. The trail travels through the woods and is well maintained.

name: Quail and Bayview Loop
description:
• Parking fee information: There is a fee to park at Coyote Hills Regional Park. For more information, please visit https://www.ebparks.org/parks/coyote-hills

Trail Highlights: This hike takes you past the Dairy Glen group camping area and out around the base of the hills to provide excellent views of the bay and the multicolored salt evaporation ponds. Seagulls wheel high above you as you are buffeted by the cool bay air. If you are lucky, you may catch a glimpse of a bald eagle amongst the seagulls, shorebirds, and redwing blackbirds that call the park their home. The trail is mostly flat, and much of it is paved, making it a good choice for runners and walkers alike. 

Trail Directions: Starting from the far end of the Visitor Center parking lot, find Quail Trail heading to the south and gently uphill. Follow Quail Trail for .15 miles until you reach the intersection with the Bay View Trail. Make a right on Bay View Trail. After .24 miles, the trail forks; follow the paved trail to your right, following signs for Bay View Trail. After .07 miles, keep straight. Follow the paved Bay View Trail along the shore for about 1.5 miles, then continue as the trail heads inward for another .8 miles back to the Visitor Center.

Park Hours: Nov-Apr 8am – 5pm; May 8am – 7pm; Jun-Aug 8am – 8pm; Sept 8am – 7pm; Oct 8am – 6pm

Fees: $5/vehicle; $2/dog 

Dogs must be leashed and under control at all times.

Accessibility: The most accessible portion of the trail is the Bayview and Nike Loop trail. Visitors using wheelchairs, mobility equipment, or strollers may need all-terrain tires or adaptive/motorized equipment for the surface type and grade. There are 5 designated van-accessible parking spaces with striped access aisles in the paved parking lot. The trail surface is paved asphalt or natural (dirt), typically at least 6 feet wide. This trail is estimated to be mostly gentle (5% or less), with some steeper sections along the way that may require assistance or need to be avoided.

name: Edgewood, Serpentine, Franciscan and Baywood Glen Trail Loop
description:
The Edgewood, Serpentine, Franciscan, and Baywood Glen Trail Loop in Edgewood Park and Nature Preserve, between San Jose and San Francisco, is a well-maintained and signposted trail. There's little shade, but you'll get nice bay views at the top.

The landscape is beautiful, but it gets muddy after rain, so aim for a dry day. Parking is limited, so plan ahead.

name: Bear Gulch and Alambique Trail Loop
description:
Towering redwoods and eye-opening vistas make this hike a great escape from Silicon Valley. This hike at Wunderlich County Park takes you through some of the most common ecosystems in the South Bay: second-growth redwood, oak, madrone, and open meadows. The park, just outside of Woodside on the west side of Silicon Valley, draws crowds on the weekends, and it can be hard to find a parking spot. If possible, it's recommended to try and come mid-week when you'll have the trails mostly to yourself.

The redwood forest deepens the further you hike in. At one point this whole hillside was logged, but now a new redwood forest is reclaiming the land. It's a great place to experience nature's regenerative powers first-hand. Trails on this track: Bear Gulch Trail, Skyline Trail, and Alambique Trail.

Wunderlich is on a hillside at the foot of the Santa Cruz Mountains; you start at the bottom so it's pretty much uphill for most of the first half, but it's downhill for the rest.

Also, the Redwood Trail is a pretty side trip, and The Meadows is an excellent open area for taking a snack break.

The best time to come is springtime because it will be a bit more scenic as the wildflowers bloom. The deepest redwood section offers a cool break from the summer heat. The redwood canopy even offers some protection on a rainy hike.

name: Maisie's Peak and Nob Hill Extended Loop
description: This loop has great views from Hunter's Point and Maisie's Peak and also tags the top of Nob Hill. The trail travels over rolling terrain and is mostly through open, sunny areas. Be sure to bring plenty of water. Keep an eye out for poison oak growing alongside the trail. The parking area is small, so getting an early start is recommended on the weekend.

name: Golden Gate Bridge Bicycle Ride
park:
Length556mElevation gainLoopThis cycling loop is typically windy and steep but offers great views of the Golden Gate Bridge and other iconic sights of the Bay Area. This classic Bay Area bike trip feels like a rollercoaster as you climb to the top of the headlands then ride down some of the extremely steep hills on this trip. 

Park
description:
This cycling loop is typically windy and steep but offers great views of the Golden Gate Bridge and other iconic sights of the Bay Area. This classic Bay Area bike trip feels like a rollercoaster as you climb to the top of the headlands then ride down some of the extremely steep hills on this trip. 

Park on the north end of the Golden Gate Bridge, then ride to the south end and back. Then, a loop over the top to Bonita Point and back up the valley, through the tunnel, and back to the parking area.

name: Twin Peaks and Mount Sutro Loop
description:
• Partial Closure: Part of this route along the North Ridge Trail is temporarily inaccessible, but you can still enjoy other sections of this trail. For more information, please visit https://www.ucsf.edu/about/locations/mount-sutro-open-space-reserve
• Partial closure: Parts of the Twin Peaks Trail are subject to closure due to construction projects, but you can still enjoy other sections of this trail. For more information, please visit https://sfrecpark.org/634/Twin-Peaks-Trails-Improvement-Promenade-

This trail is a must-visit for both visitors and locals in San Francisco. It begins at the iconic Twin Peaks, where you'll enjoy breathtaking views of the city and the bay.

From there, the trail winds its way to the Mount Sutro Open Space Reserve. This greenbelt, complete with a native garden, offers a refreshing escape from the city's hustle and bustle. Parking and restrooms are available right at the trailhead.

name: Senador Mine, Mine Hill, and New Almaden Loop
description: This is a short hike through shady old oaks, beautiful madrones, grassy hillsides, and flat plateaus. There is a wide variety of wildflowers to be seen along the route.

name: Marilyn Kane Trail to Amador Valley Community Park
park: Marilyn Kane Trail to Amador Valley Community Park
description:
This is a gentle, paved trail that is family-friendly. It explores both the beautiful natural areas of Pleasanton, as well as downtown Pleasanton. The Marilyn Murphy Kane trail has beautiful sunsets and is full of wildlife. You can stop to try out some of the amazing restaurants in downtown Pleasanton. If you would like a loop, you can shorten the walk by going turning left onto Bernal Avenue, instead of going right. 

Accessibility: 

Equipment
This trail is likely accessible for visitors using wheelchairs, mobility equipment, or strollers.

Parking
There is 1 designated van-accessible space with a striped access aisle in the paved parking lot off West Lagoon Road at the trail's west end. There are additional designated accessible parking spaces at the Bernal Community Park about halfway through the route.

Surface
The trail surface is cement or asphalt, smooth, and ranges from 3 to over 10 feet wide.

Grade
This trail is estimated to be mostly gentle (5% or less).

More Info
Benches are available along the route for resting.

name: Fifield Cahill Ridge Trail
description:
• Access Information: This area is only accessible during a
docent-led outing. For more information please visit: https://webapps.sfpuc.org/trails

Reservations are required to access this trail. Trained volunteers head excursions three days a week. For more information visit: http://sfwater.org/index.aspx?page=147

Local nature lovers can enjoy the rare opportunity to hike, bike, or ride their horses through pristine stands of old-growth Douglas Fir, evergreen and fragrant coastal scrub while enjoying ridge-top vistas of our watershed lands, reservoirs, the Pacific Ocean and San Francisco Bay. Small groups of hikers, bicyclists, or equestrians can now make reservations for guided excursions along the Fifield-Cahill Ridge Trail. 

Because of environmental restrictions within the fragile ecosystem, groups must be accompanied by a volunteer trail leader and are limited to approximately 20 people (fewer on horseback), scheduled no more than three times a day on Wednesdays, Saturdays, and Sundays. You can reserve spaces for as many as five people for any one event. Sign up for an event using the online reservation system.

name: Herb Grench Trail
description: Try this 0.9-mile out-and-back trail near Portola Valley, California. Generally considered an easy route, it takes an average of 23 min to complete. This is a very popular area for birding, hiking, and walking, so you'll likely encounter other people while exploring. The trail is open year-round and is beautiful to visit anytime. Dogs are welcome, but must be on a leash.

name: Nibbs Knob, Waterfall Loop, Contour Trail and Triple Falls
description:
• All day use requires a reservation. Please go to www.gooutsideandplay.org​ or call 408-355-2201 to make your reservation.​ There is also a fee to park. 

This route follows beautiful forested paths through Uvas Canyon County Park. The first point of interest is Nibbs Knob, where you will have incredible views rewarding the only climb on this route. After descending, you will wind through the Waterfall and Contour Trails to a beautiful bench with a view and finally Triple Falls. This area is remote, yet very accessible, making it feel as if you are somewhere far away.

name: Dawson Path
description: The Dawson Path is a partially paved trail that passes through the Juan Prado Mesa Preserve along Hale Creek. There are two entrance points and this route begins in the east on Dawson Drive. Follow the creek through the forest and a neighborhood before it ends on Stonebrook Drive. Neither end of the trail has formal parking or street parking.

name: Jones Trail
park: St. Joseph'S Hill Open Space Preserve
description:
This trail takes you from the end of Jones Road to Lexington Reservoir with the James J. Lenihan Dam. The trail is half-shaded and half-exposed, with some steep, rocky sections. During the spring, you'll find beautiful wildflowers along the way.

Bring bug spray to protect against mosquitoes. The parking area at the trailhead is limited, so it's recommended that you arrive early.

name: Hamms Gulch, Eagle Trail, and Lost Trail Loop
description:
Dogs are not allowed on Lost Trail or Razorback Trail within Windy Hill Open Space. (Dogs are allowed on the portion of Lost Trail between the Hamms Gulch Trail and the Anniversary Trail).

A nice quick escape for Peninsula hikers in need of a fix and a good workout. You still get great scenery, a bit of wildlife, moody weather, and more. You will hear some road noise once you are near Skyline.

name: Ridge Trail and Quarry Road Loop
description:
• San Bruno Mountain State Park charges a fee to enter. Fees are per vehicle. This park does not accept the California State Park Annual Day Use Pass. For more information, please visit https://parks.smcgov.org/fees-charges#vehicle.

San Bruno Mountain State Park is composed of rugged mountains, golden meadow hilltops, and sparse oak forests. Starting from Quarry Road Trail, climb steeply for almost a mile to the ridge. Head east, enjoying panoramic views of San Francisco, before taking a steep downhill to a lower trail to loop back. Some of these routes are on informal trails; download the map to help guide you.

name: Peterson Memorial Trail and Sanborn Trail
description:
• Fee Information: Sanborn County Park charges a fee to enter. For more information, please https://parks.santaclaracounty.gov/locations/sanborn-county-park

There is a fee required to access this trailhead.

name: Sequoia Trail
description:
• Parking fee information: There is a fee to park at Big Basin Redwoods State Park. For more information, please visit https://www.parks.ca.gov/?page_id=540
• CZU Lightning Complex Fire : Public access to Big Basin has been severely impacted by the 2020 CZU Lightning Complex Fire and ongoing fire recovery work, but the park is open for limited day-use access. There is currently no access to waterfalls, all camping is closed and skyline to sea trail is open to the north but access to south (towards the ocean) is closed

The Sequoia Trail is an amazing example of nature in the Big Basin Redwoods State Park, and is perfect as a beginner level day hike for any user. Since the length and elevation gain are moderately easy, this is a great option for building endurance on the journey to completing more challenging hikes. This trail is flat pretty much the whole time except at Slippery Rock which offers a short but steep incline, which is also a culturally significant location with very flat rock that indigenous people used as a mortar and pestle!

Close to the waterfall, you can use stairs to get to a nice viewpoint and get closer vantages for great photos and a mist experience. From here, you can also view the Opal Mineral Pool below, which is iconic and a sight to behold. From this location, the trail can be treated as either an out-and-back by simply returning, or continuing along the AllTrails verified route loop. As the trail continued higher, the gorgeous Sequoia trees provided shade for most of the way, and the trail can at times be slippery in spring and fall when intense rain can occur. While there may not be panoramic views like more challenging hikes would offer, this trail is unique in the access to natural landscapes. 

Parking can be difficult to find during the summer or nicer spring and fall weekends, and you should be prepared to wait in line when paying if busy. If additional parking is required, there is more available further down the road at other parking lots. It is also recommended to bring bug spray in the spring and early summer, since the further into this hike, the more bug bites that will happen.

name: Bay Area Ridge Trail: Santa Teresa and Calero/Los Alamitos Creek
description:
• Fee Information: Santa Teresa County Park charges a fee to enter. For more information, please visit https://parks.sccgov.org/plan-your-visit/santa-clara-county-park-fees#3925188384-3236192913

The Ridge Trail route branches east and west through Santa Teresa County Park. Take the trail east through high, oak-studded grasslands up to Coyote Peak. Then head back west on well-graded, exposed paths, past spring wildflower displays, serpentine outcrops, and Coast Range views. Listen to the sound of running water on the tree-lined Calero Creek Trail, and continue on the wide, paved, partially shaded Los Alamitos Creek Trail. Follow McKean Road and Mockingbird Hill Lane to continue on to Almaden Quicksilver County Park. Note: The trail through Santa Teresa County Park is exposed and can be hot in summer and early fall.

For more information, see the Bay Area Ridge Trail page here:
https://ridgetrail.org/santa-teresa-county-park-and-los-alamitos-calero-creek-trail

This trail description is excerpted from the 2019 Guidebook. For details on all of the Bay Area Ridge trails, trailheads and more buy the book from Wilderness Press: https://www.wildernesspress.com/product.php?productid=16685&cat=274&bestseller=Y

Accessibility: Only the last 3.4 miles along the Los Alamitos and Calero Creek Trails are considered wheelchair and stroller friendly as the estimated grade is gentle there (3% or less). Before that, the grade increases and the very steep (over 12% grade) sections may not be traversable for equipment users without assistance or motorized equipment. The trail surface is paved with asphalt until it crosses Harry Road (1.5 miles in), where it turns to dirt. It is typically at least five feet wide.

Designated accessible parking doesn't appear to be available for this trail.

name: Bay View and Lagoon Loop
description:
This trail starts at the Harbor Bay Landing parking lot and travels along the water's edge, passing through residential areas and Shoreline Park and offering scenic views of both San Francisco and San Leandro bays. Take care when crossing the road at Robert Davey Junior Dr.

Accessibility: This trail is likely accessible for visitors using wheelchairs, mobility equipment, or strollers. There are at least 6 designated van-accessible parking spaces with striped access aisles in the paved parking lot of Leydecker Park and several more near the trailhead. The trail surface is paved asphalt, concrete, or packed dirt, typically at least 6 feet wide. This trail is estimated to be flat (1% or less). Some visitors have noted bumpy areas at the shoreline, which may require assistance, all-terrain tires, or adaptive/motorized equipment.

name: Bay Trail: Alviso to Newark
park: Alviso is part of the city of San Jose. The Santa Clara County Park
description:
• Partial closure: Part of the Alviso Slough Trail is temporarily inaccessible, but you can still enjoy other sections of this trail. For more information, please visit https://parks.sccgov.org/sites/g/files/exjcpb961/files/documents/ShorelineProject2024Updates.pdf

This is a segment of the San Francisco Bay Trail: a 500 mile long mile trail around the Bay. This is the 7th section of the Bay Trail, taking hikers from Alviso to Newark.

A historic waterfront town at the bay's southernmost extremity, Alviso is part of the city of San Jose. The Santa Clara County Parks and Recreation Department has restored the former marina to wetlands, in addition to improving trails and constructing a boat launch at Alviso Slough. Alviso Marina County Park features a 9-mile dry season loop trail extending around the former marina. The trail offers views of wetlands, brackish and freshwater marshes, as well as salt ponds undergoing restoration as part of the South Bay Salt Pond Restoration Project. 

Visit the Environmental Education Center off of Grand Boulevard to view interpretive displays about the wetland wildlife and enjoy a walk or ride along a 4.5-mile loop trail encircling a restored salt pond. A path along Highway 237 provides access to the Coyote Creek Trail in Milpitas. This 2-mile trail follows the edge of the creek to Dixon Landing Road where the trail continues north along Fremont Boulevard, and then turns left onto a gravel levee trail that runs along the edge of the refuge wetlands. 

Bike lanes and sidewalks on Boyce, Cherry and Thornton streets lead through Fremont into Newark to the Don Edwards San Francisco Bay National Wildlife Refuge Visitor Center. Newark Slough curves around wetlands and meanders through the refuge's reclaimed salt ponds until it reaches the bay. The 1.3-mile Tidelands Loop Trail winds through uplands covered with sweet-smelling sagebrush, which offers habitat for sparrows, ground squirrels, cottontail rabbits, and gray foxes. The Newark Slough Trail branches off the Tidelands Loop Trail and reaches closer to the bay, circling around salt ponds for some 5 miles. Marshlands Road takes you to the Dumbarton Bridge pathway. To reach Ardenwood Historic Farm, follow bike lanes on Jarvis Avenue.

name: El Corte Madera Creek Trail and Tafoni Trail Loop
park: El Corte De Madera Creek Open Space Preserve
description:
This is a beautiful trail for a hot day, shaded the entire way by towering redwoods. The path itself is clearly visible and quite rocky in some parts along the Resolution Trail. There are several trails in the area that can be used to adjust the length of your adventure if you're short on time. 

This trail is shared by hikers and bikers, so take care and stay alert. There's a steady downhill at the start, and then it's mostly uphill for the second half of the trail.

name: Stream, Mill and French Loop
description: You will find great views and beautiful trees on this hike outside Oakland. This trail will make you forget how close you are to the city! Many of the trail junctions are not marked, so downloading the map ahead of time to navigate is suggested. This trail is pretty popular and parking can be a challenge on a weekend. Bring hiking boots or shoes that can get muddy if you go during the rainy season.

name: Montgomery Hill Trail
description: Montgomery Hill Trail travels east-west through a natural grassland and oak tree environment. The gravel trail follows Evergreen Creek to the north perimeter of Montgomery Hill Park and ends at Yerba Buena Road. The creek fosters a healthy waterfowl habitat, and several connecting trails allow for various route options.

name: San Francisco Crosstown Trail
description:
San Francisco's Crosstown Trail is a mixture of hiking trails, various parks, hidden paths, and more! For those looking to check out San Francisco, this trail is right for you. The crosstown trail literally takes you across San Francisco allowing hikers or bikers to see what SF has to offer! (Note that the bike trails are a bit different from the hiking trail.)

The trail begins at Candlestick Point and ends at Lands End. As you follow the trek across San Francisco, check out the different sights this trail has to offer (such as the beautiful Moraga Steps, which is also listed in AllTrails). Hikers will be able to walk past different gardens, coffee shops, bookstores and more! Thirsty? Stop by one of San Francisco's local coffee shops for some good old joe (and maybe a pastry or two)!

At the end of the trail, hikers can grab dinner at Lands End. Users have reported that this trail takes most of the day if starting early. That being said you may be able to catch the sunset at Lands End! Looking to hike some more? Check out the Lands End Trail, another fun San Francisco hike!

Hikers can also opt out of hiking the whole trail as this trail is also connected by public transportation systems.

name: Shoreline Park Loop
description: Shoreline Park has a small strip of land with a few trails weaving throughout, wedged between a pond and the San Francisco Bay. The north side of this route is a section of the San Francisco Bay Trail. The area is a popular place for walking, jogging, and casual biking. There are panoramic views of the bay, but little shade;bring plenty of water.

name: Lake Cunningham
description: Lake Cunningham, situated in Lake Cunningham Park in East San Jose, California, is an artificial lake that offers visitors a lovely  environment to enjoy various outdoor activities. The park features a skate park and the Raging Waters theme park, providing diverse recreational options. It serves as a popular destination for both locals and visitors seeking leisure and recreation.

name: Willow View and Brandon Trail
description: This trail winds uphill through a tree shaded area above the Redwood Canyon Public Golf Course Golf Course.

name: Sugarloaf Hill and Captain Hook Viewpoints
description: Climb to the top of Sugarloaf Hill. This short loop explores the views that Laurelwood Park has to offer. While the climb may be steep and challenging, your efforts are rewarded with lovely views of the surrounding hillsides and city below. Keep an eye out for ticks and snakes that can hide in the tall grasses.

name: Sylvan Loop Trail
description:
This is a lovely trail through Edgewood Park and Nature Preserve, featuring a variety of scenery and some stunning views of the Bay and Dumbarton Bridge. Meander through golden grass rolling hills and oak tree woodlands that provide shade and cool breezes.

There is plenty of wildlife to spot in the area, including deer, coyotes, birds, lizards, and rabbits. Many trails in the area can be combined with this one if you wish to adjust the length of your adventure. You can park on the roadside by the trailhead.

name: Lyon Street Steps and Palace of Fine Arts
park: What are some of the facilities available for Lyon Street Steps and Palace of Fine Arts?Park
description: The Lyon Street Steps and Palace of Fine Arts trail in California offers a short but scenic urban hike with iconic views of San Francisco. Starting at the Lyon Street Steps, this path takes you up a series of steps. The trail culminates at the historic Palace of Fine Arts, a beautiful structure with pond and impressive architecture. It’s a great route for those looking to experience a mix of natural beauty and urban landmarks, all while enjoying a good workout. This is a great spot to go check out before exploring the Golden Gate Bridge and park.

name: Rip Van Winkle Open Space
description: Discover this 1.8-km loop trail near Pacific Grove, California. Generally considered an easy route, it takes an average of 25 min to complete. This is a popular trail for hiking and walking, but you can still enjoy some solitude during quieter times of day. The trail is open year-round and is beautiful to visit anytime. Dogs are welcome and may be off-leash in some areas.

name: Los Alamitos Creek Trail and Calero Creek Trail
description:
This paved bike trail connects the Alamitos Creek Trail and Calero Creek Trails along the creeks. Please avoid parking in the school parking lot during school hours. There are several road crossings necessary to fully navigate the trail, so please use caution.

Accessibility: This is the most accessible portion of the Calero Creek Trail and Mine Trail https://www.alltrails.com/trail/us/california/bay-area-ridge-trail-santa-teresa-county-park-and-los-alamitos-calero-creek-trail. There is at least 1 designated accessible space in the paved parking lot off of Shearwater Drive at the west end of the trail. It is van-accessible with striped access aisles. 

The trail surface is paved asphalt and smooth. It is typically at least 8 feet wide. There is a painted dividing line along most of the trail which reduces the width. The whole trail is estimated to be in the mostly gentle (5% or less) grade category. This trail will likely be navigable for most wheelchairs/mobility equipment or stroller users.

name: Crissy Field to Marin Headlands via Golden Gate Bridge
park: GMTExplore near Crissy Field to Marin Headlands via Golden Gate BridgeActivitiesBirdingHikingMountain bikingRoad bikingRunningWalkingAttractionsBeachCaveCity walkEasyForestHistoric siteLakeLongModerately challengingNo dogsShortViewsWildflowersWildlifeSuitabilityDog friendlyDogs on leashKid friendlyPartially pavedPavedStroller friendlyWheelchair friendlyPoints of interestHuntington FallsRainbow FallsBaker BeachSpreckels LakeLake MercedElk Glen LakeJapanese Tea GardenSpreckels Temple of MusicDutch WindmillQueen Wilhelmina Tulip GardenLloyd LakeFisherman's WharfMurphy WindmillPine LakeTelegraph HillMount OlympusBernal HillRose GardenOcean BeachPainted LadiesActivitiesBirdingHikingMountain bikingRoad bikingRunningWalkingAttractionsBeachCaveCity walkEasyForestHistoric siteLakeLongModerately challengingNo dogsAttractionsShortViewsWildflowersWildlifeSuitabilityDog friendlyDogs on leashKid friendlyPartially pavedPavedStroller friendlyWheelchair friendlyPoints of interestHuntington FallsRainbow FallsBaker BeachSpreckels LakeLake MercedElk Glen LakeJapanese Tea GardenSpreckels Temple of MusicDutch WindmillQueen Wilhelmina Tulip GardenPoints of interestLloyd LakeFisherman's WharfMurphy WindmillPine LakeTelegraph HillMount OlympusBernal HillRose GardenOcean BeachPainted LadiesDownloadOpen mapAllTrailsExploreCountriesRegionsCitiesParksTrailsPoints of InterestTrail FeaturesMapsMy mapsCreate mapPrint mapsRoute converterCompanyAboutJobsPressAmbassadorsAffiliatesInfluencersCommunitySupportGift membershipAllTrails GearExploreCountriesRegionsCitiesPark
description:
Escape the city and head for the hills. This trip is a scenic drive tour or road biking tour. Many of the roads and highways on this route are not suitable for pedestrians, so it is not recommended to attempt this route on foot.

Cross the bridge in search of nature, beaches, lighthouses and awesome roads! Just a few short miles from the bustle of San Francisco lies the relative peace and quiet of the Marin Headlands where you can enjoy Golden Gate views among rolling hills and soaring raptors.

This route guides you along the San Francisco bay from Chrissy Field and on to the Golden Gate Bridge. From there you hang a left and head for the hills. The first part of the journey into the hills consists of a constant uphill climb for around 500ft (150m) until reaching the summit of Hawk Hill. Zipping downhill on the curvy coastal road will lead you quickly past even more scenery, a multitude of old military concrete defense structures and towards Point Bonita.

name: Middle Harbor Shoreline to Portview Park
park: Middle Harbor Shoreline to Portview Park
description:
According to Access Northern California (http://accessnca.org/access-northern-california/explore/explore-detail-view/?site_id=181): The salvaged mast of the USS Oakland, an anti-aircraft cruiser decommissioned in 1949, welcomes visitors to the park’s east entrance.

This 38-acre landscaped green space, the site of the Navy’s Pacific Fleet supply center from World War II until 1998, lies in the midst of the vast industrial landscape of an active container seaport. The Oakland’s mast heralds the park’s many historical maritime features, including bollards for tying up ships, pier remnants, and the outlined footprint of the Navy’s four-acre warehouse. Other features include a sandy beach, an amphitheater, a large restored salt marsh, and nearly three miles of wide, level trails that weave through the park.

At the park’s center is Point Arnold, a 16-acre grassy peninsula with a wharf (44-inch railings), an accessible viewing telescope, and picnic sites.

Nearby Port View Park juts into San Francisco Bay on a man-made peninsula. This little park, once a railway terminus, provides great views of operations at the nearby Port of Oakland Seventh Street Terminal, and you can fish here without a license. Just west of the parking lot is the “Room With a View” exhibit in the train tower, where railway personnel once directed traffic. A wheelchair lift takes you up to the second story, affording fantastic views of the port, the Bay Bridge, and both downtown Oakland and San Francisco, which are about equidistant from the pier. Take a look at the exhibit, too, where you will learn about Oakland’s role in the Bay Area's development.

ACCESSIBILITY: Several lots, all reachable from either Middle Harbor Rd. or Seventh St., have designated accessible spaces that are firm and with a slope of 2% or less, including the one at the southernmost end of the park road. Wheelchair-accessible restrooms (open during staff hours) are west of the Oakland’s mast near the east parking lot, and on the ground floor of the Mole’s observation tower. Several accessible picnic tables (firm and stable paths and surfaces and at least 27 inches of knee clearance) are at the park's center; one is on the pier.

For great views as well as an overview of the park, begin your exploration at the observation tower at the park’s southern end. The grade is mostly gentle (5% or less) for the whole route. Trails throughout the park have eroded and are rough in places. Don't expect a smooth ride. The width is typically at least four feet. It's best to follow the upper path from the parking lot to the tower because from the lower path you have to take an elevator to the tower, and it is out of service frequently.

Next, backtrack to the lower trails that traverse the 10-acre peninsula, which was the site of the Western Pacific Mole, an early 20th-century railroad terminal that provided both a shipping connection for local and international freight and a ferry station to take railroad passengers to and from San Francisco.

Work your way back to the parking lot, where you can pick up the .75-mile shoreline promenade that links to the park’s center and Point Arnold at the northern end.

Past the picnic area is Point Arnold and the wharf where people fish; a California fishing license is required here. You can extend your trip another half-mile to Port View Park on a section of Bay Trail that parallels Seventh Street and the railroad tracks.

name: Coyote Creek Trail: Coyote Pond to Silver Creek Valley Road
park: Coyote Creek Trail: Coyote Pond to Silver Creek Valley Road is a great place to see wildflowers.Top trails nearbyCoyote Peak and Ridge Trail LoopCoyote Peak and Ridge Trail LoopSanta Teresa County Park
description:
This is a beautiful route on a bike path along Coyote Creek. It starts at Coyote Pond, following the Coyote Creek Trail to Silver Creek Valley Road. The wetlands along the creek are incredibly scenic and host various waterfowl and other wildlife. The path is popular and will likely be busy; stay alert for others on the trail.

Accessibility:

Equipment
This trail is likely accessible for visitors using wheelchairs, mobility equipment, or strollers.

Parking
There do not appear to be any accessible parking spaces in the gravel parking lot near the trailhead.

Surface
The trail surface is paved asphalt and typically at least 9 feet wide. A painted dividing line along most of the trail reduces the width.

Grade
This trail is estimated to be gentle (3% or less).

More Info
Picnic tables and benches are available along the route for resting.

name: Buena Vista Trail to Virl O Norton Trail Loop
description: Almaden Quicksilver County Park includes over 37 miles of hiking trails, including 30 miles of equestrian trails and 16.6 miles of bike trails. All trails in the park are also open to pet owners to walk their dogs on leash. For more information visit: https://www.sccgov.org/sites/parks/parkfinder/pages/almadenpark.aspx

name: Mount Madonna Amphitheater and Valley View Loop
description:
• General fee: Mount Madonna County Park charges a fee to enter. For more information, please visit https://parks.sccgov.org/plan-your-visit/santa-clara-county-park-fees

As you make your way along the Valley View Loop, you'll be treated to sweeping vistas of the surrounding Santa Clara Valley and the distant Santa Cruz Mountains. The open sections of the trail provide perfect opportunities to stop and take in the breathtaking views, particularly on clear days when you can see all the way to the Bay Area.

name: Mariner's Lagoon and Bathhouse via Bay Trail
park: HikingGood conditionsGood viewsEasy to parkNot crowdedBathrooms availableDog-friendlyEasy walk with lovely views. You can walk a lot more than just the trail that is marked here.Show activityCharlotte Park
description:
Trail Highlights:
The Bay Trail at Robert W. Crown Memorial State Beach in Alameda is a natural treasure, offering a blend of urban and coastal environments. On the walk, notice the smooth, paved path that stretches for miles, perfect for walkers, joggers, and cyclists alike. On one side, the shimmering waters of San Francisco Bay offer stunning views, while on the other, native plants like coastal sagebrush and coyote bush provide habitats for local wildlife. Watch for shorebirds—sandpipers, willets, and herons are frequent visitors, often seen wading in the shallows or darting along the tide line. Interpretive panels along the way provide fascinating insights into the estuary's delicate ecosystem, from its tidal flows to the role it plays as a nursery for marine life. There are also picnic tables strategically placed for trailgoers to pause and enjoy a meal, perhaps while watching windsurfers dance across the waves.

Trail Directions:
From the McKay Avenue entrance, head straight to the shoreline. Turn left onto the Bay Trail following the shoreline at Freshwater Lagoon. Turn left, walk to the end of Freshwater Lagoon, then retrace steps back to Bay Trail. Turn left, walk toward the bathhouse. At the bathhouse retrace the path and return to the Visitor Center to learn about the park’s history and marine life.

Accessibility:
Robert W. Crown Memorial State Beach offers several ADA-accessible features. The paved Bay Trail runs along the shoreline, providing a smooth, level surface for wheelchair users and those with mobility devices. Accessible parking is available near major trailheads, with designated spaces close to restrooms equipped with grab bars and sufficient maneuvering space. The park also offers a beach wheelchair, which can be reserved in advance. Picnic areas have accessible tables with firm, stable surfaces, and the Visitor Center is fully accessible, offering exhibits and programs for all.

name: Harvey Bear to Willow Springs Loop
park: Coyote Lake Harvey Bear Ranch County Park
description:
• Parking Fee: Coyote Lake Harvey Bear Ranch County Park charges a fee to enter, except at Mendoza Ranch and Harvey Bear Entrances. There are varying fees depending on if you enter by vehicle, motorcycle, foot, horse, or bike. Please visit https://parks.santaclaracounty.gov/locations/coyote-lake-harvey-bear-ranch-county-park

Start and finish at the Harvey Bear park entrance.  Hike up to the Harvey Bear/Willow Spring Trail split. Follow Harvey Bear to Calaveras, to Coyote Ridge, to Blue Oak, to Gaviota, turn left on Rancho San Ysidro then left on Willow Springs to get back to the parking lot. There are two picnic benches along the route. One along the Calaveras Trail and one on Gaviota. The one on Gaviota is about fifty yards along Gaviota when you get to the Gaviota/Blue Oak Trail junction. If you're going down Blue Oak, continue straight. If you are coming from Rancho San Ysidro, just continue down Gaviota instead of turning up Blue Oak.

name: Calero Creek Trail and Mine Trail
description:
• Fee Information: Santa Teresa County Park charges a fee to enter. For more information, please visit https://parks.sccgov.org/plan-your-visit/santa-clara-county-park-fees#3925188384-3236192913

Enjoy up to 18 miles of unpaved hiking trails at Santa Teresa County Park. There are amazing wildflowers to be viewed from the months of March through June.

You can take the Pueblo Trial to connect to the Stile Ranch/Bay Area Ridge Trail.

Accessibility: There are no designated accessible spaces off of Camden Avenue at the west end of the trail. However, there is at least 1 designated accessible space in the paved parking lot off of Shearwater Drive at the west end of the trail. It is van-accessible with striped access aisles. Please avoid parking here during school hours.

The trail surface is paved asphalt, gravel, or a natural surface (dirt, rocks, roots). It is typically at least 4 feet wide. There is a painted dividing line along the paved portion of the trail which reduces the width. There are several logs at the entrance to the path at about 0.7 miles that create an obstacle of about six inches every three feet.

The most accessible portion of the trail is the paved portion in the first about 0.7 miles when going east. The majority of the trail is estimated to be in the mostly gentle (5% or less) grade category but there are steeper sections at about 1.9-4.0, 4.8, and 5.1 miles when going clockwise. Trail goers using wheelchairs/mobility equipment or strollers may need assistance in the steeper sections or to avoid them for safety. All-terrain tires or motorized equipment may be needed for the surface type and grade after about 0.7 miles. The most accessible portion of the trail is the Los Alamitos Creek Trail and Calero Creek Trail: https://www.alltrails.com/trail/us/california/los-alamitos-creek-trail-and-calero-creek-trail

name: Nature Trail, Merry Go Round and Ridge Trail Loop
description:
• General fee: Mount Madonna County Park charges a fee to enter. For more information, please visit https://parks.sccgov.org/plan-your-visit/santa-clara-county-park-fees

This trail is mostly shaded and goes up and down the mountain. There are some really nice vistas and a couple of picnic tables along the way. Near the top of the mountain there are a lot of eucalyptus trees. The trail is extremely well marked, with numbered sign posts at each junction corresponding to a numbered junction on the map.

Alternative parking found at the Sprig Recreation Area, located adjacent to Highway 152.

name: Arrowhead Marsh Trail
park: Pacific Flyway and part of the Western Hemisphere Shorebird Reserve

name: Webb Canyon, New Almaden, Prospect #3, Randol, and Mine Hill Loop
description:
• Partial closure: As of June 2, 2025,  part of this route is temporarily inaccessible, but you can still enjoy other sections of this trail. For more information, please visit https://parks.santaclaracounty.gov/locations/almaden-quicksilver-county-park

The trailhead is located on Web Canyon Dr in Almaden. There is no dedicated parking, but there are plenty of spaces available along the sidewalks of the neighboring streets.

The short, lightly trafficked Webb Canyon Trail at the bottom starts with a paved access road (closed to cars) then branches into the woods as a narrow trail along a beautiful hillside, especially in the fall with a blanket of new grass.

The trail then continues (on both sides) along a portion of New Almaden Trail, which is a narrow, shaded, canyon carving trail that zigzags in and out of the canyons at the feet of the Almaden hills with occasional short changes of elevation. The top of the trail is a section of Randol and Mine Hill Trails, which are much wider and more trafficked (including by bikes) and with generally less shade.

The trail can easily be extended by taking a longer section of New Almaden Trail at the bottom or by exploring the vast network of trails around the old mine at the eastern end of the Randol and Mine Hill Trails.

name: Martin Canyon Creek Trail
description:
The Martin Canyon Creek Trail is one of Dublin's little known treasures. This improved trail follows Martin Canyon Creek and offers amazing views of the Tri-Valley and the canyons leading to the west.

Large oaks and bay trees line the creek and trail and provide tranquil areas for respite. The trailhead is located at the corner of Silvergate and Bay Laurel Drive.

name: Coyote Rim Trail: Prospect Creek to Stevens Creek Reservoir
description: The Coyote Rim Trail travels north-south through the length of the Fremont Older Open Space Preserve. From the southern terminus at Prospect Road, the trail quickly climbs to a high point in the first mile and, from there, gradually descends to the southern terminus at Stevens Creek Reservoir. There are great views of the Santa Cruz Mountains but little shade; bring plenty of water and a hat.

name: Guadalupe Creek Overlook
description: This trail starts at the parking lot off Mount Umunhum Road, where restrooms are available, and leads to Guadalupe Creek Overlook in Sierra Azul Open Space Preserve. The trail ascends through the forest, offering beautiful views of the South Bay from the lookout. For those seeking more adventure, experienced hikers can continue to the Umunhum summit.

name: Alum Rock Road, South Rim and Woodland Trail
description:
• Parking fee information: There is a fee to park at Alum Rock Park. For more information, please visit https://www.sanjoseca.gov/Home/Components/FacilityDirectory/FacilityDirectory/2088/2028

Explore Alum Rock Park with this fantastic shaded trail. The route starts off relatively flat before heading up the Switchback Trail and gaining some good elevation.

The views at the summit are fantastic, with views of San Jose and the valley below. The path is partially paved and narrow in some sections. Along the way, visitors can spot birds, squirrels, deer, and snakes. Picnic and bathroom facilities are available along Penitencia Creek Trail.

name: Indian Joe Creek Trail, High Valley Rd, and Hayfield Rd Loop
description:
• Parking fee information: There is a fee to park at Sunol Wilderness Regional Preserve on weekends and holidays. For more information, please visit https://www.ebparks.org/parks/sunol

Begin by crossing Alameda Creek and follow the Indian Joe Creek Trail uphill towards the Cave Rocks Rd. Along the trail, there are a large few boulders where climbers are sometimes spotted. From Cave Rocks Rd, turn onto High Valley Rd where you will pass the High Valley Camp. Hayfield Rd with complete the loop and return to the trailhead.

name: Spring Ridge Trail to Windy Hill
description: There is limited parking at the trailhead and some street parking. Check the signs before parking your car.

name: Los Alamitos Calero Creek Trail: Pfeiffer Park to Almaden Lake
park: Los Alamitos Calero Creek Trail: Pfeiffer Park
description:
This is a nice paved bike path from Pfeiffer Park to Almaden Lake and back. It can be fairly crowded. 

Accessibility: There are 2 designated accessible spaces in the paved parking lot off of Camden Avenue at the south end of the trail. Both of them are van-accessible with striped access aisles. The trail surface is paved asphalt and smooth. It is typically at least 8 feet wide. There is a painted dividing line along most of the trail which reduces the width. 

The whole trail is estimated to be in the gentle (3% or less) grade category. This trail will likely be navigable for most wheelchairs/mobility equipment or stroller users. There are benches along the route for resting.

name: Deep Gulch, Mine Hill, Capehorn Pass and Hacienda Trail
description: This trail begins from the Hacienda Entrance parking lot off Alamitos Road, where restrooms and a picnic area are available. It then takes you to Almaden Quicksilver County Park. It winds along the Deep Gulch and through rolling hills with a rich mining history. At the top, it offers great views of the San Jose metropolitan area. The trail is half-covered and half-exposed, with steep sections and rocky parts—sturdy footwear and hiking poles are recommended.

name: North Bayfront Loop
description: An excellent loop for jogging, walking, or bird watching. The Palo Alto Baylands is home to the elusive California Clapperrail. This is a great loop for the entire family. Downloading offline maps can help you navigate this trail. This route is very exposed, and there is no shade, so bring plenty of water and sun protection.

name: Bay Trail and Mariner's Lagoon Loop
park: Robert W. Crown Memorial State Beach
description:
The Robert W. Crown Memorial State Beach and Washington Park are central hubs for outdoor recreation in Alameda. The parks have athletic courts, playgrounds, a dog park, beach access, and trails that link both. This route follows paved and dirt paths along the San Francisco Bay and Mariner's Lagoon before looping back on the east side, past the dog park and fields. 

Please note that dogs are only allowed on paved paths, lawns, and the dog park. This route does not allow dogs to walk along dirt paths or the beach.

Accessibility:

Equipment
This trail is likely accessible for visitors using wheelchairs, mobility equipment, or strollers.

Parking
There are 13 designated accessible spaces with striped access aisles in the paved parking lot.

Surface
The trail surface is paved asphalt, typically at least 6 feet wide, with many wider passing areas. 

Grade
This trail is estimated to be flat (1% or less).

More Info
Picnic tables and benches are available along the route for resting, though navigating some uneven/grassy terrain may be required to reach them.

name: Batteries to Bluffs Trail
description:
Experience the wild western shoreline on the Batteries to Bluffs Trail. This rugged route takes visitors along the cliffs bordering the Pacific Ocean, allowing hikers to explore historic gun batteries, seeps and springs, coastal plants and wildlife, and stunning views.

This short trail provides a great way to see the bluffs near the Presidio and offers views of the Golden Gate Bridge and Marin that are hard to beat.  The trail has several places with steps and some climbing if you decide to take the side trip down to Marshall Beach - a quiet, isolated area surrounded by rocky serpentine cliffs with breathtaking views of the Golden Gate Bridge. Try hiking this trail near the end of the day to enjoy a long sunset over the Pacific Ocean and the lights of the Golden Gate Bridge.

name: PG&E Trail, Wildcat, High Meadow and Coyote Trail Loop
park: Rancho San Antonio Open Space Preserve
description:
This lovely trail features impressive vistas across the Bay, green grass and lots of wildflowers. The surface is partly paved but mostly fairly wide and compact dirt that can get slightly muddy after heavy rain. 

Most of the route is in the shade, with some gradual rolling hills along the way. You'll likely spot wild animals in the area, including deer and turkeys.

name: Iron Horse Regional Trail
park: East Bay Regional Park District Trail Systems
description:
This is a popular paved trail good for walking and cycling.

Accessibility: 

Equipment
Visitors using wheelchairs, mobility equipment, or strollers may need all-terrain tires or adaptive/motorized equipment for the surface type and grade.

Parking
There are 3 designated van-accessible spaces with striped access aisles in the paved parking lot off Olivera Road at Hillcrest Community Park at the trail's north end. There is 1 designated van-accessible space with striped access aisles in the paved parking lot off West Las Positas Boulevard. 

Surface
The trail surface is paved asphalt or concrete and smooth. It is typically at least 8 feet wide.

Grade
This trail is estimated to be mostly gentle (5% or less), with some steeper sections that may require assistance or need to be avoided.

name: Bayview and Meadowlark Trail Loop
description:
• Partial closure: Part of this route is temporarily inaccessible, but you can still enjoy other sections of this trail. For more information, please visit https://www.ebparks.org/parks/coyote-hills
• Parking fee information: There is a fee to park at Coyote Hills Regional Park. For more information, please visit https://www.ebparks.org/parks/coyote-hills

Gentle climbs, scenic bay views, and indigenous people's history await at the west edge of Fremont, California. Coyote Hills Regional Park is a great place to introduce a friend to hiking. If the modest hills overlooking San Francisco Bay force you to work up a sweat on the way up the Red Hill Trail, you can cool down by walking the wide gravel Bayview Trail along the water's edge. An enlightening side trip is to the Tuibun Village site east of the marshes near the Visitors Center. The Tuibun Ohlone built a shell mound there 2,000 years ago.    

If you're feeling really ambitious, take the trail over Highway 84 and check out the birds and other animals at the Don Edwards San Francisco Bay National Wildlife Refuge (note dogs aren't allowed there).

Accessibility: There are 2 designated accessible spaces in the paved parking lot off of Patterson Ranch Road at the east end of the trail. Both of them are van-accessible with striped access aisles. The trail surface is paved asphalt with some bumps and cracks. It is typically at least 6 feet wide.

The most accessible portion of the trail is the northern loop in the first 2.5 miles. The majority of the trail is estimated to be in the mostly gentle (5% or less) grade category but there are steeper sections at about 2.5-2.9 and 3.1-3.2 miles when going counterclockwise. Trailgoers using wheelchairs/mobility equipment or strollers may need assistance in the steeper sections or to avoid them for safety. The most accessible portion of the trail is the Bayview and Nike Loop trail: https://www.alltrails.com/trail/us/california/bayview-and-nike-loop

name: Bay Area Ridge Trail: Mount Madonna County Park
park: Bay Area Ridge Trail: Mount Madonna County Park
description:
• General fee: Mount Madonna County Park charges a fee to enter. For more information, please visit https://parks.sccgov.org/plan-your-visit/santa-clara-county-park-fees

On an uphill trip from the Sprig Recreation Area trailhead to Mount Madonna Road, you take in excellent views of southern Santa Clara County and the Inner Coast Range. The wide service road skirts an intermittent creek, crosses boulder-strewn grasslands, swings through chaparral and scrub-oak forest, and finishes in a cool, steep-sided redwood canyon. This is the southernmost segment of the Ridge Trail.

For more information, see the Bay Area Ridge Trail page here:
https://ridgetrail.org/mount-madonna-county-park/

This trail description is excerpted from the 2019 Guidebook. For details on all of the Bay Area Ridge trails, trailheads and more buy the book from Wilderness Press: https://www.wildernesspress.com/product.php?productid=16685&cat=274&bestseller=Y

name: Pueblo Trail to Coyote Peak, Hidden Springs and Fortini Trail Loop
description:
• Fee Information: Santa Teresa County Park charges a fee to enter. For more information, please visit https://parks.sccgov.org/plan-your-visit/santa-clara-county-park-fees#3925188384-3236192913

This trail begins from the parking lot off Bernal Road, where a picnic area is available. It then takes you to Santa Teresa County Park with a short detour to Coyote Peak. The parking area at the trailhead is limited, so it's recommended that you arrive early. Coyote Peak offers stunning views of Silicon Valley, with the Diablo Range to the east and the Santa Cruz Mountains to the west. During the spring, you'll find beautiful wildflowers and butterflies. Be prepared for rocky sections and very little shade.

name: Bay Trail: Oakland to Albany
park:
Oakland to Albany.

Emeryville Marina McLaughlin Eastshore State Park
description:
This is a segment of the San Francisco Bay Trail: a 500 mile long mile trail around the Bay. This is the 12th section of the Bay Trail, taking hikers from Oakland to Albany.

Emeryville Marina McLaughlin Eastshore State Park • Albany Bulb In West Oakland, the Bay Trail follows streets through the busy trade and transportation zone of the Port of Oakland. Along 3rd Street, the bike lanes and sidewalks curve under the web of highway overpasses to Mandela Parkway. At 8th Street and Mandela, the trail splits. One leg heads towards the heart of the Port to Middle Harbor Shoreline Park and Portview Park. Breathtaking views of the Bay Bridge and the San Francisco and Oakland skylines can be seen from almost everywhere in these parks with the observation tower at Middle Harbor offering the most spectacular birds-eye views. At 7th Street, take the path along Maritime Street north through a busy port area to the Bay Bridge Trail. From 8th Street and Mandela, the trail route heads north along Mandela Parkway to Emeryville. Follow Mandela through the industrial zone of West Oakland, stopping to visit Cypress Memorial Park built in memory to those who lost their lives here in the 1989 Loma Prieta Earthquake. Mandela terminates at a shopping center; head left on Horton and left again on 40th Street to ramp over the railroad tracks. Where 40th Street turns into Shellmound Street, look for another entry to the Bay Bridge Trail to Yerba Buena Island. A future park, known as Judge John Sutter Regional Shoreline, will be constructed at the base of the Bay Bridge serving as an entry point to the path on the bridge. Continuing through Emeryville, use city streets to reach Christie Avenue, then take the trail along Christie Avenue and Powell Street and pass under the highway. Continue straight on Powell towards the bay to reach the Emeryville City Marina or turn right to follow the Bay Trail north towards Albany. This is the southern edge of Eastshore State Park. The trail passes Point Emery on its way to Berkeley, where it ducks under the Berkeley bicycle/pedestrian bridge over Highway 80. Take the bridge inland to visit Aquatic Park. Detour west along University Avenue to the Berkeley Marina, Shorebird Park, and Cesar Chavez Park. Rounding the edge of Golden Gate Fields, the Albany Mudflats Ecological Reserve is straight ahead. To your left is Albany Bulb, popular for its spectacular views of the bay and found art exhibits. The Bay Trail continues north squeezing between the highway and the mudflats en route to Richmond.

name: Kit Fox Trail and Eagle Ridge Loop
park: HikingGood conditionsEasy to parkNot crowdedBathrooms availablePark
description:
• Parking fee information: There is a fee to park at Los Vaqueros Reservoir and Watershed. For more information, please visit  https://www.ccwater.com/194/Fees

The Los Vaqueros Watershed is a popular place for boating and fishing and has an extensive network of multi-use trails and dirt roads. This route starts at the Walnut Trailhead and heads west on the Mortero Trail until connecting with the Kit Fox Trail. After a steep climb, take the Eagle Ridge Trail at the junction and follow the ridge southeast until completing the loop on the Grassland Trail. The terrain is grasslands and oaks and does not offer a lot of shade. Bring water and sun protection.

name: Rhus Ridge and Chamise Trail
park: Rancho San Antonio Open Space Preserve
description: The Rhus Ridge and Chamise Trail in Rancho San Antonio explores the open spaces and wilderness right on the outskirts of the urban sprawl of the bay area. As you stroll along this peaceful route, you’ll wander through rolling meadows and shady oak groves, with glimpses of the vast Santa Cruz Mountains in the distance. While this is a tougher hike to explore this area, its a great option, without too much fluctuation in elevation, unlike some of the other trails in this area.

name: Penetencia Creek, South Rim and Sycamore Switchback
description:
• Parking fee information: There is a fee to park at Alum Rock Park. For more information, please visit https://www.sanjoseca.gov/Home/Components/FacilityDirectory/FacilityDirectory/2088/2028

Nicely shaded hike for at least 2/3 of the way...make sure to bring sturdy shoes as there is a lot of loose dirt and rock.

name: Hidden Valley Trail
description:
A steady climb of more than 1500 feet in just over 3 miles (one way), most of it on the Hidden Valley Trail (a well-graded dirt road) offers views of the entire Bay Area.

This is not a trip for hot weather - the out-and-back route offers little shade. Bring extra clothes and a wind shell as this is a mountain environment and the weather can change quickly.

Please be aware that no bicycles are allowed on the single-track part of the Peak Trail.

name: Mount Hamilton Cycle Loop
description: Enjoy this 107.2-mile loop trail near San Jose, California. Generally considered a challenging route. This is a popular trail for road biking, but you can still enjoy some solitude during quieter times of day. The trail is open year-round and is beautiful to visit anytime.

name: Mitchell Park Loop
description: Mitchell Park was designed by the famous landscape architect Robert Royston in 1956. It is a centerpiece for outdoor recreation in Palo Alto, offering tennis courts, splash pads, a playground, and paved paths for walking. The parking lot, drinking fountains, and main bathrooms are off Middlefield Road.

name: Summit Rock Loop Trail
description:
• Fee Information: Sanborn County Park charges a fee to enter. For more information, please https://parks.santaclaracounty.gov/locations/sanborn-county-park
• Wildlife closure: Summit Rock is currently closed due to wildlife activity. For more information, please visit https://parks.sccgov.org/santa-clara-county-parks/sanborn-county-park

Summit Trail Loop is a mellow meander through redwoods, oaks and madrone. The trail goes from single track to almost as wide as a fire road and is covered in pine needles. Occasionally, it gets a bit rocky and uneven. There are great collections of larger boulders and everything is covered in moss.

name: Fairy Gates Trail
description: The Fairy Gates Trail offers a beautiful hike through lush vegetation and forest of Mount Sutro Open Space Reserve. While most of this trail heads through the forest you do get a few glimpses of the  surrounding landscape of urban San Francisco. . This trail is very shot but packs a punch with a good bit of elevation gain, perfect for those looking to experience nature whilst getting a quick workout right in the heart of San Francisco.

name: Maple Falls via Bridge Creek Trail and Aptos Creek Road
park: The Forest Of Nisene Marks State Park
description:
• Fee information: The Forest of Nisene Marks State Park charges a fee to enter. For more information, please visit https://www.parks.ca.gov/?page_id=666

Off the beaten path, The Forest of Nisene Marks is a refreshing retreat from the busy towns and beaches along Highway 1 near Santa Cruz. Its dense second- and third-growth redwood forest rises from near sea level to steep coastal mountains.

Drive up Aptos Creek Road to the park entrance kiosk. After the park entrance kiosk the road quickly become packed dirt but can be driven by to all types of vehicles. Continue on the dirt road to the Porter Family Picnic Area. There is a locked gate here closing the fire trail for vehicles, park here.

The trailhead is just a few yards beyond the locked gate. Continue north on the fire road beyond the locked gate, and start on the Loma Prieta Grade Trail on the left. In about 0.5 miles bear to the right at the fork and switch over to Bridge Creek Trail. Follow Bridge Creek Trail all the way to Maple Falls.

The park map makes mention of a winter gate on the Aptos Creek Fire road so depending on the time of year you visit the park if this gate is closed you will need to leave your car at the George's Picnic Area. Walk to the Porter Family Picnic Area to start the trail by using the Aptos Creek Fire Road. If this is the case it will add approx. 1 mile each way for a total of 2 miles roundtrip.

The trail starts out easy and quickly changes to moderate. It goes through dense redwood forest, steep trails, canyons, bridges, and a couple of river crossings hopping over rocks. It gets a bit challenging at some points especially towards the end as you get close to the waterfall.

name: Asilomar State Beach and Coast Trail
park: Guided nature walks are offered by State Park
description:
Locals and tourists flock to Asilomar State Beach. It is in close proximity to Monterey's Cannery Row, in the heart of Pacific Grove, and has a highly popular conference center for retreats. If you need a break from the regular tourist stuff, this is a great option.

The trail goes between soft and compacted sand to wood-paneled walkways with small gazebo outlooks. It is an easy walk with only a few rocks to watch out for. There are all sorts of possibilities here for ocean kayaking, paddle boarding, and diving. Being in Northern California, the water is cold and not suitable for casual swimming.

The beach and bluff walk provide ready access to spectacular coastline, tide pools, marine mammal and offshore preserves, kelp beds, and more. It's extremely popular locally for morning and afternoon walks. It's accessible, tucked between the coastal road and the ocean, and one of those places that's gorgeous no matter the weather. 

According to Access Northern CA (http://accessnca.org/access-northern-california/explore/explore-detail-view/?site_id=13): The grounds, restrooms, restaurant, and gift shop at Asilomar Conference Grounds are open to the public. An accessible boardwalk travels from the conference grounds to the beach and over sand dunes, offering a rare close-up glimpse of a dune restoration project. Guided nature walks are offered by State Parks, free of charge. Check for times at the registration building (Social Hall) on the conference grounds. You can also rent bicycles and pick up a leaflet describing dune plants.

California State Parks maintains this trail network.

Accessibility:

quipment
Visitors using wheelchairs, mobility equipment, or strollers may need all-terrain tires or adaptive equipment for the surface type and grade.

Parking
There are 2 designated van-accessible parking spaces with striped access aisles in the paved parking lot.

Surface
The trail surface is sand, paved asphalt, or wooden boardwalk with edge railings and is typically at least 3 feet wide. Sand blown onto the trail may impact surface firmness.

Grade
This trail is estimated to be mostly gentle (5% or less), with some moderately steep (5-8%) sections that may require assistance or need to be avoided.

More Info
A portion of this trail may not be accessible to visitors using wheelchairs, mobility equipment, or strollers. The most accessible portion of this route is the Conference Grounds Dune Boardwalk (first .4 miles), which follows a boardwalk with benches and areas to turn around. The transitions to the boardwalk may have a lip of greater than 2 inches. 

To enjoy the longest accessible stretch of the Coast Trail (under 0.5 mile), start at Jewell Avenue. If you go north from Jewell Ave, you will soon come to a lovely covered overlook with benches. The trail continues a little farther, then curves back to Ocean View Blvd. Traveling south from Jewell, the trail hugs the shoreline. If sections of sand are too deep, manual wheelchair riders or stroller users may need to backtrack to one of the exits at the accessible parking locations and use the bike lane along Ocean View Blvd to continue south. Traffic is light and speeds are slow. 

Beach wheelchairs are available for loan with a reservation at the store inside the Asilomar Registration Building. 

There are wheelchair-accessible restrooms in the registration building, wheelchair accessible picnic tables (with a firm and stable path to the tables, firm and stable surface, and at least 27 inches of knee clearance).

Take caution when crossing roadways; designated crosswalks are present. Traffic noise may be present on this route. This trail has little shade, so wearing appropriate sun protection is recommended.

name: Hacienda Trail, Church Hill, and Mine Hill Trail Loop
description:
This route takes you through the Almaden Quicksilver County Park area and encircles Church Hill. This trail has some steep sections with some enjoyable elevation changes throughout. 

This is also the route for the Quicksilver 10k trail running event. For more information, please see https://www.quicksilver-running.com/races

name: Cowell-Purisima Trail
park: Purisima Creek. It’s short but very steep. Park
description:
The Cowell-Purisima Trail is part of the California Coastal Trail and winds along the edge of coastal cliff-side farmland. 

Accessibility: According to the park website, most of the Cowell-Purisima Trail is wheelchair-accessible, except for some terrain in the middle where the trail crosses Purisima Creek. It’s short but very steep. Park staff recommends that those in wheelchairs pick an end of the trail (north or south) and make an out-and-back trip to this point unless assistance is available to make it up and down this grade safely. 

Visitors using wheelchairs, mobility equipment, or strollers may need all-terrain tires or adaptive/motorized equipment for the surface type and grade. There are accessible parking spaces with a cross-slope of less than 2% in the gravel parking lots at the north and south trailheads, with spaces designated for vans in the southern lot. The trail surface is gravel, typically at least 3 feet wide. This trail is estimated to be mostly gentle (5% or less). There are accessible vault toilets at the southern trailhead parking lot (but no sink) and a partially accessible portable toilet at the northern lot (with a steep lip to enter and no turnaround room inside). Cowell Ranch Beach is accessible only by a steep staircase.

According to Access Northern California (http://accessnca.org/access-northern-california/explore/explore-detail-view/?site_id=139): From the Cowell Ranch Beach parking area (northern trailhead), the trail leads west through farm fields for 0.5 miles, slightly downhill all the way, to a blufftop. Be sure to look for a metal sculpture shaped like a whale on the fence to your left. Interpretive panels along the trail describe common plants and wildlife and offer a bit of local history.

Right before you reach the blufftop viewing area, you will pass a rickety, inaccessible porta-potty next to where the Cowell-Purisima trail heads south. Continue past the trail to the bluff, where you can look down on Cowell Ranch Beach to the north. To the south, you can see a rocky cove where harbor seals like to haul out. They tend to be here from late winter through spring - use binoculars or the lowered telescope to look for seal pups in March and April. After about one mile, you come to an interpretive sign marking the site of an ancient Ohlone village.

name: Apay Way to Bay View to Red Hill Loop
description: Starting near the Newark Slough parking lot, the Quarry Trail goes across Hwy 84 to enter Coyote Hills Regional Park. From here, take Apay Way and continue on to Bay View trail, all the while enjoying fine views of the bay from the hills. You can return to Apay Way junction either taking Red Hills trail or looping back by Bay View Trail. Retrace the steps by Apay Way and Quarry trail to reach the starting point.

name: Fall Creek Trail to Ridge Trail Loop
description:
• General fee: Henry Cowell Redwoods State Park charges a fee to park at the day-use and campground areas. There are varying fees depending on if you enter by vehicle, motorcycle, foot, horse, or bike. For more information, please visit https://www.parks.ca.gov/?page_id=546


Since this can be a popular trail arriving early is recommended as the parking can be crowded on weekends. The trail signs can be a little confusing, so downloading the offline maps or following the route with GPS is helpful. The fauna, flora, and forest biodiversity are beautiful, and everyone will enjoy this peaceful route.

name: Spanish Bay Trail
park: Spanish Bay Trail is near North Moss Beach and Moss Beach.Top trails nearbyMonterey Peninsula Recreational Trail and Asilomar Ave LoopMonterey Peninsula Recreational Trail and Asilomar Ave LoopPerkins Park4.7·Easy·6.6 km·Est. 1h 19mMonterey Waterfront City WalkMonterey Waterfront City WalkLovers Point Park4.6·Easy·7.1 km·Est. 1h 19mAsilomar State Beach and Coast TrailAsilomar State Beach and Coast TrailAsilomar State Beach4.7·Easy·5.8 km·Est. 1h 13mHuckleberry Hill LoopHuckleberry Hill LoopVeterans Memorial Park4.4·Moderate·2.9 km·Est. 1h 5mSFB Morse Botanical ReserveSFB Morse Botanical ReserveSFB Morse Botanical Reserve4.4·Moderate·4.8 km·Est. 1h 15mHistoric Cannery Row Walking TourHistoric Cannery Row Walking Tour4.4·Easy·2.4 km·Est. 28mRestless Sea and China RockRestless Sea and China Rock4.6·Easy·4.5 km·Est. 51mTwo Huckleberry Hill and Outer LoopTwo Huckleberry Hill and Outer LoopSFB Morse Botanical Reserve
description: Spanish Bay Trail in Asilomar State Beach offers stunning ocean views and a relaxing walk on soft sand. The trail passes Moss Beach and Point Joe Vista Point, Spanish Bay Vista Point, and Restless Sea. At these points of interest, you can see the ocean closer, and there are pull-offs to park. There is parking available on the side of Sunset Dr.

name: Bay Trail: Alameda and Oakland
description:
This is not a hike! This is a segment of the urban San Francisco Bay Trail: a 500 mile long mile trail around the Bay. This is the 10th section of the Bay Trail, taking hikers from Alameda to Oakland.

There is much to discover along the Alameda and Oakland shorelines, including the bay's largest active port, beaches, historical sites and stretches of trail with delightful views. Beginning in Alameda's Towata Park at the base of the Bay Farm Island Bridge, enter the Elsie Roemer Bird Sanctuary, stopping to view shorebirds and waterfowl from observation platforms.

Continue on 2.5 miles of paved trail along Crown Memorial State Beach, the bay's largest and warmest beach. Near McKay Avenue, you'll find the Crab Cove Visitor Center, a great place for kids to learn about the bay with hands-on classrooms in Crab Cove. 

The Bay Trail traverses Main Street Linear Park on the way to the Alameda Ferry Terminal. Although the city of Alameda has long-range plans for a shoreline trail along the Estuary, to encircle the island you will need to use city streets on the northern, eastern, and parts of the western sides. Jump over to Oakland on the Fruitvale Bridge or the High Street Bridge. 

The Oakland Waterfront Pathway is a work in progress and can get complicated. The city's 19-mile waterfront is a dynamic mix of world trade and local industry, old warehouses and modern condominiums, yachts and container ships. Between High Street and Jack London Square, short segments of the Bay Trail are in place providing access to the edge of the Oakland Estuary, but they are not connected. 

Visit the trail between Fruitvale and High streets, Fruitvale and Park Avenue, Union Point Park, Embarcadero Cove, and Estuary Park. Bike lanes and sidewalks along Embarcadero serve as an inland connection to some of these waterfront destinations. The trail around Lake Merritt is worth exploring, accessible to the Bay Trail only along city streets. There are plans to eventually connect the trails at Lake Merritt with the Bay Trail at Estuary Park.

Visit Jack London Square, the public hub of Oakland's waterfront and learn about its rich history. Take a cruise on the Alameda-Oakland Ferry as it  runs between Jack London Square, Alameda, and San Francisco's Ferry Building and Pier 39. To reach Middle Harbor Shoreline Park and Portview Park use bike lanes and sidewalks along city streets and be rewarded with breathtaking views. Continue north to Emeryville along city streets via Mandela Parkway or to the Bay Bridge Trail along the path on Maritime Street.

name: Shinn Pond and San Francisco Bay Trail
description: Niles Community Park is among a few recreational parks along Alameda Creek. This route starts from Montecito Drive and follows the paved path south between the train tracks and Shinn Pond. It continues northeast along paved paths that weave through grassy areas and below shade trees on a strip of land between the creek and pond. Connecting trails take you to Quarry Lakes Regional Park.
