name: Parker Ranch Trail to Nob Hill Loop [PRIVATE PROPERTY]
description:
There's a sharp uphill hike in the beginning. Once you pass that, it's combination of mild uphill and downhill. In few areas, the trail passes through neighborhood and crosses the streets. 
At the vista point (Nob Hill), there are trails that go to Masie's Peak and can connect you to Steven's Canyon trail.

name: Joice, Bernal Hill, Mine, Coyote Peak, Norred Loop
description:
• Fee Information: Santa Teresa County Park charges a fee to enter. For more information, please visit https://parks.sccgov.org/plan-your-visit/santa-clara-county-park-fees#3925188384-3236192913

This trail is well-maintained and has all kinds of terrains. Steep hill at the beginning and rocky in the middle. There are beautiful views along the way.

This trail is shared by hikers, mountain bikers, and dogs. Keep your eyes out for others out there enjoying the trail. Hikers have the right of way but should be aware of mountain bikers riding around blind corners or downhill. Dogs should yield to everyone else out there on the trail.

name: Dairy, Dutch Flat and Brush Trail Loop
description: • Joseph D Grant County Park collects a day-use fee for vehicular entrance year-round. For more information, please see https://parks.sccgov.org/plan-your-visit/santa-clara-county-park-fees#3925188384-3236192913

name: Mount Davidson
description:
Named after famous geographer and Sierra Club charter member George Davidson, Mount Davidson is the highest natural point in San Francisco. Visitors to the park find striking panoramic views of the city, amidst a heavily forested backdrop.

The park is in the geographic center of the city, with Twin Peaks to the north and Glen Park to the east.

The park is also known for its large concrete cross, which is now owned by The Council of Armenian American Organizations of Northern California.

name: Historic Cannery Row Walking Tour
park: Aeneas Beach.Top trails nearbyMonterey Peninsula Recreational Trail and Asilomar Ave LoopMonterey Peninsula Recreational Trail and Asilomar Ave LoopPerkins Park4.7·Easy·6.6 km·Est. 1h 19mMonterey Bay Coastal TrailMonterey Bay Coastal TrailLovers Point Park4.7·Moderate·21.4 km·Est. 4h 10mMonterey Waterfront City WalkMonterey Waterfront City WalkLovers Point Park4.6·Easy·7.1 km·Est. 1h 19mAsilomar State Beach and Coast TrailAsilomar State Beach and Coast TrailAsilomar State Beach4.7·Easy·5.8 km·Est. 1h 13mShoreline Stroll TrailShoreline Stroll Trail4.6·Easy·15.4 km·Est. 2h 59mHuckleberry Hill LoopHuckleberry Hill LoopVeterans Memorial Park4.4·Moderate·2.9 km·Est. 1h 5mSpanish Bay TrailSpanish Bay TrailMoss Beach4.4·Easy·4.7 km·Est. 55mMonterey Bay Coastal Trail: Monterey Beach to Fort Ord DunesMonterey Bay Coastal Trail: Monterey Beach to Fort Ord DunesMonterey State Beach4.5·Moderate·20.4 km·Est. 4h 26mTwo Huckleberry Hill and Outer LoopTwo Huckleberry Hill and Outer LoopSFB Morse Botanical Reserve
description: Excellent walk exploring the historic Cannery Row made famous by the Nobel Prize winning author John Steinbeck. There are cannery buildings with facades restored to their original glory, worker shacks preserved in a state of arrested decay, a boardwalk with spectacular bay and wildlife views, 25 interpretive panels, several bronze commemorative statues, and ample restaurants offering the opportunity to take a break and enjoy some fresh seafood or local wine and cheese.

name: Camp Ohlone Road
description:
• Parking fee information: There is a fee to park at Sunol Wilderness Regional Preserve on weekends and holidays. For more information, please visit https://www.ebparks.org/parks/sunol

Trail Highlights: This hike is best done on a cool day as there is little shade. The route is an out-and-back on Camp Ohlone Road, a wide, uneven, dirt and gravel trail. The three pedestrian gates are accessible for people using wheelchairs. There are several very steep sections on this hike. The path follows the course of Alameda Creek with a scenic view at Alameda Creek Overlook.

Park Features: Chochenyo Ohlone- speaking Taunan peoples were this area’s first inhabitants. Later, since the 1860s, homesteaders ranched the land. Under the District's multi-use land management policy, cattle continue to graze many parts of the 6,859-acre wilderness. Today, picnicking, hiking, and backpacking attract thousands of park visitors a year. There is no drinking water in the park and poor cell phone reception.

Trail Directions: This hike begins at the far end of the road, past the park entrance kiosk. Go through the cattle gate at the end of the parking lot, cross the bridge, and begin following Camp Ohlone Road. Over the next mile, you’ll pass through two more gates before arriving at the Alameda Creek Overlook. There is a non-accessible vault toilet and picnic bench here. Continue on Camp Ohlone Road, heading up an incline, until you reach the park boundary. Turn around here and follow the same route back to the beginning.

name: Niles Community Park Loop
description:
This is a great path for kids. Turtles, geese, and ducks are often sighted along the path. 

Accessibility: 

Equipment
This trail is likely accessible for visitors using wheelchairs, mobility equipment, or strollers.

Parking
There are 2 designated van-accessible spaces with striped access aisles in the paved parking lot off 3rd Street at the trail's east end. 

Surface
The trail surface is paved concrete and smooth. It is typically at least 8 feet wide.

Grade
This trail is estimated to be mostly gentle (5% or less).

name: York Trail
description: Begin by hiking uphill through the forest along the stream. There is a small waterfall you will pass at one point. The trail has lots of exposed rocks and roots, so wearing good hiking shoes is recommended. It can also be slippery if it has recently rained. You will enter a clearing, from here views are looking back towards Oakland.

name: Townsprings, Harvey Bear, Coyote Ridge and Willow Springs Loop
park: Coyote Lake Harvey Bear Ranch County Park
description: • Parking Fee: Coyote Lake Harvey Bear Ranch County Park charges a fee to enter, except at Mendoza Ranch and Harvey Bear Entrances. There are varying fees depending on if you enter by vehicle, motorcycle, foot, horse, or bike. Please visit https://parks.santaclaracounty.gov/locations/coyote-lake-harvey-bear-ranch-county-park

name: Bald Knob Trail
park: Purisima Creek Redwoods Open Space Preserve
description: Begin from Tunitas Creek Road and start following the Grabtown Gulch Trail. Turn onto the Borden Hatch Mill Trail which leads to the Bald Knob Trail. Bald Knob continues uphill, eventually reaching the top of the trail's namesake. The trail is wooded and has plenty of shade, making it a good option on a hot day.

name: Twin Peaks
description:
• Partial closure: Parts of the Twin Peaks Trail are subject to closure due to construction projects, but you can still enjoy other sections of this trail. For more information, please visit https://sfrecpark.org/634/Twin-Peaks-Trails-Improvement-Promenade-

This is a must-visit for all visitors to and citizens of San Francisco. This hill is in the middle of the city, offering incredible views of the whole city. You can access it from all directions, not just the starting point shown here. There are several paved roads leading to the top, that can be driven, walked, or biked.

name: Yerba Buena to Halls Valley Trail Loop
description:
• Joseph D Grant County Park collects a day-use fee for vehicular entrance year-round. For more information, please see https://parks.sccgov.org/plan-your-visit/santa-clara-county-park-fees#3925188384-3236192913

One of the best hikes in the county park in the hills east of San Jose, California

It starts at Halls Valley Lake and climbs steeply into the nearby hills along the Yerba Buena Trail (with a highly recommended side trip to McCreery Lake). It turns at the Canada De Pala Trail and returns on the Halls Valley Trail. 

Along the way you'll see sweeping vistas of the nearby Diablo Range along with the observatories atop Mount Hamilton, the highest peak in the South Bay. Wildlife sightings are common: hikers have spotted coyotes, turkeys, bobcats, feral pigs, tarantulas and even the occasional mountain lion. 

In springtime, this is one of the best wildflower locales in the Bay Area. Summer's too hot but winter's great (if muddy) and fall is interesting when the tarantulas come out.   
 
The park sits on lands once owned by a prominent ranching family (hence the informal title "Grant Ranch"). The hiking can be arduous -- many of the rails were built for people on horses rather than on foot -- but what you can see along the way makes it worth every arduous step.

name: Goat Rock Overlook, Emily Smith Observation Point and Saratoga Gap
description:
• General fee: Castle Rock State Park charges a day-use fee to enter. For more information please visit https://www.parks.ca.gov/?page_id=538

This loop has some awesome overlooks of the Santa Cruz Mountains and even passes a waterfall overlook. The forest is scattered with large boulders that are fun to scramble on.

There are several trail junctions, so downloading the map ahead of time is recommended. The parking area is just off Skyline Boulevard.

name: Bernal Oak Woodland Loop
Dunn, Golden Spike, Monteiro, Baccharis, West Ridge and Graham Loop
description:
This stunning hike features a range of different terrain, panoramic views, and plenty of shade cover. Beginning from the Trudeau Conference Center on Skyline Blvd, you'll follow the relatively flat Golden Spike Trail before facing a steep incline on a single track through a lovely redwood forest until you reach Redwood Bowl.

There's a great picnic area at Redwood Bowl, which makes a great spot for a lunch break before returning via the pretty Graham Trail through the woods. At the end, you'll connect to the Dunn Trail, which has views of the Bay.

name: Peter Creek Falls
description: The trail is unmaintained and downloading offline maps is helpful.

name: Fern Trail, Spring Trail and Lookout Trail Loop
description:
Lookout Trail is NOT dog friendly. If you are doing this loop with a dog you will have to turn north on the western edge of the large prairie after Fern Trail onto Brayshaw Trail to connect back to the Spring Trail.

This scenic loop offers a connection between Henry Cowell Redwoods State Park, Pogonip, and the upper UCSC campus.

name: San Bruno Mountain Summit Loop Trail via Royce Way
description:
• San Bruno Mountain State Park charges a fee to enter. Fees are per vehicle. This park does not accept the California State Park Annual Day Use Pass. For more information, please visit https://parks.smcgov.org/fees-charges#vehicle.

The trailhead for this trip up to the summit of San Bruno Mountain is accessible by parking either along Chester St. or Atlanta St and walking to the end of Royce Way where it dead ends at the boundary of San Bruno Mountain State Park. The trail leading up to the summit loop is steep but rewarding. You'll pass a group of radio towers near the top.

name: Coyote Creek Trail: Metcalf Park to Hellyer County Park
park: Coyote Creek Trail: Metcalf Park to Hellyer County Park
description:
• Partial closure: The Coyote Creek Trail is closed between Hellyer Park and Embedded Way due to flooding and swiftly moving water, but you can still enjoy other sections of this trail. For more information, please visit https://parks.sccgov.org/closures-updates

The Coyote Creek Trail extends nineteen miles from San Francisco Bay to the southern end of San Jose. The multi-use trail is mostly paved with a short section of gravel. This route starts at Metcalf Park and heads northwest to Hellyer County Park, passing Coyote Pond and staying close to Coyote Creek. This is an incredibly scenic trail in an urban environment and offers traffic-free recreation. 

Accessibility:

Equipment
This trail is likely accessible for visitors using wheelchairs, mobility equipment, or strollers.

Parking
There do not appear to be any designated accessible parking spaces at the mapped trailhead, but there are 2 designated accessible parking spaces in each of the paved lots within Hellyer Park at the trail's north end.

Surface
The trail surface is paved asphalt with bumps and cracks and typically at least 8 feet wide. A painted dividing line along most of the trail reduces the width.

Grade
This trail is estimated to be mostly gentle (3% or less).

More Info
Accessible public restrooms are available in Hellyer Park.

name: Thornton State Beach to Phillip Burton Beach Loop
park: HikingGood viewsDog-friendlyParking lot was near capacity but trails not at all crowded on a cloudy weekend afternoon. Some horse poop from the trail riders. Gorgeous ocean views graced by the occasional paraglider/hanglider. No whales though. Also there are some steep/washed out parts so it’s difficult to do the loop exactly as AllTrails suggests esp in the southern end—would take it as a guideline not absolute.Park
description: Starting from Thornton State Beach Overlook, this loop heads north to Phillip Burton Memorial Beach, staying high along the sand dune. The sandy trails weave throughout the coastal sage scrub, with various options of connector trails. While this loop does not head to the beach, several side trails lead to the water.

name: Whitemore Gulch Trail and North Ridge Trail
park: Purisima Creek Redwoods Open Space Preserve
description: The trail takes you down the Whittemore Gulch Trail, which descends into the canyon and meets Purisima Creek at the bottom. Along this trail, you can see numerous mushrooms and banana slugs and enjoy the tranquil sounds of the creek. After exploring the creek, you'll be rewarded with breathtaking views of Half Moon Bay and the vast ocean. One of the hike's highlights is the expansive view from this ridge.

name: Saratoga, Travertine Springs, and Skyline Loop
description:
• General fee: Castle Rock State Park charges a day-use fee to enter. For more information please visit https://www.parks.ca.gov/?page_id=538

This is a shaded hike with a mix of forest and views of the surrounding area. There is a gun range nearby, so it is common to hear shooting while hiking around. Bug spray is recommended in the early summer. There are a few steady climbs along the way that make this trail a great workout. Bring plenty of water and snacks.

name: Best trails inCupertino
park: Lower Meadow Trail4.7(2691)•Moderate•6.8 km•Est. 1h 50mThis trail takes you to Rancho San Antonio Open Space Preserve
description:
Looking for the best walking trails in Cupertino? Whether you're getting ready to hike, cycle, trail run, or explore other outdoor pursuits, AllTrails has 53 picturesque trails in the Cupertino area. Discover hand-curated trail maps, along with reviews and photos from fellow outdoor enthusiasts.

Explore one of 18 easy walking routes in Cupertino, with child-friendly routes for your next family outing. Venture outdoors and learn more about the area's historic sites or take a break from the hustle and bustle along the many tree-lined paths surrounding Cupertino. Perfect for little feet, paws, walkers and outdoor enthusiasts of any skill level.

name: Jordan Pond via High Ridge and Dry Creek Trail
description:
• Parking fee information: There is a fee to park at Dry Creek Pioneer Regional Park. For more information, please visit https://www.ebparks.org/parks/garin-dry-creek

This trail takes you to Jordan Pond via High Ridge and Dry Creek Trail in Dry Creek Pioneer Regional Park. The trail winds through the golden California hills, climbing steeply, staying high along ridges, and passing through meadows with many cows. Parking with restrooms is available at the trailhead.

name: Redwood Loop
park: Purisima Creek Redwoods Open Space Preserve
description: The Redwood Trail is a small loop off the Purisima Creek Trail that offers a family-friendly singletrack adventure below a canopy of redwoods and among an understory of ferns. This is an excellent way to experience the mighty redwood trees that are so well-known in California. The trailhead is off Skyline Boulevard and has public bathrooms.

name: New Almaden Trail
description:
• Partial closure: As of June 2, 2025,  part of this route is temporarily inaccessible, but you can still enjoy other sections of this trail. For more information, please visit https://parks.santaclaracounty.gov/locations/almaden-quicksilver-county-park

The New Almaden Trail is a great trail for trail running - single track, rolling hills, not too strenuous. The trail is mostly shaded, but still plan to bring plenty of water, especially in the summer months. Keep an eye out for wildflowers in the late spring and early summer. There are amazing views along the way.

name: Coyote Ridge and Mummy Mountain Trail
park: Coyote Lake Harvey Bear Ranch County Park
description:
• Parking Fee: Coyote Lake Harvey Bear Ranch County Park charges a fee to enter, except at Mendoza Ranch and Harvey Bear Entrances. There are varying fees depending on if you enter by vehicle, motorcycle, foot, horse, or bike. Please visit https://parks.santaclaracounty.gov/locations/coyote-lake-harvey-bear-ranch-county-park

The Mummy Mountain Trail starts gradually in the green highlands. As you proceed, the trail switches between open grasslands and wooded regions. The trail gradually levels off as the climb gets steeper. Wide, level meadows bursting with springtime wildflowers can be seen atop Mummy Mountain. A picnic table and a bench at the lookout are ideal places to relax and enjoy the view.

As you continue, the trail meanders through a sparsely forested area to Coyote Ridge, where there are views of Coyote Lake from tree slits. You'll come across old oaks and their remnants along the route, which offer cover and shelter to various avian species and small mammals like skunks, bobcats, and opossums.

name: Hickory Oak Ridge Trail Loop
description: The trail begins at the preserve's entrance and gently ascends through a picturesque landscape of oak woodlands, meadows, and mixed forests. The route offers a peaceful escape, as hikers move through shaded areas, with towering trees and the scent of pine and wildflowers in the air. As you trek along the Hickory Oak Ridge Trail Loop, you’ll encounter several stunning viewpoints that provide panoramic views of the Santa Clara Valley and the surrounding mountain ridges. On clear days, you can also enjoy distant views of San Francisco Bay and the Pacific Ocean in the distance.

name: De Anza Trail Cupertino Segment
park: De Anza Trail Cupertino Segment is a city walk.Top trails nearbySeven Springs LoopSeven Springs LoopFremont Older Open Space Preserve4.7·Moderate·2.8 mi·Est. 1h 23mRainbow Knoll and Hunter's Point via Seven Springs LoopRainbow Knoll and Hunter's Point via Seven Springs LoopFremont Older Open Space Preserve4.6·Moderate·3.7 mi·Est. 1h 47mMaisie's Peak and Nob Hill Extended LoopMaisie's Peak and Nob Hill Extended LoopFremont Older Open Space Preserve4.5·Moderate·6.1 mi·Est. 2h 51mMaisie's Peak and Nob Hill from Prospect  ParkingMaisie's Peak and Nob Hill from Prospect  ParkingFremont Older Open Space Preserve4.6·Moderate·4.3 mi·Est. 2h 5mHunter's Point and Older Pet Cemetary LoopHunter's Point and Older Pet Cemetary LoopFremont Older Open Space Preserve4.7·Easy·2.0 mi·Est. 58mHayfield Trail to Toyon and Bay View LoopHayfield Trail to Toyon and Bay View LoopFremont Older Open Space Preserve
description: This bike path is a segment of the Juan Bautista de Anza National Scenic Trail. It connects to Joe's Trail, which is also part of the de Anza National Historic Trail. There is a small parking area and trailhead for this segment that can be accessed off of Saratoga-Sunnyvale Road just south of Sea Gull Way.

name: Randol Creek Trail
description: Cathedral Oaks Park has a paved bike path that extends north along Randol Creek. The seasonal arroyo fosters a thriving wildlife habitat, and the trail offers scenic and traffic-free recreation. The route stops at the beginning of a private road. Please turn around here and stay on public trails. There are no services at the park. Bring plenty of water and sun protection.

name: Dunn, Stream, Graham Trail Loop
description:
This loop follows the Dunn, Golden Spike, Tate, West Ridge, Orchard, Bridle, Stream, Tres Senda, Starflower, Madrone, West Ridge, Graham, and Dunn Trails Loop.

This hike showcases every aspect of the park. It begins above a large meadow, then drops down into oak and bay woodlands before climbing over streams and through redwoods, with views of the valley along the way. Golden Spike Trail and Tate Trail in particular have gorgeous valley views. After descending from West Ridge Trail to parallel Redwood Creek, enjoy the picnic areas and redwood groves along the Stream Trail. Additionally, Graham and Dunn Trails at the end of the hike both have points at which they overlook the bay.

name: Central Park Loop
description:
This is a beautiful inner-city park trail with lots of ducks and geese.

Accessibility: There are 4 designated accessible spaces in the paved parking lot off of Patricia Drive at the east end of the trail. All of them are van-accessible with striped access aisles. The trail surface is paved concrete or asphalt and smooth. It is typically at least 8 feet wide. 

The whole trail is estimated to be in the flat (1% or less) grade category. This trail will likely be navigable for most wheelchairs/mobility equipment or stroller users. There are benches and picnic tables along the route for resting.

name: Highlands Summit Loop Trail
description: The Highlands Community has a public trail network open to cycling and foot recreation. The trails pass through oak forests and open grassy areas dotted with sage. The views are beautiful, and there is plenty of shade when temperatures are hot. The parking lot is off Lexington Avenue, but you can also enter on foot at Bunker Hill Drive.

name: Bay Trail: San Francisco - Oakland Bay Bridge
park: Bay Trail: San Francisco - Oakland Bay Bridge is near Radio Beach and Toll Plaza Beach.Top trails nearbyLake MerrittLake MerrittLakeside Park4.6·Easy·5.0 km·Est. 55mShoreline Trail: Salt Marsh OverlookShoreline Trail: Salt Marsh OverlookRobert W. Crown Memorial State Beach4.5·Easy·7.1 km·Est. 1h 17mBay Bridge TrailBay Bridge TrailJudge John Sutter Regional Shoreline4.5·Moderate·9.0 km·Est. 1h 51mSan Francisco Bay Trail: Emeryville to Richmond Inner HarborSan Francisco Bay Trail: Emeryville to Richmond Inner HarborMcLaughlin Eastshore State Park4.6·Easy·15.1 km·Est. 2h 45mBay Trail LoopBay Trail LoopMcLaughlin Eastshore State Park4.5·Easy·4.8 km·Est. 53mRincon Park to Crissy FieldRincon Park to Crissy FieldGolden Gate National Recreation Area4.7·Easy·16.7 km·Est. 3h 9mFerry Building to Lands End and Ocean BeachFerry Building to Lands End and Ocean BeachGolden Gate National Recreation Area4.8·Moderate·18.7 km·Est. 4h 7mCrab Cove Visitor Center to USS Hornet: SF Bay TrailCrab Cove Visitor Center to USS Hornet: SF Bay TrailRobert W. Crown Memorial State Beach4.4·Easy·1.3 km·Est. 14mMiddle Harbor Shoreline to Portview ParkMiddle Harbor Shoreline to Portview ParkMiddle Harbor Shoreline Park
description:
This is a segment of the San Francisco Bay Trail: a 500 mile long mile trail around the Bay. This is the 11th section of the Bay Trail. The Bay Trail is currently under construction, but will ultimately take pedestrians across the San Francisco - Oakland Bay Bridge. There is currently no way to complete the route along the Bridge from Treasure Island to San Francisco, but trail construction is in progress. If you wish to reach San Francisco from Treasure Island instead of going back to Oakland, you can take bus 25. 

For more information, visit: https://mtc.ca.gov/operations/regional-trails-parks/san-francisco-bay-trail/bay-trail-navigational-map

In 1955, the American Society of Civil Engineers honored the San Francisco Oakland Bay Bridge as one of the seven “Modern Civil Engineering Wonders” of the world. At first, the bridge carried autos on its top deck, and trucks, buses, and two tracks for the Key System rail service on the lower deck. In 1958, the rails were removed and both levels were assigned to motor vehicles. Today, the Bay has been transformed with the new east span of the San Francisco Oakland Bay Bridge. 

Rising over the bay between Oakland and Yerba Buena Island, a self-anchored suspension span extends for 2.2 miles with a single signature tower. Following damage to the east span as a result of the Loma Prieta Earthquake in 1989, it was determined that the existing span would be completely replaced. Under construction since 2002, the new bridge opened in 2013 with a 15-foot-wide bicycle and pedestrian path on its southern edge. Take the four mile Bay Bridge Trail from the entryway off Shellmound Street in Emeryville to Yerba Buena Island and gaze up at the aweinspiring tower of the new Bay Bridge. 

Work to plan, design, and complete the bicycle/pedestrian connection between Yerba Buena Island and San Francisco on the West Span of the Bay Bridge is underway. Where the bridge lands in Oakland, a future regional park, known as Judge John Sutter Regional Shoreline, is being planned to welcome travelers to the East Bay and to serve as an entry point for the bridge pathway.

East Span Bay Bridge Tower Treasure Island was created with bay fill in the late 1930s, and was the site for the 1939–40 Golden Gate International Exposition or World's Fair. Some 4,000 trees and 2 million flowering plants were planted for the occasion. Many of the palms and varieties of eucalyptus are still alive. Future redevelopment plans include a mix of residential, hotel, marinas, restaurants, retail and entertainment venues—plus nearly 300 acres of parks and open space. With this project, a new segment of the Bay Trail will encircle the island and connect to the Bay Bridge pathway. Two segments of Bay Trail currently exist on Treasure Island and are worth a visit.

name: Jones, Novitiate, Range and Manzanita Trail
park: St. Joseph'S Hill Open Space Preserve
description: This trail begins at the end of Jones Road and leads into St. Joseph's Hill Open Space Preserve. It's primarily uphill for the first half of the journey, providing a nice workout before descending via the Manzanita Trail. From the top, there's a nice view of the lake. Along the way, there's a good mix of shade and sun and lots of options for extending your journey. These trails are popular with mountain bikers and hikers, so stay alert and share the space.

name: Edgewood Trail Loop
description: The Edgewood loop trail runs east to west on the northern side of Edgewood Park. The trail has junctions with the Franciscan Trail and Serpentine Loop for options to explore more. Starting from the east, in the Day Camp parking lot, one has a strenuous first half mile with an approx. 9.5% uphill grade.

name: Best trails inSanta Clara
park: Top trails1#1 - San Tomas Aquino Creek Trail: Souza Park to Agnew Road4.4(345)•Easy•6.1 km•Est. 1h 11mThis section of the San Tomas Aquino Creek trail begins at Everett N. "Eddie" Souza Park
description:
Looking for the best walking trails in Santa Clara? Whether you're getting ready to hike, cycle, trail run, or explore other outdoor pursuits, AllTrails has 4 picturesque trails in the Santa Clara area. Discover hand-curated trail maps, along with reviews and photos from fellow outdoor enthusiasts.

Explore one of 4 easy walking routes in Santa Clara, with child-friendly routes for your next family outing. Venture outdoors and learn more about the area's historic sites or take a break from the hustle and bustle along the many tree-lined paths surrounding Santa Clara. Perfect for little feet, paws, walkers and outdoor enthusiasts of any skill level.

name: Sylvan Park Loop
description: Discover this 0.4-mile loop trail near Mountain View, California. Generally considered an easy route, it takes an average of 7 min to complete. This trail is great for hiking, running, and walking, and it's unlikely you'll encounter many other people while exploring. The best times to visit this trail are January through November. Dogs are welcome, but must be on a leash.

name: Stevens Creek Nature Trail Loop
description: The Stevens Creek Nature Trail Loop offers an quick escape into the Santa Cruz Mountains. The trail follows Stevens Creek, passing through shaded areas and open meadows, making it a peaceful hike with plenty of opportunities to spot wildlife and take in the views along the way. It’s a great spot for a short, relaxing walk close to the bay area, perfect for those looking to enjoy some fresh air without venturing too far.

name: Whispering Creek, Shady Canyon, and Ridgetop Loop
park: Chabot-Garin Regional Trail. This path will take you to Five Canyons Park
description:
• Partial closure: The Whispering Creek Trail is temporarily inaccessible due to storm damage, but you can still enjoy other sections of this trail. For more information, please visit https://www.ebparks.org/parks/don-castro

This trail takes you through two park areas, each very different from the other. The route offers varied terrain, including a walk along an old reservoir as well as a climb up a ridge that provides stunning views of the Bay Area. The hike back to Don Castro winds along a shaded creek, a welcome respite from the sunny ridge.

From the Don Castro main parking lot, head towards the entrance and the entry kiosk. Continue past the kiosk, following the sidewalk across the bridge until you come to the Whispering Creek Trail on your left. Follow Whispering Creek Trail along the lake for .41 mile. 

At the fork, keep left and continue for .24 mile following the shoreline. At the next signpost, keep right and follow signs for Chabot-to-Garin Regional Trail. At the bridge, keep straight; do not cross. Continue until you come to a paved road; turn left, following the Chabot-Garin Regional Trail. 

At the Private Property sign, make a right to continue on Chabot-Garin Regional Trail. This path will take you to Five Canyons Parkway. Make a right and cross safely at the first crosswalk. Turn right, then walk about 50 feet. Enter Five Canyons on your left, following signs for Chabot-Garin Regional Trail. 

After .51 mile, cross through the cattle gate and make a left onto the paved fire road. Keep to the shoulder and climb for .31 mile. At the top, the paved road becomes gravel. Cross through the cattle gate and continue for .54 mile, then make a right onto Shady Canyon Trail. 

At the next intersection, turn right to stay on Shady Canyon Trail. At the sign for Deer Canyon Trail, make a right again to stay on Shady Canyon Trail. Head straight, crossing Canyon Terrace Drive safely. Continue for about 400 feet, then cross Boulder Canyon Drive and follow the paved trail through Ridge Trail Park. 

After exiting the park, make a sharp left to continue to follow Shady Canyon Trail. Once you reach the sidewalk, turn left. Continue until you reach the “fire trail” gate, then head left down Chabot-Garin Regional Trail. Turn left at the private property sign. 

After about 200 feet, make a right, following signs for Chabot-Garin Regional Trail. Cross the bridge to your right, then head left to follow Ridgetop Trail. At the next fork, keep right to continue on Ridgetop. Come to a gate, cross through it, then head left to return to
the parking lot.

name: Waterwheel Trail
description: • Access Information: A permit is required to park at this trailhead. For more information, please visit https://www.openspace.org/where-to-go/permits/general-access-permit

name: John S Brooks Memorial Trail Loop
park: What are some of the facilities available for John S Brooks Memorial Trail Loop?Park
description:
A short but sweet loop that is popular with mountain bikers in the area.

Take the Lake Road, Berry, Chaparral, Canyon Creek, Ohlone, Elevator, and Johns Brook Trail. The loop has a few climbs and is mostly shaded. Some trail junctions are not well marked, so downloading the map ahead of time is helpful.

name: Dimond Park and Sausal Creek Loop
description: This scenic trail starts in Dimond Park in the south and travels north through dense woods along Sausal Creek. The route stays close to the creek with a slight incline for over a mile until it makes a tight switchback on Old Cañon Trail. Watch for all the birds and other wildlife in the scrub and around the creek.

name: Figueroa and Cottle Loop Trail
description:
A loop hike that explores the wonders of Calero Reservoir County Park. This hike offers views of the reservoirs and great overlooks of the surrounding park, which are great rewards after the section of elevation gain.  This is a really spectacular trail that varies a lot throughout and makes for a great option for runners, dog walkers and hikers.
The trail is popular among mountain bikers, too, so please be aware of them.

name: Martin Murphy Loop
park: Coyote Lake Harvey Bear Ranch County Park

name: Kings Canyon to Upper San Leandro Reservoir
description:
• Access information: All visitors must obtain a permit before hiking this area. For more information, please visit https://www.ebmud.com/recreation/buy-trail-permit/

All visitors must obtain a permit before hiking this area. More information here: https://www.ebmud.com/recreation/buy-trail-permit/

name: Presidio and Baker Beach Loop
description:
• Access Information: Part of this route is temporarily closed to dog walking to reduce the potential for coyote/dog conflict, but you can still enjoy other sections of this trail. For information, please visit https://presidio.gov/about/sustainability/coyotes-in-the-presidio

Park near the Presidio Arguello Gate, and hike alongside the Presidio Golf Course to the Mountain Lake.  From there, loop around the lake, walk under the Veterans Blvd and follow the Park Boulevard Trail.  Once you've passed The Presidio Landmark, head down the sandy Lobos Creek Valley Path and cross the El Camino del Mar road.  

You will now be heading toward the Coastal Trail, which leads you - while walking on a sandy path - along Baker Beach.  The Coastal Trail then winds up and down, following northward the coast.  Be prepared to climb multiple-step stairways up and down along the way until you reach the Golden Gate Overlook near the Golden Gate Bridge. You will be passing several Battery stations built around 1900 and mostly active until the early 1940s. 

To return to the Arguello Gate, you follow the path to Kobbe Ave and then take the Park Trail up the hill to the Cemetery Overlook, and from there along the Golf Course to the gate.

name: Hacienda and Virl O Norton Loop
description: This trail is one of many different ones in the park. The park includes over 37 miles of hiking trails, including 30 miles of equestrian trails and 16.6 miles of bike trails. All trails in the park are also open to pet owners to walk their dogs on leash. For more information visit: https://www.sccgov.org/sites/parks/parkfinder/pages/almadenpark.aspx

name: Sierra Vista and Calaveres Fault Trail
description:
• Partial Closure: The Lower Calaveras Fault Trail is temporarily inaccessible, but you can still enjoy other sections of this trail. See https://www.openspaceauthority.org/preserves/sierra.html for more information. 

The preserve is home to diverse flora and fauna, including wildflowers like lupines and California poppies in spring, and golden grasses in summer. Wildlife sightings are common and may include hawks, deer, bobcats, and a variety of smaller mammals and birds. The views from the trail’s higher points, especially at sunrise or sunset, are breathtaking, with sweeping vistas of the surrounding valleys and mountains.

name: Buena Vista, New Almaden, and Randol Trail
description: Almaden Quicksilver County Park includes over 37 miles of hiking trails, including 30 miles of equestrian trails and 16.6 miles of bike trails. All trails in the park are also open to pet owners to walk their dogs on leash. For more information visit: https://www.sccgov.org/sites/parks/parkfinder/pages/almadenpark.aspx

name: Best trails inSanta Cruz
park: Take the Big Ben Trail to the Fall Creek Trail and return via the Lost Empire Trail.4#4 - Natural Bridges to Lighthouse Field Trail4.5(981)•Easy•7.7 km•Est. 1h 28mExplore tide pools and beach habitat at Natural Bridges State Park
description:
Looking for the best hiking trails in Santa Cruz? Whether you're getting ready to hike, bike, trail run, or explore other outdoor activities, AllTrails has 107 scenic trails in the Santa Cruz area. Enjoy hand-curated trail maps, along with reviews and photos from nature lovers like you.

Explore one of 50 easy hiking trails in Santa Cruz or discover kid-friendly routes for your next family trip. Check out some trails with historic sights or adventure through the nature areas surrounding Santa Cruz that are perfect for hikers and outdoor enthusiasts at any skill level.

name: Quarry Park Loop
description: This loop follows the Quarry and Vista Point Trail. The trails are both wide, well-defined, and easy to follow. The loop is mostly wooded and passes a rock garden on the way back to the trailhead. The area is very popular with mountain bikers, so expect to run into several different user groups out on the trail.

name: Lower Meadow, Rogue Valley, Wildcat Loop, Farm Bypass, and Coyote
park: Rancho San Antonio Open Space Preserve
description: The hike starts with a gentle terrain. After crossing a bridge, you'll continue on a broad walk that borders a massive California bay tree and passes by a vast grassy meadow and picnic area. The trail becomes narrower and winds uphill through grasslands and oaks, with a bench beneath a coast live oak providing a pleasant place to relax. The trail also winds alongside a creek. Hikers in this area should be cautious of poison oak. Wildlife enthusiasts can see deer, turkeys, bobcats, quails, and coyotes.

name: Merry-Go-Round, Bayview, and Sprig Trails Loop
description:
• General fee: Mount Madonna County Park charges a fee to enter. For more information, please visit https://parks.sccgov.org/plan-your-visit/santa-clara-county-park-fees

Initial up-hill on Merry-Go-Round doesn't offer much shade and is fairly steep.  Coming back down along Sprig Trail has more cover.  Nice hike of about 4.5 hours for a non-avid hiker.  Several places to stop along the way for bathroom breaks or picnic lunch.  Horses accepted on first 4 miles or so of the loop, but then it is hiking only.

name: Tidelands Trail Loop
park:
A visitor center in Fremont and the Environmental Education Center in Alviso provide information about the refuge and how to explore it.

At the Fremont location there’s an accessible fishing pier at the end of Marshlands Road; from there you can also pick up a section of the Bay Trail that crosses the approximately 1.5-mile Dumbarton Bridge to San Mateo County. From Marshlands Road you can also follow the Quarry Trail to Coyote Hills Regional Park
description:
According to Access Northern California (http://accessnca.org/access-northern-california/explore/explore-detail-view/?site_id=174): The Don Edwards San Francisco Bay National Wildlife Refuge, the first and largest urban national wildlife refuge in the United States, is just one piece of the larger San Francisco Bay National Wildlife Refuge Complex. Encompassing 30,000 acres, the Don Edwards refuge consists primarily of tidal marsh, salt ponds, mud flats, and seasonal wetlands. It provides habitat for nine species of federally listed threatened or endangered species, including the salt marsh harvest mouse, California clapper rail, and western snowy plover, and is home to 227 species of birds. As a safe haven for vast numbers of birds traveling the Pacific Flyway, it is a prime destination for bird watching.

Public entry points for visiting Don Edwards are at its headquarters at the refuge's north end in Fremont, and at Alviso, which is around the southern tip of San Francisco Bay. More than 30 miles of trails lead along sloughs and past salt ponds on San Francisco Bay that are being restored to a mix of habitats. Depending on the season and the stage of salt development, the water ranges in color from green to mauve. A visitor center in Fremont and the Environmental Education Center in Alviso provide information about the refuge and how to explore it.

At the Fremont location there’s an accessible fishing pier at the end of Marshlands Road; from there you can also pick up a section of the Bay Trail that crosses the approximately 1.5-mile Dumbarton Bridge to San Mateo County. From Marshlands Road you can also follow the Quarry Trail to Coyote Hills Regional Park via a bridge that crosses Highway 84.

Accessibility: There are firm, designated accessible parking spaces with a 2% slope or less at the visitor center, in the large lot behind it, and at the end of Marshlands Rd by the fishing pier. The trail surface is loose dirt/gravel and it is typically at least four feet wide.

Before starting out on the trail, you can travel a short distance up a very steep service road to a platform with broad views of the marshlands, salt ponds, sloughs, and Bay. Further uphill are more trails, but they have very steep grades. To begin your hike, from the service road travel a few hundred feet downhill to a trail junction and an accessible picnic area overlooking the marsh. For the most wheelchair accessible route, follow the Tidelands Trail to the right.

Continue following signs for the Tidelands Trail, then cross an accessible long wooden bridge over Newark Slough to the junction with Newark Slough Trail. Here an abandoned hunting lodge has interpretive panels. At this junction, the trail is named both Newark Slough and Tidelands. Traveling in either direction, the 5.2-mile Newark Slough levee loop trail follows the curving path of Newark Slough around salt ponds and tidal marshes. Refuge staff advise that sections of the loop are inaccessible due to overgrown vegetation and narrow dirt passages. You can follow it to the left for 0.25 miles to another accessible wooden bridge, then travel uphill and reconnect with the Tidelands Trail. Here you can turn left and follow the trail 0.25 miles back to the start, or turn right to connect to the Harrier Spur Trail.

As the trail curves inland, noise dissipates, the East Bay hills come into view. In less than 0.3 miles you reach the Harrier Spur Trail, which the map says is accessible. However, it has a steep approach so you may want to follow the signs for Tidelands Trail back to the start instead.

The visitor center is wheelchair accessible. There are accessible restrooms outside the visitor center and accessible portable toilets halfway out to the fishing pier and by the picnic tables and overlook at the start of the lower Tidelands Trail. There are accessible picnic tables with a firm and stable path and surface and at least 27 inches of knee clearance at the visitor center, the trail junction for the Learning Center and Tidelands Trail, and the Learning Center. Halfway along the boardwalk over Newark Slough, an area that juts out over the marsh has a few tables, and there is one past the second bridge crossing.

name: Mosaic Pig, Matadero and Page Mill Loop
description: This easily accessible trail begins just off Three Forks Lane, near the Pandemonium Aviaries Sculpture. The trail follows a wide path through the neighborhood and along a small vineyard. The trail is mostly forested and sometimes opens up to provide views of the San Francisco Bay. This loop is a great hike for the whole family!

name: Bay Area Ridge Trail: San Francisco Peninsula Watershed
description:
• Access Information: This area is only accessible during a
docent-led outing. For more information please visit: https://webapps.sfpuc.org/trails

In this remote open space, dedicated volunteers will lead you through dense forests and over hilly grasslands with extensive views of the entire Bay Area. This trip is a unique opportunity to experience the 23,000-acre watershed, a state Fish and Game Refuge and home to the highest concentration of rare, threatened, and endangered species in the Bay Area. The pristine property contains Crystal Springs, Pilarcitos, and San Andreas Reservoirs.

The SF Crystal Springs Watershed trail is only accessible by reservation, with a docent-led group. The Skylawn Memorial Park Ridge Trail is open during regular business hours (approximately 7AM – 6PM). Docents are not required as long as you stay on the cemetery property.

Restrooms can be found every two miles from the trailhead. For more information on mountain biking and horseback riding, talk with the team at sfwater.org.

For more information, see the Bay Area Ridge Trail page here: https://ridgetrail.org/san-francisco-watershed-skylawn-trail/

name: Sawyer Camp Trail: San Andreas Lake to Lower Crystal Springs Reservoir
description:
A lovely, paved family stroll with a little incline and a scenic lake view. The Sawyer Camp Segment continues southeast for another 3 miles past this end of this route. The full Sawyer Camp Trail can be found here: https://www.alltrails.com/trail/us/california/sawyer-camp-trail. 

Accessibility: There do not appear to be any designated accessible spaces in the paved parking lot off of Hillcrest Boulevard at the north end of the trail. The trail surface is paved asphalt and smooth. It is typically 3 to 7 feet wide with some wider passing spaces. There is a painted dividing line along the trail which reduces the width. There is a gate across the trail at the start and the estimated width to go through it is 3 feet. 

The majority of the trail is estimated to be in the mostly gentle grade category (5% or less) but there is a steeper section from about 0.0 through 1.1 miles when going south. According to the park website, this trail is wheelchair-accessible. Trail goers using wheelchairs/mobility equipment or strollers may need assistance in the steeper section or to avoid it for safety. There are benches and picnic tables along the route for resting. There are wheelchair-accessible bathrooms along the trail.

name: Las Palmas Park
description: Las Palmas Park is a Polynesian-themed park that features palm trees, a pond, and a "tropical island" playground in the center of the pond. There are picnic areas, a dog park, and paved paths for walking and jogging. This is a unique place to enjoy outdoor recreation in an otherwise dense suburban neighborhood.

name: Woodland Star Trail to Bowl Loop
description:
• Seasonal closure: This area is subject to seasonal closure due to weather conditions. For more information, please visit https://www.cityofpaloalto.org/News-Articles/Community-Services/Pearson-Arastradero-Preserve-Seasonal-Trails-Status

The Pearson-Arastradero Preserve has miles of trails open to hiking and biking. This specific loop is on multi-use trails, but the Bowl Loop Trail is designed with cyclists in mind, and this loop would probably be most fun for mountain bikes. A small trailhead on Arastradero Road is the beginning of the Juan Bautista de Anza Trail.

name: San Leandro Creek Trail West and San Francisco Bay Trail Loop
park:
HikingGreat for families
Nice and easyShow activityHit the trail Frequently asked questionsWhat are some of the facilities available for San Leandro Creek Trail West and San Francisco Bay Trail Loop?Enter the Park
description: Dogs must remain on a leash because the park is part of the Pacific Flyway for migrating birds.
