name: Los Gatos Creek Trail: Fruitdale to Los Gatos
park: Los Gatos Creek Trail: Fruitdale to Los Gatos is paved.Top trails nearbyLos Gatos Creek Trail: Camden Ponds to Vasona ReservoirLos Gatos Creek Trail: Camden Ponds to Vasona ReservoirLos Gatos Creek Park4.5·Easy·5.4 mi·Est. 1h 39mLos Gatos Creek Trail: Campbell Park to Meridian AvenueLos Gatos Creek Trail: Campbell Park to Meridian AvenueCampbell Park4.5·Easy·2.3 mi·Est. 42mLos Gatos Creek Park and Lexington Reservoir via Los Gatos Creek TrailLos Gatos Creek Park and Lexington Reservoir via Los Gatos Creek TrailLos Gatos Creek Park4.6·Moderate·12.7 mi·Est. 4h 8mCommunications Hill TrailCommunications Hill Trail4.6·Easy·1.4 mi·Est. 33mGuadalupe River Park TrailGuadalupe River Park TrailGuadalupe River Park4.0·Easy·9.5 mi·Est. 2h 52mCamden Pond LoopCamden Pond Loop4.5·Easy·1.5 mi·Est. 27mSan Tomas Aquino Creek Trail: Souza Park to Agnew RoadSan Tomas Aquino Creek Trail: Souza Park to Agnew Road4.4·Easy·3.8 mi·Est. 1h 11mCentral Park LoopCentral Park LoopCentral Park4.1·Easy·1.8 mi·Est. 32mBay Area Ridge Trail: Coyote Creek Parkway NorthBay Area Ridge Trail: Coyote Creek Parkway North4.1·Easy·12.8 mi·Est. 3h 55mCoyote Creek TrailCoyote Creek TrailHellyer County Park3.8·Moderate·21.6 mi·Est. 6h 34mMission Santa Clara de AsisMission Santa Clara de Asis4.5·Easy·0.9 mi·Est. 16mJapanese Friendship GardenJapanese Friendship GardenKelley Park
description:
• Seasonal closure: Vasona Lake County Park is subject to seasonal closure during the wintertime and wet weather due to weather conditions. For more information, please visit https://parks.sccgov.org/closures-updates

A paved greenway paralleling Los Gatos Creek.

Accessibility: 

Equipment
Visitors using wheelchairs, mobility equipment, or strollers may need all-terrain tires or adaptive/motorized equipment for the surface type and grade.

Parking
There are 4 designated van-accessible spaces with striped access aisles in the paved parking lot off Saint Elizabeth Drive at the northeast end of the trail. 

Surface
The trail surface is asphalt, cement, or wooden bridge (with railings), and typically at least 5 feet wide. A painted dividing line along most of the trail reduces the width.

Grade
This trail is estimated to be mostly gentle (5% or less), with some steeper sections that may require assistance or need to be avoided.

More Info
Picnic tables and benches are available along the route for resting.

name: Arana Gulch Loop
Fort Point - Baker Beach Coast Trail
park: What are some of the facilities available for Fort Point - Baker Beach Coast Trail?Park
description:
The Baker Beach Coast Trail meanders amongst the bluffs above Baker Beach and has a stunning view of the Golden Gate Bridge, and the Marin Headlands.  Start from the Fort Point National Historical Site. The East and West Gun Batteries were built in 1873 and stocked with cannons for coastal defense.

Be aware that a portion of Baker Beach is a nude beach.

name: Maisie Peak and Nob Hill
description: This lovely trail leads hikers up to Maise's Peak and then across to Nob Hill. The first section is a relatively steep incline that is mostly shaded. The trail here is narrow and can be overgrown with poison ivy, so long pants are recommended. After the incline, the trail becomes wider and more exposed to the sun. There are beautiful views along the way and a bench to rest on at Nob Hill. The trail begins and ends at the parking lot on Stevens Canyon Road.

name: Presidio Ecology Trail
description: The Presidio Ecology Trail is a short pathway that travels between Arguello Gate and the Presidio's Main Post. This short hike through the woods also has a small detour to Inspiration Point with views of the Bay and Alcatraz. While short, the trail is home to many diverse habitats such as serpentine grasslands as well as groves of redwoods eucalyptus, Monterey pine, Monterey cypress and oak trees. Since the trail is located within the Presidio's largest watershed, the Tennessee Hollow, there are many different animal species to be found including humming birds and a variety of butterflies.

name: Arastradero Lake Via Juan Batista de Anza and Wild Rye Trails
description:
This is a pleasant trail in Enid Pearson-Arastradero Preserve. It starts at Pearson/Arastradero Preserve Parking and is popular with mountain bikers. 
The trail offers varied scenery including rolling savanna grasslands, broadleaf evergreen forests, and a small lake. 

Along the way, visitors will be treated to beautiful sweeping views of the surrounding area. There is plenty of wildlife to see here, too. Keep an eye out for deer, rabbits, and birds. Wildflowers such as poppies and lupines add color to the surrounding landscape in spring.

name: Tony Look to Coyote Ridge Loop
description: The Tony Look to Coyote Ridge Loop adjoins a lake and winds through a forest, providing panoramic views of the valley. The trail is well-maintained. As you progress, you'll enjoy views of the reservoir and expansive vistas of San Jose. Be mindful of the thorny vegetation that lines parts of the trail. Along the way, you can also appreciate the local flora and fauna.

name: Bayside/Joinville Park
description: This route follows paved paths and connects Joinville Park and Bayside Park. It travels along the Marina Lagoon before crossing a scenic bridge over the Seal Slough to end at Anchor Park. There is access to a playground, athletic fields, picnic areas, and bathrooms. Seal Point Park is within walking distance and can be added to your route.

name: Deep Gulch, English Camp, Castillero and Mine Hill Trail Loop
description: Almaden Quicksilver County Park includes over 37 miles of hiking trails, including 30 miles of equestrian trails and 16.6 miles of bike trails. All trails in the park are also open to pet owners to walk their dogs on leash. For more information visit: https://www.sccgov.org/sites/parks/parkfinder/pages/almadenpark.aspx

name: Hawk Ridge, Alder Spring, Charquin, Ancient Oaks, and Bo Gimbal Loop
description: This is a lovely scenic trail in Russian Ridge Open Space Preserve. The hike begins from the parking lot off Skyline Boulevard, where parking is limited. Along the way visitors will be treated to panoramic views with expansive vistas out to the ocean. The trail mostly runs along exposed ridges with some shaded parts. Watch out for rattlesnakes sunning near the trail.

name: Stream View, Red Tail Hawk, and Grey Fox Loop
park: Bishop Ranch Regional Open Space Preserve
description:
This route is an option for hikers only. There are no bikes permitted on this loop. 

Park Features: Bishop Ranch is a serene parkland located on 806 acres in San Ramon. Watch for deer, red-tailed hawks, and turkey vultures while you enjoy lovely views of open skies and Mount Diablo to the northeast. Hiking, jogging, kite flying, dog walking, and picnicking are some of the activities to be enjoyed on this ridgetop refuge.

Trail Highlights: The seasonal creek is active in the winter months and into spring, depending on rainfall. Enjoy the pleasant groves of oak trees sprawling throughout the park. Delight in views of the San Ramon, Dublin, and Pleasanton valleys, with Mount Diablo as the backdrop. There are no restroom facilities, so plan ahead.

Trail Directions: Begin southwest on Grey Fox Trail. Walk .06 miles and take the first right onto Stream View Trail. The trail splits off around the bottom of the seasonal creek: keep to the path left/southwest of the creek (though either route will lead back to the same trail). There is a brief uphill section before the hiker-only section of the Stream View meets the wider multi-use section of Stream View. Take a right at that junction and continue along Stream View above and parallel to the creek. The last section of Stream View Trail heads steeply uphill, away from the creek, gaining an elevation of about 400 feet. Atop this small hill, *turn left onto Redtail Hawk Trail. Follow the trail for .18 miles, turning left onto Grey Fox Trail to finish the loop. This final stretch of the hike will take you back to the start and grace you with sweeping views of Mount Diablo to the northeast.

*If you would like to extend your hike, turn right onto Redtail Hawk Trail. This is an out-and-back hike which adds 1.48 miles total to your hike.

Park Curfew/Hours: 5 a.m. to 10 p.m.

name: Skyway and Bay Trail [PRIVATE PROPERTY]
park: Skyway and Bay Trail [PRIVATE PROPERTY]. Bring plenty of water and wear sunscreen and protective clothing.Top trails nearbyMontgomery HillMontgomery HillMontgomery Hill Park4.6·Moderate·1.6 mi·Est. 42mCoyote Creek Parkway: Hellyer County Park to Silver Creek ValleyCoyote Creek Parkway: Hellyer County Park to Silver Creek ValleyHellyer County Park4.5·Easy·6.0 mi·Est. 1h 48mAvenue of the Noble GiantsAvenue of the Noble GiantsJoseph D Grant County Park4.6·Hard·10.9 mi·Est. 5h 13mBay Area Ridge Trail: Coyote Creek Parkway SouthBay Area Ridge Trail: Coyote Creek Parkway South4.6·Easy·9.2 mi·Est. 2h 46mYerba Buena to Halls Valley Trail LoopYerba Buena to Halls Valley Trail LoopJoseph D Grant County Park4.6·Moderate·6.7 mi·Est. 3h 18mYerba Buena Trail to Los Huecos Trail LoopYerba Buena Trail to Los Huecos Trail LoopJoseph D Grant County Park4.6·Moderate·5.9 mi·Est. 3h 2mMáyyan ‘Ooyákma – Coyote Ridge Open Space PreserveMáyyan ‘Ooyákma – Coyote Ridge Open Space PreserveCoyote Ridge Open Space Preserve4.5·Moderate·5.3 mi·Est. 2h 32mOhlone To Coyote Peak LoopOhlone To Coyote Peak LoopSanta Teresa County Park
description:
This trail is only accessible to those who live in the nearby neighborhood. This trail is not open to the public.

In the hills southeast of San Jose is an extensive network of trails that travel among the golden hills and coastal sage that California is known for. The views of the Pacific Ocean are beautiful, and the hills are steep, offering an array of outdoor recreation. This loop is one of the easier routes in the network, ascending Skyway Trail to the ridge and descending on Bay Trail.

name: McCorkle, Indian Joe, Cave Rocks, Vista Grande, and Cerro Este Loop
description:
• Parking fee information: There is a fee to park at Sunol Wilderness Regional Preserve on weekends and holidays. For more information, please visit https://www.ebparks.org/parks/sunol

This trail takes you across rolling hills, through scattered oak woodlands, and through scenic valleys dotted with wildflowers in spring. You’ll pass the giant boulders at Cave Rocks, traverse breathtaking ridgelines, and finally descend to Alameda Creek near Little Yosemite. The trails are steep and the weather can be hot, so make sure to pack plenty of water and protection from the sun. Enjoy expansive views in every direction from the crest of the hills. With grueling climbs and stunning descents, there is never a dull moment on this trail.

After passing the entrance kiosk, follow the road to the last parking lot. Cross the bridge and follow Camp Ohlone Road. Take the first left onto McCorkle Trail, make a right after the cattle gate, and continue for .6 miles. Turn left onto Canyon View Trail and follow for .53 miles, then turn right on Indian Joe Creek Trail. This trail is a narrow footpath that heads uphill. Climb steeply up Indian Joe Creek Trail until you reach the Cave Rocks after about 1.2 miles. You may wish to explore the area but use extreme caution. Continue uphill for another .25 miles and make a left on Cave Rocks Road. At High Valley Camp, next to the barn, you will find water and a restroom. Continue on Cave Rocks Road, make a right on Vista Grande Trail, and follow to the ridgetop. At the top, turn right on Eagle View Trail. After .84 miles on Eagle View Trail, make a left on Cave Rocks Road and climb for .58 miles to the Cerro Este Overlook. Take a right on Cerro Este Road and follow it for 1.7 miles. Make sure to follow signs for Cerro Este as there are several branching trails. Cerro Este Road will take you to Little Yosemite and Ohlone Road. Turn right on Ohlone Road and continue for .85 miles to return to the parking lot.

Park fees: 
Parking- $5/seasonal, weekends and holidays. 
$4/trailered vehicle. 
$25/bus. 
Dogs- $2/dog; guide/service dogs free

name: Tuibun Trail
description:
This beautiful trail leads to the summit of Glider Hill and back again. Before reaching the ascent, the majority of the trail is paved and flat. It is a good hike for the winter months, as the trail is very exposed and there is no shade along the way.

After making the climb, you'll be rewarded with stunning views of the bay, lake, marshlands, and surrounding mountains. Parking is available in the first lot after the pay booth at the entrance. If this lot is full, you can park outside the park and walk an extra mile or so.

name: San Francisco Bay Trail: Foster City and San Mateo Bikeways
description:
Enjoy the beauty of the San Francisco Bay Trail. This section in Foster City can be completed in a loop and offers scenic views. This paved path offers chances for kite-flying and watching the kite-boarders in the Bay. Kids (and some adults too) will enjoy watching the airplanes landing nearby. This route also goes by Shoreline Park which encompasses Ryder Park and Seal Point Park.

According to Access Northern CA (http://accessnca.org/access-northern-california/explore/explore-detail-view/?site_id=171): The Bay Trail is a recreational corridor that, when complete, will encircle San Francisco and San Pablo bays with a continuous 500-mile network of bicycling and hiking trails—much of it wheelchair and stroller accessible. 

The Bay is just to your left nearly all the way on this trail, and to your right, or right in front of you, is one little park after another. A half-mile out from Coyote Point you will see a very steep path running inland to small Harbor View Park, which people use mainly for baseball games and picnics. A half-mile farther is Ryder Park, with an accessible playground, group picnic area, outdoor classrooms, and restored wetlands. A large, tiered, concrete “water art” piece, the Shell Mound Gurgle, demonstrates how tidal action works.

Accessibility: There is designated, van-accessible parking at the parking lot behind the yacht club at Coyote Point Recreation Area, and at Ryder, Seal Point, and Bayside/Joinville Parks. At the entry to the Bay Trail from the parking lot behind the yacht club, an exceptionally large divot makes passage difficult. 

The trail surface is paved or gravel and it is typically at least five feet wide. It is gentle in grade, all estimated to be 3% or less. Continuous cross-slopes may be tiresome for some manual wheelchair or stroller users. At Seal Point Park the side trail to lookout points are on firm terrain. There are accessible bathrooms at Ryder Park, Bayside/Joinville Park, and Seal Point Park and accessible picnic tables (with firm and stable paths and surfaces and at least 27 inches of knee clearance) at Ryder Park and Harbor View Park.

name: Peak Meadow Trail
description: This loop follows the Hidden Valley and Peak Meadow Trails through Mission Peak Regional Preserve.  The first half of the loop is uphill, and you will enjoy a steady descent along the second half. The trail travels across an open hillside so it can be hot and sunny. Be sure to bring plenty of water along during the warmer months.

name: Salson, Slip, Headbangers Ball, and Amphitheater MTB Loop
description:
• Partial Closure: Part of this route near the San Juan Canyon Trailhead is temporarily inaccessible, but you can still enjoy other sections of this trail. For more information, please visit https://www.belmont.gov/Home/Components/FacilityDirectory/FacilityDirectory/96/509

Head out into the Sugarload Mountain Open Space to enjoy this great mountain bike Loop offering a great variety of trails through California’s hills. This mountain biking loop combines challenging climbs, technical descents, and plenty of flowy sections, taking riders through a variety of landscapes. With rocky outcrops, tight turns, and sweeping views, its a great way to explore the area. Downloading offline maps is recommended.

name: John McLaren Park Loop
description: Located not far from downtown San Francisco, John McLaren Park is a perfect place to wander with easy accessibility. The park has many features, including various hiking trails, overlook towers, small ponds, picnic areas, a golf course, and various sports fields. This loop trail goes thorugh the park with a redwood grove and beautiful views of San Francisco.

name: Little Yosemite, Canyon View Trail, McCorkle Trail
description:
• Parking fee information: There is a fee to park at Sunol Wilderness Regional Preserve on weekends and holidays. For more information, please visit https://www.ebparks.org/parks/sunol

True to its name, the Canyon View Trail provides breathtaking views of a canyon lined with oak trees. As you go along the trail's mild ups and downs, you'll be treated to serene views of rolling hills and shaded trees. Hikers can take in the calming sounds of Alameda Creek, commonly called Little Yosemite, by following the trail that runs parallel to it.

A charming brook and a miniature waterfall may be found in Little Yosemite. They are both flowing water during and right after the wet season. This picturesque gorge in Little Yosemite offers stunning views of the canyon dotted with oak trees. In addition, hikers can experience the roaring waterfalls by climbing the boulders along the gorge. Hikers will also pass by the well-marked McCorkle Trail. This trail leads hikers through calm rivers and verdant meadows.

name: Quicksilver 100k
description: This is the route for the Quicksilver Running Club's 100k event. For more information, please see https://www.quicksilver-running.com/races

name: Alviso Marina Loop
description: The Alviso Marina Loop, located in Alviso Marina County Park near Milpitas, California, offers a unique trail to explore the park’s natural beauty. The trail provides scenic views of the surrounding marshlands and the San Francisco Bay, making it a great spot for birdwatching and wildlife observation. The Salt pond is the highlight of this short trip, with its vibrant red waters. Visitors can also enjoy the park’s picnic areas and boat launch, adding to the relaxed outdoor experience.

name: West Loop
description: Almaden Quicksilver County Park has an extrensive network of trails through the golden hills and oak woods. This route starts on the Senador Mine Trail, a wide dirt path that skirts the northwest flanks of the park. It heads south on the Guadalupe Trail, passing the north shores of the Guadalupe Reservoir. It completes the loop on the New Almaden and Mine Hill Trails.

name: Black Mountain via Rhus Ridge
park: Rancho San Antonio Open Space Preserve
description: Starting at the little-known Rhus Ridge parking lot, you can enjoy a healthy workout and a grand panoramic view of Silicon Valley. The trail is partially shaded, but be sure to bring sun protection for the more exposed sections, especially during the hot summer months. The first and last mile before the summit are the most challenging.

name: Little Yosemite
description:
• Parking fee information: There is a fee to park at Sunol Wilderness Regional Preserve on weekends and holidays. For more information, please visit https://www.ebparks.org/parks/sunol

This is a wide gravel road with hilly views and some views of the creek below. 

According to Access Northern California (https://accessnca.org/access-northern-california/explore/explore-detail-view/?site_id=243): Bedrock mortars used by Native Americans for pounding acorns that were found in the area are reminders of Sunol's first inhabitants. For the past century, however, the land known today as Sunol Wilderness Regional Preserve was used almost exclusively as ranch land. Cattle continue to graze in the 6,859-acre wilderness but visitors can enjoy camping, picnicking, and hiking. The park is most popular in the spring when Alameda Creek is flowing, and the hills are green with wildflowers.

Several trails offer some accessibility with Camp Ohlone Rd being the longest and most accessible, albeit with continuous grades.

This 2-mile out and back, the hilly hike follows Alameda Creek (not always visible or running) past oak woodlands and weathered serpentine and sandstone outcrops. Alder, willow, and sycamore are seen creekside. It’s best to complete this hike on a cooler day as the route is fully exposed and the elevation gain can be very challenging in hot weather.

Start by crossing a paved bridge over Alameda Creek but shortly after the trail turns to hard-packed dirt and gravel. Just beyond the first gate, adjacent to the first of three cattle guard crossings, a mostly level, dirt spur trail goes off to the right and gets you closer to the creek and lots of wildflowers in the spring (California poppies, mustard, goldfields, and lupines) on this short detour, and elsewhere. After less than .2 miles you'll need to backtrack to reconnect to the main trail.

For the first .3 miles, the grade is 8% or less but afterward, sections can be greater than 11%. The inclines and declines are mostly continuous so be prepared for a good workout. Acorn woodpeckers, butterflies, and damselflies were plentiful along the route.

At 1.1 miles you will reach the third and final cattle gate, continue another .1 mile to reach “Alameda Creek Overlook” (formerly known as Little Yosemite). The overlook is best in the wetter months when there’s more water. This is a good point to turn back however, according to an elevation chart if you continue for another .8 mile the grade is less than 8%, thereafter it increases.

There are some level stretches but for the most part, continually ascends and descends. The grade for the initial .3 miles is 8% or less but afterward sections can be greater than 11% Very wide service road except for the spur trail which is less than 4ft. wide

Accessibility: Visitors using wheelchairs, mobility equipment, or strollers may need all-terrain tires or adaptive/motorized equipment for the surface type and grade. Visitors using wheelchairs, mobility equipment, or strollers may need assistance along this entire route due to the consistent sections above a 5% grade (especially if using manual equipment).

Accessible Parking:
Number of designated accessible spaces: 1 at the trailhead;
Number of van-accessible spaces with access aisles: 1;
Parking lot surface: paved.

Trail Details:
Trail surface: gravel;
Average trail width: 10 feet;
Estimated average grade category: moderately steep (5-8%) with a steeper section at about 0.8 miles when going east;
Picnic tables: yes, firm and stable path to tables, firm and stable surface, 27" or greater knee clearance; Several tables are in Alameda Grove nearby to the Camp Ohlone Rd. trailhead. All have access at each end of the table and the path of travel to them is thick with plant debris and bumpy in places but, should be manageable for most individuals. Other tables are by the visitor center and only have access at each end.
Other accessible features: Accessible restrooms are located throughout the park and are typically located near the accessible parking. A 3-4 inch threshold at the visitor center restroom and a degraded threshold at the restroom across from Ohlone Wilderness Trailhead, may impede access for some. There is a small, accessible visitor center to learn about recent animal sightings and to meet some animal ambassadors: a gopher snake, rattlesnake, western toad, western pond turtle, and a tarantula. You can also view samples of over 600 plant specimens found in the park.

name: Mine, Bernal Hill, Vista, Joice, Norred Loop
description:
• Fee Information: Santa Teresa County Park charges a fee to enter. For more information, please visit https://parks.sccgov.org/plan-your-visit/santa-clara-county-park-fees#3925188384-3236192913

This is a marvelous hike in Santa Teresa County Park. The route follows a wide fire road and features some short, steep climbs. The views along the way are spectacular. There are benches at several of the viewpoints where visitors can take a break and enjoy the scenery. 

Beautiful blooming wildflowers dot the surrounding landscape in spring. There isn't much shade along this trail, so bring plenty of water with you and wear sun protection.

name: San Tomas Aquino/Saratoga Creek Trail
description:
This section of the Saratoga Creek Trail starts from Sterling Barnhart Park and leads south along Saratoga Creek. Wedged between the Lawrence Expressway and the creek, the traffic-free trail blends nature and a dense urban environment. The creek hosts various waterfowl. After passing Murdoch Park, this route ends at English Drive.

Accessibility:

Equipment
This trail is likely accessible for visitors using wheelchairs, mobility equipment, or strollers.

Parking
Street parking is available near the trailhead on Sterling Blvd., but there are no designated accessible spaces nearby.

Surface
The trail surface is paved asphalt or wooden boardwalk with edge railings, and is typically at least 8 feet wide.

Grade
This trail is estimated to be flat (1% or less).

name: Alma and Redwood Springs Loop
park: Bear Creek Redwoods Open Space Preserve
description: The Alma (the Spanish word for soul) Trail is located west of Bear Creek Road and is accessible using the new pedestrian crossing. This trail traverses into densely wooded fir and redwood forests, through bay and oak woodlands, eventually linking to the Madrone Knoll Trail. Be prepared: These trails climb from the parking area located at 1,000 feet in elevation to Madrone Knoll, the highest point, at 2,400 feet.

name: Thermalito Ridgeline Oak Tree Trail
description:
Pleasanton Ridge Regional Park is an often overlooked getaway from the seemingly never-ending suburbs that fringe the San Francisco Bay Area. 

This hike from the Foothills Staging Area is an excellent introduction to the park: long enough to get your heart rate up, but not nearly as arduous as some hikes in the nearby hills. 

Once you hike up to the ridge, you meander up and down with far-reaching views of the nearby scenery, including Mount Diablo and the San Francisco Bay. 

Once nice amenity: a smattering of water spigots to refill your water bottle. And a surprise: The hike passes through a grove of olive trees planted when a local rancher owned the land.

Note this park is popular with mountain bikers, so keep an eye out.

name: Monte Bello Black Mountain Loop
description: This loop starts at the Monte Bello Open Space Preserve parking lot and takes the shortest path to Black Mountain, with nice views of the area on Bella Vista Trail. The return path goes down to Stevens Creek and back up to the parking lot with Canyon Trail. Variations are possible by branching off to Stevens Creek Nature Trail and others from there (Skid Rd Trail, White Oak Trail).

name: San Andreas Fault Trail
description: Discover this 2.6-km loop trail near Los Altos, California. Generally considered an easy route, it takes an average of 41 min to complete. This trail is great for hiking, running, and walking, and it's unlikely you'll encounter many other people while exploring. The trail is open year-round and is beautiful to visit anytime. You'll need to leave pups at home — dogs aren't allowed on this trail.

name: Inner Bair Island Walk
park: HikingNot crowdedGreat conditionsGreat viewsEasy and beautiful.Park
description: This Inner Bair Island Trail just opened to the public in 2016.  The island itself will take some years before the marsh fills in, but it is nice open area for a walk.  With a lot of high density housing nearby, it will be great for those that like to walk. Each end of the trail has a viewing platform to overlook the slough.  There are also benches along the way.  There is also a good sized parking lot and restroom where you start the walk.

name: Stevens Creek Reservoir East Trail
description: Stevens Creek County Park is known for its boating access, campground, and day use. It also has a small network of multi-use trails open to hiking, biking, and equestrians. This route starts on the Rim Trail and leads to the Stevens Creek-Tony Look Trail along the lake's southeast side. After a half mile, branch off on a side trail leading north and stay along the lake's shoreline.

name: Bernal Heights Park Trail
description:
Bernal Heights features stunning panoramic views of San Francisco. Do a full spin (360 degrees) at the top of Bernal Hill and be awed by how beautiful the sights are. Visitors will be able to catch glimpses of the Golden Gate Bridge, the East Bay hills, downtown SF and so much more! This park is a hidden treasure for both locals and visitors.

This trail is family-friendly and dog friendly. It's accessible year-round and can also be used for running. Make sure to check out the California poppies and other flora or fauna living here. Additionally, this park is home to over 40 bird species, making it a fun location to go bird watching.

As one of the larger parks in SF, visitors, and locals come to watch fireworks during the holidays or have picnics here. Bernal Heights Park also has both dirt and paved trails, a recreation center, playgrounds, and a community garden. Check out the "Painted Rock," as you're trekking around in the park. This rock gets painted every so often depending on the season.

Park Hours: 5 AM to Midnight

Only the lower portion of this trail is considered wheelchair or stroller friendly because it begins as a paved trail. Near the top, however, the trail surface turns to rocky dirt and it gets steeper (over 8% grade). There are also some staircases in the park.

name: Meyer's Ranch and High Ridge Loop
description:
• Parking fee information: There is a fee to park at Dry Creek Pioneer Regional Park. For more information, please visit https://www.ebparks.org/parks/garin-dry-creek

Dry Creek Regional Park is located in the hills above Hayward, a hidden gem that is worth visiting. The park offers sweeping views of the Bay and you also have the option to run up some pretty challenging hills if you’re interested. The hills are especially beautiful and green in the springtime, and there are creeks and wildflowers to enjoy. 

This route starts at the parking lot on May Road, then follows the path to Meyers Ranch Trail, a huge, long, exposed climb, followed by a fun and flying downhill on the High Ridge Loop Trail. 

Fees:
$5 per vehicle 
$2 per dog

name: Long Ridge to Peters Creek
description: Enjoy this 18.2-mile out-and-back trail near Los Altos, California. Generally considered a challenging route, it takes an average of 9 h 32 min to complete. This trail is great for hiking, and it's unlikely you'll encounter many other people while exploring. The best times to visit this trail are January through November.

name: Clarkia, Sunset, Live Oak and Serpentine Loop
description: This is a pleasant hike in Edgewood Park and Nature Preserve. The route features panoramic views of the bay and beautiful scenery. Along the way, you can spot wildlife, including lizards, deer, and rabbits. Watch out for rattlesnakes sunning beside the trail. There is a parking lot at the start of the trail near the Clarkia Trailhead.

name: Máyyan ‘Ooyákma – Coyote Ridge Open Space Preserve
park: Máyyan ‘Ooyákma – Coyote Ridge Open Space Preserve
description: • Access Information: This loop is closed on Mondays and Tuesdays. A Butterfly Pass is required for certain sections of the trail. For more information, please visit https://www.openspaceauthority.org/preserves/coyoteridge.html

name: Zinfandel and Bear Meadow Loop
description: This scenic loop trail takes you through rolling hills, oak woodlands, and open meadows, offering breathtaking views of the surrounding valley and distant mountains. It’s a perfect option for those looking to enjoy a blend of nature, quiet woodlands, and sweeping vistas. The trailhead also shares its location for the Picchetti Winery, which offers wine tasting and other services.

name: Crystal Springs to Pulgas Water Temple
description:
The trail starts as a narrow, rocky trail surrounded by poison oak patches, coyote brush, oaks, and plants. Along the trail, you may hear birds chirping and see plants, including toyon, blackberry, madrone, and honeysuckle.

The trail winds through brown, dry fields at first. As you get closer to the Pulgas Water Temple, the landscape opens into an oasis of well-kept green lawns and vegetation. As you enter the temple via the stone gates, you'll be transported back to 1938, when the Hetch Hetchy Aqueduct was completed.

name: Across the Golden Gate Bridge to Sausalito
park: GMTExplore near Across the Golden Gate Bridge to SausalitoActivitiesBirdingHikingMountain bikingRoad bikingRunningWalkingAttractionsBeachCaveCity walkEasyForestHistoric siteLakeLongModerately challengingNo dogsShortViewsWildflowersWildlifeSuitabilityDog friendlyDogs on leashKid friendlyPartially pavedPavedStroller friendlyWheelchair friendlyPoints of interestHuntington FallsRainbow FallsBaker BeachSpreckels LakeLake MercedElk Glen LakeJapanese Tea GardenSpreckels Temple of MusicDutch WindmillQueen Wilhelmina Tulip GardenLloyd LakeFisherman's WharfMurphy WindmillPine LakeTelegraph HillMount OlympusBernal HillRose GardenOcean BeachPainted LadiesActivitiesBirdingHikingMountain bikingRoad bikingRunningWalkingAttractionsBeachCaveCity walkEasyForestHistoric siteLakeLongModerately challengingNo dogsAttractionsShortViewsWildflowersWildlifeSuitabilityDog friendlyDogs on leashKid friendlyPartially pavedPavedStroller friendlyWheelchair friendlyPoints of interestHuntington FallsRainbow FallsBaker BeachSpreckels LakeLake MercedElk Glen LakeJapanese Tea GardenSpreckels Temple of MusicDutch WindmillQueen Wilhelmina Tulip GardenPoints of interestLloyd LakeFisherman's WharfMurphy WindmillPine LakeTelegraph HillMount OlympusBernal HillRose GardenOcean BeachPainted LadiesDownloadOpen mapAllTrailsExploreCountriesRegionsCitiesParksTrailsPoints of InterestTrail FeaturesMapsMy mapsCreate mapPrint mapsRoute converterCompanyAboutJobsPressAmbassadorsAffiliatesInfluencersCommunitySupportGift membershipAllTrails GearExploreCountriesRegionsCitiesPark
description:
Walk or bike across one of the most beautiful bridges with great views of the San Francisco Bay and the one of the longest suspension spans in the world.

The Golden Gate Bridge, which spans from San Francisco to Marin County, is thought by many to be one of the most beautiful bridges in the world, and the opportunity to walk or bike across at least part of it should not be missed. The bridge spans a total length of 1.7 miles, but most people only walk to the first tower and back again.

If you are feeling more adventurous, walk across the bridge and continue under the bridge up to the Hendrik Point vista point for a great view of the bridge with the San Francisco skyline in the background. You will also have a great view of Alcatraz and even the Bay Bridge from here. From the Marin side of the Golden Gate Bridge you can continue into the Marin Headlands or head down into Sausalito along the Bay Trail.

This is a very popular route across the Golden Gate Bridge all the way to Sausalito. You also have the option to hop on the ferry with your bike and come right back to San Francisco. 

Accessibility: There is a wheelchair-accessible ramp leading from the Visitors Center up to the bridge entrance with handrails and a gentle slope. Once on the Bridge, the path is paved, flat (estimated 1% or less), and typically at least six feet wide. There is a safety barrier protecting pedestrians and cyclists from motor vehicle traffic on the Bridge. There is a wheelchair accessible bathroom with grab bars in a separate building across from the Visitor Center at the south end of the Bridge.

name: Poplar Beach Trail
park: Purisima Creek TrailPurisima Creek Redwoods Open Space Preserve
description:
This trail follows part of the Coastal Trail through Mateo Coast State Beaches. It’s a short hike from the end of Poplar Street to Half Moon Bay State Beach. The trail along the coast is paved, mostly flat, and easy to follow. There are benches along the way to enjoy the sea views and access to the beach. During the spring, there are beautiful wildflowers.
Parking is available at both ends of this trail.

name: Purisima Creek Trail to Whittemore Gulch Trail Loop
park: Purisima Creek Redwoods Open Space Preserve
description: This loop follows the Purisima Creek, Craig Britton, Harkins Ridge, North Ridge, and Whittemore Gulch Trails.  The first stretch is along the water before heading further into the forest. Sections of the Craig Britton and Harkins Ridge Trail are more open and offer nice views. On a clear day, the ocean is visible.

name: Baker Beach Loop
park: Baker Beach Loop is near Baker Beach.Top trails nearbyBatteries to Bluffs TrailBatteries to Bluffs TrailPresidio of San Francisco4.8·Easy·2.3 mi·Est. 1h 7mBay Area Ridge Trail: The Golden Gate Bridge to Marin HeadlandsBay Area Ridge Trail: The Golden Gate Bridge to Marin HeadlandsGolden Gate National Recreation Area4.7·Easy·1.7 mi·Est. 45mPresidio Loop TrailPresidio Loop TrailPresidio of San Francisco4.6·Moderate·5.9 mi·Est. 2h 29mFort Point - Baker Beach Coast TrailFort Point - Baker Beach Coast TrailPresidio of San Francisco4.7·Moderate·4.1 mi·Est. 2h 2mBlue Heron Lake and Strawberry Hill LoopBlue Heron Lake and Strawberry Hill LoopGolden Gate Park
description: Baker Beach offers a mile of coastline and nearby hiking trails. There are picnic areas, grills, and restrooms. The trails offer a scenic walk among the coastal oaks, with gorgeous views of the Pacific Ocean, and it's easy to forget you are in an urban area. There are three parking areas on Bowley Street; this area is usually busy.

name: Bay Area Ridge Trail: Almaden Quicksilver County Park
park: Bay Area Ridge Trail: Almaden Quicksilver County Park
description:
A steady climb to the slopes of Mount Umunhum takes you through a beautiful landscape once actively mined for quicksilver. The Ridge Trail follows old mining roads over these hills, where you can imagine New Almaden Mine’s heyday. Historic buildings and interpretive panels tell the story of the community that once occupied these hills. Superb views look out over the Santa Clara Valley and Santa Cruz Mountains. Much of this route is exposed and can be hot in summer; plan accordingly.

For more information, see the Bay Area Ridge Trail page here: https://ridgetrail.org/almaden-quicksilver-county-park/

This trail description is excerpted from the 2019 Guidebook. For details on all of the Bay Area Ridge trails, trailheads and more buy the book from Wilderness Press: https://www.wildernesspress.com/product.php?productid=16685&cat=274&bestseller=Y

name: Brooks Falls Loop
description: This route offers beautiful views of the Linda Mar area, and enough incline to get your heart pumping. If going counter-clockwise, near the end you'll find a turn-off to Brook Falls. Please note that sometimes during drier months the waterfall does not flow. The route on this page forms a loop with the Montara Mountain Trail.

name: Pioneer Trail
description:
• Parking fee information: There is a fee to park at Dry Creek Pioneer Regional Park. For more information, please visit https://www.ebparks.org/parks/garin-dry-creek

This trail takes you to Dry Creek Pioneer Regional Park. It’s a short loop hike through the golden California hills, climbing steeply and passing through meadows. Bring plenty of water and layers to block the sun, as only a small part of the trail is shaded by trees. The area tends to get muddy after rainfall, so it's best to hike during a dry spell.

name: Tafoni and Fir Trail
park: El Corte De Madera Creek Open Space Preserve
description:
This pleasant route offers, cool redwood canyons that transition to either mixed evergreen forest or chaparral as one travels up the drier, warmer ridges. There are views toward the San Mateo Coast, intriguing sandstone formations, and even a grove of old-growth redwoods.

Trail are closed seasonally for biking, check before you depart.

name: Arroyo Rd Staging Area to East Shore and Heron Bay Trails
description:
• Parking fee information: There is a fee to park at Del Valle Regional Park. For more information, please visit https://www.ebparks.org/parks/del-valle

Park Features: Deep in a valley framed by oak-covered hills, with sailboats and sailboards skimming over its waters, Del Valle is like a lakeside resort only 10 miles south of Livermore. 5,000 acre Del Valle Regional Park features two swim beaches, a boat launch, family and group camping (by reservation) and excellent, stocked fishing. 

Trail Highlights: This hike around the northern part of the lake is removed from the busy swim beaches in the southern part of the lake; enjoy the wilderness feel and explore a part of Del Valle you may not have seen before. The contrast in scenery from the ridge of East Shore Trail and the lakeside Heron Bay Trail provides a diverse recreational experience. This hike features several steep climbs and descents and is recommended for those with a good level of fitness. There is a drinking fountain but no restrooms at the trailhead. Be sure to carry plenty of water on your hike. 

Trail Directions: Start along the trail from the Arroyo Road Staging Area, going up the large hill. Go left to start the East Shore Trail. Continue on East Shore Trail, avoiding four turnoffs for the Heron Bay Trail; take the fifth turn off, turning right onto Heron Bay Trail. Complete the first Heron Bay loop and take a left to connect back with East Shore Trail. Go left at the next turnoff for Heron Bay Trail and complete a small loop back to East Shore Trail again; take East Shore a very short distance and turn left again for the last section of Heron Bay Trail. Make a left at the last intersection with East Shore Trail and follow it back down the large hill and to the staging area.

name: Japanese Friendship Garden
Mt. Ellen Summit Trail and Trillium Nature Loop
description: This route steadily climbs switchbacks up the Mount Ellen Summit Trail to the forested summit of Mount Ellen. Continue northwest,  descending switchbacks heading west. Do not continue north on Pomponio Canyon Trail to follow this route. Complete the loop on the Trillium Nature Trail, which is surrounded in blooming trilliums in the spring and summer.

name: Eucalyptus Loop Trail
description:
• San Bruno Mountain State Park charges a fee to enter. Fees are per vehicle. This park does not accept the California State Park Annual Day Use Pass. For more information, please visit https://parks.smcgov.org/fees-charges#vehicle.

The Eucalyptus Loop Trail in San Bruno Mountain State and County Park is loop trail that connects back at the trail head parking lot. The trail is a dirt trail with some sections with gravel. The trail goes through a eucalyptus forest, coastal scrubs, and open grasslands. The trail offers views of the San Francisco city skyline and the bay.

name: Slacker Hill via Morning Sun, Alta, SCA and Slacker Ridge
description: This trail begins at the Morning Sun Trailhead, where a parking lot is available, and leads to Slacker Hill in the Golden Gate National Recreation Area. You’ll enjoy stunning city views, the Golden Gate Bridge, and the rolling hills. Be prepared for steep, narrow sections with switchbacks, rocky terrain, and some scrambling.

name: Horseshoe Lake Trail Loop
description:
This loop is one of the best easy hikes in the Santa Cruz Mountains, and perfect for just about anyone, no matter their age or ability. And it has a beautiful lake, which always adds to the pleasure of a hike. The trail tread up to the dam is considered wheelchair friendly but beyond that is a little more difficult with some narrow and uneven areas including a hillside traverse - not recommended for strollers or wheelchairs - but there are places to turn around before then.

This route can be made more adventurous by connecting to the open space preserves to the north (Russian Ridge Open Space Preserve) and south (Long Ridge Open Space Preserve); there's even an old Christmas tree farm to the south.

There are benches along the way for resting. There are gravel parking areas at the start of the trail on the north end but they do not appear to have designated accessible parking spaces.

name: Best trails inCoyote Lake Harvey Bear Ranch County Park
park: Coyote Lake Harvey Bear Ranch County Parkbest Trails In Coyote Lake Harvey Bear Ranch County Park Best Trails In Coyote Lake Harvey Bear Ranch County Park
description: This 4,595-acre park is nestled in the Diablo Range east of the City of Gilroy. It features a 635-acre lake, camping and boat launch facilities, showers, and miles of horse, bicycle and hiking trails. The Bear and Mendoza Ranch sections of the park have over 15 miles of hiking, biking and equestrian trails that wind through oak studded canyons; and on top of grassy ridgelines, providing spectacular views of the south Santa Clara Valley. Trailheads can be found in all three sections of the park. Dogs on-leash are welcome. The park is open 8am to sunset.

name: Bayview, Red Hill and Soaproot Trail Loop
description:
• Parking fee information: There is a fee to park at Coyote Hills Regional Park. For more information, please visit https://www.ebparks.org/parks/coyote-hills

Coyote Hills offers diverse lessons in history and many activities. At the Visitor Center, you can learn about Ohlone history, settlers and ranching, salt production, bio-sonar research, and more! Other features include picnic areas, groups camps, the Alameda Creek Trail, the marsh boardwalk, the wildlife refuge, and salt evaporation ponds. Coyote Hills is a haven for cyclists, joggers, walkers, birdwatchers, nature explorers, and picnickers. 

This level-pathed, Bayview trail is mostly paved and offers astounding views of the National Wildlife refuge, salt evaporation ponds of the San Francisco Bay, shoreline birds, and the water. This hike is in full sun with little shade, but the Bayview trail has a wonderful breeze before you make your climb and limber up for the many steep inclines (7) and declines (5) that the Red Hill trail has to offer. The rock formations and views from the top of Red Hill make it all worthwhile. Enjoy a snack or break and 360-degree views at the hilltop picnic areas on Red Hill, before you head back on the soaproot trail to make your way back to Bayview trail to complete the loop. 

Begin at Quarry Staging Area off Patterson Ranch Road. Follow the paved Bay View Trail west for .28 miles until you reach the Dairy Glen group campsite. Stay left before the campground on the loose gravel Meadowlark-to-Bayview Trail for .14 miles (with the South marsh at left). At the intersection with No Name Trail and Apay Way, continue straight towards the Bay View Trail. The gravel path will continue to No Name trail, veer to the right on the paved trail, this is the Bay View Trail continued and you will follow it along the water until you reach Red Hill Trail about 2.1 miles into your hike. When you come to the observation platform and viewing area on the Bay View Trail, follow it to the right around the bend and Red Hill will be ahead of where you will make a sharp right onto the trail going uphill to start your climb, there will be a trail post sign for the Red Hill Trail to guide you. Follow the Red Hill Trail for about .9 miles until you reach your last decline. At the bottom of the hill, you will take a left on the Soaproot trail and follow it back to the Bay View trail for about .3 miles at the bottom of Soaproot make your way back towards the Dairy Glen group campsite, walk towards the campsite and veer to the left which takes you back to the paved Bay View Trail and another .28 miles back to the staging area to complete the loop.  

Accessibility: There are 3 unlined designated accessible spaces in the gravel parking lot off of Patterson Ranch Road at the east end of the trail. None of them appear to be van-accessible with striped access aisles. The trail surface is paved asphalt, gravel, or a natural surface (dirt). It is typically at least 6 feet wide.

The most accessible portion of the trail is the paved Bayview Trail in the first about 2.1 miles when going clockwise. The majority of the trail is estimated to be in the mostly gentle (5% or less) grade category but there are steeper sections from about 2.1-3.5 miles when going clockwise. Trail goers using wheelchairs/mobility equipment or strollers may need assistance in the steeper sections or to avoid them for safety. All-terrain tires or motorized equipment may be needed for the surface type and grade after about 2.1 miles. There are benches along the route for resting.

name: Presidio Loop Trail
description:
• Access Information: Part of this route is temporarily closed to dog walking to reduce the potential for coyote/dog conflict, but you can still enjoy other sections of this trail. For information, please visit https://presidio.gov/about/sustainability/coyotes-in-the-presidio

This charming trail offers seclusion, natural wonders, and historic and cultural variety of the Presidio. Stunning views can be found on this trip through forests grasslands, and along coastal bluffs.

While the loop can be started in many different spots, this route begins at the parking lot on Pacific Avenue and heads east along the Mountain Lake Trail. You'll soon take a left at Lovers Lane and follow the winding path through the towering eucalyptus trees. The western section of the trip circles the Presidio Golf Course and passes the SF National Cemetery.

The Bay Area Trail and Anza Loop circumnavigate the Presidio Golf course.

name: Grizzly Flat South and Grizzly Flat North Loop
description: Stevens Creek County Park has a network of multi-use trails through the coastal oak groves. This route starts at Skyline Boulevard, which is a popular trailhead, and descends the Grizzly Flat Trail South. At the intersection, it continues on the north trail and steadily climbs to complete the loop. The parking area is in an open meadow and has scenic views.

name: Best trails inSt. Joseph's Hill Open Space Preserve
park: St. Joseph'S Hill Open Space Preservebest Trails In St. Joseph'S Hill Open Space Preserve Best Trails In St. Joseph'S Hill Open Space Preserve
description: Hours: half an hour before sunrise to half an hour after sunset

name: Best trails inAlmaden Quicksilver County Park
park: Almaden Quicksilver County Parkbest Trails In Almaden Quicksilver County Park Best Trails In Almaden Quicksilver County Park
description: Almaden Quicksilver County Park is in the southern end of San Jose, California, in the hills overlooking Silicon Valley. The park occupies the site of a former quicksilver (aka mercury) mine that at one time was among the largest of its kind in the world. Relics of the mine still stand at the park. The park includes over 34.2 miles of hiking trails, including 23 miles of equestrian trails and 10 miles of bike trails.

name: Blue Oak and Polly Geraci Trail
description: Explore the wonders of the Pulgas Ridge Open Space Preserve. The is variety of terrain on this trail. There are some steep sections and the trail is a mix of paved and dirt trails. There are nice views along the way, and in winter and spring the trail is very green. Bring plenty of water, especially in the summer. Make sure to stop by the Water Temple.

name: Old Creek Trail and Wood Duck Trail
description:
• Parking fee information: There is a fee to park at Quarry Lakes Regional Park. Fees are collected on weekends and major holidays from April through October and only at the Redwood Gate entrance. For more information, please visit https://www.ebparks.org/parks/quarry_lakes/

The Wood Duck Trail winds through wooded areas. This area is abundant in hardwoods, with spectacular 100-foot-tall White Pines mixed in with towering Sugar Maples and Black Walnuts.

The trail crosses a small creek and ascents steadily uphill as you proceed. You may see blackberry bushes and wildflowers like fleabane along the trail. The trail then becomes steeper as it gets closer to the creek. Benches are placed thoughtfully throughout this trail section to offer an ideal location to watch the birds.

name: Los Gatos Creek Trail: Camden Ponds to Vasona Reservoir
Fifield-Cahill Ridge Trail Exploration
description:
• Access Information: This area is only accessible during a
docent-led outing. For more information please visit: https://webapps.sfpuc.org/trails

After mile 3.4, the Fifield Cahill Trail is only open by docent-led tour and is not publicly available unless you register with SFwater for a scheduled docent-led outing. The Portola gate on Sweeney Ridge trail is the transition point and it is locked. Please find more information here: https://sfwater.org/trails

It is a through hike that starts at the Sweeney Ridge Trailhead behind Skyline College and ends at Skyline Quarry near Hwy 92. The majority of the hike sports great views of the Pacific, SF Bay and the Coastal Range. Wildlife spotting should be more favorable than other parks due to less human interference and the wildflowers are stunning in spring. This trip takes some planning in that you need to select a date that is available, get your permits, and arrange for enough vehicles to shuttle your group North to Sweeney Ridge to start the hike.

name: Saratoga Toll Road, Beekhius Road Trail, and Skyline to the Sea Trail
description: • General fee: Castle Rock State Park charges a day-use fee to enter. For more information please visit https://www.parks.ca.gov/?page_id=538

name: Windy Hill Loop
description: This loop travels around Windy Hill Open Space on either side of Hamms Gulch. Start by hiking up the Spring Ridge Trail, then follow the Anniversary Trail and Lost Trail closer to Skyline Boulevard. The Hamms Gulch Trail heads back down to the start. The first half is more sunny while the second half is more wooded and shaded.

name: Alta Loma Loop
description:
Alta Loma is a small community park with access to baseball fields, tennis courts, a playground, picnic areas, bathrooms, and a paved perimeter path perfect for walking and jogging. There are a few access points, but the best public parking is in a large parking lot at the end of Camaritas Avenue. There is an extended gravel path that loops behind the Alta Loma Middle School.

Accessibility:

Equipment
This trail is likely accessible for visitors using wheelchairs, mobility equipment, or strollers.

Parking
There are 2 designated accessible parking spaces, 1 of which is van-accessible, with striped access aisles in the paved parking lot.

Surface
The trail surface is smooth concrete and typically 8 to 10 feet wide.

Grade
This trail is estimated to be gentle (3% or less).

More Info
Picnic tables and benches are available along the route for resting.
